lyrics: [Produced by T-Minus]
annotation:
This woozy, atmospheric beat, has hard drums that are complemented by Kendrick’s lyrics and tweaks on his vocals.

Producer T-Minus and TDE’s in-house engineer MixedByAli talked about the process of making this song in an interview with Complex,

T-Minus:

I’m good friends with the A&Rs at Interscope. We were working together and he had a bunch of beats of mine. He played it for Kendrick and he just fell in love with that one beat. Its funny, I was thinking maybe an R&B artist was gonna jump on that beat.

He had the beat, he went in on it, and he sent it back to me. I did a little bit of post-production. On his end, he had his people touch up things on the record, vocally and instrumentally. That’s one thing that’s really important, getting that post-production done because a lot of times producers just wanna send out beats and hope that the record’s just gonna make itself. But it takes more than that.

MixedByAli:

That song was actually fun to mix. Me and Dr. Dre mixed that one. The beat is real open so you can kind of do whatever you want to it, as far as messing with the vocals. So I was just playing with some delays, some reverbs, tweak it out make it sound real eerie.

On the extended version, the production switches into soft synths and then building up with the drums hitting harder in an almost boom bap style with Kendrick rapping until the outro skit.

lyrics: [Intro]
annotation:
While this song is about alcoholism, to a casual listener it might sound like it’s glorifying alcohol.

In an interview with Complex, TDE’s Punch explained why it sounds this way:

It’s a real deceptive record if you’re a casual listener. It sounds like we are celebrating having a good time before you actually dive into what he’s saying. He wrote it deceptive like that on purpose. If you just a casual listener go ahead, have fun. But if you really a fan of him you’ll get the message behind the record.

lyrics:
Pour up (Drank), head shot (Drank)
Sit down (Drank), stand up (Drank)
Pass out (Drank), wake up (Drank)
Faded (Drank), faded (Drank)
annotation:
Those lines describes how parties go, in a chronological order from pouring liquor and shots excessively to passing out.

It’s often misreported that Kendrick doesn’t drink or smoke. While it’s true he doesn’t smoke, he occasionally does have a drink. Keep in mind that GKMC is him reminiscing about growing up in Compton. So he probably doesn’t smoke/drink anymore but he might have before. Also, some casual drinkers or weed smokers often refer themselves as non-smokers or “people that don’t drink”.

lyrics: Now I done grew up 'round some people livin' their life in bottles
annotation: This song is about me reminising about my years a kid witnessing a housing that indulged adults in alcohol. So much alcohol that it could fill a swimming pool. Eventually that me reminising became a reality when i became an adult.

lyrics: [Produced by DJ Dahi]
annotation:
The song features background vocals by Anna Wise and the beat samples “Silver Soul” by American dream pop duo Beach House. In a 2018 interview, Beach House’s singer Victoria Legrand said:

I’m glad we did the Kendrick thing, because that was a great song.

In the video below, DJ Dahi breaks down the process of making the beat. He also discussed in a documentary the story behind his collaboration with Kendrick on this record.

lyrics: [Verse 1: Kendrick Lamar]
Granddaddy had the golden flask
annotation:
The fact that K Dot’s granddad drank from a golden flask reflects how much he adored the habit since gold is considered as a substance of very high quality. The golden flask romanticizes the experience of alcohol and alcoholism, giving it a sheen of classiness and style.

Since alcohol comes in its own bottles, if you have to decant it into an opaque flask and carry it around—maybe you have a problem.

Gold is also used in anniversaries to signify 50 years, symbolizing his grandfather’s long-term drinking problem, which points to the issue of alcoholism as being a long-standing problem in Kendrick’s family.

lyrics: Backstroke every day in Chicago
annotation: back stroke. playing on the word swimming pool. him drowning in a pool of liquor in Chicago.

lyrics:
Uh, me and my niggas tryna get it, ya bish (ya bish)
Hit the house lick: tell me, is you wit' it, ya bish? (ya bish)
annotation:
Kendrick grew up in Compton, CA which is notoriously impoverished. Growing up in that environment gave Kendrick the motivation to do whatever it took to pull himself out of poverty. “It” could refer to everything and anything including money, power, and respect.

“bish” = “bitch”

The various meanings of ya bish are explored here. It has its own website, which includes apparel, ya bish.

“Hit a lick” means armed robbery, and it’s a term Kendrick has used regularly in his music:

Fuck am I ‘posed to do when I’m lookin’ at walkin' licks?
The constant big money talk ‘bout the mansion and foreign whips

It’s also the jumping point for his narrative on “The Art of Peer Pressure”

lyrics:
America, God bless you if it's good to you
America, please take my hand
Can you help me underst—
annotation:
The U.S was built on the principle of the American Dream, which is the idea that people in America are protected by the U.S. Constitution, can choose any career, practice any religion, and follow the pursuit of happiness. While this policy was limited to white male property owners at its conception, it slowly expanded out to everyone else living in the U.S. Kendrick believes these rights still don’t apply to everyone.

The word “understand” cutting off represents the lack of understanding of problems in America. Bono’s final word “around” is also cut off to bookend the ending of the song.

In 2018, Bēkon released a full version of this intro, entitled “America.”

lyrics:
Home invasion was persuasive (was persuasive)
From nine to five I know it's vacant, ya bish (ya bish)
annotation:
Home invasion was an appealing lick. Kendrick knows the house will be vacant from 9 to 5 as that is when most people are working, making the urge to rob the home that much more powerful. Note how Kendrick mentions “nine to five” during his plot for house robbery, this contrasts the homeowners who work honest jobs and Kendrick and his friends who are about to make easy money by robbing their home.

This line refers to the home invasion in “The Art of Peer Pressure”.

Home Invasion also is an Ice-T album from 1993.
“Money Trees” contains many references you can find later in the song: E-40, Halle Berry, Louie Burger and so on…

lyrics:
Some people like the way it feels
Some people wanna kill their sorrows
Some people wanna fit in with the popular,
annotation: Kendrick points out a few reasons why someone might drink alcohol. Some drink for the feeling of drunkenness and some for a distraction and sedative for their problems, while others drink to fit in with a certain clique briefly to become popular.

lyrics: New Kung Fu Kenny!
annotation:
Kid Capri introduces Kendrick with the same moniker he does on “YAH.,” “ELEMENT.,” and “LOYALTY.”

Kendrick first called himself “Kung Fu Kenny” on Mike WiLL Made-It’s 2016 song “Perfect Pint.” In an April 20, 2017 Pitchfork interview, Don Cheadle revealed that “Kung Fu Kenny” was inspired by his character Kenny from the 2001 movie Rush Hour 2. Cheadle also stars in the video for Kendrick’s song “DNA.”

Hip-hop has been a competitive art since its inception, and rappers have been using martial arts analogies to promote their skills since Wu Tang Clan took their name from a classic kung-fu flick. Like a trained fighter, Kenny is prepared to defeat all challengers with lyrical skills that have been honed by hard work and persistence.

lyrics:
Dreams of livin' life like rappers do (like rappers do)
Back when condom wrappers wasn't cool (they wasn't cool)
annotation:
Here, the phrase “condom wrappers” is used as a homonym, alongside “condom rappers.” The origins of the latter term are disputed, but it has been theorized that “condom rappers” are either ones who rap incessantly about sex or artists from the ‘80s who warned against the dangers of unprotected intercourse.

Kendrick reminisces about when he would dream of being as successful as the rappers he listened to. Back then, using condoms wasn’t considered “cool,” as the dangers of STDs were not very well known. At the time, Compton hip-hop was not yet famous—Compton was put on the map starting with N.W.A, who released their debut album Straight Outta Compton in 1988. Given the possible reference to 1980s hip-hop and condoms, this could also be a subtle shout-out to fellow Compton rapper and N.W.A member Eazy-E, who died from complications of AIDS in 1995.

The Notorious B.I.G. also mentioned this cultural transition from a contraception-averse society to wearing condoms due to the dangers of disease on his September 1994 track, “The What”:

I used to get feels on a bitch
Now I throw shields on the dick, to stop me from that HIV shit

lyrics: that was my problem
annotation:
Peer pressure influenced his decision to begin drinking, as is the case with many teenagers.

Kendrick uses some more wordplay with his inflection here, just as he does later in the verse. “That was my problem” is emphasized so as to sound like a question: ‘Then what’s my problem?’

So, while identifying the given reasons for drinking as a problem he is personally dealing with, he is also asking a rhetorical question: “If drinking feels good, if drinking kills my sorrow, if drinking will help me to become popular why should I be concerned?”

Watch Kendrick modify this line during his 2013 SNL performance:

lyrics:
Throw a steak off the ark to a pool full of sharks, he'll take it
Leave him in the wilderness with a sworn nemesis, he'll make it
Take the gratitude from him, I bet he'll show you somethin', whoa
annotation:
These lines represent the mindset of young black males growing up in poverty stricken and crime infested areas.

Kendrick used the shark metaphor before on Dr. Dre’s 2015 song, “Deep Water,” a song that uses wildlife in the ocean as an analogy for gang culture in Compton:

They worry him to death, but he’s no vegetarian
The beef is on his breath, inheriting the drama better than
A great white, nigga, this is life in my aquarium

The idea is that the environment black males grow up in makes them more vicious than sharks.

“Ark” is another word for boat, but this could also be a reference to the story of Noah’s Ark in the Old Testament. Although Noah’s ark is about the obedience and faith of God’s servant, perhaps Kendrick uses the ark to symbolize wealth and privilege. If this is the case, the ark is home of the upper classes of society where people escape the “flood” of violence and crime that happen in lower class urban areas, which Kendrick refers to as “pool full of sharks.”

K.Dot also compares the youth to Jesus in the wilderness with his sworn nemesis, Satan. The Book of Matthew says:

Then Jesus was led up by the Spirit into the wilderness to be tempted by the devil

Kendrick’s narrative shows that certain people in harsh situations will find a way to survive, but stripping things away from them, including their “gratitude,” will result in them becoming ruthless and willing to kill, as the following lines suggest.

lyrics:
I fucked Sherane and went to tell my bros (tell my bros)
Then Usher Raymond "Let It Burn" came on ("Let Burn" came on)
annotation: That was a metaphor for both. Not saying that I actually had an STD. But that is the consequences I could have gotten messing with somebody like Sherane.

lyrics: I was in a dark room, loud tunes
annotation:
He was literally in a dark room or a party when he had fallen into pressure and drank. He’s describing the surroundings for us to picture or reminisce a similar vibe or alcohol abuse we had in a club or house party, zombiing around in a dark environment with music pounding through our head.

Similarly, the “dark room” reference is found on “Poetic Justice” (explained by Kendrick here), as a metaphor for the mAAd City he grew up in.

lyrics:
I'll chip a nigga lil' bit of nothin', I'll chip a nigga lil' bit of nothin'
I'll chip a nigga lil' bit of nothin', I'll chip a nigga, then throw the blower in his lap
Walk myself to the court like, "Bitch, I did that!," X-rated
annotation:
“Chip” means to kill, and a “blower” is a gun.

The person Kendrick describes has a “no fucks given” mentality. He’s reckless to the point that he’ll bypass society’s laws to murder and won’t have any remorse or think anything of it. He gains satisfaction from knowing his son’s death is avenged. Kendrick would adapt the same mentality if anyone close to him is harmed.

Kendrick employs imagery similar to a mic drop when he says the gun is thrown on the victim’s lap. Mic drops symbolize that no one can challenge what was said and the job is definitively done.

In a 2017 interview with Zane Lowe, Kendrick explained the meaning of “X-rated”:

It’s an idea of complete chaos and madness. Organized madness, controlled madness; us trying to control this madness.

lyrics: Lookin' to make a vow soon
annotation:
The word vow, is interesting here – according to Google and Latin Word List, “vow” is a solemn oath or a promise to God.

K. Dot is about to pass the point of no return – make a commitment to “getting fucked up” (as per the next line), which is, in its own right, a vow.

lyrics:
Johnny don't wanna go to school no mo', no mo'
Johnny said books ain't cool no mo' (No mo')
Johnny wanna be a rapper like his big cousin
Johnny caught a body yesterday out hustlin'
God bless America, you know we all love him
annotation:
Kendrick is talking about how America dissuades black youth from going to school. The media typically portrays blacks excelling in hip-hop, sports, or crime, so black youth tend to aspire to do those things.

These bars are reminiscent of Dr. Dre’s lines in his 1999 song “Bang Bang”:

Johnny got a shotgun
And he ain’t even strong enough to cock one
Fuck trying to job hunt

Kendrick also used the name “Johnny” in his 2011 song, “Little Johnny,” and applied the name to the police in another 2011 song, “Ronald Reagan Era”:

Heart racin', racin' pass Johnny because he’s racist

The use of the name “Johnny” stems from the phrase “Johnny get your gun,” which was used in America in the 19th and 20th centuries to get young men to enlist in the military. The phrase was made into a song of the same name in 1886 and popularized by George M. Cohan in his 1917 song, “Over There.” Anti-war proponents eventually restructured it to “Johnny Got His Gun” and used it to promote pacifism. David Bowie also used the name “Johnny” in his 1997 song, “I’m Afraid of Americans.”

lyrics: Hot sauce all in our Top Ramen, ya bish (ya bish)
annotation:
Ramen noodles are very famous cheap eats.

This is a continuation of the burn from fucking Sherane “ya bish.” Hot sauce in his noodles is a euphemism for an STD that burned his “noodle.”

There’s the literal meaning to adding hot sauce to Top Ramen to make them more palatable. But metaphorically, it’s also a way of improving on shitty situation by adding a certain condiment to make the situation easier to handle. That seems to be the theme of this song, which is about escaping poverty, mental depravity and the trappings of the hood.

Also a play on words as pronunciation sounds like “top rhymin'”

lyrics: That I'ma get fucked up, fillin' up my cup
annotation:
Kendrick has made a commitment to getting drunk. It’s an interesting play on words because people usually make vows when they have something difficult and positive to accomplish, not something like getting drunk.

Also, the way that Kendrick sort of separated​ this from the previous line, “looking to make a vow soon,” could mean that maybe he was trying to break his negative habits, but the more he drank, the more that commitment shifted to getting fucked up.

lyrics:
Yesterday I got a call like from my dog like 101
Said they killed his only son because of insufficient funds
annotation:
Kendrick may be referencing Martin Luther King Jr.’s famous “I Have a Dream” speech:

America has given the Negro people a bad check, a check which has come back marked ‘insufficient funds.’ But we refuse to believe that the bank of justice is bankrupt. We refuse to believe that there are insufficient funds in the great vaults of opportunity of this nation. And so, we’ve come to cash this check, a check that will give us upon demand the riches of freedom and the security of justice.

This person’s son who was killed may have been involved in criminal activity and simply didn’t have the money to cover his debts with some drug or arms dealer. His death serves as a symbol for a greater theme presented in DAMN.—justice that has been compromised due to racial prejudice and governmental corruption.

“From my dog like 101” could refer to the time of the call (1:01AM), a “one-on-one” conversation, or a play on the Disney film about dogs, 101 Dalmatians.

lyrics:
Park the car, then we start rhymin', ya bish (ya bish)
The only thing we had to free our mind (free our mind)
annotation: Freestyling is used by Kendrick and his friends to escape rough life in Compton. This line refers to ‘Backseat Freestyle’.

lyrics:
I see the crowd mood
Changin' by the minute
annotation:
He sees the crowd’s mood changing by the minute, because they’re getting more and more intoxicated.

Also, the way he pronounces “mood” can be misinterpreted as “move,” which is show business lingo to describe how an audience gets into the music at a show or a party.

Some examples of this phrase throughout hip hop history include “Move The Crowd” by Eric B. & Rakim, as well as lyrics by 2Pac and Ice Cube—two of Kendrick’s biggest influences.

lyrics:
He was sobbin', he was mobbin', way belligerent and drunk
Talkin' out his head, philosophin' on what the Lord had done
annotation:
Often when people suffer tragedy like the loss of a loved one, they ask God why he allowed it to happen or sometimes try to come to terms with the death by telling themselves it all happened for a greater reason. Kendrick explores this concept further on “FEAR.”:

Why God, why God do I gotta suffer?
Pain in my heart carry burdens full of struggle
Why God, why God do I gotta bleed?
Every stone thrown at you restin' at my feet

lyrics: Then freeze that verse when we see dollar signs (see dollar signs)
annotation:
Despite freestyle exercise being the one escape from their dysfunctional reality, Kendrick Lamar and his friends would be easily distracted by an opportunity for some quick cash; often through illegal activity. Another interpretation is that they stop trading verses once they see someone walking down the street who looks like they have money, as implied by the next two lines.

Watch how Ali freezes the track at this exact point in the song for dramatic effect, during their first ever live performance of “Money Trees” in New York on October 23, 2012—allowing Kendrick to emphasize his homies' priorities.

lyrics: and the record on repeat
annotation:
Kendrick Lamar might mean every song playing at the club is about consuming alcohol, and one after the other they begin to sound the same.

This could also be a metaphor for his partying, alcohol consuming life. This party, this drinking, is going to continue over and over again like a record on repeat.

lyrics:
He said: "K-Dot, can you pray for me?
It been a fucked up day for me
I know that you anointed, show me how to overcome."
He was lookin' for some closure
Hopin' I could bring him closer
To the spiritual, my spirit do know better, but I told him
"I can't sugarcoat the answer for you, this is how I feel:
If somebody kill my son, that mean somebody gettin' killed."
annotation:
Kendrick uses these first two bars in the intro to the album version of “HUMBLE.”:

Nobody pray for me
It’s been that day for me

“Anointed” means to have God’s favor. It applies to people who deliver powerful messages and have a lot of influence. The application of the word, in this context, originated with priests and kings in the Old Testament, who had oil poured over them to symbolize the divine nature of their position.

This man wants to pray and move on, but K-Dot suggests that revenge is optimum. On “The Heart Part 4,” Kendrick says:

I ain’t sanctified enough to say that I won’t shoot ya

Note the interchangeability between “do no better” and “do know better.”

lyrics: You lookin' like a easy come-up, ya bish (ya bish)
annotation:
This is street slang that may not be obvious to all listeners. An “easy come up” is an easy way to get money. When applied to people, it refers to someone on the streets who is easy to “jump” or rob. For example one might hear a thug say, “I don’t usually rob niggas, but he was just walking around with 3 ounces on him! It was such an easy come up!”

Take this into consideration with the very next line; Kendrick is dissing someone from a higher class family. Someone with lots of cash and no street experience is the epitome of an easy come up.

lyrics: Took a sip, then another sip, then somebody said to me
annotation:
He was casually drinking then somebody told him to drink more and quicker.

A common theme in this album is peer pressure—there’s even a whole song dedicated to the topic“. This line could show how easily 17-year-old Kendrick, (who this album is about), can be influenced as he does become drunk and questioning his life and relationships by the end of the song.

lyrics:
Tell me what you do for love, loyalty, and passion of
All the memories collected, moments you could never touch
annotation:
“LOVE.” and “LOYALTY.” are the titles of two of Kendrick’s tracks. Both songs are about his fiancé, Whitney Alford, and he mentions some of his memories from their past. Kendrick shows that in spite of his status as a religious and moral figure, he’s willing to abandon his ethics for the people closest to him, like his fiancé. This line echoes the same idea found on the track “ELEMENT.” when he says he’ll:

Put the Bible down and go eye for an eye for this shit

lyrics:
A silver spoon I know you come from, ya bish (ya bish)
And that's a lifestyle that we never knew (we never knew)
annotation:
Being “born with a silver spoon in your mouth” means you come from a well off family. K.Dot and the homies don’t know what that life is like.

Also, young Kendrick is justifying robbing this person. They inherited opportunity. That is something Kendrick and his friends have never had. They garner resentment toward the well off, and outlet that through robbing them.

lyrics: [Chorus]
annotation:
The deceiving hook sounds like something that you would blast at a party to drink to but when viewed with the rest of the song it only shows Lamar’s criticism of the glamour of the drinking culture and alcoholism.

As TDE’s Punch told Complex:

It’s a real deceptive record if you’re a casual listener. It sounds like we are celebrating having a good time before you actually dive into what he’s saying. He wrote it deceptive like that on purpose. If you just a casual listener go ahead, have fun. But if you really a fan of him you’ll get the message behind the record.

lyrics:
I'll wait in front a nigga's spot and watch him hit his block
I'll catch a nigga leavin' service if that's all I got
annotation:
These lines are reminiscent to bars Kendrick spit on his song, “untitled 05 | 09.21.2014.”:

Watch you when you walk inside your house
You threw your briefcase all on the couch
I plan on creeping through your fuckin' door and blowin' out
Every piece of your brain

“Service” refers to church service. A person’s home and place of worship are considered sacred, but Kendrick would disregard his respect for those structures to enact street justice.

lyrics: Go at a reverend for the revenue
annotation:
This line speaks to their ‘by any means necessary’ mentality. They would even rob a person as upstanding as a reverend to get money.

Prime example: Pastor Winans was being beaten, robbed, and car-jacked at a gas station in Detroit back in May of 2012.

Profit is revenue minus the cost. With profit being the money made and the costs his sins, he could be going to a reverend to remove the costs.

lyrics: Nigga, why you babysittin' only two or three shots?
annotation:
His peers are calling him out for sipping slowly (babysitting). This is the peer pressure. Kendrick doesn’t want to get drunk, he knows that there will be consequences but he must drink to fit in.

Kendrick is pointing out a flaw in our mindset about alcohol, saying basically that you can’t just drink casually, you have to get fucked up.

lyrics: Ain't no Black Power when your baby killed by a coward
annotation:
On “The Blacker The Berry,” Kendrick showed his hypocrisy with supporting black rights, but seemingly having killed prior:

So why did I weep when Trayvon Martin was in the street when gang banging make me kill a nigga blacker than me?
Hypocrite!

Kendrick is ready to throw out “black power” and “the black rights movement” to defend his son, who was killed by another black man. Kendrick’s defence for his family breaks through race barriers.

lyrics: It go Halle Berry or hallelujah
annotation: You can either go right, or you can go left and get crazy with us. Basically just saying we throw the evils of the world in the air. Now, K. Dot, you can either get with the program or you don’t have to, it’s whatever. Of course, hallelujah being the more good in me and Halle Berry being the actual vice of what’s going down – the lust for the money, the lust for this mission we are about to go on. Pick your poison, tell me what you’re doing. But when you tell me, tell me right now. We ain’t got time to wait.

lyrics:
I'ma show you how to turn it up a notch
First you get a swimming pool full of liquor, then you dive in it
Pool full of liquor, then you dive in it
annotation:
Kendrick said that this line was about buying so much liquor that you could fill a swimming pool with it.

The person speaking to Kendrick was telling him to get loads of alcohol and drink it quickly, or “dive in it.” Peer pressure can drive someone to drink more than they physically are able to.

He uses hyperbole to highlight the ridiculousness of some people’s consumption of alcohol.

lyrics:
I can't even keep the peace, don't you fuck with one of ours
It be murder in the street, it be bodies in the hour
annotation:
A common practice promoted by activist groups is peaceful protesting. For instance, the Black Lives Matter movement often protests in the wake of killings of blacks and other minorities by law enforcement, like they did when 12-year old boy Tamir Rice was killed by police in 2014.

Kendrick implies that peaceful protesting isn’t working, so he suggests militant measures reminiscent of human rights activist Malcolm X.

Maybe fewer innocent people would be killed by law enforcement if, as Kendrick suggests, violence was met with violence instead of passiveness and peace.

Sidenote: “ours” can refer to one’s own inner circle of friends and family, but it most likely means “ours” as in the black community in the United States.

lyrics: I wave a few bottles, then I watch 'em all flock
annotation:
Many young people just want to party and get fucked up. They can be easily manipulated by the presence of alcohol and will often use it as an excuse to lose self-respect and do things they probably shouldn’t be doing. These people will assemble or “flock” to the nearest person who has a few bottles. (Think of this scene in Superbad)

Metaphorically, the physical action of “waving” while in a pool is a sign for lifeguard to come rescue you. Therefore, Kendrick is mentioning his divergence from our generation’s ways of drowning their problems.

His wordplay with “flock” could also refer to sheep, how he began drinking by chasing after fake dreams to fit in with the crowd, like sheep to a shepherd.

lyrics: Ghetto bird be on the street, paramedics on the dial
annotation:
A “Ghetto Bird” is a police helicopter, used primarily to spot crime or to track fleeing suspects. Ice Cube dedicated his track of the same name to the topic.

The content and vocal delivery of this line is similar to a line on his 2012 song “m.A.A.d city”:

Go buy a chopper, and have a doctor on speed dial, I guess.

lyrics: Pick your poison, tell me what you doin'
annotation:
Halle Berry is an Oscar-winning actor, but she’s also a veritable sex symbol. Kendrick equates her name with worldly pleasure, contrasting it with the similar-sounding biblical phrase, “Hallelujah,” meaning “praise the Lord” in Hebrew.

Whether it’s pussy or religion, Kendrick illustrates that dedicating one’s life to either can lead to suffering. This is a direct symbol for the “poison” Kendrick had to endure by making the choice to follow salvation in the midst of the darkness that defines Compton.

lyrics: All the girls wanna play Baywatch
annotation:
Baywatch was a famous TV show about sexy beach lifeguards. Kendrick is saying that the girls are playing a Pam Anderson as they dive into a pool of liquor.

A poetic play on how in Baywatch, the lifeguards need to resuscitate people who have drowned in the water. These girls drink a lot, essentially drowning in a pool full of liquor, and then receive mouth to mouth from some dude or want to change the partner they are with.

lyrics:
Let somebody touch my momma
Touch my sister, touch my woman
Touch my daddy, touch my niece
Touch my nephew, touch my brother
annotation:
Kendrick has an abundance of love for his family. This is the album’s second shoutout to his niece, whom he shouted out in the previous track, “YAH.”

My latest muse is my niece, she worth living, see me on TV, scream, “That’s Uncle Kendrick!”

Kendrick’s love for his family is deep, with him being willing to kill anyone who threatens any of them.

lyrics:
Everybody gon' respect the shooter
But the one in front of the gun lives forever
(The one in front of the gun, forever)
annotation:
The shooter may get the temporary attention from committing the murder, but the victim is remembered and honored forever. Although the circumstances were different, Kendrick’s friend Dave died in a shootout and is living forever through this album.

This is an analogy to suggest that a controlling regime (The shooter) gets respect (Obedience), but “the one in front of the gun” (The people) will always exist, no matter what threats are given.

Similarly Nas alludes to this same idea in “One Love.” Jay-Z had a different opinion of this idea in the song “30 Something.”

Kendrick’s lines are similar to the famed last words of civil rights activist Huey Newton:

You can kill my body, but you can’t kill my soul. My soul will live forever!

The person who chooses the street life will get respect for shooting someone but the one who gets shot goes to heaven and lives forever. This could just be a statement of martyrdom in general given the heavily Christian themes of the album. There are countless examples throughout history of the inverse Jay-Z, respecting the one who got shot over the shooter.

lyrics:
I got a swimming pool full of liquor and they dive in it
Pool full of liquor, I'ma dive in it
annotation: This song’s content is not only about normal drinking, it seems like it’s about excessive drinking. Imagine a whole pool filled with liquor, and you’re swimming and diving in it. This means that you’ll not only take one or two sips.

lyrics:
Alright, kids, we're gonna talk about gun control
(Pray for me) Damn!
annotation:
This is the turning part of the song where the “complete chaos and madness” that Kendrick claimed “X-rated” represents is exposed further.

There is an argument that gun violence occurs more in areas where there is gun control laws, ie the 2017 Las Vegas shooting. Kendrick, for the most part has shown to be a pacifist, so we should logically assume that he’s aware of gun control’s consequences. However, that’s where the irony of the song comes in. After just declaring that “his dog” should “chip a nigga and throw the blower in his lap”, he goes to a convention to preach to kids a practically opposite message, something he criticized America itself for doing in the third verse (“Look what you taught us!”). He illustrates himself as a hypocrite by disattaching himself from the moral position he first presented.

This has been compared to Blacker The Berry off Kendrick’s sophomore album To Pimp A Butterfly, which at the end pointed out that hypocrisy and loose morale is somewhat inevitable in a chaotic environment.

The hypocritical nature of Kendrick in this line could also be tied to America’s disconnection with God, a running theme in the DAMN. album that Carl Duckworth touched upon in FEAR., the song after this one:

Verse 2 says, “You only have I known of all the families of the Earth, therefore I will punish you for all your iniquities.”
So until we come back to these commandments
Until you come back to these commandments
We gonna feel this way, we gonna be under this curse
Because He said He’s gonna punish us

lyrics:
And I been hustlin' all day
This-a-way, that-a-way
Through canals and alleyways, just to say
annotation:
Kendrick and his crew have been striving to get money from sun-up-to-sun-down in the poverty-stricken community that is Compton, California. These simple lines help to emphasize the rat race of daily life taking the listener into the geographic recesses of the underworld.

His delivery of “this-a-way, that-a-way” is similar to that of Mac Shawn on the chorus of E-40’s March 1995 track, “Sideaways.” Kendrick references E-40 in the second verse.

lyrics: [Verse 2]
annotation:
Rapped from the perspective of Kendrick’s conscience, rather than from Kendrick himself.

Kendrick explains this verse and how it relies on the art of peer pressure in this video, at a high school. The art of peer pressure is a recurring theme within the album.

TDE’s in-house engineer MixedByAli talked about mixing this verse in an interview with Complex:

When I heard the second verse and heard his conscience come in, I knew we had to do something to switch it up right there. So we changed that, did some panning, some vocal animations and stuff like that…I was just playing with some delays, some reverbs, tweak it out make it sound real eerie.

lyrics:
It's not a place
This country is to me a sound
Of drum and bass
annotation:
The U2 segment is a sample from the 2017 song “American Soul” which appeared on the album, Songs of Experience. On “American Soul,” Kendrick returns the favor with some spoken word poetry.

These lines are broadly interpretable, but the song’s content suggests “drum and bass” represent gunfire.

Author and music critic, Steven Hyden, suggests the following interpretation in a close look at the collaboration, which emphasizes the themes in common with other U2 songs:

Bono’s vocal hook is an extremely Bono vocal hook, in that it seems to communicate broad truths without quite making literal sense… . Aside from the shout-out to his boys Larry and Adam, what Bono seems to hint at is a familiar theme from many U2 songs: Mankind perpetually feels dislocated in every way — physically, emotionally, spiritually —–which inevitably sends our eyes heavenward in search of guidance and, hopefully, deliverance. Later, Lamar distills this feeling down to a question: “But is America honest or do we bask in sin?”

“Larry and Adam” refer to Larry Mullen Jr. and Adam Clayton, the percussionist and bassist of U2. Bono’s reference to “the sound of drum and bass” is probably figurative, but it is also definitely literally referencing the song’s new riff, presumably played by Larry and Adam.

lyrics:
Money trees is the perfect place for shade
And that's just how I feel, nah, nah
annotation:
Having a lot of money is the most comfortable place to be. Kendrick is trying to suggest that although he feels passionately about the above statements, having a large amount of money shades him from facing hardships that many people encounter today.

You have two options: pursue money or pursue meaning. Both can get you rich if you hustle hard enough. However, the pursuit of purely money is just a temporary place for security. This also implies that money and wealth is extremely susceptible to evil (might make you do some shady things).

Later in the album, Kendrick tells us that they are ‘dying of thirst’. Literally speaking, shade can serve to temporally subdue their need to be saved, but does not fix the problem.

lyrics:
Okay, now open your mind up and listen me, Kendrick
I am your conscience, if you do not hear me
Then you will be history, Kendrick
I know that you're nauseous right now
annotation:
Kendrick has taken his body for granted, consuming excessive amounts of alcohol, which is badly affecting his health. In his mind, he knows what he’s doing to his body but he’s not trying to stop drinking—this is his conscience’s last effort to keep him from hurting his body even more than he already has.

When his conscience warns Kendrick about becoming “history”, it refers to death. If he drinks too much, he will be history => dead.

lyrics: You close your eyes to look around
annotation: “Closing your eyes to look around” is a paradoxical statement as one normally opens their eyes to see. Notice that the last line is cut off by the song “FEAR.” It’s like trying to take a second and look inside yourself, but being cut off by fear.

lyrics:
A dollar might just fuck your main bitch
That's just how I feel, nah
A dollar might say fuck them niggas that you came with
That's just how I feel, nah, nah
A dollar might just make that lane switch
That's just how I feel, nah
A dollar might turn to a million and we all rich
That's just how I feel
annotation:
Some people’s desire for money will, ironically, leave them exhausted, disillusioned, or alone—not to mention broke. Others may wander from their faith or loyalty. This notion coincides with the “Halle Berry” or “Hallelujah” theme found earlier in the chorus.

The closing lines, however, evoke winning the lottery; where the purchase of an inexpensive ticket can result in millions of dollars. This blurs the lines between the misconception that “money is the root of all evil” and its ability to change lives. In actuality, it is the love of money that is considered to be evil, according to 1 Timothy 6:10:

For the love of money is the root of all evil: which while some coveted after, they have erred from the faith, and pierced themselves through with many sorrows.

These bars might also allude to Dolemite, an April 1975 blaxploitation film about a rebellious pimp.

lyrics:
If I take another one down
I'ma drown in some poison, abusin' my limit
annotation:
Kendrick is past his limit, just a shot away from alcohol poisoning

The previous lines, which are delivered in an eerie voice, are Kendrick’s conscience. The second part this verse is Kendrick’s reaction to his own conscience.

This is Kendrick fighting the urge to drink more alcohol. If he continues, he will metaphorically drown.

lyrics: Hail Mary, Jesus and Joseph
annotation:
Kendrick uses the religious motif once more, this time is acknowledging the Hail Mary prayer:

Hail Mary, full of grace.
Our Lord is with thee.
Blessed art thou among women,
and blessed is
the fruit of thy womb, Jesus.
Holy Mary, Mother of God,
pray for us sinners,
now and at the hour of our death.
Amen.

The prayer which is a request for the Virgin Mary, mother of Jesus, to intercede on behalf of a Christian to receive mercy or a blessing of some sort. This is immediately contrasted when Kendrick mentions the violence, illness, and discord that exist in the world today.

“Hail Mary” is also a classic Tupac song about revenge on a faulty justice system in America. Tupac is one of Kendrick’s favorite rappers.

The phrase “hail mary” is also echoed later on DAMN. in it’s final track, “DUCKWORTH.”:

Oh Lamar
Hail Mary and marijuana, times is hard
Pray with the hooligans, shadows all in the dark
Fellowship with demons and relatives, I’m a star

lyrics:
Dreams of livin' life like rappers do (like rappers do)
Bump that new E-40 after school (way after school)
You know, “Big Ballin' With My Homies” (my homies)
Earl Stevens had us thinkin' rational (thinkin' rational)
annotation:
“Big Ballin' With My Homies” is a song off of Charlie Hustle: The Blueprint of a Self-Made Millionaire by West Coast legend E-40, real name Earl Stevens. The album made Kendrick’s list of 25 Favorite Albums, which he used to play after school.

E-40 usually portrays a luxurious lifestyle in his music, and since Kendrick and his homies are under his music influence, obtaining money seems more than “rational” to them. The usage of “rational” also takes a ironical meaning; pointing out how rap songs gave him and his homies un-realistic ambitions of wealth, and with California having the highest poverty rate in the US, it’s something that’s almost impossible to achieve.

lyrics: I think that I'm feelin' the vibe, I see the love in her eyes
annotation:
Kendrick is mocking the “feeling” of alcohol—he’s one shot away from death but somehow “feeling the vibe” thinking he’s getting the feeling alcohol is suppose to give you.

The alcohol might also be giving him liquid courage—making him so confident that he think a girl he’s making eye contact with likes him.

He thinks what he’s seeing is great for him and his party life and peer pressure keeps persuading him to push his limits.

lyrics: The great American flag is wrapped in drag with explosives
annotation:
The line references the role of America in foreign politics and it’s efforts of being the “world police.” It often is overzealous with its foreign policy and is quick to resort to violence in resolving foreign conflicts, but only when it enriches us.

This album was released the same day America dropped the largest non-nuclear bomb ever constructed in Afghanistan.

lyrics:
Back to reality, we poor, ya bish (ya bish)
Another casualty at war, ya bish (ya bish)
Two bullets in my Uncle Tony head (my Tony head)
He said one day I'll be on tour, ya bish (ya bish)
That Louis Burgers never be the same (won't be the same)
A Louis belt will never ease that pain (won't ease that pain)
annotation:
After the lavish lifestyle ideology propelled by the music, who’s influence he was under, Kendrick is back among the cruel reality of Compton, a place where rivalry between gangs causes casualties, similar to a war. A victim of the the ongoing violence was his Uncle Tony, killed at Louis Burgers. Not only is Kendrick poor in a monetary sense, he and his crew are now pouring liquor on the curb in memory of his Uncle Tony.

Kendrick’s family have always been portrayed as supportive, but here his Uncle displays the kind of encouragement a lot of rappers and entertainers never experience; a belief in his abilities.

The shock of losing a supportive figure puts a permanent stain on that Louis Burgers, and exemplifies the deep ties that Kendrick has to his city. His “dreams of living life like rappers do” are interrupted by the pain that gang culture brings, and that pain is not eased by expensive clothing.

lyrics:
I see the feelin', the freedom is granted
As soon as the damage of vodka arrived
annotation:
Now they’re drunk, Kendrick and the girl have lost their inhibitions, they’re free. They can “capitalize” on their lack of inhibition by having sex without nerves.

Although it’s not clear if it’s a coincidence or it was Kendrick’s intention, there is a brand of vodka called Freedom.

lyrics:
Compulsive disorder, sons and daughters
Barricaded blocks and borders
annotation:
A Compulsive disorder is the obsession with repeating something over and over. Kendrick is using the term here, to show people’s obsession with keeping out unwanted immigrants, and also separating the poor from the wealthy.

More specifically, this could be a shot at Trump, who ordered the construction of a wall on the US-Mexico border. The “sons and daughters” may represent the people who follow Trump, and their posterity. Kendrick sees this as a recurring problem that is being passed down from generation to generation.

“Sons and daughters” also plays into the first few lines. Jesus was referred to as the son of Mary and Joseph in the Bible, and most importantly, the son of God.

lyrics: But I'ma purchase when that day is jerkin' (that day is jerkin')
annotation:
When that day is troubling him or “jerkin'” (i.e. the sad memories get to him), he’s gonna buy material objects in hope that they might ease the pain momentarily.

Material objects won’t heal him, but when he’s paid (now!) he’ll cop it anyway. It’s part of the victory of his perseverance.

Notice the wordplay on “jerking” and “belt” as a belt can be used to stop something from jerking in the literal sense.

lyrics:
This how you capitalize, this is parental advice
Then apparently, I'm over-influenced by what you are doin'
annotation:
Kendrick may be “capitalizing” by taking advantage of a girl as drunk as he is now that they’re both “free” and there’s “love in her eyes.” The “parental advice” may be necessary now because they’re having sex.

The phrase “over-influenced” is a play on being under the influence of alcohol.

Kendrick might be alluding back to the first verse about how alcoholism runs in his family, now Kendrick is following their lead because he’s “over-influenced” by their actions. This also harkens back to the peer pressure in “Art of Peer Pressure”.

lyrics:
Homicidal thoughts; Donald Trump's in office
We lost Barack and promised to never doubt him again
annotation:
In the wake of Donald Trump’s presidency, many of the people who criticized Barack Obama during his two-terms are starting to lament his absence. Kendrick openly criticized Trump in his guest feature on Isaiah Rashad’s “Wat’s Wrong”:

Might stay in the Trump Tower for one week
Spray paint all the walls and smoke weed
Fuck them and fuck y'all and fuck me

Barack Obama is a recurring and dynamic topic in Kendrick’s discography. On one hand, Kendrick openly stated on “Dreams” that some Americans did not want a black president. Similarly, “Hood Politics,” Kendrick lamented he wished to see more of Obama’s campaign promises come to fruition while acknowledging the limitations on his power as president.

Furthermore, we may mention that a lot of ink has been spread in hip-hop about the former president’s limitations. In fact, some rappers expressed some concerns about his legacy towards black people, Lamar, and others rappers such as J.Cole definitively seems to understand he tried the best he could.

It’s also worth noting that Kendrick has a personal relationship with the former president. A few months after the release of To Pimp a Butterfly, President Obama labeled “How Much a Dollar Cost” his favorite song of 2015. A year later in 2016, Kendrick visited the White House via a personal invitation from Obama himself.

lyrics: Pull off at Church's, with Pirellis skirtin' (Pirellis skirtin')
annotation: Pirelli’s are a brand of expensive tires. He’s going to be driving off from Church’s Chicken squealing his tires. It takes some wordplay to contrast Pirelli’s, (expensive), and Church’s, (cheap).

lyrics: I thought I was doin' the most 'til someone said to me
annotation:
He thought he was really partying hard until he realized it was nothing compared to the guy who confronted him.

In the context of the story, this line and chorus can give you a real feeling of concern for Kendrick at this point, he’s already put his life on the line with how much he’s drinking and now someone is saying he’s barely partying.

lyrics:
But is America honest, or do we bask in sin?
Pass the gin, I mix it with American blood
annotation:
Kendrick uses irony for dramatic effect with these lines. After asking whether America values sin more than honesty, he proceeds to take a shot of Gin and “mix it with American blood"—a euphemism for assaulting someone else. The consumption of alcohol and violence are typically associated with sinful behavior, which makes Kendrick seem hypocritical.

It’s also worth noting that gin is a popular drink for west-coast rappers, particularly those with gang affiliations. Snoop Dogg, a collaborator on Kendrick’s last album and a west coast rap legend, helped popularize the consumption of gin with his hit song “Gin and Juice”.

lyrics:
Gang signs out the window, ya bish (ya bish)
Hopin' all of 'em offend you, ya bish (ya bish)
annotation:
Gang signs are meant to intimidate and offend the people that are viewing them pass by. There’s a nonchalance within the line that is the sentiment of the youth. It’s the uncaring arrogance we all displayed, that “IDGAF” attitude. Those are exactly the sentiments within Kendrick as he rolls around with his homies. There’s some irony portrayed because the song before is The Art of Peer Pressure. He wasn’t a gang banger but he still threw up gang signs because it was what the homies were doing.

These bars and one before, are all related. It’s the mentality of how Kendrick deals with troubled days when he can’t ease the pain of his past. In one way or another, he lashes out and acts recklessly (in actions or money).

lyrics:
I ride, you ride, bang
One chopper, 100 shots, bang
Hop out, do you bang?
Two chopper, 200 shots, bang
I ride, you ride, bang
One chopper, 100 shots, bang
Hop out, do you bang?
Two chopper, 200 shots, bang
annotation:
The bridge is all a play on words of the dangerous Compton lifestyle themed in this album, to actual fireshots, comparing them to liquor shots; both can take you down.

Note also the peer pressure theme; The more shots you take, the more you influence someone else to do the same. Thus the cycle continues: since Kendrick or the homie’s doing it, it must be cool, whether it be drinking, shooting someone, or fucking someone.

  • “I ride, you ride” – When I drink, you should drink
  • “One chopper, one hundred shots, bang” – alcohol abuse.
  • “Hop out, do you, bang?” – Peer pressure; influence someone to drink excessively.
  • “Two chopper, two hundred shots, bang” – If one person takes 100 shots, you can assume that they’re both at it now and perpetuating the cycle

In “Hop out, Do you bang?” he references on how it goes down in Compton walking down the streets as a youngster and having gangsters stop their cars and hop out to ask him about which gang he is affiliated to, then Kendrick proceeds to flee from them, hence the 100 shots fired at him by the gang bangers pursuing him.

lyrics:
Then bash him in, you Crippin' or you married to Blood?
I'll ask again—oops, accident
annotation:
Compton Crips and Piru Bloods are two rival West Coast gangs. Given the political nature of “XXX.,” Kendrick may be talking about the Democrats—whose party is represented by the color blue like the Crips and the Republicans—whose party is represented by the color red like the Bloods. Kendrick also made this comparison on his 2015 song, “Hood Politics”:

From Compton to Congress, set trippin’ all around
Ain’t nothin' new, but a flu of new Demo-Crips and Re-Blood-licans
Red state versus a blue state, which one you governin'?

The “oops” line could mean one getting shot and killed for asking about gang affiliations.

lyrics:
They say your hood is a pot of gold (a pot of gold)
And we gon' crash it when nobody's home
annotation: Wealthy neighborhoods are essentially “pots of gold” because of how many valuables can be stolen from them. For example, the house lick in the third verse of “The Art Of Peer Pressure” describes Kendrick and his friends robbing a house that they had been watching for 2 months.

lyrics: [Chorus]
annotation:
The single version of this song ends here, after the chorus. On the album, however, there is another verse and a skit that further the story presented in GKMC.

Kendrick and company head out to exact revenge upon his assailants, but once after shots are fired, Dave is killed. This altercation marks a symbolic change of heart in the album.

lyrics:
It's nasty when you set us up
Then roll the dice, then bet us up
You overnight the big rifles, then tell Fox to be scared of us
Gang members or terrorists, et cetera, et cetera
America's reflections of me, that's what a mirror does
annotation:
Kendrick calls out the hypocrisy of American politicians and the media, stating that they like to portray African-Americans as “violent gang members” or “terrorists,” even though the government “overnights” or ships the weapons and drugs to the African-American communities. This criticism isn’t new for Kendrick—he previously blamed the government for the proliferation of weapons and violence on “Wesley’s Theory.”

As Kendrick also points out, the American government has a pattern of “setting up” African-Americans by implementing policies like Nixon’s “War on Drugs,” which disproportionately targeted African-American men. Politicians metaphorically “roll the dice” to make financial gains off of their hardship; together with the “War on Drugs,” the privatization of America’s prison system made the over-incarceration of African-Americans a profitable industry.

Kendrick references FOX News multiple times throughout this album, most notably on “BLOOD.” and “DNA.” Here, Kendrick addresses the fearful rhetoric FOX uses during its discussions about the black community.

Rather than blaming FOX for perpetuating fear, Kendrick recognizes that this fear is inevitable. Just like a mirror can distort someone’s features so that they appear unattractive, Lamar’s reputation can be distorted as well—a point he highlights by pronouncing “that’s what a mirror does” to sound like “that’s what Ameri-does.”

lyrics: [Bridge: Anna Wise]
annotation:
Anna Wise is a part of the group Sonnymoon. She has collaborated with TDE before, on Ab-Soul’s “Double Standards” as well as with Kendrick on “Cartoon and Cereal” and “Bitch, Don’t Kill My Vibe”

The second round of the bridge is punctuated with machine gun onomatopoeia, used as a reminder of the lifestyle that Kendrick and his homies are following in order to get their “Money Trees.”

lyrics: [Interlude: Sherane]
annotation:
“Sherane” is a fictional name attributed to the album’s recurring love interest. In a 2013 BET interview, Kendrick explained how Sherane represents a real person:

It’s funny because it’s a weird thing when I go back to the neighborhood and the homies know who I’m talking about. It’s a big joke, and I’ve been hearing things, you know. She’s more excited and surprised that I put her in a song than anything.

This is not included on the radio version of the song, it only exists on the album version. Most likely because it helps tie the song back to the larger Sherane narrative of the album.

lyrics:
It's not a place
This country is to me a sound
Of drum and bass
annotation:
In U2’s preeminent “rockumentary” Rattle and Hum and the accompanying Original Motion-Picture Soundtrack, Bono discusses his love of America at length. Interestingly enough, this hugely popular U2 project began production in 1987, the year of Kendrick’s birth, and had two working titles: U2 in the Americas and The Two Americas.

This chorus further acquaints us with the notion that America is not just a piece of land, but an idea or representation of something; In this case, a sonic representation.

In the last beat switch of the song, the instrumental is literally composed of only drums and a bassline.

lyrics: Be the last one out to get this dough? No way!
annotation: The early bird gets the worm, whether you’re in the hood or a high-rise. Fitting with the theme of the song, this bridge (sung by Anna Wise) touches on all the ways NOT to get money–i.e. snoozing, losing, quitting or breaking the code implemented by the likes of Tupac and his contemporaries.

lyrics:
Aw man… where is she takin' me?
Where is she takin' me?
annotation:
This part is the transition from the party style atmosphere of the earlier half of the song to the philosophical commentary on drinking in general. He is possibly torn by two “shes,” one being a woman at the party that Kendrick’s conscious is trying to get him to sober up enough to have a good time with, the other alcohol in general. The question where is she taking me leads to wondering both physically where she is dragging him, but also where his life is going to end up if he continues living his life like this

The deepened voice presented here is to show the drunkedness of Kendrick Lamar, how his blood alcohol content has reached such a peak as to cause his voice to slur, and his senses to be disoriented as well as making him lose control of his actions.

Right before this section, during Sherraaaneee the bridge plays again, in the same slowed-down drunken slur. The “dive in” sounds a lot like “slide in”, insinuating that Sherane has seduced Kendrick. This is also supported by the “Aw man, where is she taking me?” bar.

lyrics: Love one of you bucket-headed hoes? No way!
annotation:
With a bucket on your head, your vision becomes rather limited – and you probably don’t have a good sense of direction.

On the contrary, escaping the hood and achieving bigger dreams was a major priority of Kendrick’s. With his direction in mind, young K Dot avoided interaction with women that had near-sighted ideas of their future, and could distract him from seeing his goals.

‘Bucket-headed’ is also likely an alternative to saying “chickenhead,” which refers to a promiscuous woman. He’s got no love for them. Buckets are hollow, so females with “bucket heads” don’t have much going on in their noggins either.

As Dr. Dre would say,

You can’t make a ho a housewife

lyrics: [Verse 3]
annotation: This verse is not included on the radio version of the song, it only exists on the album version. This is probably because the third verse helps tie the song back to the larger Sherane narrative of the album.

lyrics: Hit the streets, then we break the code? No way!
annotation:
The G-code is a term which refers to the systematic dissuasion of snitching. The phrase, initiated by propaganda in Baltimore, MD, was intended to prevent members of inner-city communities from ratting each other out to the authorities.

Tupac was the poster-boy for the code of T.H.U.G.L.I.F.E. as hip hop was reaching new heights in the 90s. It was coordinated by and implemented with the help of his stepfather, Mutulu Shakur.

Tupac had “THUG LIFE” tatted on his chest… sort of.

lyrics: All I have in life is my new appetite for failure
annotation:
The fear of change forces some people to almost relish failure in a way. To continue living in the present is much more comforting than looking ahead into the future. It also has to do with his environment.

In Compton, the people are put in a environment which sets them up to fail. Living there, he feels the need or appetite for failure. His hunger is growing, pushing him toward failure. This fear has caused him to become addicted to alcohol, which keeps him from being successful at anything other than getting what causes him to fail.

It’s even more poignant because the hunger for failure is a paradoxical statement (failure depletes one of energy instead of providing sustenance) – yet it’s a necessary element all artists have. The thing that alcohol provides (release and catharsis) is also what one seeks in his art. As the writer Samuel Beckett said, “Fail better”

lyrics: [Verse 3: Jay Rock]
annotation: I first heard the record before it dropped, riding in the car with Top Dawg listening to the whole album. I was like, “Okay, I want to hit this shit hard and rock this.” So one day I was just at the studio and Top came in and K Dot was like, “Man, jump on it. Just do a verse.” I wrote two or three versions before I could get writing. I didn’t want to put just anything on there—I’m going against Dot. I wanted to go in for the homie. But I didn’t think he was going to put it on the album, honestly, because he was already done. Kendrick loved the song so he kept it. That was one of my favorites off the album too, that shit is too hard.

lyrics: And I got hunger pain that grow insane
annotation:
Kendrick’s playing off “appetite” from the previous line, but what he means here is that his desire for change is growing out of control. His appetite is causing pain.

He’s saying he’s tired of the same old shit and that he can’t take it anymore (hence the dependence on drugs that’s discussed later in the song)

lyrics:
Tell me, do that sound familiar?
If it do, then you're like me
annotation: He’s connecting the symptoms with an alcoholic’s response in these lines, saying that if you feel the way he’s described feeling, then your treatment is probably like his: alcohol.

lyrics:
Imagine Rock up in them projects
Where them niggas pick your pockets
annotation:
Moving out the projects was hard. That’s home. I still got family there and sometimes it feels good to come back. A lot of people that grew up in certain neighborhoods don’t get to come back. But even though I have good days and bad days in the projects, it taught me how to be strong and be a man. It’s gutter, that is all I can say.

Any real street person will tell you, get money and move out when you are successful. See different things. Then come back and talk to the young cats and show them the way. The projects are always going to be here. But sometimes it’s good to see other people going through the same thing or even worse struggles than you.

lyrics:
Makin' excuse that your relief
Is in the bottom of the bottle and the greenest indo leaf
annotation:
Alcoholics and drug addicts find their “relief” in the consumption of liquor and taking of drugs. Kendrick is calling all these people out saying that their “relief” is nothing but an excuse; that there should never be a reason for dependency.

Further to this, not only is he speaking to addicts but to a generation that use drugs and alcohol to escape their problems rather than face them, forming a self-sustaining cycle of failure causing substance abuse, then the substance abuse causing failure.

“The greenest indo leaf” most likely refers to indica, a powerful form of cannabis.

lyrics:
As the window open I release
Everything that corrode inside of me
annotation:
He throws up, releasing the alcohol and drugs he had taken.

This symbolizes the pain and negativity that has been brewing up inside of him and amplified by the consumption of alcohol.

lyrics: Santa Claus don't miss them stockings
annotation:
Noted in his Decoded video two lines above, Jay Rock states this line means:

they goin in your socks, nahmean"

Which if you don’t know, means when you get mugged/robbed whomever is robbing you is checking every little place you could hide your loot, including your socks. Drug dealers are also known to keep their stash in their socks as well. It should also be noted that Jay Rock and friends are known to be Bloods who would wear the color red a lot, just like Santa Claus.

lyrics:
I see you jokin', why you laugh?
Don't you feel bad? I probably sleep
And never ever wake up, never ever wake up, never ever wake up
annotation:
When Kendrick throws up because of the alcohol in his system, his friends think it’s funny. They don’t think it’s doing him any harm.

He’s also talking about dying of alcohol poisoning and no one either cares or knows how serious all this alcohol can be – everyone is just having a good time.

lyrics: Liquors spillin', pistols poppin'
annotation:
The effect and cause of being in the m.A.A.d city: Liquor spilling is commonly known as a sign of respect for the dead. Dump out your homie’s favorite 40 oz to honor their memory.

Pistols popping will have your dumping your liquor out sooner or later. “Liquor spilling” could also be interpreted in the sense of bottles being dropped during the fray of a drive-by shooting or being run up on. As was the case in Kendrick’s “Ignorance is Bliss” video:

lyrics: In God I trust, but just when I thought I had enough
annotation:
Most religions advise against indulging in shallow physical pleasures, alcohol being one of which. So if you believe in God, then you really shouldn’t be drinking any alcohol in excess, when Kendrick starts feeling dizzy and can’t drink no more cuz he’s gonna overdose, even then he says he believes in God and stops drinking

This line is also a confession of his hypocrisy. He only recalls his faith when he’s “had enough” of these vices.

Also, check the double entendre:

  • Even though he thinks he’s had enough, he’s just going to go into more drinking, which would loop it back to the beginning of the song.

  • This also leads into the skit at the end of the song — he’s had enough, but even more shit’s about to hit the fan.

lyrics:
Bakin' soda YOLA whippin'
Ain't no turkey on Thanksgivin'
annotation:
YOLA whipping refers to using baking soda to cook down cocaine into crack. That’s the only cooking going on in his kitchen – there’s no turkey being made on Thanksgiving like there would be in most, more-fortunate homes.

Jay Rock also has a track called “YOLA.”

lyrics: [Outro]
annotation: This is the big impact moment of the narrative. The plan is to take revenge on the dudes that jumped K.Dot. One of K.Dot’s homies, “Dae Dae,” talks about maybe dropping K.Dot back off at home, but this idea is turned down, and K.Dot stays. The homies see the dudes that jumped K.Dot and a shoot-out begins. During the battle K.Dot’s friend Dave gets shot. The dudes that shot Dave drive off and K.Dot is left holding Dave as he dies in his arms.

lyrics:
My homeboy just dome'd a nigga
I just hope the Lord forgive him
annotation:
Jay Rock hopes God forgives his friend, who shot somebody in the head.

Additionally it is a prayer for the person who was killed and is now facing God’s judgment. Jay believes that his homeboy would not have killed someone if it was not deserved, noting that his homeboy was not forgiving and that perhaps God will be.

lyrics: They stomped the homie out over a bitch?
annotation:
It is revealed that Kendrick was jumped because of Sherane. Recall from “Sherane a.k.a. Master Splinter’s Daughter”:

Two niggas too black hoodies I froze as my phone rang

This is also a reference to Menace II Society:

A stark moment of clarity after the inebriated thoughts which it had just played: Is violence justified over a girl? Of course, this morality is not followed any further, but it represents the fact that morality can exist even in the darkest shadows…

lyrics: Pots with cocaine residue
annotation:
He been cookin' up that hard white (crack cocaine).
Within the song this sounds like “pockets” which implies that he’s had cocaine in his pocket because he’s been dealing normal coke too.

lyrics:
That nigga's straight, man, that nigga ain't trippin'
We gon' do the same ol' shit
I'ma pop a few shots, they gon' run, they gon' run opposite ways
Fall right in ****'s lap
And he gon' tear they ass up, simple as that
annotation: Dave’s brother quickly shoots down the idea to bring Kendrick back home and goes on to explain that the goal is simple. They are just going to fire off a couple of “warning shots” and the opposing group will fall right into the trap and get jumped.

lyrics:
What else is a thug to do
When you eatin' cheese from the government?
annotation:
Paying with government-sponsored food stamps, is eating (with) government money.

He may be alternatively referring to literally eating government cheese which used to be issued to people on welfare. A lot of the times, legit businesses do not give “thugs” a chance at a job, so most of the time they resort to selling drugs in order to make ends meet, since welfare isn’t enough.

References to money growing on trees and government cheese were both used in the opening sequence for Friday:

It could also be a double entendre since “cheese” is slang for money. So it’s like how cheese represents food being issued by the government, or it could also be discussing welfare. The welfare one could also connect to the line about pick-pockets since they are related through the idea of money.

Hence “Cheese” is slang for money, maybe he literally meant that he got money from flipping his cocaine from the United States Government.

lyrics:
And I hope that bitch that set him up out there
We gon' pop that bitch too
annotation:
In “Sherane a.k.a Master Splinter’s Daughter”, Sherane invited Kendrick over to her house to get it on. But instead of sex, he got beat up by two men waiting for him to arrive.

Kendrick’s friends are now seeking revenge. Their plan was to kill some people, but spotting Sherane and beating her up would be considered a bonus.

lyrics:
Gotta provide for my daughter n'em
Get the fuck up out my way, bish
annotation: Jay Rock will do whatever it takes to provide for his family, whether it is dealing drugs or robbing houses. So get out of his way.

lyrics: [Car door opens and gunshots are fired]
annotation:
At this time, Kendrick is riding with the homies to get back at the dudes who set Kendrick up when he went to go see Sherane.

Kendrick’s homies got what they wanted killing the other dudes, but they also got one of the guys Kendrick was riding with, shooting and killing Dave

Which carries into the next song by Kendrick Sing About Me, I’m Dying of Thirst and in the first verse that Kendrick emulates is Dave’s brother, a Piru

lyrics:
Got that drum and I got them bands
Just like a parade, bish
annotation:
Firearms are sometimes equipped with drums that hold more ammo than regular magazines. Bands refers to the rubber bands that wrap around Jay’s huge amounts of cash.

A simile is used here, as parades usually have marching bands participating and those bands have drums (snare, bass, toms).

lyrics:
Dave, you good?
Dave? Dave, say somethin' – Dave?
These bitch-ass niggas killed my brother!
annotation:
Dave’s brother doesn’t hear Dave respond so he runs over to Kendrick holding Dave and begins to shake him. We hear the word “Dave” being partially beeped out, similar to expletives on television. This beeping sound could be a reference to a heart rate monitor and with the last beep we discover Dave is dead.

This signifies a turning point in the album. Initially K.Dot was trying to get it in with Sherane, him and the homies were causing mischief; staging robberies, smoking and drinking excessively. Their actions have led to Dave getting killed.

K.Dot has the realization that his actions can have profound consequences and from this realization he determines that he’s tired of this shit and must change his ways.

This concept is expanded upon in the next song, “Sing About Me, I’m Dying Of Thirst.”

lyrics:
Drop that work up in the bushes
Hope them boys don't see my stash
If they do, tell the truth
This the last time you might see my ass
annotation: If you’ve ever watched the show Cops, then you know what he’s talking about. While Jay is running from the police he tosses his enormous stash of drugs in the bushes. If the police find it, he’ll be getting locked up for a really long time.

lyrics: From the gardens where the grass ain't cut
annotation:
Jay Rock is from the infamous Nickerson Gardens section 8 projects in Watts, California. He plays off the name of his project housing (“gardens”) but unlike most gardens, his was unkempt.

This is also a play on the phrase “my ass is grass.” That term is used when a person gets in trouble. If the feds pick up his cocaine from the bushes, his ass will definitely be in trouble.

lyrics:
Them serpents lurkin', Blood
Bitches sellin' pussy, niggas sellin' drugs
But it's all good
annotation:
In the Nickerson Gardens Projects, which is one of the biggest section 8 housing systems in America, the concentration of people are thugs, prostitutes, and drug dealers. This life was forced on them by our government. By saying “but it’s all good,” Jay portrays the idea that he has grown accustomed to these people being from the same neighborhood.

Serpents represent those who will “snake” on you. If you don’t keep those whom you roll with in check/ keep your circle small (grass cut), there are bound to be snakes lurking. One of the gangs that originated in the Nickerson Gardens was the Bounty Hunter BLOODS.

Them serpents lurking could be a play on words referring to the garden of Eden and the story of Adam and Eve in the book of Genesis; implying that serpents are also in his place temping people.

lyrics:
Broken promises, steal your watch
And tell you what time it is
annotation:
Double meaning here: While literally stealing someone else’s watch will give you the power to tell them what the time is, the actual act of theft is also letting your victim know that this is what’s going down, and they can’t do anything about it. You can also mark the passage of time with these broken promises.

Also, the scenario described here is adding “insult to injury” – Jay Rock fully underlines the unrepentant harshness of the ghetto life.

Nevertheless, Jay Rock still might be talking about the “snakes” – the people you can’t trust, the backstabbers, the ones that break promises; the same people that are helping you are hurting you. He is letting you know the time but is using your watch, just like the snake in the grass, or the snake that lurks in the flowers, its tempting and promising to go out and pick a flower, but once you do (trust those snakes) they will bite you (steal your watch, J’s, break the promise, backstab you)

lyrics: In the streets with a heater under my Dungarees
annotation:
Dungaree is generally the heavy cloth used to make jeans (and so can refer to jeans in general).

However in popular usage the term refers specifically to jean overalls. Dungaree overalls were popularized in the 1990s by a variety of rappers, most notably 2Pac – for instance Biggie referred to dungarees in order to throw a subliminal shot at Pac

Heater of course refers to a gun Jay is keeping on his person, to protect himself from the aforementioned dangers of the hood.

lyrics: Dreams of me gettin' shaded under a money tree
annotation:
Jay Rock juxtaposes the realities of life against his unattainable dreams.

He’s at a crossroads in his life: In order to fulfill his dream of living well under a “money tree”, he must perform unsavory acts as alluded by him carrying around a gun. Does one compromise one’s own ethics and morals in order to achieve one’s dream? This is what Jay Rock contemplates this whole verse.

There’s also a subtle juxtaposition of the heater against the coolness of shade.

Also Jay Rock’s word choice of “shaded” could be interpreted as an allegory for death (i.e. the brightness of life in contrast with the darkness of death). Him carrying a gun also reiterates the same tone of the hook that follows; the gun gives him power to achieve his monetary dreams but it could potentially also be the death of him as a result.

lyrics:
K’s Mom: Kendrick, just bring my car back, man. I called in for another appointment. I figured you weren’t gonna be back here on time anyways. Look, shit, shit, I just wanna get out the house, man. This man is on one, he feelin' good as a motherfucker. Shit, I’m tryna get my thing goin', too. Just bring my car back. Shit, he faded. He feelin' good. Look, listen to him!
K’s Dad: Girl, girl, I want your body, I want your body, 'cause of that big ol’ fat ass. Girl, girl, I want your body, I want your body, 'cause of that big ol’ fat ass
K’s Mom: See, he high as hell. Shit, and he ain’t even trippin' off them damn dominoes anymore. Just bring the car back!
K’s Dad: Did somebody say dominoes?
annotation:
This is a skit where K.Dot’s mother leaves another voice-mail. She wants her car back. In the background, Kendrick’s dad can be heard. Now that he’s in his groove (seemingly drunk/high), he playfully sings about his desire to handle the “assets” of Kendrick’s mom. This helps transition to the soothing and sexual vibe given off on the next track, “Poetic Justice.”

As is to be expected of an album that’s all about the narrative, the story of Kendrick’s parents mirror the overall tone of the album at any given time.

Here, as the album continues its descent into despair, we see the same thing shown by Kendrick’s parents — his father’s already drunk/high, and his mother has gone from wanting the van to go to the County building and get food stamps for the family so they can eat (as shown at the end of “Sherane”) to figuring that Kendrick won’t be back in time so she may as well “get her thing going” (go get drunk too). The priorities of the characters shift with the tone as it gets darker and darker.

The tune Kendrick’s dad sings is also seen in the video for “Backseat Freestyle.”

Note again that Kendrick’s dad wants his dominoes. Dominoes is slang for Amphetamines. Kendrick’s mom wants him to come back so he can help her deal with her drug-addicted husband.

lyrics:
I love bad bitches, that's my fuckin' problem
And yeah, I like to fuck, I got a fuckin' problem
I love bad bitches, that's my fuckin' problem
And yeah, I like to fuck, I got a fuckin' problem
I love bad bitches, that's my fuckin' problem
And yeah, I like to fuck, I got a fuckin' problem
annotation:
The hook is centered around a pun—Chainz both has a “fuckin' problem,” and a problem with fucking—i.e. he enjoys it so much that it has become a problem.

Drake detailed the hook’s genesis:

“Fuckin’ Problems” came from a song me and 2 Chainz had done. He said in his verse—it was really slow too—“I love bad bitches too that’s a fuckin’ problem.” I stopped his verse while we were listening to it, and I said, “Yo, that needs to be a hook. I don’t know how we’re going to explain this to him that we chopped a piece of his verse to do the hook.”

This hook is possibly inspired by a similar Kanye pun from Big Sean’s “Marvin & Chardonnay.”

lyrics: If findin' somebody real is your fuckin' problem
annotation:
Attention bad bitches: these are the real dudes you’ve been looking for. Fucking them will solve all your problems.

On the album version of the song, Drake performs both of these lines. However, in the video version of the song, Drake performs the first line, and Rocky performs the second.

lyrics: [Verse 1: A$AP Rocky]
annotation:
It’s almost comical how profane this verse is. The censored version makes the verse sound very different, to the point where it’s pretty funny listening to it. Censored words:

  • “bitches”
  • “bitch”
  • “pop”
  • “semi”
  • “nine”
  • “raw”
  • “motherfucker”
  • “motherfuckers”
  • “chrome”
  • “nigga”
  • “nigga”
  • “nigga”
  • “fuckin”
  • “bitches”
  • “rolling”
  • “swishers”
  • “bitches”
  • “niggas”
  • “lick it”
  • “nigga”
  • “niggerish”
  • “nigga”
  • “nigga”
  • “fucking”
  • “fucking”
  • “dyke”
  • “bitch”
  • and last but not least, “fucking.”

About 20% of the verse is changed (such as making “bitches” into “chickens”) or censored.

lyrics: Make that thing pop like a semi or a 9
annotation:
Semi and nine refer to guns (a “semi-automatic” and a gun that uses 9mm caliber bullets). Like the “popping” that comes from a gun when it’s shot, A$AP wants this girl to pop it for pimp.

The choice between “a semi or a nine” is a confusing one, because 9mm guns don’t come in revolver style—they are exclusively semi-automatic.

Since a “nine” is a “semi” by definition, saying “make it pop like a semi or a nine” makes as much sense as saying “driving a BMW or a car.”

lyrics:
I got, I got, I got, I got—
Loyalty, got royalty inside my DNA
annotation:
Kendrick’s mom taught him the value of loyalty, as described on 2010’s “Cut You Off (To Grow Closer)”:

Yeah, my momma as loyal as any sister would come

In a 2015 interview with The Breakfast Club, he spoke about loyalty for his friends and significant other, Whitney Alford:
