I’m loyal to the soil. At the end of the day, you want to always have real people around you. Period. Whether it’s male or female. Everybody that’s been around me, they’ve been around since day one.

The “royalty” in Kendrick’s DNA represents his pride as a black man and respect for his heritage. On “i,” from 2015’s To Pimp a Butterfly, Kendrick addresses his black royalty:

Well, this is my explanation straight from Ethiopia
N-E-G-U-S definition: royalty; king royalty—wait, listen
N-E-G-U-S description: Black emperor, king, ruler, now let me finish
The history books overlook the word and hide it

In track six on DAMN’s tracklist, Kendrick dives deeper into the concept of loyalty with assistance from Rihanna.

lyrics: Ooh, baby like it raw with the shimmy shimmy ya, huh?
annotation:
“Shimmy Shimmy Ya” is a song by Ol' Dirty Bastard off his debut album, Return to the 36 Chambers: The Dirty Version. In the song’s hook, ODB famously croons “ooh baby I like it raw”, and here Rocky flips the line to illustrate his girl’s love of raw—or unprotected—sex.

A$AP has similar lines in his songs “Bass” and “Long.Live.A$AP”, and expressed his strong admiration for ODB in a Genius verified annotation.

lyrics: Cocaine quarter piece, got war and peace inside my DNA
annotation:
Kendrick has addressed his family’s history of selling cocaine several times. On 2010’s “Night Of The Living Junkies,” he talked about how his uncles sold drugs in front of his house, and on Pusha-T’s 2013 song “Nosetalgia,” he rapped about his father’s days of dealing dope:

My daddy turned a quarter piece to a four and a half
Took a L, started selling soap fiends bubble bath

Kendrick’s seen both war and peace throughout his life. While he has voiced his dislike for gang violence and has hopes of bringing unity and peace to the streets of Compton, he’s detailed darker times throughout his music, including the dichotomy of themes on his second album, good kid, m.A.A.d city. This is represented both in the title itself and in such songs as “m.A.A.d city”:

If I told you I killed a nigga at 16, would you believe me?
Perceive me to be innocent Kendrick you seen in the street

lyrics: A$AP (Yeah,) get like me (Uh)
annotation:
Double entendre: at first glance, of course it’s a reference to his name, A$AP Rocky, but he’s also saying “get like me As Soon As Possible”

“Get Like Me” was also a hit song by Mississippi-born rapper, producer, and entrepreneur David Banner.

lyrics:
I got power, poison, pain and joy inside my DNA
I got hustle though, ambition flow inside my DNA
annotation:
Kendrick’s personality traits align with those of the people around him. While commenting on “The Blacker The Berry” during a 2015 MTV interview, Kendrick said:

A few people think it’s just talk and it’s just rap; no, these are my experiences. When I say, ‘Gang banging made me kill a nigga blacker than me,’ this is my life that I’m talking about. I’m not saying you, you might not even be from the streets. I’m not speaking to the community, I’m not speaking of the community, I am the community.

He reiterated a similar point during an interview later that year with The Guardian, saying:

These are issues that if you come from that environment it’s inevitable to speak on. It’s already in your blood because I am Trayvon Martin, you know. I’m all of these kids.

lyrics:
Never met a motherfucker fresh like me (Yeah)
All these motherfuckers wanna dress like me (Uh)
annotation:
ASAP’s style and swag was very unique but now everyone is trying to copy it. This makes sense since he’s one of Complex’s 50 most stylish rappers of all time.

He may also be speaking about SpaceGhostPurrp who he has beef with and included in this beef, they both claim that the other stole their style.

Coincidentally, Kendrick dresses similarly to Rocky in the song’s music video:

lyrics:
I was born like this, since one like this, immaculate conception
I transform like this, perform like this, was Yeshua new weapon
annotation:
Kendrick compares his birth to the Immaculate Conception of the Virgin Mary. Catholics believe that the Virgin Mary was free from sin since she had to give birth to Christ.

Yeshua (יֵשׁוּעַ) is Hebrew for Jesus. Kendrick discussed the return of Yeshua in his guest feature on DJ Khaled’s “Holy Key”:

I don’t wear crosses no more, Yeshua’s coming back

By depicting himself as a son of God and a tool for His will, Kenny’s suggesting that he’s a savior—for both rap and his community. In a March 2017 interview with Rolling Stone, K-Dot talked about using God to solve real world problems:

To Pimp a Butterfly was addressing the problem. I’m in a space now where I’m not addressing the problem anymore. We’re in a time where we exclude one major component out of this whole thing called life: God. Nobody speaks on it because it’s almost in conflict with what’s going on in the world when you talk about politics and government and the system.

He also aligned himself with Jesus in the video for “HUMBLE.,” as he sat in the middle seat during a live enactment of the Last Supper portrait.

lyrics: But the chrome to your dome make you sweat like Keith
[Produced by Scoop DeVille & Sounwave]
annotation:
According to the liner notes, the track was produced by Scoop DeVille with additional production by Sounwave. Scoop also produced the bonus track “The Recipe.”

Below is a video of Scoop DeVille breaking down his part of the production:

The beat is sampled from Janet Jackson’s “Any Time, Any Place,” and Scoop DeVille said in an interview with Complex magazine that the sample was “a special piece that I was saving for the right artist.” The sample can be heard below:

Fun Fact: Janet Jackson starred in the 1993 movie, Poetic Justice, alongside Tupac Shakur, a role model of Kendrick’s.

lyrics:
I don't contemplate, I meditate, then off your fucking head
This that put-the-kids-to-bed
annotation:
Kendrick has referenced the practice of meditation on multiple occasions in his music, like on “untitled 03,” “Black Friday,” and later on this project in “LOYALTY.”

In a 2016 GQ interview with Rick Rubin, he said that he often meditates in order to get himself in the right place, particularly to gain perspective on subjects for his songs:

I have to have at least 30 minutes to myself. If it’s not on the daily, every other day, to just sit back, close my eyes, and absorb what’s going on. You know, the space that I’m in.

Kendrick contrasts the serene and blissful art of meditation with talk of lyrical murder; he remains cool-headed even when delivering brutal lyrics.

lyrics: [Intro: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation: I mean, that record considers itself as a radio record, or whatever you make it out to be, a hit record or whatever. But for the most part, that song was still in the concept of the first track on the album, which was Sherane. So it had its time right there but for the most part it covered everything as far as the concept of dealing with a promiscuous woman.

lyrics:
This that I got, I got, I got, I got—
Realness, I just kill shit ’cause it's in my DNA
annotation:
These bars may suggest two interpretations. Kendrick’s DNA enables him to kill beats and his competition through his “realness”. This figurative killing is stated in his “Control” verse to his hip-hop contemporaries:

I got love for you all, but I’m tryna murder you niggas

Alternatively, and possibly more fitting for the verse at hand, the wickedness of his DNA draws him to violence and murder.

In a voicemail skit on “Real” from 2012’s good kid, m.A.A.d city, Kendrick’s dad tells him:

Any nigga can kill a man, that don’t make you a real nigga. Real is responsibility. Real is taking care of your motherfucking family. Real is God, nigga.

lyrics:
‘Cause I'm the nigga, the nigga nigga, like how you figure? (Yeah)
Gettin' figures and fuckin' bitches
annotation:
“The nigga…the nigga nigga” is a iconic phrase in New Orleans rap that originated in the bounce music scene, as heard in TT Tucker’s “Where Dey At”. It later appeared in songs by Cash Money Records, including Mannie Fresh’s verse on the hit “Back That Ass Up”:

He’s the “nigga"—similar to saying he’s "the man"—because he gets money and women (both represented by the word "figure”).

lyrics:
Every second, every minute
Man, I swear that she can get it
annotation:
The screwed-up voice is saying his girl can get it any time, and is likely young Kendrick’s thoughts about how badly he wants Sherane.

There is a Janet Jackson sample, and during the intro it includes “Any time, any place”

lyrics: I got millions, I got riches buildin' in my DNA
annotation:
Despite growing up in the impoverished inner-city of Compton, Kendrick has overcome his socioeconomic struggles to become wealthy. As of 2017, Kendrick’s career earnings are close to $35 million dollars.

Kendrick’s career has opened doors for prosperity, which he’ll be able to pass down to his future generations, akin to the teachings in Proverbs 13:22:

A good man leaveth an inheritance to his children’s children

lyrics: she rollin' Swishers
annotation: A Swisher is a flavoured cigarette, however, they are notorious for the terrible quality of their tobacco and are commonly broken up down the middle, and refilled with marijuana, and then rolled back up.

lyrics:
Say if you a bad bitch, put your hands up high
Hands up high, hands up high
Tell 'em dim the lights down right now
Put me in the mood
I'm talkin' about dark room, perfume, go, go
annotation:
These lines show Kendrick’s appreciation for attractive females and how he wants to be in his “mood” by drenching them in perfume and placing them in a darkroom. A darkroom is a room with zero normal light present and is commonly used as a popular photographic technique. The intro to “Poetic Justice” may also serve as a representation of his teenage desires as shown on “The Art of Peer Pressure”.

Basketball shorts with the Gonzales Park odor
We on the mission for bad bitches and trouble

This may also depict his lust for Sherane as expressed throughout the majority of good kid, m.A.A.d city. Ultimately, one of the major thoughts that circle around K.Dot’s brain as a teenager is having intercourse with her as prominently expressed on the opening track of the album, mainly since he considers her to be a “hoodrat”.

lyrics:
I got dark, I got evil, that rot inside my DNA
I got off, I got troublesome heart inside my DNA
annotation:
Kendrick’s early releases included morally conscious material. He prefers not to sugarcoat the reality of his imperfections. On the outro to his 2010 track, “Cut You Off (To Grow Closer),” he says:

See it’s known today that the human race is nothing. No morals, no standards

In a 2016 interview with Rick Rubin, he talks about why he includes both good and evil themes in his music:

I was raised in an environment where my father was a complete realist from the streets and my mom was a dreamer […] that was implanted in me first; that’s just DNA of who I am […] it’s always the yin and the yang—the good versus the evil

“I got off” is likely in reference to committing crimes and not being arrested. He’s grateful for not ending up dead or in jail, but he has a troubled heart, which comes from feelings of guilt.

There’s also a double entendre here. “Rot inside” can be also heard as “rotten side”.

lyrics: She love my licorice, I let her lick it (Alright)
annotation:
Licorice is a metaphor for ASAP’s dick.

Also possibly a reference to the previous line about liquor, because several liquors—including Ouzo, Sambucca, Pernod, Arak, and Jägermeister—are known for tasting like black licorice.

Danny Brown had a similar line on his 2010 song “White Stripes”:

Hoes say I’m inconsiderate
Cause I make ‘em treat my dick like licorice
But they can’t get a pack of Twizzlers on me

lyrics: [Produced by Sounwave]
annotation:
This song’s producer, Sounwave, speaks on how the record and beat came to be:

Me and Kendrick found this crazy record from this foreign group and we didn’t know where to go with it. So we looped that, I took it to my spot, and did the drums. I added everything I needed, the extra guitars, strings, all that. That inspired Kendrick to bring it to another level. Kendrick is hands-on with [beats]. He will find something he likes and call me right up: ‘Yo let’s go check this out!’

The only sample used in the song is from the Boom Clap Bachelors' “Tiden Flyver.” The sample is at the beginning of the track in the sample and in Kendrick song:

Fun Fact: Producer Robin Hannibal left Boom Clap Bachelors and formed the duo Quadron, with singer Coco O. Kendrick guests on the song “Better Off,” from Quadron’s album Avalanche.

lyrics: [Verse 1: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation:
In this verse Kendrick talks about him going to see the infamous Sherane, talks about their relationship so far.

He also tells her “If I told you that a flower bloomed in a dark room, would you trust it?”
Where he tells her that even though they are in a Maad City there’s always going to be a good kid and the good kid is Kendrick.

It should also be said that Kendrick’s one biggest idol and role model is 2Pac,

He not only influences his music, but his day-to-day lifestyle, having dedicated many concerts or parts of concerts to him.

Not only does this song sample Janet Jackson, but Janet also starred with Tupac as the two main leads on the film Poetic Justice,

Coincidence?

lyrics: I just win again, then win again like Wimbledon, I serve
annotation:
Wimbledon, also known as “The Championships,” is a renowned London-based tennis Grand Slam tournament, founded in 1877. The serve is a shot in tennis that is used to start a point. To further reinforce this line, the sound of a tennis ball plays in the beat.

Kendrick’s fellow Compton natives, Serena and Venus Williams, have 11 Wimbledon singles trophies between them and have won Wimbledon doubles six times together. Kendrick “serves” up great albums, but instead of winning trophies, he picked up seven Grammys in two years.

It’s possible that Kendrick is referencing these bars by Jay Z on “The Return Remix”:

So when we does what we do, we win
And win again, like deja vu
Then we win again, like MJ do…

lyrics:
They say money make a nigga act niggerish (Uh)
But least a nigga nigga rich
annotation:
“Nigga Rich” is a derogatory term; it usually connotes the idea of the nouveau-riche but in relation to the successful African-Americans of the entertainment and sports industries (i.e. Basketball players & rappers).

This line emphasizes how Rocky isn’t bothered by haters looking down on him as tastelessly rich, because he enjoys the benefit of bountiful, liquid wealth. He may not have generational wealth, but at least he has the dough to blow on expensive things for the time being.

It’s worth noting that the unusual radio edit version of this line:

They say money make money act licorice
At least Hilfiger rich

lyrics: [Chorus]
annotation:
When Kendrick ended the last line with with all disrespect let me say this, what he meant by this is bitch don’t kill my vibe – a warning to artists that aren’t on his level to not get in his way or impede what he’s trying to do with his music.

In the version with Lady Gaga, this second hook is slightly different from the first: Gaga says “human” instead of “sinner” and “fall again” instead of “sin again”, which are references to the Christian doctrines of “The Fall of Man,” Adam and Eve’s expulsion from Eden, and “Original sin,” humanity’s sinful state resulting from Adam and Eve’s disobedience of God.

lyrics:
I recognize your fragrance
Hold up, you ain't never gotta say shit
annotation:
When Kendrick’s girl comes up to him from behind, she doesn’t have to talk. He knows it’s her just from her aroma.

Notice the use of one of his notable phrases “Hol' up,” in a different context.

He also has the ability to pick out high class women based on simple surface observations such as her scent, touching on the studied fact that smell is our most evocative sense.

lyrics:
Yeah, that’s him again, the sound that engine in is like a bird
You see fireworks and Corvette tire skrrt the boulevard
annotation:
The “bird sound” a car makes is the whistling created by turbo engines. “Fireworks” are the flames emitted from having customized shortened exhaust pipes, and “Tire skrrt the boulevard,” may be a reference to a popular pastime in Los Angeles—doing donuts on Crenshaw Boulevard.

On his 2012 track, “Sherane a.k.a Master Splinter’s Daughter,” while driving his mother’s van, he almost crashed into a Corvette:

Sent a picture of her titties blowing up my texts
I looked at ‘em and almost ran my front bumper into Corvette

On “untitled 08 | 09.06.2014.,” Kendrick spoke of making it big and getting his dream ride, but on Big Sean’s 2013 track “Control,” Kendrick made it clear that he graduated to his own Corvette:

White T’s and Nike Cortez this red Corvette’s anonymous

lyrics: I be fuckin' broads like I be fuckin' bored
annotation:
Like the hook, this line plays with different meanings of the word “fucking"—in this case, as a verb and an intensifier. Also, if Rocky’s becoming apathetic about fucking, maybe he’s just fucking the wrong women?

He told NME:

I’m a weirdo: I don’t want a virgin. I don’t. That’s boring. You’re gonna cheat on that girl, man. What about a girl that’s open-minded?

lyrics:
I am a sinner who's probably gonna sin again
Lord, forgive me! Lord, forgive me!
Things I don't understand
Sometimes I need to be alone
Bitch, don't kill my vibe!
Bitch, don't kill my vibe!
annotation:
A major theme in Kendrick’s music is his faith, and how he reconciles it with the sinful activities that he has indulged in.

Kendrick humbly acknowledges that he is a human who makes mistakes. Saying “sometimes I need to be alone” is his need to avoid peer pressure and gather his thoughts to find himself. His resentment of peer pressure was further shown in “Swimming Pools (Drank).”

If the target of this song is the industry and/or his competition, he may be accusing those elements of holding him back. He wants to be in a category by himself – and the pressures around him are not helping.

lyrics:
Uh, and I know your taste is
A little bit, hmm, high maintenance
annotation:
She likes the finer things in life, that tend to cost money.

He is engaging the listener with words that reference the senses, “recognize” = sight, “fragrance” = smell, “say” = sound, “taste” = self explanatory.

lyrics:
I know how you work, I know just who you are
See, you's a, you's a, you's a—
Bitch, your hormones prolly switch inside your DNA
Problem is, all that sucker shit inside your DNA
Daddy prolly snitched, heritage inside your DNA
annotation:
On a biological level, hormones dictate sexual differentiation—if you have more testosterone you develop as a male, while more estrogen promotes female development. Kendrick insults his competition by saying they have more feminine traits.

It’s possible these bars are directed at Big Sean, who Kendrick fired shots at on “The Heart Part 4.” On “Bounce Back,” Sean raps:

My daddy a G, it’s genetics (Straight up)

lyrics: Turn a dyke bitch out, have her fuckin' boys; beast
annotation:
He’s a beast* because he’s irresistible to all women—even to lesbians. This is an old hip-hop meme invoked by various artists, including The Notorious B.I.G. on “The What”.

If Rocky can really do what he claims, he should go to Hong Kong and catch a quick £40 million check:

*It’s worth noting that every verse in this song ends with the word “beast.”

lyrics: I can feel your energy from two planets away
annotation:
These lines may infer a romantic relationship with a woman who won’t give Kendrick his space. This is also a possible reference to the old adage that “men are from Mars and women are from Venus”—a notion that was popularized in a 1992 book by John Gray. Mars is two planets away from Venus:

This analogy may also make reference to the Sun. The Earth is the third planet from the sun, making it two planets away from our planetary system’s central energy force. In the music video, the sun is a prevalent feature for much of the outdoor segments.

lyrics: You live life on an everyday basis
annotation:
Alludes to the fact that this girl lives her life as if everyday counts.

“Live not one’s life as though one had a thousand years, but live each day as the last.” – Marcus Aurelius

Essentially a YOLO reference.

Or even more appropriate to the Roman Emperor’s words and Kendrick Lamar is the Latin maxim, “carpe diem” which means “seize the day.” While YOLO can be used to vaguely justify acts, no matter what the consequence; in essence “seizing the day” can be an encouragement to live life the best way you can. Lamar’s original statement, when looked at this way, can be more connected to the next verse poetic justice, which is a just end to your actions good or bad.

lyrics: Backbone don't exist, born outside a jellyfish, I gauge
annotation:
Being “spineless” means being cowardly and “soft,” while “onside” means on the same team. Jellyfish don’t have backbones.

In addition, part of the structure of the DNA is called the “backbone.”

lyrics: Ooh, I know you love it when this beat is on
annotation:
Excuse Drake if he’s particularly proud of this beat—he co-produced it (using his alias C. Papi) with his partner 40.

Drake has dabbled in co-production throughout his career, including his songs “Cameras,” “The Real Her,” “Practice,” and “Back To Back.”

lyrics: [Produced by Sounwave; Additional production by Terrace Martin]
annotation:
According to Sounwave, the original beat for King Kunta “was like the jazziest record in the world”. Kendrick wanted a nastier version however, so Sounwave simplified it by taking out the 10 guitars he had initially laid on the track.

The beat that was left was essentially a remake of “Get Nekkid” by Mausberg, which was produced by DJ Quik. Mausberg was one of Kendrick’s favorite rappers growing up, so this beat was created with the idea of paying homage to “a guy that didn’t reach his full potential”.

Bass: Thundercat
Additional Guitar: Marlon Williams & Matt Schaeffer
Background Vocals: Whitney Alford

The liner notes credit three samples:

  • “We Want the Funk” by Ahmad Lewis

  • Elements of James Brown’s “The Payback”

  • Re-sung lyrics from Michael Jackson’s “Smooth Criminal”

lyrics:
I got my drink, I got my music
I would share it, but today I'm yelling
annotation:
Sometimes Kendrick just needs to be left alone. At present, he doesn’t feel the need to share, because he is happy with his drink and his music.

His drink (alcohol), and some forms of music that could contribute to “sin,” or could be a sin in itself. Kendrick may or may not understand this, but in any event, he doesn’t want anyone to ruin his good mood.

lyrics: With poetic justice, poetic justice
annotation:
Interestingly enough, poetic justice is an actual literary notion, in which virtue is ultimately rewarded (or vice punished) often by an ironic twist of fate intimately related to the character’s own conduct.

For example, Wile E. Coyote always sets traps for Road Runner, but ends up in them.

Essentially, it means to live life in adherence to karma, in a sense—that whatever happens to you is earned through the deeds you perform, whether positive or negative.

Another entendre:

There’s a movie called Poetic Justice, starring 2Pac and Janet Jackson (which is significant because Janet is sampled in the track and Kendrick feels he is carrying Pac’s legacy).

Another interesting fact: Maya Angelou acted in Poetic Justice for an important scene. Between scenes, she encountered a young 2Pac in an altercation with another man on set. She would have a profound influence on him, as she broke up the fight and took him away to speak with him privately—much as she does for Kendrick and his friends in “Sing About Me, I’m Dying of Thirst.”

lyrics: See, my pedigree most definitely don't tolerate the front
annotation:
“Pedigree” is the recorded ancestry or lineage of a person or family, playing off the song title, “DNA.” Pedigree diagrams show who has certain genetic traits.

Kendrick’s family has been through tough times—from his dad being a gang member and selling drugs, to Kendrick stealing from his own job. Kenny doesn’t appreciate anyone who’s dishonest about their past.

lyrics:
Make you think about all of the niggas you been leadin' on
Make me think about all of the rappers I've been feedin' on
Got a feelin' that's the same dudes that we speakin' on, oh word?
annotation:
Drake is claiming that the same dudes this girl has been leading on are the same rappers Drake has been feeding off of. He is out of their league in the rap game and she is too damn sexy for them so she rolls with Drake.

Of course, this could be another Chris Brown reference, since the line is allegedly directed at Rihanna who (at the time of the song’s release) had an on-again/off-again relationship with/had been accused of leading on Chris Brown, with whom Drake is beefing.

This can also be seen as a Common reference. Earlier in 2012, these two rappers began beefing after Drake fired shots on the Ricky Rozay banger Stay Schemin', which Common responded to by releasing a remix of the same song, after Common was accused of referring to Drake on the song “Sweet,” which he later confirmed was true.

lyrics: [Intro: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation:
The opening high-hat double-hit and the backbeat are strikingly similar to a breakdown in Curtis Mayfield’s “Kung Fu.” The double-hit appears at the end of the original line. Many believe that this is an uncredited sample.

Although similar, this is not the same beat that drives “Get Nekkid” by Mausberg.

lyrics:
Bitch, don't kill my vibe! Bitch, don't kill my vibe!
Bitch, don't kill my vibe! Bitch, don't kill my vibe!
annotation:
Kendrick is trying to chill – he doesn’t mind if you are around, just don’t fuck up his mood.

But to further this conjecture, this song hook is a complex revelation of Kendrick’s true psychology and the chorus is actually a declaration of his attitude towards the world.

Kendrick is a diverse person, and there are many layers to his personality. He is spiritual, accepting and thoughtful, but he also comes from a city of violence, drugs, crime, etc. Kendrick is an incredibly empathic person; he sees things from all points of view and thus does not fall into any specific classification but rather covers the entire spectrum of humanity. Because of his debilitating empathy, there is a slight distance between himself and his peers. He lives in his own kind of world, observing the behavior and the nature of everything and everyone around him and contemplating it to himself. He is sincere and stable and his ultimate quest is to spread peace.

However, a common tendency for people of this personality-type is to shy away from complex, inexplicable situations where no fair and amicable solution is apparent. When such scenarios occur they may try to retreat into their metaphysical bubble and escape the paradoxical anxieties of life. This is exactly what Kendrick demonstrates in this song (either consciously or subconsciously), and the phrase “Bitch Don’t Kill My Vibe” is a solemn declaration of his desire to attain peace when things cannot be resolved easily.

lyrics:
If I told you that a flower bloomed in a dark room
Would you trust it?
annotation: Am I the flower? No, I am thinking she is the flower the whole time because I have no idea about her background, just being oblivious to it. Being young and not knowing. She may look good on the outside, but this flower may be full of bees and no honey. You feel me?

lyrics: Shit I've been through prolly offend you,
annotation:
Kendrick talked about this line with Rolling Stone saying:

I can’t tell you the shit that I’ve been through without telling you the shit that I’ve been through. I’m gonna say, “I know murder, conviction, burners, boosters, burglars, dead, redemption, scholars, fathers dead.” I’m-a give you a breakdown of my life from the time I was born all the way till I was 21.

Kendrick often talks about his upbringing in Compton, something that might not sit well with people who don’t understand the struggle of growing up there.

On songs like 2012’s “Compton,” Kendrick detailed his life in the city plagued with gang violence:

So come and visit the tire screeching, ambulance, policeman
Won’t you spend a weekend on Rosecrans nigga
Khaki creasing, crime increasing on Rosecrans nigga

To hold his own on the Compton streets, he had to toughen up like a soldier. He used the same “belly of the beast” analogy on “King Kunta” and “untitled 02 | 06.23.2014.” to show the difficulties with the city of Compton.

lyrics:
Ain't heard my album? Who you sleepin' on?
You should print the lyrics out and have a fuckin' read-along
annotation:
Drake released the hit album Take Care on November 15, 2011, giving rap fans approximately 11 months to peep it before “Fuckin' Problems” was released in October 2012. Funny enough, Drake’s mentor Lil Wayne was one of the few people who admitted that he hadn’t listened to Thank Me Later until months after it came out.

We hear Genius is a pretty good place to go if you want to print out Drake lyrics…

lyrics:
I got a bone to pick
I don't want you monkey-mouth motherfuckers
Sittin' in my throne again
Ayy, ayy, nigga, what's happenin'?
K-Dot back in the hood, nigga!
I'm mad (He mad!), but I ain't stressin'
True friends, one question
annotation:
Since the release of good kid, m.A.A.d. city in 2012, Kendrick’s made his claim for hip-hop’s crown on a slew of guest spots – most notably during his verse on Big Sean’s “Control” and TDE’s 2013 BET Cypher. With the release of his new record, Kendrick wants to make sure the likes of Kanye West, JAY-Z and Drake aren’t claiming hip-hop’s top honor.

“I’m mad” is a reference to James Brown’s “The Payback,” which is also referenced later on in the song.

The line “I got a bone to pick” is a common phrase which means to have a disscussion. This could also have a double meaning of saying that he has something in his teeth. He may mean that these other rappers are little more than a nuisance, or something stuck in his teeth that he is picking at.

lyrics:
Look inside of my soul and you can find gold and maybe get rich
Look inside of your soul and you can find out it never exist
annotation:
This line is reminiscent of Plato’s Myth of Metals. Kendrick calls his soul golden, segregating himself above others. Continuing the analogy between human qualities and gold, he promises growth to people who are willing to journey into his soul, or listen to his music.

He touches on a similar subject in his featured verse on 2015’s “Classic Man (remix)” by Jidenna:

I ain’t got no jewelry on me, bitch, I got the jewelry in me…

lyrics: this is Paula's oldest son
annotation:
This isn’t the first time Kendrick has referred to himself as the oldest son of his mother, Paula Oliver. He made a similar reference in “Trip” from The Kendrick Lamar EP:

Courtesy of Paula’s oldest son, pay homage

He also discussed the burden of rapping for his siblings as the eldest of his family on “Wanna Be Heard” from his 2009 EP:

I don’t represent no colors, I represent my lil' sisters and brothers,
I’m the oldest, nigga

lyrics: Ain't a fuckin' sing-along 'less you brought the weed along
annotation:
A possible reference to Drake’s song “Crew Love”, which featured this line from The Weeknd:

This ain’t no fucking sing-along
So, girl, what you singing for?

#CAUSE SHE LOVIN' THE CREEEEEEEEEEWWWWWWWWWWWW

lyrics:
Bitch, where you when I was walkin'?
Now I run the game, got the whole world talkin'
King Kunta, everybody wanna cut the legs off him
Kunta, black man taking no losses, oh yeah
Bitch, where you when I was walkin'?
Now I run the game, got the whole world talkin'
King Kunta, everybody wanna cut the legs off him
annotation:
Kunta Kinte was a fictional 18th-century black slave featured in Alex Haley’s best-selling novel Roots: The Saga of an American Family. According to the novel, Kunta had his foot cut off to prevent him from escaping his plantation.

“King Kunta” is an oxymoron—Kendrick is simultaneously oppressed like a slave and dominant like a king.

Although Kendrick’s well off (running) like a king, it wasn’t too long ago that he was poor (walking) like the rest of us. Those who weren’t interested in Kendrick before his success now want to know him, but he isn’t fooled by their duplicity—they just want to cut his legs off to keep him from running away with the game.

lyrics:
I can feel the changes
I can feel a new life, I always knew life can be dangerous
annotation: Yeah, we talk about a group of people and it is really focusing on people that want to hold you back and not see you better yourself and want to see you in this predicament where you are going to be just another statistic. I can feel the changes, I can feel a new life – They don’t really understand the drive and the ambition behind it, they just see it for the life. I see it a whole other way. I see it because of my family history. I see it because of what people feel I should be in life, just another statistic, like I said. And much more, just challenging myself. I see it as a challenge rather than just seeing it on TV and wondering why this dude has got girls and cars and all that, it is more of a mental thing for me.

lyrics: I mean, I write poems in these songs dedicated to you when
annotation:
The song itself seems to be an ode to Sherane asking for her trust and love.

But given Kendrick is now on a larger stage, “you” may very well refer to his audience. After all, Kendrick’s mom later encourages him to “tell [his] story for the little black and brown kids of Compton”.

lyrics:
my expertise checked out in second grade
When I was 9, on cell, motel, we didn't have nowhere to stay
At 29, I’ve done so well, hit cartwheel in my estate
annotation:
Kendrick was 29 years old when he released DAMN.. At age 9, just after graduating from second grade, Kendrick was living in motels, near Section 8 housing. Back on the bonus song ‘'County Building Blues’' of his 2012 album Good Kid M.a.a.d City he told us about these struggles:

I’ve been waiting on this day since Dr. Dre and Pac
Was on Rosecrans in that burgerstand at ‘95
People staring at 'em in amazement
Reservations at the Days Inn
We was living out a hotel at the time

But 20 years later, he’s ecstatic that his success has allowed him to own property. In 2014, he bought a house is Eastvale, California worth $500,000—a modest price for a wealthy rapper.

Kendrick spoke of his success at the age of 29 on his feature for Isaiah Rashad’s “Wat’s Wrong”:

I told Zay, I’m the best rapper since twenty five
Been like that for a while now, I’m twenty-nine
Any nigga that disagree is a fuckin' liar

lyrics:
Then ju… okay, I got it
Then just drop down and get your eagle on
annotation:
This is a reference to Nelly’s song “Flap your Wings.” “Getting yo eagle on” is a dance move, as seen in the video. Maybe instead of the dance, he wants her to get spread eagle for him.

Drizzy holding out the “just” may insinuate that he began a sing-along, so someone must have brought the weed along.

lyrics: When you got the yams—(What's the yams?)
annotation:
This line includes an allusion to Ralph Ellison’s Invisible Man; the unnamed narrator is walking down the streets of New York City when he smells yams, triggering memories of his hometown in the South. The yam is used as a symbol of authenticity; the protagonist famously declares, “I yam what I am.” Here Kendrick is declaring his own authenticity, unlike the rappers he disses in the rest of the verse.

Yams are a key ingredient in African cuisine and have significance in some parts of Africa as a sign of social status. In his novel Things Fall Apart, Chinua Achebe begins by documenting how a man’s worth in Igbo society was largely determined by his yearly yam yield. When Kendrick says he “got the yams,” he means he has attained money, power and prestige.

Big butts on healthy ladies and balloons filled with drugs (particularly heroin) are also colloquially known as “yams.”

lyrics: You're in the mood for empathy, there's blood in my pen
annotation: I don’t want it to be so one-sided. I want you to feel my perspective but at the same time know where she is coming from. She may come from a broken home where she wasn’t taught actual home training and dealing with men. I mean, not to actually say that in a blunt manner, but when I do a record like Poetic Justice, you see that she does have something about her that is attractive, and I really just want to show both sides of the fence. I never wanted to really completely slander her all the way down, so that is a good point. I am glad you caught that, and it is real tricky and that is something that I thought about writing that record, knowing the history that me and her had.

lyrics: And I'm gon' shine like I'm supposed to, antisocial extrovert
annotation:
An “extrovert” is someone who is outgoing and sociable, while an antisocial person prefers not to associate with other people. Kendrick’s juxtaposition of “antisocial” and “extrovert” makes him ambivert, which is a balanced mixture of the two personality traits. Similarly, on 2016’s “untitled 06 | 06.30.2014,” he referred to himself as “evenly odd.”

Kendrick has admitted that he was quiet and shy in school, but rapping requires a more social personality. He still struggles with the contradicting requirements of his job. In a 2015 interview with Billboard, he said:

I’ve been called a recluse. There’s definitely truth in that. I like to spend time alone.

In a 2015 Rolling Stone interview, his mother confirmed he was a lonely child until the age of seven.

lyrics: Or we can stare up at the stars and put the Beatles on
annotation:
While telling a girl to drop down and get her “eagle on” represents Drake’s wild side, don’t forget that he’s got a sensitive side too.

If Drizzy needs to pick a Beatles song to put on while star-gazing, he should consider “And I Love Her,” which includes this fitting verse:

Bright are the stars that shine
Dark is the sky
I know this love of mine
Will never die
And I love her

Similar to Drake’s “sing-along” line a few bars before, the star-gazing here could possibly be to his song “Crew Love”, which features the line:

Smoking weed under star projectors
I guess we’ll never know what Harvard gets us

And perhaps there’s even more connecting The Beatles to the previous line’s Nelly reference? “Flap Your Wings” could be a nod to Wings, the band started by Paul McCartney after he left the Beatles. The “get your eagle on” could also be some classic rock wordplay, referencing iconic ’70s band the Eagles.

lyrics:
I can dig rappin', but a rapper with a ghost writer?
What the fuck happened? (Oh no!)
I swore I wouldn't tell, but most of y'all sharing bars
Like you got the bottom bunk in a two-man cell (A two-man cell)
annotation:
“I can dig rapping” is a quote from the 2nd verse of James Brown’s track “The Payback.”

While cellmates share a room behind “bars,” ghostwriters also share their “bars” (lyrics) with other rappers. Ghostwriters write for another person without receiving credit. Whether you’re a teenage vlogger or a world famous rapper, like Kendrick’s mentor Dr. Dre – whom Kendrick wrote for on “The Recipe” – this is often seen as a phoney move.

In an MTV interview with Rob Markman, Kendrick states that these lines are directed primarily at new artists who have not established their credentials.

As a new artist, you have to stand behind your work, and you have to really truly honor the code of Hip Hop…

Months after this song was released, Meek Mill went on Twitter to denounce Drake for “not writing his own raps,” so many fans wondered if Kendrick was also talking about Drake here. Some said Kendrick performed these lines Drake-style in his September 2015 performance on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert.

Incidentally, Harold Courlander, the writer of the novel The African was a “ghostwriter” for Alex Haley, who plagarized the story of Kunta Kinte in his novel Roots.

lyrics:
I can say that I like a challenge and you tell me it's painless
You don't know what pain is
annotation:
The “challenge” Kendrick means could be getting through to these empty-souled people and giving them a message. It’s difficult to try to make people listen deep into music these days but Kendrick is willing to try.

The word “painless” holds the meaning here:

  • Defeating his rivals is a painless exercise because it’s so easy

  • These rivals are painless – without pain – because they haven’t endured a life as challenging as Kendrick (“you don’t know what pain is”)

  • In the following, bars, “painless” relates to the metaphor of painting a picture/color blind – i.e. a window that is *pane-less"

It’s also possible to understand “Youth to me is painless” because of the way Kendrick pronounces the line. That could mean that he’s young (he was 25 at 2012, when the album dropped), and his mindset is completely reckless.

lyrics:
And excellent mean the extra work
And absentness what the fuck you heard
annotation:
Kendrick mentioned doing extra work on “Black Friday,” where he referred to Gladwell’s rule:

And I won’t mention my ten thousand hours in training

Kendrick shifts his tone, addressing the long gaps between good kid, m.A.A.d city, To Pimp a Butterfly, and DAMN.. Each album is approximately 2 years apart. To Kendrick, “Absentness” is one of the prices he has to pay for excellence. He doesn’t want to rush his work and prefers to take his time on his albums in order to make the best product possible.

lyrics:
All that shit you talkin' 'bout is not up for discussion
I will pay to make it bigger, I don't pay for no reduction
annotation:
In an interview with Nardwuar, Drake said that

I try and showcase the fact that you know, women with you know a full chest. It’s nothing to be ashamed of, and you shouldn’t go get them reduced. They’re beautiful. (emphasis ours)

2 Chainz definitely approves of this course of action…

lyrics:
Something's in the water (Something's in the water)
And if I gotta brown-nose for some gold
Then I'd rather be a bum than a motherfuckin' baller (Oh yeah!)
annotation:
Kendrick isn’t the type to kiss ass to become successful – he’d rather be back in Compton with nothing than compromise his principles, unlike new rappers who allow the labels to use them as a face for someone else’s words.

In the context of the broader story of To Pimp a Butterfly, Kendrick is the butterfly the industry wants to pimp — they want his art to promote their interests. Kendrick refuses to let that happen, and stands firm in his cause.

“Something’s in the water” is a common phrase for when lots of people are behaving strangely—something’s wrong with so many people, that it must be spreading through the drinking water. In this case, the prevalence ghostwriting in the industry is so far beyond common sense, that something must be in the water to make people lose their minds.

lyrics:
How can I paint this picture
When the color blind is hangin' with you?
annotation:
Metaphorically, to “paint a picture” is to describe something clearly. It’s difficult for Kendrick to describe the pain he’s been through to someone who can’t see his colors. This alludes to thinking in terms of black and white, which is to lack a nuanced perspectives on complicated topics

In Kendrick’s life one might say red and blue instead are the only relevant colors. Gangs operate somewhat like cults, and members may be blinded by their gang indoctrination

By “hanging with the color blind”, Kendrick may be referring to hanging out with bitches (dogs are color blind), in this case women (or weak men). They may be killing your vibe and not allowing you to see things as they are.

“Hanging/"blind” and “pain/pane is also a play on words, since blinds hang in a window. Whoever Kendrick is addressing, they are unable to see through the window into his life and soul – they can’t relate to him/his pain.

It may also be a reference to racial colorblidness, a philosophy that suggests that “if one doesn’t see race, one is not racist.” It’s a neoconservative philosophy that has become wide spread among Americans from all ethnicities and backgrounds. The problem with this philosophy is that it ignores people’s cultures and history. This is a problem because of long history of colonization and white supremacy that has ruled over the United States.

In other words, how can you understand Kendrick Lamar’s story if you cannot see who he is, where he comes from, and his history as a Black man living in Compton. If you don’t see race than you don’t see Black. If you don’t see Black, then you don’t see Kendrick. How can he tell his story, when you are blind to who he is and where he comes from?

It can also be understood this way: How can Kendrick make music of substance when most of the music being made has none and how will his audience understand his music when they have become used to music with no substance?

lyrics:
Better yet, where your friends and 'em?
I really wanna know you all
annotation: By asking Sherane to introduce her friends to him, Kendrick adheres to the “be-friends-with-your-lover’s-friends” mentality. However, his intentions are likely more sinful, in hope of manipulating her to arrange some kind of ménage.

lyrics: And pessimists never struck my nerve
annotation:
This line is directed towards FOX News' commentator Geraldo Rivera, who criticized Kendrick’s BET performance of the 2015 song “Alright.” Geraldo claims that his lyrics are counterproductive, but Kendrick labels him a pessimist since he fails to see the positive aim of the song. In a 2015 interview with TMZ, Kendrick said:

How can you take a song that’s about hope and turn it into hatred? The overall message is ‘we’re gonna be alright.’ It’s not the message of ‘I wanna kill people.’

Kendrick also sampled the clip from Fox News in the songs, “BLOOD.” and “YAH.”

lyrics: If it's comin' from a nigga I don't know, then I don't trust it
annotation: Drake’s “no new friends” mentality is in full effect here. This possibly explains why Drake sent back a $2,000 bottle that Chris Brown bought him—a move that allegedly escalated their beef.

lyrics:
The yam brought it out of Richard Pryor
Manipulated Bill Clinton with desires
annotation:
Kendrick, within the tradition of Ellison and Achebe, continues his play with the meaning of yams – they can stand for power, drugs, anger, and lust — all within the same line.

Comedian Richard Pryor was well known for setting himself on fire after free-basing cocaine, while former president Bill Clinton was so overwhelmed by the “yams” (slang term for legs) of intern Monica Lewinsky that he cheated on his wife and lied under oath about the affair, leading to impeachment hearings (though he was never convicted or removed from office).

This juxtaposition illustrates that everyone from hood rats to powerful celebrities and political figures can be corrupted by power and addiction.

lyrics:
Fell on my face and awoke with a scar
Another mistake livin' deep in my heart
annotation: I think it probably relates more to the music, to me having a situation where I am following a trend and my music wasn’t getting out there. And then me learning from that, a bunch of battle scars, and trying to be successful in general. It can take that side or it can take side of the streets, kind of like a double entendre, that type of thing. For the most part, I am really reflecting on the music and me getting to where I wanted to go in life.

lyrics: I really wanna show you off
annotation:
It’s not uncommon for people in burgeoning relationships to want to showcase their significant other to friends or the public. There is a sense of pride and commitment associated with this interaction.

Kendrick’s distinctive pronunciation of “fuck that” echoes the chorus of his previous song “A.D.H.D.”

lyrics:
And Nazareth gon’ plead his case
The reason my power's here on earth
Salute the truth, when the prophet say
annotation:
Kendrick believes that he is on earth for a purpose being a voice for the voiceless. He feels that he should be respected the same as a prophet or someone who speaks the very word of God.

K-Dot has spoken several times about prophesying in his music. On “Mortal Man,” he spoke about standing up for the truth like Nelson Mandela. On “The Heart Pt. IV,” he confirmed that “Mortal Man” was indeed a prophecy:

I prophesized on my last song, you laughed at me

lyrics: If you comin' for my head, then motherfucker get to bustin'
annotation:
Double Entendre:

  • If someone is coming at Drake, then they really need to do it instead of saying they will. Ironically, Drake sure didn’t seem to appreciate it much when Common did this and instead resorted to having his father intervene to avoid the battle
  • If a girl is on his dick, particularly the head, then he’s gonna get to bustin'

Peep the bust/ head wordplay

And we all know the rumors about Drake “busting” at Chris Brown’s head

lyrics:
24/7, 365 days times two
I was contemplatin' gettin' off stage
Just to go back to the hood, see my enemy, and say… (Oh yeah)
annotation:
Kendrick’s been working hard for two years, waiting to perform on the big stage. Now that his time has come, he considers going back to his hometown of Compton solely to show people how successful he is.

Kanye West had a similar line on his song “All Day”, on which Kendrick has a writing credit. There is also a reference track of Kendrick laying down the early version of the verse, so it’s possible he wrote it.

lyrics:
Fuck that, pour up plenty of champagne
Cold nights when you curse this name
annotation:
In order to have a nice romantic evening Kendrick orders her to pour up some champagne. Also, Kendrick says “Fuck that” in the same voice as his song “A.D.H.D”.

The way he says “Fuck that” could also mean “Fuck thought”. In this line he might imply living his life in the moment, not thinking or worrying about anything else.

lyrics: I got loyalty, got royalty inside my DNA
annotation:
This bridge samples a FOX News clip in which commentator Geraldo Rivera criticizes lyrics from from Kendrick’s 2015 song “Alright.” This segment received criticism from across the music scene, with Kendrick himself stating that he was preaching hope in the face of adversity, not violence.

He also used a different clip of the same segment on “BLOOD.,” and outright named Geraldo on “YAH.”

The “5-4-3-2-1” countdown audio is sampled from Al Shepard’s space flight in 1961 on Freedom 7. The track time of the record lines up exactly at (1:05, 1:04, 1:03, 1:02, 1:01), ticking down to 1:00 where the second beat begins.

On the day that DAMN. was released, Geraldo Rivera responded to the lyrics with this to say:

Aside from Drake, in my opinion [Lamar is] probably the best hip-hop artist today.

Despite his endorsement of Kendrick, he continued to criticize the culture of hip-hop:

[Hip-hop is] the worst role model. It’s the worst example. It’s the most negative possible message.

Kendrick also asserts that his African DNA is royalty, a common tenet of Afrocentricism. This echoes a similar sentiment from his 2015 song “i”:

N-E-G-U-S definition: royalty; King royalty
N-E-G-U-S description: Black emperor, King, ruler, now let me finish
N-E-G-U-S, say it with me

lyrics: Yes, Lord,
annotation: Drizzy seems to have a new favorite ad-lib:

lyrics: You goat-mouth mammyfucker
annotation:
This line may be an homage to the classic Dogg Pound track “Smooth”:

Wake your goat-mouth ass up

In Jamaican Patois, to be goat-mouthed is to be jinxed. In standard English, this line might be “You God-damned mother fucker.”

But a Mammy is not simply a mother. The mammy archetype is a familiar and powerful one in American culture—the black women who often took care of white children in the American South. Famous examples include Aunt Chloe in Uncle Tom’s Cabin and Hattie McDaniel’s character “Mammy” in Gone with the Wind.

“Goat-mouth mammy fucker” is also a modified version of the “monkey-mouth motherfuckers” called out in the first verse.

lyrics: Wear it on top of my sleeve in a flick
annotation: I’m really putting my vulnerability out there, and putting my mistakes out there. When the cameras are on me, I’m still going to show you because I know you can relate to it, at the end of the day. That is one of my favorite lines in there, in that record, because it shows the emotion of the line but at the same time is showing that I’m not scared. I’m putting my mistakes out there for people to actually latch onto and know that they can make a difference within themselves at the same time, too.

lyrics:
You called up your girlfriends
And y'all curled in that little bitty Range
annotation: A scene we can all imagine clearly: the girls riding around and gossipin' in the Range about boys.

lyrics: [Verse 2]
annotation:
In an interview with NPR, Mike WiLL-Made It revealed that Kendrick recorded this verse a cappella and asked him to build the beat around it:

With ‘DNA.,’ he went the whole way [through] and then he just started rapping a cappella. He said, ‘I just want to see if you can put some drums around this.’ I said, ‘Man, hell yeah.’ But he was going so hard; that man was rapping so crazy. Just imagine him a cappella rapping the second half of ‘DNA.’ and I had to build a beat around that. I didn’t want the beat to just sound like a regular boom-clap, boom-clap. I wanted that shit to sound just as crazy. I wanted it to sound like he’s battling the beat.

Also note that throughout this verse that you can hear someone shouting “gimme some ganja!” continuously in the background. This sample comes from the deceased American musician and composer Rick James performance of “Mary Jane” live, where he shouts “gimme some ganja!” on stage:

Sampling an influential American legend also plays into one of the themes of “DNA.” – celebrating black heritage and the major accomplishments African-Americans have made within the music industry.

lyrics:
I don't really say this often
But this long-dick nigga ain't for the long talkin';
annotation:
Drizzy channels his inner Wayne, who said on his 2012 single “No Worries”:

“I would talk about my dick, but man that shit be a long story”

Ms. Cat Washington from Bad Girls Club on her relationship with Drake:

He is a phenomenal “peach eater” and he is black and Jewish and the black side is Mandingo

lyrics:
I was gonna kill a couple rappers, but they did it to themselves
Everybody's suicidal, they ain't even need my help
annotation:
Using a line from JAY-Z’s “Thank You”, Kendrick claims he will kill any rappers wanting beef, but he finds they ruin their own chances by not stepping up their game.

In his 2013 “Control” verse, Kendrick called out Drake, J. Cole, Wale and others specifically. Just as JAY-Z uses this line to imply rappers are killed by their own record sales, Kendrick suggests that he doesn’t have to drop any new records because no one can compete with his level of power at the moment.

Kendrick disses rappers who share lines in the first verse, yet uses a JAY-Z line here. Yet there is a marked difference between making a sly interpolation and using ghost-written raps to establish yourself in the business.

lyrics: I heard that she wanna go and party, she wanna go and party
annotation:
The infamous Sherane at it again.

Kendrick has a thing for these types of party girls

lyrics:
Tell me somethin'
You mothafuckas can't tell me nothin'
I'd rather die than to listen to you
annotation:
Although the antecedent for “you motherfuckas” is unclear, its proximity to the sound clip from FoxNews suggests this couplet is directed toward conservative pundits with no connection to the world of hip-hop.

In the video, this verse appears with Kendrick in a coffin, being lectured by a white man with glasses.

lyrics: I'm beast
annotation: Each rapper finishes their verse with “beast” because they have a similar mentality to Marshawn Lynch:

lyrics: This shit is elementary,
annotation:
Alluding to the classic Sherlock Holmes catchphrase, killing rappers is as easy as elementary school for Kendrick.

Kendrick could also be referencing the school-to-prison pipeline, when elementary students in impoverished areas end up in jail is quite easy – a topic Kendrick addressed on “Poe Man’s Dreams”.

lyrics: I can admit that it did look like yours
annotation:
If the mistakes that Kendrick wears on his sleeve look like the person he’s talking to, they may have made some mistakes themselves that they aren’t afraid of sharing.

He sees that he has come from the same upbringing as those around him. Kendrick and others have all made the same mistakes in the past, but he’s been able to overcome them

lyrics:
Nigga, don't approach her with that Atari
Nigga, that ain't good game, homie, sorry
annotation:
The Atari 2600 was released in 1977 and ushered a shift in video games from arcades to homes. When compared with modern gaming consoles, it is extremely outdated.

Additionally, “Sorry” could be a connotative reference to the board game (where there are several ways to negate the progress of your opponent while issuing an unapologetic “Sorry”):

The line is comparable to one in Cee-Lo Green’s hit “Fuck You.”, though here Kendrick plays on the use of the word “game” meaning the ability to flirt or seduce.

lyrics:
My DNA not for imitation
Your DNA an abomination
annotation:
Kendrick takes aim at those who profit from black culture by copying and imitating it for their own personal gain. He touched on this on “Untitled 03,” rapping:

(What the white man say?)
A piece of mine’s
That’s what the white man wanted when I rhyme
Telling me that he selling me just for $10.99

“Your DNA an abomination” probably refers to the groups of white people who have committed and still commit countless atrocities like slavery, police brutality, mass incarceration, and cultural appropriation. It’s also a shot at Geraldo Rivera and the media for twisting his message of hope and spreading the message that hip hop has done more damage than racism.

lyrics: [Verse 3: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation: EVERYBODY JUST DECIDED LET’S HIT EM WITH ONE. I LOVE WORKIN' WITH KENDRICK

lyrics:
I'll probably go to jail
If I shoot at your identity and bounce to the left
annotation:
As hammered home in “The Blacker the Berry,” gang violence is a manifestation of an internalized identity crisis, created by whites barring African Americans from various aspects of a society dominated by the white identity.

“Bounce to the left” may also refer to Kunta’s missing right foot and the way he must have walked/hobbled post-amputation.

lyrics: Why you resent every making of this?
annotation:
He is talking to his old self – his old mind state. The entire album shows how much he has changed as an individual from where he is from. He escaped, and the old Kendrick may have seen this happen to other people in the past and been jealous of their success and ability to get out.

Asking the listener why do you resent every making of his? Whether that be physical attributes or even just your past, personality and family. This could be something Kendrick has asked himself before.

lyrics: They say conversation rule a nation, I can tell
annotation:
Kendrick gives a nod to the Conscious Rapper school of thought – that rap (and words in general) have real power and ability to influence people, governments, nations, incite revolution, and create change. Pac and many of his followers understood his own calling in this way – leading to conspiracy theories after his death that the government got him offed to silence his philosophy. Kim’s wise words on the subject.

This is also a concept in the wider literary, philosophical world-but here Kendrick uses it on a smaller scale to illustrate how he can get a woman’s attention on him just by talking to her.

It’s also a pretty sly wordplay – “conversation rule a nation, I can tell

lyrics:
This how it is when you in the Matrix
Dodgin' bullets, reapin' what you sow
annotation:
The Matrix is a 1999 science fiction film that depicts humans living in a simulated reality—they’re hooked up to computers that place them in a quasi paradise.

Neo, the protagonist, has to choose between escaping into a harsher reality or continuing to live in the fantasy world. In a famous scene from the movie, Neo dodges bullets while inside the simulation.

Kendrick previously referenced The Matrix a couple times on “Backseat Freestyle”:

Goddamn, I feel amazin'
Damn, I’m in the Matrix

Later, he described himself as Neo on DJ Khaled’s “Holy Key”:

But when you the only king, you the only one in the matrix

Furthermore, the line “what you reap is what you sow” is a biblical phrase in 2 Corinthians 9:6 which also appears on the song “Wake Up” by Rage Against the Machine, featured at the end of The Matrix.

lyrics:
Stuck a flag in my city, everybody's screamin', "Compton!"
I should probably run for mayor when I'm done, to be honest
annotation:
Like he said in 2011:

“Compton!”, a nigga gotta scream that shit

Kendrick’s success has put Compton back at the forefront of the rap game. He’s as closely associated with his hometown as anyone, so he’d have a good chance of being elected mayor once he’s done rapping.

lyrics:
Tell me your purpose is petty again
But even a small lighter can burn a bridge
Even a small lighter can burn a bridge
annotation:
The bridge between gang life and being successful (as a rapper) or getting out of the hood can be destroyed easily. After all, it takes one match to start a forest fire.

Also, these are the last two lines Kendrick raps before he goes into the bridge of the song about how his life is evolving. He burned his bridge from a negative past – he won’t go back.

Even something as small or petty as a lighter could bring down a big structure like a bridge.

lyrics:
But I could never right my wrongs
'Less I write it down for real, P.S
annotation:
The usage of this post script (P.S.) is to segue into the chorus by extending the play on the words write/right.

This is a play on words using the “right/write” homophones… very similar to what Kanye West used in the end of the second verse in “Touch the Sky”:

I’m tryin' to right my wrongs
It’s funny, them same wrongs help me write the song

This shows the irony of being unable to right his wrongdoings and negative experiences of his youth unless he “writes them down for real”. Everything he spits is real or has happened and the only way to right his wrongs is by writing them.

It could be a play on the line before about him communicating with us through his lyrics and hip-hop, and sharing it with other people so we can all learn and relate. It’s up to our generation to save this nation and Kendrick does so by creating music for the masses.

lyrics:
And stackin' up the footage, livin' on the go
And sleepin' in a villa
Sippin' from a Grammy, walkin' in the buildin'
Diamond in the ceilin', marble on the floors
Beach inside the window, peekin' out the window
annotation:
Kendrick was nominated for 11 Grammy’s in 2016, which is only one less than the all-time record held by Michael Jackson. He swept the rap category and took home 5 Grammy’s that year.

K. Dot drinks from his Grammy in the same way that Jay Z drank from his in 2013. A few months later, Drake followed Jay’s example. Hov won again in 2014 and called the trophy “a gold sippy cup” for his daughter.

lyrics: Uh, yeah, ho, this the finale
annotation:
Kendrick Lamar takes the final verse.

As Jay Electronica learned on “Control,” it’s usually best to let Kendrick go last.

lyrics:
And I put that on my momma and my baby boo too
20 million walkin' out the court buildin', woo-woo!
annotation:
Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X often spoke of 20 million oppressed African Americans.

This isn’t the first time Kendrick has referenced the number 20 million – in “Hol' Up”, Kendrick says:

I’ll prolly die in a minute, just bury me
With 20 bitches, 20 million, and a Comptown fitted

The “Momma/baby boo” reference comes from Snoop Dogg’s “Murder Was The Case.”

lyrics:
I can feel the changes
I can feel the new people around me just want to be famous
annotation:
Now that he’s becoming a rap star, Kendrick notices that a lot of people he didn’t know before are clinging to him, hoping to ride his star to fame and fortune.

He is also making a commentary on the rap industry, and how everyone is trying too hard to become the biggest thing.

lyrics:
You can get it, you can get it
You can get it, you can get it
And I know just, know just, know just
Know just, know just what you want
Poetic justice, put it in a song, alright
You can get it, you can get it
You can get it, you can get it
And I know just, know just, know just
Know just, know just what you want
Poetic justice, put it in a song, alright
annotation:
“Poetic justice is a literary device in which virtue is ultimately rewarded or vice punished, often in modern literature by an ironic twist of fate intimately related to the character’s own conduct.” He is also referring to the film Poetic Justice, starring Tupac Shakur and Janet Jackson.

Poetic Justice: a twist of fate.
Within the context of the short film, “poetic justice” is possibly following him going to see Sherane to get down, but instead he ends up getting jumped by two men in hoodies (see skit).

Also, in the video, these lyrics are juxtaposed with images of a drive by shooting, implying the meaning of “you can get it”, as being that, in the hood, you can become victim of senseless violence at anytime.

Also, “You Can Get It” is a triple entendre composed of the compliment “You can get it,” (the colloquialism meaning “you’re attractive,” with “it” implying the dick), the inspirational message “You can get it,” (with the “it” implying whatever you desire), and the challenging statement “You can get it,” (with the “it” implying the meaning of the poetic lyrics)

lyrics: Baby in the pool, godfather goals
annotation:
Nirvana’s Nevermind album cover depicts a naked baby boy underwater with a US dollar bill on a fishhook just out of his reach. Kendrick mentioned the suicide of Cobain on “HiiiPower”:

The reason Lauryn Hill don’t sing,
or Kurt Cobain
Loaded that clip and then said bang, the drama it bring is crazy

This line foreshadows the mentioning of Nirvana only a couple lines later.

The Godfather is a classic 1972 mob film commonly referenced in rap. Kendrick aspires to the same type of power as the protagonist Michael Corleone.

lyrics: My pep talk turn into a pep rally
annotation: His raps are good enough to have people hyped up as if they were at a pep rally—evidenced by his “pep rally” that shut the city down in 2012!

lyrics:
Aw, yeah, fuck the judge
I made it past 25, and there I was
A little nappy-headed nigga with the world behind him
annotation:
This line is reminiscent of Kanye West’s from “We Don’t Care” and 2Pac’s “Can’t C Me” (which, interestingly, features George Clinton, who is featured on the opening track for To Pimp a Butterfly, “Wesley’s Theory”.

It’s commonly said that black males who live in impoverished areas would either be dead or in jail by age 25 – which the imagery of black males of all ages on the album’s cover helps debunk. 2Pac was also killed at the age of 25, adding to the significance of Kendrick making it past that number.

Kendrick expressed a similar idea on “Chapter Six”:

Ridin' with them boys and girls and we’re high
All we want to do is have a good time
Young, wild, and reckless is how we live life
Pray that we make it to twenty-one (One, one, one)

lyrics:
You can see that my city found me
Then put me on stages, to me that's amazin'
annotation:
Compton is riding for Kendrick and he’s still coming to terms with the realization that he’s like the new Dre, Quik or Eiht for the city.

He knows that he was able to get where he is today because his city recognized his talent and got his name out there. It’s rare that an artist becomes a star through sheer talent, but Kendrick seems to have done it. Amazing.

lyrics: [Verse 2: Drake]
annotation:
Kendrick told Complex about Drizzy:

Me and Drake had been working for a while off the fact that I was on his tour and I was on Take Care. We were talking about what joints we wanted to do. When Scoop shot me the track, I immediately came up with the concept of doing that vibe and the first person I had in mind was Drake. Drake killed it and it came out crazy. I think that’s going to sit for a while.

lyrics:
Only Lord knows I've been goin' hammer
Dodgin' paparazzi, freakin' through the cameras
Eat at Four Daughters, Brock wearin' sandals
Yoga on a Monday, stretchin' to Nirvana
annotation:
The success of Kendrick’s music career makes it difficult for him to get around without being seen by paparazzi. After dodging them, he might enjoy a meal by the beach at Four Daughters Kitchen.

Brock Korsan is a TDE A&R who frequently wears sandals and manages a few producers who collaborate with Kendrick—such as DJ Dahi and Cardo.

Kendrick plays on the term “Nirvana.” While Buddhists believe that meditation results in a transcendent state through the extinguishing of Trishna, or desires, it’s also the name of a famous rock band from the 1990’s—previously referenced only a couple lines earlier.

lyrics: Say she from the hood, but she live inside in the valley, now
annotation:
He’s referring to Southern California’s San Fernando Valley, which is known for being suburban, safe, and wealthy—at least compared to the “hood,” where Kendrick is also from.

A “valley girl” is a popular term to describe a stereotypical woman from this area who is materialistic and arrogant. While Alicia Silverstone’s character in Clueless was actually from Beverly Hills, she represents the image of the Valley girl in popular culture.

He could also be implying that the girl is a porn star, since nearly 90% of all legally distributed pornographic films made in the United States are either filmed in or produced by studios based in the San Fernando Valley, according to the L.A. Times.

This line could also be a metaphor for the rap game, which started in the streets but has now become suburban.

lyrics: Life ain't shit but a fat vagina
annotation:
Kendrick’s way of portraying the common idea in hip-hop that “Life’s A Bitch”. Also a likely callback to the famous line from “Backseat Freestyle”, which he’s described as himself “going as ignorant as possible”:

I pray my dick get big as the Eiffel Tower
So I can fuck the world for seventy-two hours

This also emphasizes “King Kunta’s” purpose as a show of Kendrick’s power getting to him. Life just becomes something for him to fuck, whether it’s rappers or women.

lyrics: To you that's a quick check
annotation: Kendrick is truly amazed by his city putting him on and helping him get big, while other rappers just use their regional connections and fans to get them into the spotlight where they can put out some bullshit and make quick money.

lyrics:
I really hope you play this, 'cause ol' girl, you test my patience
With all these seductive photographs
And all these one-off vacations you've been takin'
Clearly a lot for me to take in,
annotation:
Drake’s verse is towards Zineb (a.k.a Nebby), his ex-girlfriend from Toronto. He has been known to go back and forth with her with songs directing at her such as “Sooner Than Later”, “Best I Ever Had” and “Look What You’ve Done”.

Nebby is known to have a huge fan following on Twitter and Instagram, and is notorious for taking seductive pictures of her working out or showing off her assets.

However, because Nebby is not from “East Africa,” we are prone to think he’s talking about Maliah. She’s Ethiopian. Ethiopia is in East Africa. She takes lots of sexy pictures being that she’s famous for “dat ass”. A “one off vacation” is when you go on vacation alone. It “doesn’t make sense” because she’s constantly sending him seductive photos and yet going places alone and she’s “too busy fucking with her other man” so he doesn’t get why she wouldn’t take a vacation with him when she clearly has the chance.

lyrics:
Watchin' all the snakes, curvin' all the fakes
Phone never on, I don't conversate
annotation:
After the 2015 Grammy nominations were announced, Wale tweeted that he felt like Kendrick had been giving him the cold shoulder:

[Kendrick] ain’t answered that phone since the last nomination. I get the Demi Lovato treatment from him now. It’s hard out here.

Whether he’s too focused on his work or just isn’t interested in socializing, Kendrick can’t be bothered to be reached.

TDE label-mate Schoolboy Q expresses a similar sentiment in his 2016 song, “THat Part,” where he repeats “Me no conversate with the fake” on the hook. Kendrick appears on the Black Hippy remix of the song as well.

Ironically, snakes move from side to side in a curvy manner.

lyrics: Vaca'd in Atlanta, then she goin' back to Cali, mmm
annotation:
The girl has been on holiday in Atlanta but is finally headed back home to Kendrick, who’s from Compton.

This line—and much of the verse—also works as a metaphor for the hip-hop game. Southern rap centered on Atlanta has been the dominant force in the rap scene for many years, but now that Kendrick’s on top, it’s coming back to the West Coast.

This is also a reference to the song “Going Back to Cali,” though unclear whether it’s the one by Biggie Smalls or LLCool J

lyrics: Screamin', "Annie, are you okay? Annie, are you okay?"
annotation:
Kendrick is referencing the break and chorus of Michael Jackson’s hit single, “Smooth Criminal,” one of Jackson’s funkiest singles ever:

Annie, are you okay?
So, Annie, are you okay? Are you okay, Annie?

One of the first songs to sample “Smooth Criminal” was “Givin Up the Nappy Dugout” by Ice Cube. The phrase “nappy dugout” is a slang term for “vagina” that originates from Funkadelic’s “Nappy Dugout”. This ties together the previous three lines.

Kendrick played To Pimp A Butterfly for Jackson’s eldest son, Prince, before it was released.

lyrics: With all disrespect, let me say this
annotation: In contrast to the common phrase with all due respect Kendrick specifically wants to disrespect artists he sees that lack integrity.

lyrics: it don't make sense
annotation:
There could be a stretching use of the quasi-homophones sense, cents and scents. If some of these Drake lines relate back to Kendrick’s first verse, then we can connect sense and scents, a la Kendrick’s recognizing fragrances, as a way to explain Drake’s longing for Neb. However, if we go with the classic “if it don’t make dollars, it don’t make sense/cents” homophone use, then it may correspond with her lavish, one-off vacations.

But we can probably rest most assure knowing that it is probably just another straightforward, dull Drake line, where he doesn’t understand what this flirty girl is trying to accomplish by sending him seductive photos.

lyrics:
I don't compromise, I just penetrate
Sex, money, murder—these are the breaks
annotation:
These two lines reference Kurtis Blow’s “The Breaks,” and black rapper stereotypes. To add another layer, it’s also a reference to 9th Wonder’s program that he runs at Harvard University of the exact same name. This is the same program also immortalised Kendrick’s critically acclaimed 2015 To Pimp A Butterfly album in it’s library archive. 9th Wonder also has production credits on DAMN. for DUCKWORTH., the final song on the album.

Throughout “The Breaks,” Kurtis gives “the breaks” various, ambiguous definitions; all describing the sometimes unfortunate “facts of life.”

A similar reference to the “facts of life” is in “untitled 05 | 9.21.2014.,” when Jay Rock references “the breaks” towards the end of his verse–just after Kendrick mentions having to deal with dream-killers:

I’m sleep walkin', I’m street stalkin', I’m outta place
Reinforcing this heat barking, these are the brakes

Interestingly, Sex, Money & Murder is the name of one of the original Blood gangs in New York City.

lyrics:
Got your girl on my line, world on my line
The irony, I fuck 'em at the same damn time
annotation:
Kendrick references Future’s 2011 single “Same Damn Time,” which spawned countless remixes. The irony is that “your girl” is also “your world” if she means everything to you.

This isn’t the first time Kendrick used this metaphor. For instance, on 2012’s “Backseat Freestyle” he said:

I pray my dick get big as the Eiffel Tower
So I can fuck the world for seventy-two hours

lyrics:
Limo tinted with the gold plates
Straight from the bottom, this the belly of the beast
From a peasant to a prince to a motherfuckin' king (Oh yeah)
annotation:
Kendrick started from the bottom in Compton, but the top isn’t such a simple place to be either.

His success has made him a target for his fellow rappers. He’s in a dangerous place (“the belly of the beast”), but it doesn’t matter because he’s a king, and peasants can’t touch him.

Kendrick also referred to himself a king on his legendary “Control” verse:

I’m Makaveli’s offspring, I’m the King of New York. King of the Coast, one hand, I juggle them both

lyrics:
I'm tryin' to keep it alive
And not compromise the feeling we love
You're tryin' to keep it deprived
And only co-sign what radio does
annotation:
With his music, Kendrick is trying to create the kinds of feelings that he loves to get as a fan of hip-hop.

He’s trying to keep hip-hop as he sees it alive, while other artists will make whatever kind of music they think will make them the most money.

The latter could be viewed as an attack on the the current state of rap and how many rappers change because of the industry, instead of staying true to themselves.

lyrics:
you too busy fuckin' with your other man
I was tryna put you on game, put you on a plane
Take you and your momma to the motherland
annotation:
Drake says, “Young East African girl” in the previous line, but if he is still evoking Nebby, then his geography might be a bit off. Nebby (and her mother) are from Casablanca, Morocco.

Drake has been known to express his interest in Ethiopian women, as is seen in the song “Where To Now”. The clique “XO” merged with OVO, and most of them were from Ethiopia, so this could explain where the attraction was fostered.

Considering the connotations Ethiopia/Abyssinia has as being the African “mother land”, referred to wistfully as such in songs like Bunny Wailer’s “Dream Land” and the Abyssinians' “Forward Unto Zion”, it is most likely that Drake is addressing an Ethiopian girl in this particular verse.

This is also a decent example of the smooth lover man image Drake enjoys projecting. He’s not only out to charm the girl in question but her mother as well.

lyrics:
These are the times, level number 9
Look up in the sky, 10 is on the way
Sentence on the way, killings on the way
Motherfucker, I got winners on the way
annotation:
Kendrick’s probably referring the Ten Plagues of Egypt, or the ten biblical plagues from the Book of Exodus. The plagues were actions of Yahweh (God) and were used to free the persecuted Israelites from Egyptian slavery. Kendrick refers to being an Israelite on the next song, “YAH.”

The ninth plague was “Darkness for three days,” which ties into the “look up at the sky” lyric. The tenth plague was “Death of firstborn sons,” which ties into the next line: “sentence on the way, killings on the way.”

Kendrick has alluded to Biblical end of the world events before, citing Judgement Day from Revelations on “Untitled 01” and “Untitled 02,” as well as commenting on the “last days” in a 2015 interview with Billboard, saying:
