We’re in the last days, man – I truly in my heart believe that. It’s written. I could go on with Biblical situations and things my grandma told me. But it’s about being at peace with myself and making good with the people around me.

lyrics:
She eyein' me like a nigga don't exist
Girl, I know you want this dick
annotation:
The way he says, “Girl, I know you want this dick” is a reference to Martin Lawrence’s standup movie You So Crazy.

Kendrick also wears a leather outfit similar to Martin’s in the song’s video.

lyrics: Bitch, where you when I was walkin'—*Gunshot*
annotation:
The first line of the hook is cut off by the sound of gunfire, as if Kendrick’s enemy knows that violence is the only way to take the king down. The video strengthens this interpretation when the camera suddenly spins wildly out of control.

Kendrick, of course, survives the attack and turns the funk back on his enemy. The video flashes portraits of Martin Luther King and Malcolm X near the end of the hook.

lyrics: And I'm lookin' right past you
annotation:
Kendrick doesn’t want money hungry rappers to kill his vibe. He’s ignoring them and only focusing on his own vision and the bigger picture of his career.

He’s also possibly addressing rap fans who are stuck in the box of radio music and letting them know that he’s looking past those kind of fans and targeting the core hip hop audience.

lyrics:
I could do it, maybe one day
When you figure out you're gonna need someone
When you figure out it's alright here in the city
And you don't run from where we come from
annotation:
He wants her to realize he’ll be back at home all along. He is possibly alluding to Toronto in “Shot For Me” when he blames the “city we came from” for the men being jealous and the women being in competition.

Nebby and Drake are both from the heart of Toronto.

They all have the common friends and all the happiness Drake ever wanted, is right here in his city. His family, friends, and true love. He did not have to look anywhere else but his close circle. But Nebby is tired of all the gossip and all problems caused by being the same circle and city Drake is from, that she finds her heart will find love elsewhere.

lyrics: You ain't shit without a body on your belt
annotation:
Back in the days of the Wild West, gunslingers would add a notch to their belt for everybody they killed. Those with no notches on their belt wouldn’t be taken seriously if they tried to act tough, but someone with a ton of notches was not to be trifled with. He may also be referring to a gun; whoever he is adressing has no power or influence without their gun.

Kendrick has hinted several times that he may have actually killed someone, but he could also be referring to “killing” other rappers on songs— something he’s constantly trying to do.

lyrics: Girl, I'm Kendrick Lamar
annotation:
Kendrick knows how famous he is, and you should too.

This line inspired a popular meme:

lyrics:
By the time you hear the next pop
The funk shall be within you—*Gunshot*
annotation:
Kendrick doesn’t let his enemy kill the vibe. Just like a bullet breaking the sound barrier, Kendrick is hitting us with the funk before we even recognize it. We are feeling the music before we hear the sound. It is already inside us as a society, he is just making us realize it.

This is reminiscent of Parliament’s “Bop Gun.”

Where did you get that funk from?
They’re spoiling the fun
Shoot them with the bop gun

As stated in his interview with Rolling Stone, the album ended up with a predominately funky/jazzy vibe:

Musically, the album… is adventurous, borrowing from free jazz & 1970s funk. Lamar says he listened to a lot of Miles Davis and Parliament… MixedByAli says Lamar works synesthetically – “He talks in colors all the time: ‘Make it sound purple.’ ‘Make it sound light green.’”

Kendrick’s line here is similar to Hittman on “Light Speed”, and uses a voice very similar to the narrator of Section.80.

Interestingly, Kendrick begins his rewind on Duckworth with this same POP.

lyrics:
We live in a world, we live in a world on two different axles
You live in a world, you livin' behind the mirror
I know what you scared of
The feeling of feeling emotions inferior
annotation:
To be in front of a mirror is to obviously look at your own reflection. Kendrick accuses other artists of standing behind the mirror (ie. not being honest with their view of themselves). He suspects they shy away from introspection because they are afraid to investigate weak emotions inside themselves. He accepts a part of himself that understands where these artists are coming from. He feels, rather than them shying away, they put on a front.

Kendrick is empathizing with record labels/producers/etc. saying he sees why they’re afraid to experiment with new or unique styles of music. He knows they take a risk by supporting something that isn’t as easy to sell in the charts.

Kendrick keeps making a distinction between what he’s trying to do, compared to what other rappers in the mainstream are trying to do. He’s interested in making music that’s great and sees others as trying to make music for the sake of money.

lyrics: That sound like poetic justice, poetic justice
annotation:
Drake is using the title of the song, “Poetic Justice,” to describe the hypothetical idea that the woman he was pursuing would realize the good Drake is doing for her. If she is to ever come to this realization as well as figuring out what she really needs in life and remembering that it’s all in the city she grew up in, Drake would describe that as “justice”.

The woman is receiving poetic justice, or karma: getting what she deserves. She cheated on him with another man while he was planning expensive trips for her and her mother, but soon she’ll realize she needs him still.

lyrics: You ain't shit without a ticket on your plate
annotation:
This is a play on the term “meal ticket”—a way to earn money.

Most of Kendrick’s earnings are from his album sales and live performances. The other ticket on his plate is an endorsement deal with Reebok.

lyrics: A.K.A. Benz is to me just a car
annotation:
Kendrick’s giving himself a creative nickname, but it’s unclear if he’s using it to:

  1. Brag about the money he has. To regular people a Mercedes Benz is a huge investment, but for him it’s inconsequential.

  2. Show how anti-materialistic he is. Who cares about a Benz—it’s just a car!

The staccato delivery of this line (continued over the following two) is worth noting. He peppers the syllables in an almost child-like rhythm which is simultaneously ‘sing-song’ and very, very direct—almost machine-gun like.

Kendrick doesn’t do drugs either, so a Benz to him isn’t a benzodiazepine (benz, benzo) but a car.

lyrics:
[Outro: Kendrick Lamar & Whitney Alford]
Funk, funk, funk, funk, funk, funk, funk, funk, funk, funk, funk
We want the funk
We want the funk
Now if I give you the funk, you gon' take it?
We want the funk
Now if I give you the funk, you gon' take it?
We want the funk
Now if I give you the funk, you gon' take it?
We want the funk
Do you want the funk?
We want the funk
Do you want the funk?
We want the funk
Now if I give you the funk, you gon' take it?
We want the funk
annotation:
Similar to a later cut on the album, “The Blacker the Berry,” Kendrick aligns himself musically with jazz and funk. The final line could hint at the next track, “Institutionalized,” and how Americans have lost touch with their musical heritage.

“We want the funk” is a sample of Ahmad’s song with the same title. The phrase can be read as “We want our roots” or “We want to validate true black music.” It is also a nod to the Parliament song “Give Up the Funk (Tear the Roof off the Sucker).” In an interview with Rolling Stone, Kendrick talked about listening to Parliament.

lyrics:
This shit is vital, I know you had to
This shit is vital, I know you had to
annotation:
Money is vital, so in some ways Kendrick understands the artists who do anything to achieve mainstream success.

He may be mocking them when he says “I know you had to”, suggesting that they don’t have the true talent to be successful without pandering to the masses.

The focus in music needs to be the vision first, and that the money will follow suit if the vision is right and the music is touching people.

lyrics: You were so new to this life, but goddamn, you got adjusted
annotation:
She was new to the perks of being a celebrity – this lavish life of hers. However, presumably with Drake’s help, she grew to understand the finer things.

It goes along with Kendrick describing his girl as high maintenance. Even though these girls came from humble places, they have no problem being spoiled and given the finer things. Perhaps it is because of their humble beginnings that they are so accepting of this affluent way of living

lyrics:
You ain't sick enough to pull it on yourself
You ain't rich enough to hit the lot and skate
annotation:
“Pull it on yourself” is slang for shooting yourself in the head. Kendrick dealt with depression on his song “u,” but his moods swings aren’t severe enough to end his own life.

Kendrick chooses to live a modest lifestyle, so he may be experiencing criticism from people who do not think he has a lot of money. If that’s the case, “Hit the lot and skate,” may be haters saying his bank account isn’t full enough to retire from the rap game, or he doesn’t have enough money to go to a luxury car dealership and make a purchase without financing.

lyrics:
That mean your friends-es need be up to par
See, my standards are pampered by threesomes tomorrow
Mmm,
annotation:
Kendrick is going to have threesomes with bad women in the future so the girl he’s with today better have friends that meet up to his standards.

Also a play on words with par and threesomes which are both golf terms.

Additionally, these two lines (along with the previous two) are rapped in a triplet meter as opposed to the duplet meter in the rest of the verse, creating a possible (unintentional) play on “three"somes.

The reason these lines, starting with “AKA,” stand out is that Kendrick has switched over to a poetic meter known as “anapestic tetrameter,” or a repeated pattern of “short-short-LONG” syllables.

This is pretty rare in rap: another good example is Eminem on “The Way I Am.” Anapestic tetrameter occurs more commonly in comic poetry like Dr. Seuss or Twas the Night Before Christmas.

lyrics: I remember you was conflicted, misusing your influence
annotation:
This is the first line of a poem that Kendrick recites throughout the album; with each appearance, the excerpts get longer, building up to the album’s final track “Mortal Man,” where it is completed.

“King Kunta” explores the idea of Kendrick as an influencer, and how he’s grown from a “peasant, to a prince, to a motherfucking king” from the success of good kid, m.A.A.d city.

Continue the poem on “These Walls.”

lyrics:
Die in a pitiful vain, tell me a watch and a chain
Is way more believable, give me a feasible gain
Rather a seasonal name
I'll let the people know this is somethin' you can blame
On yourselves, you can remain stuck in a box
annotation:
KDOT can’t understand why other rappers don’t strive for more substantive success.

Instead they would rather get a quick check and some fame whenever they release an album then quickly fade into relative obscurity again (like a season). Kendrick wants to be an artist that people are always talking about because his music is rich.

Kendrick threatens to show people through his music that artists don’t have to sell out to be successful. If they’re stuck in a box they only have themselves and their music to blame.

His mission is to gain fame and success by BEING unique and writing more meaningful lyrics, so that people starting out look to emulate HIS style and create their own unique music.
These ideas are the “locks” that he wants to break out and hide.

lyrics: I mean, I write poems in these songs, dedicated to the fun sex
annotation:
A play on the phrase “fairer sex”, referring to women. Also to play on writing about sex in his songs/poems.

In an interview with Cosmo Magazine, he was asked:

Is there anything that feels as good as sex does?

He replied:

When I finish writing a rap verse. It’s a lot like sex: You start off slow with ideas, like foreplay, and then you put your all into it. When you end it with the perfect thought, it’s like that perfect last stroke.

lyrics:
Tell me when destruction gonna be my fate
Gonna be your fate, gonna be our faith
Peace to the world, let it rotate
annotation:
Given the religious themes of the album and Kendrick’s allusion to the ten biblical plagues only a few lines prior, this could refer to being damned by God.

By living wickedly your fate becomes death and destruction. This theme is also mentioned in “YAH.” when Kendrick says:

And Deuteronomy say that we all been cursed
I know he walks the Earth
But it’s money to get, bitches to hit, yah
Zeroes to flip, temptation is, yah
First on my list, I can’t resist, yah

He also makes use of a homophone for “peace” and the slang term for a handgun (“piece”)—rotation may refer to rounds in a clip or the Earth spinning.

lyrics: kill 'em all, dead bodies in the hallway
annotation:
He killed everyone with his crazy rap flow, hence the dead bodies

“Kill em all” is phonetically similar to “K. Lamar”

He could be referring to having had sex(killing) with some girls simultaneously. They’re all wasted, lying around, sleeping, probably drunk, in the hall way (dead BODIES).

lyrics:
I'ma break out and then hide every lock
I'ma break out and then hide every lock
annotation:
By breaking the mold of becoming successful in rap by appealing to dated industry views, Kendrick hopes to create a hip-hop landscape where a rapper has to produce good music to attain success.

It’s like once he breaks out of the metaphorical box, he’s gonna hide every lock that keeps other people stuck in it too. This way they’ll never be stuck again.

The listener can make an interesting comparison between the idea of breaking out of the box and hiding the locks in this song and an idea he expressed in his 2011 verse on the Buried Alive Interlude when he was less of a veteran in the rap game…

If you was in a pine box
I would surely break the lock
I’d jump right in and fall asleep
Cause you are the death of me

The box could also be referring to Compton, and he would hide every lock so other rappers from Compton could be successful too. Also could be referring to that the box is that Compton rappers only are gansta rappers, and he would break out and hide the locks so others could follow the same path.

lyrics:
Your natural hair and your soft skin
And your big ass in that sundress, ooh
annotation: Reminiscent of the girl from Rozay’s “Diced Pineapples” track, Sophia Marie, though she’s probably sporting hair extensions. Surely, this is still referring to Nebby, though they both fit the description.

lyrics: [Video Outro]
annotation:
This outro is only found in the music video version of the song:

This lyrics “Gimme some ganja” are sampled from a 1982 live performance of Rick James' “Mary Jane.”

“Aint no ho inside my DNA” may be a nod to Earl Sweatshirt’s song “DNA,” where Earl raps:

Ain’t no bitch in my DNA

lyrics: Don't get involved, listen what the crystal ball say
annotation:
Crystal balls usually warn people of the dangers to come, much like Kendrick warns rappers not to mess with him or they may suffer the same fate as the those in the previous line.

Pretty fucking prescient of K-dot, really, a year before he shook the hip-hop world with similar words on his “Control” verse. Was he planning on shaking up the rap game way ahead of time?

lyrics:
Bitch, don't kill my vibe!
You ain't heard the coast like this in a long time
annotation:
The period from the mid ‘80s to the mid '90s is often considered to be hip-hop’s golden age. Dr. Dre, Tupac, and Snoop Dogg were all actively turning out great albums in this era. It was also the time in which there was a feud between artists and fans of the East Coast and West Coast.

Starting at the end of the ‘90s, there was a lot of criticism about the state of hip-hop. Eventually, Nas even called his 2006 album Hip Hop Is Dead.

However, Kendrick—and others who have reviewed his major label debut—believe his music harkens back to an earlier era in hip-hop.

lyrics: Good God, what you doin' that walk for?
annotation:
Many females know how to do a certain type of walk that when done, makes that ass sway perfectly.

Drake knows better but asks anyways assuring her that it’s obvious that he knows how she carries herself.

lyrics:
Halle Berry, hallelujah
Holla back, I'll do ya; beast
annotation:
On his 2012 song “Money Trees,” Kendrick says:

It go Halle Berry or hallelujah
Pick your poison, tell me what you doing

It’s unclear which line was recorded first, since both songs were released around the same time. Kendrick explained the “Money Trees” line in a verified Genius annotation:

You can either go right, or you can go left and get crazy with us…Of course, hallelujah being the more good in me and Halle Berry being the actual vice of what’s going down – the lust for the money, the lust for this mission we are about to go on. Pick your poison, tell me what you’re doing. But when you tell me, tell me right now. We ain’t got time to wait.

Here, Kendrick also seems to be using the line to praise Halle Berry’s beauty. He’d like her to “holla” at him so he can “do” her. Can you blame him?

lyrics: Don't you see that long line?
annotation:
Look at the line, it’s so diverse
They getting off work and they wanna see Kendrick

Fans, other artists, and the industry as a whole are heavily anticipating this album.

Also, the line before this is longer than the other lines in the outro.

lyrics:
When I see that thing move
I just wish we would fight less and we would talk more
annotation: Basically, even though Drake and his girl get into fights and what not, once he see’s his girls backside move back n forth he just wants it all to work out.

lyrics: [Produced by 40 & Drake]
annotation:
Drake’s longtime collaborator 40 handles the production here, but Drake is also given a producer credit under his C. Papi moniker.

The song’s beat interpolates a snippet of unreleased vocals from Drake’s girl Aaliyah, from a song called “Quit Hatin'.” The vocals run throughout, but can be heard most clearly in the song’s instrumental intro. (The sample can be heard at 2:19 in this video).

Drake explained the Aaliyah connection:

We were working on the Aaliyah project [a never-released posthumous album from 2012] at the time, and we had this vocal sample that we were playing with, which we ended up having someone re-sing and in a different melody. We ended up with “Fuckin’ Problems.”

lyrics: And they waiting on Kendrick like the first and the fifteenth
annotation:
People that rely on government assistance usually get it on the first and the fifteenth of every month.

The world is waiting on Kendrick like they wait for their paychecks, which is what they need to survive, tying in with the previous line:

Don’t you see that long line

In addition, 2Pac had a very similar line to this on “All Eyez on Me”:

Say money bring bitches, bitches bring lies
One nigga’s gettin' jealous, and motherfuckers died
Depend on me like the first and fifteenth

1st and 15th is also Lupe Fiasco’s record label; so this could be interpreted as “waiting on Kendrick to be the next socially aware rapper” (we’re fine with the Lupe Fiasco we have). However, Kendrick previously said on Ab-Souls Outro that he didn’t want this label.

lyrics: They say communication save relations, I can tell
annotation:
Many people believe that the key issue of saving a relationship is communication.

Also, a reference to earlier line by Kendrick

“They say conversation rule a nation, I can tell”

lyrics: Threes in the air, I can see you are in sync
annotation:
You’re in sync with Hiii Power if you’re throwin' up the 3.

He is also relating to the previous line: We have been needing that “Kendrick fix” and we’ve been waiting in line to get it.

lyrics:
But I can never right my wrongs
Unless I write 'em down for real, P.S
annotation:
Identical with the end of the first verse.

Again, this is a play on words using “right”… very similar to what Kanye West used in the end of his second verse in “Touch the Sky”:

I’m tryin' to right my wrongs
It’s funny, them same wrongs help me write this song

Not to mention the transition to the hook by extending use of the term “P.S.” at the end.

This reiteration of the last line in the first verse is to re-emphasize the theme of poetic justice – making things right with finely crafted compositions.

Lamar’s verse was all about the responsibility he feels as an artist to utilize his negative personal experiences to help other people overcome the same problems and about how he believes the role of rap/words/art is powerful enough to fix a nation.

Drake brings it down to another, personal level – he only cares about winning back his girl and hopes that writing a bunch of songs about her will fix all the mistakes he made in their relationship and get her to see that they should get back together

lyrics: I'll take your girlfriend and put that pussy on a pedestal
annotation:
This “woman” can be a metaphor for hip-hop. He’s talking to other rappers, and hip-hop is like a girlfriend to them. The whole song is about Kendrick saving the industry—he’s gonna elevate it to its highest form.

“Pussy on a pedestal” was first used in Eddie Murphy’s classic 1987 stand up special, Raw. Also, this line could also be taken as an antithesis to the usual attitude in rap, where they treat women like they’re inferior; whereas, Kendrick will do the opposite. Using a women as a metaphor for hip-hop is a classic technique used by the likes of Kanye West, Common, and many more.

Kendrick was later featured on Travis Scott’s September 2016 hit, “goosebumps,” where he would re-use these lines:

Put the pussy on a pedestal
Put the pussy on a high horse
That pussy to die for

lyrics: Every time I write these words they become a taboo
annotation:
Kendrick’s beliefs are considered taboo to mainstream society. Songs like “Keisha’s Song,” “m.A.A.d City,” and “P&P” contain controversial themes

In another cultural sphere, him telling stories that actually have meaning is taboo to today’s rappers, since the majority of them just talk about money, cars, and other material things.

Expressed sexual thoughts are often considered taboo in public.

lyrics: Bitch, don't kill my vibe! Bitch, don't kill my vibe!
annotation:
At this point, you can hear a woman’s voice (Anna Wise’s), take over the song.

(You could actually hear Anna’s voice since the very beginning of the song as she accompanied Kendrick in the first hook but now it is integrated more clearly.)

lyrics:
Makin' sure my punctuation curve, every letter here's true
Livin' my life in the margin and that metaphor was proof
annotation:
Kendrick poetically justifies why his writing is vital to hip-hop. To explain this, he sneaks 4 literary mechanisms into the inner-workings of his rhymes (punctuation, letter, margin, metaphor):

  • “make sure my punctuation is curved”, i.e. a comma, which is curved, instead of a period, which would signify a full stop. i.e. Kendrick doesn’t stop!

  • His use of “letter” not only emphasizes that each and every character he writes is truthful, but it also refers to the fact that each verse of the song is structured as a letter, as evidenced by his sign-off and the postscripts.

  • Kendrick “lives his life in the margin”, which is literally the small blank space at the end of the lines he writes. Metaphorically he lives his life in the periphery outside the masses.

  • “Proof,” as in proofread. One often writes in the margin of the page when he or she is proofreading. But also, a mathematical ‘proof’ to show the answer and conclusion to your equation. Looks like Kendrick’s equation here is sound…

lyrics: Walk out the door and they scream it's alive
annotation:
In the movie “Frankenstein”, in which the mad scientist has created a monster, he yells “It’s Alive!” when he finally awakens. Perhaps Kendrick is portraying himself as a monster (in a good way).

Fans have the same reaction listening to Kendrick’s music. They scream “it’s alive”, because their faith has been restored that hip-hop still lives with Kendrick Lamar.

lyrics:
If I told you that a flower bloomed in a dark room
Would you trust it?
annotation:
The “flower” is Kendrick and the dark room is his hometown, Compton. Plants (flowering or otherwise) require exposure to light to grow, as they use the energy from that light to transform carbon dioxide into sugars (that the plant feeds on) and oxygen.

Kendrick asks the girl if she trusts him and believes that he turned out to be a good and decent man despite the fact that he grew up in a hood riddled with violence and gang warfare, knowing it seems difficult to believe this is possible.

The reiteration of this line from the first verse suggests an emphasis on the figurative idea of trust in relation to the flower.

This could also be metaphoric to love between two people blooming in an unorthodox way; a one night stand or in a club, both physically and metaphorically darker places.

Also, during the flowering phase of marijuana or its blooming, it is said that one method is to give the plant only 11 hours of light through the day and leave in darkness for the rest.In the end this marijuana has many clinical and recreation uses. Kendrick could be refering to this and that just like this flower(marijuana) that grows in the dark, he did too in Compton.

lyrics:
My New Year's resolution is to stop all the pollution
Talk too motherfuckin' much, I got my drink, I got my music
annotation:
Kendrick’s “resolution” or new focus in his career is to stop whack rappers from polluting the music industry with inferior content.

“Stop all the pollution / Talk too motherfucking much” is homophonically phrased as “Stop all the poll-you-shouldn’t talk too motherfucking much.” The second meaning being he doesn’t want to hear you so that he can stay in his vibe – a lyrical bridge to help him get back to the meaning of the chorus.

lyrics:
I mean, you need to hear this
Love is not just a verb, it's you lookin' in the mirror
Love is not just a verb, it's you lookin' for it, maybe
annotation:
Love is not just sex, and love is way more than an action or feeling, it is many things.

Kendrick uses 2 analogies to cut some of the ambiguity: It’s looking in the mirror, loving thyself, and it’s actively looking for it, rather than waiting for it to come.
*In other words, you have to do some soul searching to find out what it means to you personally.

Another track from GKMC, “Real,” expounds in its entirety on this motif of what love is and is not, with the key connecting lyric being:

But what’s love got to do with it when you don’t love yourself

Love is not just something that happens, in order to really love another person, you have to be willing to be honest about who you are, what you do, and why you do it. If you’re not willing to own what you do and who you are you cannot truly love a person fully, it’s selfish. Love doesn’t just happen, you have to be open to it.

lyrics: [Death to Molly]
annotation:
In the “Bitch Don’t Kill My Vibe” music video, the string ensemble that plays during the outro is cut off with a black shot with the text: Death to Molly.

Molly is the purest form of ecstasy, usually given as a free powder or contained in a capsule. MDMA is consistently mentioned in contemporary rap, be it most humorously referenced by Trinidad James in the legendary:

Popped a Molly I’m sweating (woo!)

However it has also got artists in hot water, on Rocko’s “U.O.E.N.O.”, which features rapper Rick Ross, he rhymes:

Put Molly all in her champagne, she ain’t even know it
I took her home and I enjoyed that, she ain’t even know it"

Ross, who also remixed this Kendrick classic, has had his endorsement deal with Reebok dropped as as result of these lyrics.

Kendrick spoke on wanting to kill the Molly trend in hip-hop:

Sometimes you have the trends that’s not that cool. You may have certain artists portraying these trends and don’t really have that lifestyle and then it gives off the wrong thing. And it becomes kinda corny after a while. When everybody consciously now uses this term or this phrase and putting it in lyrics, it waters the culture down. So it’s really just time to move on. It’s really about keeping hip-hop original and pushing away the corniness in it.

lyrics: A fatal attraction is common, and what we have common is pain
annotation:
A “fatal attraction” is a situation where a spurned partner in a romance turns vengeful, often murderous.

There is some wordplay here as well: something “fatal” can be causative of death and therefore “pain,” which is what they have in common.

Referring back to Sherane, the fatal attraction that left pain along with other nameless painful upbringings has made them meant for each other.

This could also plead reference to a 1987 thriller-romance called Fatal Attraction, where an insane woman comes back to haunt her lover in scornful revenge.

lyrics:
[Outro]
Ayy, K-Dot, get in the car, nigga!
Come on, we finna roll out!
Nigga, I got a pack of blacks and a beat CD
Get yo' freestyles ready!
annotation:
Continuing good kid, m.A.A.d city’s narrative, Kendrick’s homies pick him up in their white Toyota with a “pack of blacks and a beat CD"—that is, Black & Mild cigars and an playlist of instrumentals. The word ‘'finna’‘ is also a slang of ’‘gonna’‘.

Presumably they’re about to rap in the vehicle, a segue into the album’s next track “Backseat Freestyle.”

lyrics: I mean, you need to hear this, love is not just a verb
annotation:
People need to realise love just doesn’t happen. Again with the emphasis on hearing possibly the key line in the song. Tell that to John Mayer.

See “Real” from good kid, m.A.A.d. city for an expounding on this repetitive lyric.

Love is also a noun, not just a verb. Cheers, Professor K Dot.

lyrics:
And I can see power steerin', sex drive when you swerve
I want that interference, it's coherent, I can hear it
annotation:
Power steering = troubles
Sex drive when she swerves = Horny girl when she drinks
Interference = He wants to take care of the troubles

The girl is troubled and resorts to alcohol as a solution, but Kendrick believes he’s all she needs. It also could mean the way she rides the D, it’s like she’s power steering it. She “swerves” or i.e. she can ride a mean dick.

Her interfering signals, (moans), are clear, which brings us to the Wave theory: Coherence is a special property of waves, (in this case sound waves), which makes it possible for the waves to interfere in a unique way with each other. In the lyrics, he hears her coherent moaning sounds interfere, (he perceives them louder than a ordinary moan).

Sex Drive is also a reference to fellow Black Hippy member Schoolboy Q’s track of that name which came out a few months before GKMC.

lyrics:
Uh-huh, that's your heartbeat
It either caught me or it called me, uh-huh
annotation:
The ‘mmhmm’ and drums in the back play to the sound of her heart beating and him hearing it.

Kendrick seems to be very driven by “The Heart”

lyrics: Read slow and you'll find gold mines in these lines
annotation:
The depth of these lyrics are figurative gold mines as they produce invaluable, mental treasures.

A common saying goes: Gold is where you find it

The topic of gold being within Kendrick’s lines also was referenced back in an other line.

lyrics: Sincerely, yours truly,
annotation:
“Sincerely” and “Yours truly” are two common endings to letters. However, collectively, the line itself could be interpreted in two ways:
Sincerely, yours truly (yours truly being Kendrick)… and
Sincerely yours, truly (meaning that he truly means that he wants to love her and her only)

lyrics: and right before you go blind,
annotation:
Allusion to the popular statement “Love is blind.” Kendrick uses this statement to tie together the theme of love that is present in this verse.

It can also mean write back before she goes blind from love.

This line ties together the 2Pac references throughout with a subtle nod to Pac’s line, “when I write rhymes I go blind and let the Lord do his thing”.

Further, he’s referencing the common phrase “justice is blind,” meaning that truth and justice will be meted out without bias.

lyrics: P.S
annotation: P.S. or postscript is writing added after the main body of a letter. The term comes from the Latin post scriptum, an expression meaning “written after” and used here, again, to segue into the following hook and skit.

lyrics:
[Outro Skit]
"I'm gon' ask you one more time, homie
Where is you from? Or it is a problem."
"Ayy, you over here for Sherane, homie?"
"Yo, I don't care who this nigga over here for
If he don't tell me where he from, it's a wrap! I'm sorry."
"Hol' up, hol' up, hol' up, we gon' do it like this, okay?
I'ma tell you where I'm from, okay?
You gon' tell me where you from, okay?
Or where your grandma stay, where your mama stay, or where your daddy stay, okay?"
"Enough with all this talkin'."
"Matter of fact, get out the van, homie! Get out the car before I snatch you out that motherfucker, homie!"
annotation:
This skit links back to the final line of “Sherane a.k.a. Master Splinter’s Daughter,” where K.dot was on his way to Sherane’s house but got stopped by two guys in black hoodies. The ghostly vocal sample from “Sherane” plays over the opening of the skit, signifying the return to “present day,” and the end of the extended flashback that began with the skit at the end of “Bitch, Don’t Kill My Vibe.”

The conversation follows the two hooded guys interrogating Kendrick because they don’t like that he’s on their turf, and are definitely not a fan of his relationship with Sherane. Kendrick is obviously staying in the van and silent trying to avoid confrontation but it doesn’t go down like that…

He finds himself away from his hood, his desire of meeting with Sherane can’t be fulfilled because he’s blocked by these two guys who don’t recognize him from around there.

This skit appears to depict the introduction of the track “m.A.A.d city” in where ScHoolboy Q asks the same questions of “Where you from” and “Where you stay.” They both appear to be similar depictions of the same incident, however, the version in this song is much more realistic and sounds as if it was captured on a tape recorder.

lyrics:
New Kung Fu Kenny
Ain't nobody prayin' for me
annotation:
“Kung Fu Kenny” is one of Kendrick’s monikers. He previously crowned himself “Cornrow Kenny” on 2016’s “untitled 02 | 06.23.2014.”

The Chinese term “kung fu” originally referred to any skill or discipline achieved through diligence, but now it’s an umbrella term for Chinese martial arts in the Western world. Kendrick first used the name on the March 2017 Mike WiLL track “Perfect Pint”:

Kung Fu Kenny, look look
Who the fuck you talkin' to? You maney (You maney)

In an April 2017 interview with Pitchfork, Don Cheadle revealed that Kung Fu Kenny was inspired by his character, Kenny, from Rush Hour 2. Cheadle also stars in the video for Kendrick’s song “DNA.”

lyrics:
I'm willin' to die for this shit
I done cried for this shit, might take a life for this shit
annotation:
Kendrick cried when the OGs of West Coast hip-hop—Snoop Dogg, Kurupt, Game and Dr. Dre—passed him the torch in August 2013 and made him responsible for continuing their legacy.

“Take a life” could be a metaphor for lyrically destroying another MC, but on “The Heart Part 4,” he admitted that his ambition and drive could make him literally shoot someone:

I ain’t sanctified enough to say that I won’t shoot ya

lyrics: Put the Bible down and go eye for an eye for this shit
annotation:
The phrase “eye for an eye” comes from the Code of Hammurabi laws, written in roughly 1754 B.C.

It is quoted in the Bible in Exodus 21:23-25, but Jesus was actually against it:

You have heard that it was said, ‘An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.’ But I tell you not to resist an evildoer. On the contrary, whoever slaps you on the right cheek, turn the other to him as well.

Instead of turning the other cheek, Kendrick will slap his antagonists and make it look sexy.

lyrics: D-O-T my enemy, won't catch a vibe for this shit, ayy
annotation:
One of Kendrick’s first stage names was K. Dot. His work prior to DAMN. was conscious and thought provoking, but he’s considering returning to his old ways to kill his opponents' careers.

He could also be spelling out “dot,” as in red dot sight—an aiming mechanism that can be equipped on firearms. Such imagery draws parallels to the video for “HUMBLE.”

lyrics: [Produced by Boi-1da & Koz]
annotation:
Although the liner notes don’t credit any samples, the main drum part of “The Blacker the Berry” certainly comes from the Cold Grits record, “It’s Your Thing”:

The same was used by Kanye West on his songs “Crack Music” and “Power.”

The jazzy outro was produced by Terrace Martin.

Instrumentalists for the outro include: Ronald Bruner, Jr. on the drums, Robert Glasper on the keys, Thundercat on bass guitar, Terrace Martin on alto saxophone, and Larrance Dopson with percussion. Background vocals were provided by Lalah Hathaway, who was sampled earlier on the album, on the song “Momma.”

The liner notes also credit production duo Katalyst with additional drum programming and engineering.

In a 2016 interview with Noisey, Boi-1da details how he came to work with Kendrick Lamar:

I’ve known Kendrick for a while pretty much before everything started happening with him. My good friend named Manny Smith that works at Interscope kind of put me on Kendrick before he really even transcended to where he is now. I’ve always had a cool relationship with him but Manny [Smith] just put us together. We just did a bunch of tracks, I was in with Kendrick for maybe a week and it was just really fun to work with him. He’s a great guy and he has a lot of energy in the studio. That was a joint that I had from before but I ended up playing it for him and he really liked that one. He said he had an idea for it so he did his thing on that one.

lyrics: I been stomped out in front of my mama
annotation:
In a June 2017 interview, Kendrick told Big Boy that he was stomped out by three or four guys at the Avalon Swap Meet in Los Angeles. He was 15 years old at the time. The guys ran when they saw his mother witnessing the altercation:

Kendrick has also admitted to being beat up on other songs. On his 2010 track, “Average Joe,” he rapped:

Got jumped, got jacked, shot at, shot back

The outro skit on 2012’s “Swimming Pools,” established he was stomped out after a woman he met at a party named Sherane set him up. Coincidentally, his dad was also threatening to stomp him out for losing his dominoes while he was being jumped at Sherane’s house:

Keep losing my damn dominoes and we gone have to go in the backyard, and squab homie

lyrics: [Intro: Kendrick Lamar & (Lalah Hathaway)]
annotation:
The intro vocals are performed by Lalah Hathaway, a three-time Grammy award winning neo-soul singer from Chicago, and the daughter of soul music legend Donny Hathaway.

She also provided background vocals on “Complexion” and “Momma”–the latter she helped to write.

lyrics: My daddy commissary made it to commas
annotation:
A prison commissary is a convenience store of sorts within a prison complex catering to the basic needs of the inmates—hygiene products, snacks, stationery, etc. An inmate’s commissary account is funded by contributions from friends and family and/or wages earned working within the prison.

Kendrick’s probably referring to how he’s put so much money in his dad’s “commissary” that the amount has “commas,” a.k.a. hundreds of thousands of dollars.

In a 2015 interview with Rolling Stone, author Josh Eells wrote about Kendrick’s financial situation growing up:

The Duckworths survived on welfare and food stamps, and Paula did hair for $20 a head. His dad had a job at KFC, but at a certain point, says Lamar, ‘I realized his work schedule wasn’t really adding up.’ It wasn’t until later that he suspected Kenny was probably making money off the streets.

lyrics:
Everything black, I don't want black (They want us to bow)
I want everything black, I ain't need black (Down to our knees)
Some white, some black, I ain't mean black (And pray to the God)
I want everything black (We don't believe)
Everything black, want all things black
I don't need black, want everything black
Don't need black, our eyes ain't black
I own black, own everything black
annotation:
Kendrick’s monologue describes the struggles faced by African Americans in modern society and the frustration that comes with wanting and deserving more than you have.

The backing vocals suggest that American society wants African Americans to submit to it and praise it, even though many of them have suffered from it.

lyrics:
Bitch, all my grandmas dead
So ain't nobody prayin' for me, I'm on your head, ayy
annotation:
Kendrick’s grandmother was important to him and his family. He touched on her passing on his 2010 song “Cut You Off (To Grow Closer)”:

Ever since grandma died, everyone parted ways
Argue on holidays, left my uncle in prison
For 15 years, no one paid him attention but moms
Yeah, my momma as loyal as any sister would come

The hook from his 2015 song “Institutionalized” is also sung from his grandmother’s perspective. It offers advice on how to change something for the better.

lyrics:
Six in the morn', fire in the street
Burn, baby, burn, that's all I wanna see
And sometimes I get off watchin' you die in vain
annotation:
Kendrick describes a riot situation while paying homage to West Coast legends Ice-T and DJ Magnificent Montague.

Ice-T’s 1986 song “6 ‘N The Mornin’” depicts Ice escaping from police after they arrive on his doorstep at 6am. He begins the song with:

Six in the morning, police at my door…

Ice went on to release a prequel titled “Midnight” in 1991, which ended with the lyrics:

Looked at my watch, it was six in the morning…

“Burn, baby, burn” was the catchphrase (and subsequent autobiography) of soul DJ Magnificent Montague. It inadvertently became the rally cry of the 1965 Watts riots—another historic moment of urban unrest close to Lamar’s native Compton.

The “you, you, you” ad-lib also appears on Kendrick’s “The Art of Peer Pressure.”

lyrics:
Thirty millions later, know the feds watchin'
Auntie on my Telegram like, "Be cautious!"
annotation:
In 2016, Forbes estimated Kendrick had made over $30 million in total career earnings. Kendrick also mentioned his $30 million earnings on “The Heart Part 4.”

The FBI’s war against the black community has been well documented, and it’s been speculated they target rich, young black males because they’re unsure if they acquired their currency through legal means. Telegram is a popular encrypted messaging app used to thwart government surveillance.

lyrics: [Intro: Mr. Talkbox]
annotation:
The intro to “LOYALTY.” is a sped up, chopped, reversed, and pitched up sample of the intro to Bruno Mars’s song “24K Magic,” sung by Mr. Talkbox. By sampling “24K Magic,” a song about opulence and partying, it could signify that he feels as though his girl’s loyalty lies within wealth rather than in him.

Unscrambled, the lyrics read:

You higher
Tonight
Throw your hands up in the sky
I just want to take you higher
Tonight

This was the sampling process:

lyrics:
It's such a shame they may call me crazy
They may say I suffer from schizophrenia or somethin'
But homie, you made me
Black don't crack, my nigga
annotation:
Both Azealia Banks and Kid Cudi criticized Lamar for his opinion on the 2014 events in Ferguson following the lethal shooting of Mike Brown, but Kendrick believes that “black don’t crack”—a phrase normally pertaining to naturally radiant skin, but denoting ‘thick skin’ of a metaphorical nature in this instance.

Critics might accuse Kendrick of a schizophrenic break with reality, as “phrēn” refers to the mind and “schizein” means to split or crack, but Kendrick insists that his mind is sound and dismissing his words would be a mistake; after all, “you” (America) made him.

Lamar may also be evoking the idea of “double consciousness"—an idea first formulated by the scholar and political organizer W.E.B. Du Bois in his influential book The Souls of Black Folk.

lyrics: I be hangin' out at Tam's, I be on Stockton
annotation:
Tam’s Burgers is a fast food restaurant chain located throughout Southern California. Kendrick is likely referencing Tam’s #21 in Compton; he told Nardwuar in 2012 he gets chili cheese fries there.

In 2012, K.Dot told Complex:

Everybody loves In-N-Out, but it’s a very clean-cut burger. Tam’s is street-sloppy, burgers and shakes. It’s a chain, but it’s still hood.

Kendrick can also be seen kicking it at Tam’s with Dr. Dre and Ice Cube in the Straight Outta Compton red-band trailer.

The Compton Swap Meet, also known as the Compton Fashion Center, was located on East Stockton Street and Long Beach Boulevard. Kendrick dances on its roof in the “King Kunta” video. It closed in 2015 and was replaced with a Walmart.

Kendrick continues to stress that he isn’t far removed from where he grew up. Even with his fame and fortune he’s still down to earth.

lyrics:
I said I'm geeked and I’m fired up (Fired, fire)
All I want tonight is just get high (High, high, high)
Girl, you look so good, it's to die for (Die for)
Ooh, that pussy good, it's to die for (In fire)
annotation:
“Geeked” means to be high on drugs, while “Girl, you look so good, it’s to die for” was probably inspired by the hyperbolic idiom “dressed to kill"—the girl referenced here looks so good that it’s literally a cause for death.

Kendrick expresses his love for a woman’s “pussy” in the same way on DAMN.’s lead single, “HUMBLE.”:

Ooh, that pussy good, won’t you sit it on my taste bloods?

It’s also a callback to Kendrick’s feature on Travis Scott’s “goosebumps”:

Put the pussy on a pedestal
Put the pussy on a high horse
That pussy to die for
That pussy to die for

lyrics: [Verse 1: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation:
Kendrick started writing this song in 2012, immediately after the murder of Trayvon Martin. This was confirmed in an interesting article by Rolling Stone:

About three years ago, Lamar was flipping through the channels on his tour bus when he saw on the news a report that a 16-year-old named Trayvon Martin had been shot to death in a Florida subdivision. “It just put a whole new anger inside me,” Lamar says. “It made me remember how I felt. Being harassed, my partners being killed.” He grabbed a pen and started writing, and within an hour, he had rough verses for a new song, “The Blacker the Berry”:

“Coming from the bottom of mankind

My hair is nappy, my dick is big

My nose is round and wide

You hate me, don’t you?

You hate my people

Your plan is to terminate my culture. . . .“

lyrics: I don't do it for the 'Gram, I do it for Compton
annotation:
“‘Gram” is short for Instagram. Kendrick is motivated to make improvements to his city, rather than impress his Instagram followers. He made it clear when he featured on Big Sean’s 2013 song “Control”:

Your Instagram can gobble these nuts

Senator Isadore Hall III praised what Kendrick does for Compton by naming him the 35th Senate District’s Generational Icon in 2015:

Lamar’s donations totaled hundreds of thousands of dollars for sports, after-school, music and other programs.

“Do it for the ‘Gram” stems from the original phrase “Do it for the Vine,” which Aniya Smith popularized in 2014.

lyrics:
It’s a secret society
All we ask is trust (All we ask is trust)
All we got is us
Loyalty, loyalty, loyalty
Loyalty, loyalty, loyalty
annotation:
Kendrick interpolates JAY-Z’s infamous Roc-A-Fella Records maxim from 2000’s “Get Your Mind Right Mami,” a line he previously utilized on 2010’s “The Heart Part 2”:

It’s a secret society, all we ask is trust

A “secret society” is an organization whose members are expected to have full confidentiality about its activities. You have to be loyal to be welcomed into Kendrick and Rihanna’s inner circle.

Later on the album, Kendrick shows how important trust is on “LOVE”:

Keep it a hundred, I’d rather you trust me than to love me

And on “For Sale?” from Kendrick’s 2015 album To Pimp A Butterfly, the devil asks for these exact things from him:

Lucy just want your trust and loyalty

lyrics:
I'm the biggest hypocrite of 2015
Once I finish this, witnesses will convey just what I mean
annotation:
Kendrick begins every verse with the point of view of an African-American angered by the destruction of black lives. Similar to “i”, Kendrick speaks to an individual mindset. Those who condemn white-on-black violence but are also violent within their own communities, might need to step back and re-evaluate their own actions.

It isn’t until the very final lines of the song that Kendrick reveals why his outrage over violence towards young black men is hypocritical.

lyrics:
I'm willin' to die for this shit, nigga
I'll take your fuckin' life for this shit, nigga
We ain't goin' back to broke, family sellin' dope
That's why you maney-ass rap niggas better know
annotation:
These lyrics emphasize that for both Kendrick and anybody who challenges him, the stakes are life and death.

“Maney” is term used in the Bay Area of Northern California. It’s a shorthand version of the word “maniac,” and an alternative way of saying “weird” or “crazy.”

Kendrick alludes to his father hustling later in the album on “DUCKWORTH.,” rapping:

He worked the window, his name was Ducky
He came from the streets, the Robert Taylor Homes
Southside Projects, Chiraq, the Terror Dome
Drove to California with a woman on him and 500 dollars
They had a son, hopin' that he’d see college
Hustlin' on the side with a nine-to-five to freak it

lyrics: Kung Fu Kenny now
annotation:
“Kung Fu Kenny” is one of Kendrick’s monikers, which he called himself on Mike WiLL Made-It’s March 2017 song “Perfect Pint”. He previously dubbed himself “Cornrow Kenny” on 2016’s “untitled 02 | 06.23.2014.”

In an April 2017 interview with Pitchfork, Don Cheadle revealed that Kung Fu Kenny was inspired by his character, Kenny, from the movie Rush Hour 2. Cheadle also stars in the video for Kendrick’s song “DNA.”

Kendrick recently had the acclaimed jeweler Ben Baller make him a grill that reads “Kung Fu Kenny.”

lyrics:
Been feeling this way since I was 16, came to my senses
You never liked us anyway, fuck your friendship, I meant it
I'm African-American, I'm African
I'm black as the moon, heritage of a small village
annotation:
If I told you I killed a nigga at 16, would you believe me?

Kendrick explores what it means to be black in today’s society. He refers to himself as an African American, but retracts the last word, expressing himself as an African (like Zulus and Xhosas) – not really a part of (white) America.

Kendrick knows that Black History Month is just a political “necessity” rather than a true national celebration. Just as the dark side of the moon is never lit up, the real face of black culture is never seen in today’s America.

This may also be a nod to Black Moon, a 90s NYC hip hop collective.

lyrics:
If I gotta slap a pussy-ass nigga, I'ma make it look sexy
If I gotta go hard on a bitch, I'ma make it look sexy
I pull up, hop out, air out, made it look sexy
They won't take me out my element
Nah, take me out my element
annotation:
Kendrick’s a unique artist who can effortlessly intertwine and interchange hard hitting lyrics with a concept, social message and great music—no matter what he does, he’ll be the best at it; even if he has to assert his dominance through violent measures.

Kendrick throws subliminal insults throughout the song. To “air out” is slang for leaving someone or something left with bullet holes.

“I pull up, hop out, air out, made it look sexy” is a reference to a car with adjustable suspension, so when he pulls up and hops out, he “airs out” his ride—which lowers the car and eliminates wheel gap for a clean (sexy) look.

lyrics: [Produced by Pharrell Williams & Sounwave]
annotation:
“Alright” was produced by Pharrell Williams and TDE exclusive in-house producer, Sounwave. The track also features Terrace Martin on alto sax and Pharrell, Candace Wakefield, and Thundercat on background vocals.

While there are no credited samples, the background vocals sound very similar to those on “Presidential,” which Pharrell produced for Rick Ross' album, God Forgives, I Don’t.

Further details on the album’s credits can be found in the liner notes.

In an interview with SPIN Sounwave discussed the making of the beat:

That beat… I don’t think Pharrell was even going to play it for us, but one of his close friends, [who is also] of our close friends who set up the session, was like, “Pharrell, you gotta play them that beat.” And he played it for Kendrick, and it was there, but it was not all there, vibe-wise, so that was my job to layer in the drums, get Terrace [Martin] to throw some sax riffs on it, and make it us. It’s a completely different song than the original…you’d understand if you were able to compare them, but that’s probably never gonna happen. You just have to have your ears open for every little sound that has potential.

If you’re interested in exactly how this beat was made, here’s a cool video breakdown:

Fun Fact: Pharrell also produced Kendrick’s “good kid” and Sounwave was given production credits on “m.A.A.d city.”. These two tracks combined make up the title of Kendrick’s sophomore album, good kid, m.A.A.d city. Additionally “good kid” and “Alright” are both track 7 on their respective albums.

lyrics:
My resume is real enough for two millenniums
A better way to make a wave, stop defendin' them
annotation:
A millennium is 1,000 years—Kendrick’s saying that his music lives on through time. 2015’s To Pimp a Butterfly holds the highest critic score by a rap album ever, while good kid, m.A.A.d. city is considered a modern classic.

Kendrick may also be comparing his influence to that of Jesus Christ, since we measure time according to the birth of Christ in Christianity and we’re in the second millennium thereafter.

lyrics:
Pardon my residence
Came from the bottom of mankind
My hair is nappy, my dick is big, my nose is round and wide
annotation:
Kendrick plays on different meanings of “the bottom of mankind” and research suggests all modern humans descended from Africa.

Reiterating his point, Kendrick lists typical physical characteristics associated with Africans in order to describe his ancestry–the preceding line “pardon my residence” (i.e. excuse my blackness) frames the proceeding rhetorical question: “you hate me don’t you.”

According to Kendrick’s interview with Rolling Stone, he first wrote these lines in his frustration after seeing the news of Trayvon Martin’s death on TV.

lyrics:
I'm allergic to a bitch nigga, ayy
An imaginary rich nigga, ayy
Seven figures ho, that's slimmer than my bitch figure, ayy
annotation:
Kendrick is comparing his own wealth to that of others. If someone has “seven figures,” they have more than a million dollars. Kendrick mocks people who think they are rich after they become millionaires, saying they are “imaginary rich.” On “The Heart Part 4,” Kendrick bragged of having earned more than 30 million dollars:

Thirty millions later, my future favors
The legendary status of a hip-hop rhyme savior

He also plays on the word “figure,” which can mean a number or a person’s bodily shape. An hourglass body shape is reminiscent of a figure eight; the number 7 is literally smaller than the number 8.

lyrics: [Directed by Colin Tilley]
annotation:
Director, Colin Tilley, worked in collaboration with Kendrick and president of TDE, Dave Free, in developing the concepts for the ‘Alright’ music video.

In a interview with MTV, Tilley answers the many questions watching this video leaves us wondering and speaks on what it was like working with Kendrick:

As the concept continued to develop, I had a lot of great conversations with Kendrick and Dave. We just kept hammering the concept home to really keep digging deeper and deeper. I’ve never actually worked with an artist like Kendrick that wants to keep pushing the creative to a whole ‘nother world. Every little detail matters to him. So, it was really fun to continue to mold the concept from where we started.

The video version of the track opens with an original intro not used on the album. The intro shows Kendrick, ScHoolboy Q, Ab-Soul and Jay Rock in a car and as the the camera pans down it’s revealed that the car is being held up by four cops, like servants lifting carriage.

Tilley describes:

…all of a sudden, Kendrick was like, “Hold on, man. I’m totally hearing something completely different for this right now.” He’s like, “I’m gonna write this song and we’ll send it to you tonight. But we’ll do this song as a segment before the video even starts.” So, they sent me the song like two days later and we continued to build on it.Once you get an image that strong, everything builds from there…this is what’s real and what’s going on in the world right now.

lyrics: I meditate and moderate all of my wins again
annotation:
In his 2016 GQ interview with Rick Rubin, Kendrick discussed his use of meditation as a tool to ground himself and live in the moment:

Yeah, man. I have to have at least 30 minutes to myself. If it’s not on the daily, every other day, to just sit back, close my eyes, and absorb what’s going on. You know, the space that I’m in. When you in music—and everybody knows this—the years are always cut in half, because you always have something to do. We in the studio for four months, that go by. Now you gotta go on the road for five months, that go by. Next thing you know, five years going by and you 29 years old. You know? So I have to find a way to understand the space that I’m in and how I’m feeling at the moment. ‘Cause if I don’t, it’s gonna zoom. I know. I feel it. And I’m sure you know what I’m talking about. It just goes and then you miss out on your moment because you’re so in the moment you didn’t know the moment was going on, if that makes sense.

Kendrick references the practice of meditation on 2015’s “Black Friday” and 2016’s “untitled 03 | 05.28.2013.,” as well as earlier in DAMN. on “DNA.”

lyrics:
You hate me don't you?
You hate my people, your plan is to terminate my culture
annotation:
Kendrick calls on his listeners to question their own feelings, towards him, his people, and his culture.

The culture Kendrick refers to is black culture. He feels like anything black people create in America is simultaneously loved for its inherent creativity as human expression, and envied/hated because it wasn’t the direct product of white consciousness.

lyrics: Goin' digital and physical on all y'all, ayy
annotation:
Over the last few years, the sales of digital copies have dominated, which has made even Billboard incorporate streams into their algorithm.

Many artists such as Kanye West with The Life of Pablo have started to move away from physical forms of albums as it can result in the album getting leaked prior to the actual release date. Kendrick is an outsider in that he claims he will still drop physical copies alongside his digital releases.

Ironically, this album leaked six hours before the official release time on April 14th, 2017 at 12:00 A.M. Another interesting point to note about DAMN’s physical and digital copies is that they are slightly different.

lyrics: [Intro: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation:
Pharrell uses his trademark intro technique: the song’s first beat is repeated four times, as if stuck on a loop, before dropping.

Here’s a list of other tracks he started in this way:

  • SWV – “Right Here (Human Nature Remix)”
  • Pharrell – “Frontin'”
  • Kelis – “Milkshake”
  • Snoop Dogg – “Drop It Like It’s Hot”
  • Robin Thicke – “Blurred Lines”
  • Shakira – “Why Wait”
  • Frank Ocean – “Sweet Life”
  • Pharrell – “Brand New”
  • Paloma Faith – “Can’t Rely On You”
  • Pharrell – “Happy”
  • Pharrell – “Hunter”
  • JAY-Z – “I Know”
  • Pharrell – “Gust of Wind”

lyrics:
I'm hangin' on the fence again
I'm always on your mind
annotation: To “sit on the fence” means to stay in the middle of two viewpoints and be unable to make a decision one way or the other. Kendrick may be alluding to the “wickedness” or “weakness” theme that runs throughout the album.

lyrics: You're fuckin' evil I want you to recognize that I'm a proud monkey
annotation:
“Monkey” is a racist slur directed towards black people who are perceived by some to be primitive and ape-like.

Instead, Kendrick embraces the word and turns it into a sense of empowerment, just as the words “nigga” and “queer” have been reclaimed by the respective communities at which they’re aimed.

Since black men broke into professional football in the 1970s, they’ve had bananas thrown at them by racists in the crowd. Barcelona full back Dani Alves reacted so well to it in 2014 that people started tweeting photos of themselves eating bananas with the hashtag #WeAreAllMonkeys (in Portuguese #SomosTodosMacacos).

lyrics:
We okay, we let the A1 fly
Relocate, jump on the same G5
annotation: “A1” is a term used to describe something that is top quality or of the highest classification; both A and 1 can represent the highest value in their respective categories (with the exception of a monetary value in the case of the latter). Kendrick’s bragging about the success of his music. His A1 rhymes earned him the luxury of travelling on “G5" Gulfstream G550 Business jets.

lyrics:
Alls my life I has to fight, nigga
Alls my life I...
annotation:
Kendrick starts the track with a reference to Alice Walker’s Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, The Color Purple:

All my life I had to fight. I had to fight my daddy. I had to fight my brothers. I had to fight my cousins and my uncles. A girl child ain’t safe in a family of men. But I never thought I’d have to fight in my own house. She let out her breath. I loves Harpo, she say. God knows I do. But I’ll kill him dead before I let him beat me.

This reference was also made famous by Oprah Winfrey’s portrayal of Sofia in the film adaptation of the novel:

Kendrick is referring to his own fight with depression – how not even money can stop a suicidal weakness.

In a 2018 interview with Ari Melber, on the MSNBC show “The Beat with Ari Melber,” Alice Walker reacted and responded to Lamar quoting her work:

lyrics:
I put my lyric and my lifeline on the line
And ain't no limit when I might shine, might grind
annotation:
In an April 2015 interview with MTV, Kendrick explained his release therapy is writing music. His life is music, and he sacrifices himself to get a message out.

Kendrick is dedicated to working on his music constantly, something he acknowledged in a February 2016 interview with the Recording Academy about his 11 nominations for the 58th Grammy Awards:

I knew I had to sit in the studio for a year or so process and just create, not letting no type of boundary stop me from doing what I’m doing. And that goes for the concepts. That goes for the writing process. That goes for throwing ideas on the wall [to] see if they stick, and different flows. Speaking on things that I feel like people don’t have voices can speak on.

lyrics: You vandalize my perception but can't take style from me
annotation: Kendrick addresses the appropriation of black culture in mainstream media. While they portray Kendrick as a “rapper”, he feels more like a writer or poet. This appropriation of black culture is rampant, but even so, Kendrick cannot be persuaded or bought.

lyrics:
Years in the makin', and don't y'all mistake it
I got 'em by a landslide, we talkin' about races
You know this'll never be a tie, just look at they laces
You know careers take off, just gotta be patient
annotation:
While Kendrick’s career didn’t reach the mainstream until 2012’s good kid, m.A.A.d city, he’s been rapping since he was 16. He released his first mixtape Y.H.N.I.C. (Hub City Threat: Minor of the Year) in 2003.

It’s common in the rap world to see loose or untied sneaker and boot laces, which may look cool but also make a person less ready to run. Kendrick may be saying that this reflects that many of his competitors value a fashionable appearance over practicality and utility. Such a superficial opponent is no match for someone who prioritizes developing his skills above all else. Comparing the rap game to a race, Kendrick implies that other rappers simply aren’t prepared to best someone with his mindset.

The idea of maintaining patient relentlessness in the pursuit of important goals, as one would in a long-distance race, is a well established trope in literature and hip-hop in particular. Drake, Dilated Peoples, Wiz Khalifa, GZA and G-Easy are just a few artists who have used the analogy.

lyrics: [Produced by Hit-Boy]
annotation:
The production has an amped up feel with hard-hitting drums and background bells. This is complemented with Kendrick’s fired up verses. “Backseat Freestyle” contains 2 samples:

  • Vocals from “Yo Soy Cubano” by The Chakachas.
  • Drums from “Good Good Night” by Roscoe Dash.

The vocals also appear on “Magic Carpet Ride” by Mighty Dub Katz, which could also be where Hit-Boy heard the sample from.

lyrics:
Hard times like, "Yah!"
Bad trips like, "Yah!"
Nazareth, I'm fucked up
Homie, you fucked up
But if God got us, then we gon' be alright
annotation:
No weapon on me shall prosper

Kendrick plays with the idea that we address God differently depending on the circumstance, but feels that with real faith on his side, nothing can harm him. Kendrick often incorporates religious imagery and ideas in his lyrics and this song is no different. Many Christians believe that God has a plan and if you’re actively a part of that plan, everything will ultimately be ok.

“We gon' be alright,” is repeated throughout the track to send a message of hope; despite the pain and suffering, in solidarity we will survive. This message is deeply associated with Black Lives Matter and the fight against police brutality of black and brown bodies. In solidarity, activists across the United States chant “We gon' be alright.”

Nazareth, Israel is reputedly where Jesus grew up, studied and prayed. It was thought to be a low, foul city and Nathaneal asked (after learning that Jesus hailed from here) “Can anything good come out of Nazareth?” (John 1:46). His hometown caused many to shun him.
Kendrick could be drawing parallels from Nazareth to his city of Compton, California.

lyrics: Bad girl RiRi now
annotation:
“Bad girl RiRi” is one of Rihanna’s monikers, and “badgalriri” is her Instagram handle.

This line follow the same structure of Kendrick’s “Kung Fu Kenny” line introducing his first verse.

lyrics:
And this is more than confession
I mean I might press the button just so you know my discretion
I'm caught in my feelings, I know that you feel it
annotation:
Kendrick threatens to go off on those who oppose him. The button symbolizes a trigger of a gun, or the “record” button in a studio – that fire off Kendrick’s feelings of aggression and hatred. It also explains that Kendrick is capable of inciting mass violence if he chooses to. His power is that he doesn’t.

He does keep most of his inner thoughts under control and the opposition knows it, even though he disclosed a lot of his mental state prior to these lines.

lyrics:
Mr. One through Five, that's the only logic
Fake my death, go to Cuba, that's the only option
annotation:
On “The Heart Part 4,” Kendrick proclaimed:

Yellin', ‘One, two, three, four, five
I am the greatest rapper alive!’
So damn great, motherfucker, I’ve died

While rappers often claim they’re among the top five best in their trade, Kendrick goes a step further—he’s good enough to occupy all five spots. This line draws similarities to KRS-One’s line from 1997’s “Step Into the World,” and Eminem’s lines from 2013’s “Evil Twin.”

2Pac died on September 13, 1996. Many conspiracy theories suggest 2Pac faked his death and moved to Cuba to escape his immense fame. Theorists believe that Pac wanted out of the spotlight as it caused him to become depressed and was resulting in threats on his life. Eminem has also mentioned this previously. Kendrick may be feeling like he’s in the same situation.

lyrics:
Uh, Martin had a dream
Martin had a dream
Kendrick have a dream
annotation:
A play on Martin Luther King, Jr’s “I Have a Dream” Speech. Martin had a dream that would defy all odds and Kendrick feels he does too.

This is brilliant satire which plays well into his criticism of gang culture, a prominent motif throughout the album. MLK Jr.’s dream was noble and visionary – black people successfully integrating into American society. Kendrick however outlines his immature youthful dream of attaining money, power, bitches, etc. The contrast between the two plays up just how immature he was when he was 16 years old and amidst the gang culture of Compton.

Side-note: It could also be a throwback reference to a line from fellow Compton MC Game’s song “Dreams”, and the influence that Game had on Kendrick’s youth.

Kendrick Lamar already mentioned Martin Luther King, Jr in “HiiiPower”.

lyrics: [Chorus: Pharrell Williams]
annotation:
Pharrell is not only a producer on the track, but he also sings the hook. This formula was also used on “good kid,” Kendrick and Pharrell’s previous collaboration

Little known fact: Pharrell originally produced this track for Fabolous who premiered his version at the “Holy Ship” rap party in 2014.

After Kendrick’s official release, Fabolous released his version of the track titled “Awwright.” Thanks to Pharrell, the two tracks have basically the same hook.

lyrics: On your pulse like it's EDM
annotation:
Rihanna plays on “pulse,” like the human heart beat. EDM (Electronic Dance Music) typically has a BPM (beats per minute) of 125-130.

Pulse is also a radio station that plays Electronic Dance Music or EDM. It started in Bondi Beach Australia and is headquartered in Los Angeles.

lyrics:
You sabotage my community, makin' a killin'
You made me a killer, emancipation of a real nigga
annotation:
As Kendrick was born into the Ronald Reagan era, the community sabotage he’s familiar with is the influx of crack cocaine into impoverished areas facilitated in part by the white-run CIA. They profited from introducing a drug that led to thousands upon thousands of killings.

Kendrick sees these killings, and the violent mentality they produce within communities and individuals, as the antithesis of what it means to be “real.”

lyrics: Damned if I do, if I don't (Yuh)
annotation:
This line may allude to John Calvin’s theory of predestination, which states that your fate is decided long before you are born—that you are destined for either Heaven or Hell regardless of your actions during life.

Kendrick Lamar touches on many religious concepts on DAMN.. On “FEAR.,” Lamar receives a voicemail from his cousin Carl Duckworth. In the voicemail, Carl Duckworth says the following:

But you have to understand this, man, that we are a cursed people Deuteronomy 28:28 says, ‘The Lord shall smite thee with madness And blindness, and astonishment of heart’
See, family, that’s why you feel like you feel
Like you got a chip on your shoulder

Kendrick Lamar seems to be applying a similar philosophy in this line. He believes that he is damned to Hell no matter what he does in life.

This line also concerns Lamar’s perceived popularity in the music industry. Though he has achieved major success, he is still a controversial figure. Kendrick Lamar’s 2015 release, To Pimp a Butterfly, touched on topics such as racism and police brutality in songs like “Alright.” Throughout DAMN., Lamar plays a clip from Fox News of two reporters speaking about the song. Here’s what they had to say:

Lamar stated his views on police brutality
With that line in the song, quote:
‘And we hate the popo, wanna kill us in the street fo’ sho'.‘
Oh please, ugh, I don’t like it

Here, Lamar demonstrates awareness of the fact that whether or not he releases a great album, he will be heavily criticized by experts and casual listeners alike.

lyrics:
All my life I want money and power
Respect my mind or die from lead shower
annotation:
Kendrick riffs on the phrase “money, power, and respect.” The word “respect” comprises the end of one line and the start of the next, adding that it’s his intellect that deserves respect.

“Lead” is used as a homonym alluding to both a shower of lead (bullets) and lead from his pencil.

Another example of this is in Ab-Soul’s track, “Black Lip Bastard,” which features Kendrick:

Lead shower, Anna Pebble hour bitch, stand the rain

“Respect My Mind” is a Hot Boyz song from their album Guerrilla Warfare. Kendrick has stated that he is a fan of theirs.

lyrics: [Verse 1: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation:
It’s clear, right away, that “Alright” is very different from the previous track, “u.” It’s more upbeat and positive, though it still deals with several serious topics. Verse two introduces the character “Lucy,” who represents the evils of the world.

It’s interesting Kendrick did not introduce Lucy until after the peak of his depression in the album (“u”) as Lucy may have been one of the main causes of his sadness in the first place.

lyrics: Been a bad bitch way before any cash came
annotation:
Rihanna points here that her wild and wreckless, unapologetic behaviour is not a product of her being rich and famous but the other way around.

It’s her confident personality what has taken her so far in her life & career, which connects with the following line in which she states “I’m established, hundred carats on my name”.

It might also be a reference to her 2014 track “Bitch Better Have My Money”.

lyrics:
The blacker the berry, the sweeter the juice
The blacker the berry, the sweeter the juice
The blacker the berry, the sweeter the juice
The blacker the berry, the bigger I shoot
annotation:
Kendrick has a modern-day take on 2Pac’s feminist anthem “Keep Ya Head Up.” While both songs have roots in Wallace Thurman’s novel The Blacker the Berry, 2Pac’s version expands on the idea that black women are beautiful and Kendrick’s version describes the turmoil all black people face, regardless of gender.

The original phrase, “the blacker the berry, the sweeter the juice,” was a positive affirmation of blackness. This phrase was also referenced by the Harlem Renaissance novelist Wallace Thurman in the title of The Blacker the Berry: A Novel of Negro Life. However, the final line of the chorus reverses this positivity by reworking the phrase as a justification for racial profiling: the assumption in the mind of the racist cop that black men carry guns and are dangerous and deserving of being shot. “The juice” in that context could mean the blood of a black person. In other words, the darker-skinned the black person is, the more likely that person is to get killed.

In the musical film Hairspray’s “Run and Tell That,” a song about racism, the phrase “the blacker the berry, the sweeter the juice” is the main hook.

lyrics:
Niggas thought they wasn't gonna see me, huh?
Niggas thought that K-Dot real life
Was the same life they see on TV, huh?
Niggas wanna flex on me and be in L.A. for free, huh?
Next time they hit the 10 freeway, we need a receipt, huh?
annotation:
The flow Kendrick employs here is reminiscent of Juvenile’s 1998 hit song “HA,” while the lyrics allude to people assuming that fame has changed him. Kendrick used this Juvenile flow before, on his 2007 song “On My Momma.”

People expect Kendrick not to be as present in Compton since he’s become rich and famous, but he’s still K-Dot, a kid from Compton trying to improve his city.

The last two lines may also be a shot at Drake. Drake featured on DJ Khaled’s 2016 song “For Free” and alluded to one of Kendrick’s previous one-liners on the track, rapping:

And like your boy from Compton said
You know this dick ain’t free!

Of course, Drake reps his hometown Toronto, but still lives in Calabasas, California, north of Los Angeles.

lyrics:
I pray my dick get big as the Eiffel Tower
So I can fuck the world for seventy-two hours
annotation: That is just me capturing the moment and being 16 and saying the most outlandish shit when you are around your homeboys or you are around whoever. You know, you really don’t care what you’re talking about. That is the type of way we used to talk. That is dope because that was me going as ignorant as possible, and they are still analyzing it as ignorant as possible and putting national stats behind it. That is funny.

lyrics:
Uh, and when I wake up
I recognize you're looking at me for the pay cut
annotation:
This reflects Kendrick’s perception of the industry; they want him solely for economic purposes, and not because they care about him. This speaks to the metaphorical significance of the album as a whole in the sense that Kendrick writes and raps for himself, rather than some type of superficial gain or yield in the industry.

This also applies to the common man; more so to African Americans who have the highest spending power in the country. Businesses are always willing to prey on black consumers to buy expensive and unnecessary items.

This point goes on to be reiterated in “untitled 03,” a b-side from To Pimp a Butterfly.

Furthermore, “pay cut” may not directly be about spending, though. The song’s frequent address to the black community suggests the phrase may also / instead means a drop in earned wages – i.e. African-Americans are the first targets.

lyrics:
I’m established, hundred carats on my name
Run the atlas, I'm a natural, I’m alright
annotation:
About a week before “Loyalty” dropped,
Rihanna announced her collaboration with iconic Swiss luxury jewelry brand Chopard, where she helped create and design a high-end jewelry collection called “Rihanna ♥︎ Chopard.” A few days after the song came out, she was spotted wearing a diamond-encrusted bodysuit while partying at Coachella.

By using the phrase “run the atlas,” Rihanna is possibly referencing Beyoncé’s “Run the World”, a 2011 anthem about female empowerment. She may also be signifying an upgrade from “running this town”—as she sang in the chorus of her 2009 JAY-Z and Kanye West collaboration—because she has since solidified her global superstardom with 213.2 million global sales of certified albums and singles as of February 2017.

lyrics: [Chorus: Assassin]
annotation:
In an interview with XXL, Assassin said he recorded the hook in a studio in Kingston, Jamaica.

This collaboration draws parallels to the recently-leaked song “Heaven Help Dem” on which Kendrick delivered a guest verse for Jamaican artist Jonathan Emile.

Producer Boi-1da said:

lyrics:
'Cause most of y'all ain't real, most of y'all gon' squeal
Most of y'all just envy, but jealousy get you killed
Most of y'all throw rocks and try to hide your hand
annotation:
These lines are directed at Kendrick’s competition; most likely Drake, Jay Electronica, or Big Sean. He has previously collaborated with all three artists: alongside Drake on his 2012 single, “Poetic Justice”; with Big Sean and Jay together, on 2013’s “Control”; and with Big Sean on DJ Khaled’s July 2016 track, “Holy Key.” All three rappers subsequently dissed Kendrick. These lines draw parallels to DAMN.’s seventh track, titled “PRIDE.”:

Love’s gonna get you killed
