But pride’s gonna be the death of you

“Throwing rocks” refers to the subliminal messages Kendrick receives from other artists—it also ties into the biblical notion of “Envy” being one of the Seven Deadly Sins, which were punishable by death or stoning. Jay Electronica used a similar line on “Exhibit C,” which was coincidentally released on September 11, 2001:

My mama told me, ‘never throw the stone and hide your hand

lyrics: [Intro: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation:
Physical Intro: Kid Capri

We still lettin' it spin, y'all
Here we go!

Kid Capri contributed vocals to four other songs on the album, namely “YAH.,” “ELEMENT.,” “XXX.” and “DUCKWORTH..” All of his vocals were introductions like this one.

In a Genius interview he talked about how he got involved in the project:

Kendrick reached out to me and asked me to come through. He sat there and told me what he was doing, what kind of album that he was making. When I thought about putting my presence on it, it made sense— it was definitely something I wanted to do… That’s how it happened, he called me and I went to a studio down in Manhattan and we just went in. This was about in January or Febuary. We didn’t really have a relationship before this; I met him maybe once or twice in different places. But this right here definitely brought us together.

lyrics: But homicide be looking at you from the face down
annotation:
Homicide is defined as the deliberate and unlawful killing of one person by another; murder.

Kendrick is referring to the countless killings of black people by police. With increased awareness around this kind of police brutality, many people of color are in a constant state of fear for their lives and the lives of their loved ones.

lyrics: I'm a savage, I'm an asshole, I'm a king
annotation:
Kendrick presents himself as a walking contradiction. How can one man be a savage, a king, and an asshole all at once? Just by being human, a message we’ve heard from him before on the Section.80 tracks “Ab-Soul’s Outro” and “Kush and Corinthians”:

I’m a loser, I’m a winner
I’m good, I’m bad, I’m a Christian, I’m a sinner
I’m humble, I’m loud, I’m righteous, I’m a killer
What I’m doing, I’m saying that I’m human, now people just

In a July 2017 DJBooth article, Miguelito drew comparisons between this line and Kendrick’s characterization in the DAMN. music videos—“savage” relates to the video for “ELEMENT.,” “asshole” relates to the video for “DNA.,” and “king” relates to the video for “HUMBLE.”

Since this line comes right after Rihanna’s verse, “I’m a savage” could be a nod to her song 2016 “Needed Me” where she sings:

Didn’t they tell you that I was a savage?

lyrics:
I said they treat me like a slave, cah' me black
Woi, we feel a whole heap of pain, cah' we black
annotation: “Black” is a racial term applied to Africans, African descendants, and many brown or dark-skinned individuals, defining them socially and culturally. Assassin explicitly connects enslavement and pain with blackness.

lyrics:
Just say his name and I promise that you'll see Candyman
Because it's all in your eyes, most of y'all tell lies
annotation:
Candyman is a 1992 horror film based on the British short story “Forbidden.” In the movie, Candyman is summoned when his name is said five times in row.

Kendrick is a West Coast artist who is heavily influenced by 2Pac, so it is likely that this line is inspired by what Pac said on “Troublesome ‘96”:

Say my name three times like Candyman
Bet I roll on yo' ass like an avalance

This may be directed at Jay Electronica, who maligned Lamar in his Periscope in 2016. Electronica called himself the Candyman on his track of the same name.

Kendrick equates himself to Candyman because if a rapper disses him, he’ll murder their career. Since Kendrick dropped his verse on “Control” in 2013 (where he shared a feature with Jay Electronica), rappers have resorted to subliminally dissing him.

lyrics:
Damn, love or lust
Damn, all of us
annotation:
“Love” is the deep, intimate affection one feels for another, while “lust” is a strictly physical desire. These lines directly nod to “LUST.,” the previous song where K-Dot touches on the superfluous amount of lust people in his position have.

Kendrick uses similar thematic opposites throughout the album, including “wickedness or weakness” on “BLOOD.” and “HUMBLE.,” and “Damned if I do, if I don’t / Goddamn us all if you won’t” on “ELEMENT.”

Kendrick used a similar lyric on “Sherane a.k.a Master Splinter’s Daughter,” the intro track from his 2012 debut, good kid, m.A.A.d city:

Love or lust, regardless, we’ll fuck cause the trife in us

lyrics: Goddamn I feel amazin', damn, I'm in the Matrix
annotation:
He’s feeling heeeella good, but it’s cloyingly artificial…

“Red or green pill, you live and you learn” as Hov once wrote. It’s also reminiscent of this line from Kendrick’s appearance on Drake’s Take Care track “Buried Alive Interlude,” with Kendrick envisioning fame as a paradise-like the matrix inside reality.

The contrast of red and blue pills in The Matrix could be evoking either the Bloods/Crips colors or the mars lights that Kendrick would have encountered daily in Compton.

He is also aware he’s in the matrix, so he knows reality is more than his ‘bitches, maserati and twenty-five lighters on my dresser’.

lyrics: What MAC-11 even boom with the bass down?
annotation:
A Mac-11 is a fully or semi-automatic gun. This line cleverly relates the “boom” sound of a firing gun to the “boom” of bass. Mac-11’s are often equipped with a sound-suppressor to minimize the noise of the gun-shot. Building off of the previous line, Kendrick might be asking, what gun fires in the absence of instigation?

Similar to how a Mac-11’s gunfire is suppressed, the truth about police brutality and institutional racism is kept hushed by the media and general public; leaving citizens unaware of this vital issue at the expense of the black community.

lyrics: Shimmy ya, shimmy ya, shimmy ya rah (Yeah)
annotation:
This is a reference to Ol' Dirty Bastard’s 1995 hit, “Shimmy Shimmy Ya.” ODB opens his first verse with:

Shimmy shimmy ya, shimmy yam, shimmy yay

A$AP Rocky interpolated the same line in “Fuckin Problems,” which featured Kendrick.

lyrics:
And man a say they put me inna chains, cah' we black
Imagine now, big gold chains full of rocks
How you no see the whip, left scars 'pon me back
But now we have a big whip parked 'pon the block
annotation:
These lines play with images of slavery in the past and African American life in the present. Black people have gone from being whipped to owning whips—or expensive and flashy cars; from being locked in chains, to wearing gold and diamond chains. Whips and chains were tools of oppression and control during slavery. Now, they represent luxury, but perhaps still tools of a different kind of oppression.

Kanye West’s June 2013 single, “New Slaves,” contains similar subject matter.

“Cah” can be interpreted as ‘cousin’ or ‘cause, as in 'because,’ and ‘pon means upon.

lyrics:
Last LP I tried to lift the black artists
But it's a difference 'tween black artists and wack artists
annotation:
In an interview with Rolling Stone, Kendrick was asked about this line and how he would describe a wack artist:

How would I define a wack artist? A wack artist uses other people’s music for their approval. We’re talking about someone that is scared to make their own voice, chases somebody else’s success and their thing, but runs away from their own thing. That’s what keeps the game watered-down. Everybody’s not going to be able to be a Kendrick Lamar. I’m not telling you to rap like me. Be you. Simple as that. I watch a lot of good artists go down like that because you’re so focused on what numbers this guy has done, and it dampers your own creativity. Which ultimately dampers the listener, because at the end of the day, it’s not for us. It’s for the person driving to their 9-to-5 that don’t feel like they wanna go to work that morning.

Kendrick’s last album (LP)—To Pimp a Butterfly—dealt with various topics, such as loving yourself, social injustices, and black empowerment.

Shifting his tone, he shows the difference between him and his competition. Kendrick tries to empower and motivate, whilst his competition is “wack” artists.

lyrics: [Chorus: Zacari & Kendrick Lamar]
annotation: I came up with that hook mid-last year, around that time, and the whole thing about that was, a lot of times when I write songs, I try to think of just phrases that people use, so it really started with the phrase, “Just give me a run for my money” and I built off of that. But then it actually turned into a song. It’s really about confidence, like give me a run for my money, and it’s about loving yourself in that way. And when I say things like, “Just love me, just love me,” it just had to do with people who used to be my friends who started acting different for stupid reasons, and it’s just me telling them, “Just love me. Love yourself. I love myself. I love you. Just love me.”

lyrics: My mind is livin' on cloud nine and this 9 is never on vacation
annotation:
Kendrick’s mind is in a state of happiness but his 9 mm handgun works overtime and never takes a day off. Despite his good feelings, the reality of his life is always grounded.

(On a side note Kendrick made a song called “Cloud 10”)

This line might be related to the 1st one too, Kendrick is living his dream and reaching his goal, he feels so good that his mind is in a state of happiness, but there is struggle everywhere. The human contradiction (good/evil, red pill/blue pill) once again.

lyrics:
Schemin', and let me tell you 'bout my life
Painkillers only put me in the twilight
Where pretty pussy and Benjamin is the highlight
annotation:
Kendrick finds only temporary bliss from drugs, women, and money.

Benjamin Franklin’s face is on the $100 bill which represents Kendrick’s monetary temptations.

lyrics: Ain’t no other love like the one I know
annotation:
Kendrick practices what he preaches. He’s been with his fiancée Whitney Alford since high school and the two got engaged in 2015.

In a 2015 interview with The Breakfast Club, Kendrick stated:

I’m loyal to the soil. At the end of the day, you want to always have real people around you. Period. Whether it’s male or female. Everybody that’s been around me, they’ve been around since day one.

lyrics:
All them say we doomed from the start, cah' we black
Remember this, every race start from the block, jus 'member dat
annotation: Note that Assassin uses his Patois accent to perform a double entendre. He pronounces black and block almost identically and uses two meanings of the word race. It is believed that the first humans originated in Africa, as Kendrick alludes to in verse one. In other words, every ethnicity originated in Africa. Those lines also tie in with track and field, because runners begin on a starting “block.”

lyrics:
Give me a run for my money
There is nobody, no one to outrun me
annotation: This isn’t directed at a certain person or a group or people, it’s just my music in general. I’m talking about my music and my songs, and challenging artists in music. I’m looking for artists to make stuff that’s new. I’m looking for people to not make things that sound like other things. A lot of people go into the studio and think, “Yo, we should make a song like this, or yo we should do it like this.” To me, I just see a lot of artists doing the same things.

lyrics: Start up that Maserati and – vroom-vroom! – I'm racin'
annotation:
Kendrick knows his car sounds like a T-Rex.

Oddly, it is unlike Kendrick to talk about materialistic items like Maseratis. This song depicts a young, ignorant Kendrick Lamar, freestyling in the backseat of his friends car. He is full of typically excessive indulgence, reflecting society and the filling of youth with false ideals.

lyrics:
Now tell my momma I love her, but this what I like, Lord knows
Twenty of 'em in my Chevy, tell 'em all to come and get me
Reaping everything I sow, so my karma come in heaven
No preliminary hearings on my record
I'm a motherfucking gangster in silence for the record, uh
annotation:
Kendrick has a lot of love for his mother and feels he might be disappointing her by giving in to his vices. He wants her to understand that he knows what he’s doing—he realizes his sinful ways will come back to haunt him.

To “reap what you sow” (Galatians 6:7-10) means you get what you give. Bad karma catches up to him and he fears he will be denied from Heaven, a recurring theme on the album.

Since there’s no “preliminary hearing,” he will let karma deal with him while he leaves his gang out of it. They don’t have to talk or testify and will thus remain silent.

lyrics:
Loyalty, loyalty, loyalty
Loyalty, loyalty, loyalty
10-4, no switchin' sides
annotation:
“10-4” is police ten-code meaning “understood”; Kendrick is asking his girl if she understands there is “no switchin' sides” once she sides with him.

Also, ‘10’ and ‘4’ are on opposite sides of a clock. Perhaps Kendrick is warning her not to pull a 180°.

lyrics: I mean, it's evident that I'm irrelevant to society
annotation:
American society has made it brutally obvious over the course of its history that African Americans are irrelevant. One such example is in the eyes of the law. In 2014, a string of police killings of black men sparked the #blacklivesmatter movement. Yet even these recent protests for justice have had to fight commercial events like the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade for attention.

However, the law is but one example of the struggle faced by African Americans. Schools setting up young black men to fail, gun violence being the leading cause of death in black children, and the blatant racism in corporate America are just some of the issues they face.

lyrics:
Yeah
7:30 in the night, yeah
Ooh-oooh, ooh
annotation:
A 2016 HyperAllergic article broke down Travis Scott’s use of ambience, dark themes and drug-infused experiences. The darkness that Travis embraces may be a byproduct of his mental state, following the consumption of antidepressants, which are known to cause fluctuations in mood.

“7:30” is a rather early time for Travis, who sets the scene for an eerie night of mischief and drug usage.

This could also reference the way Travis' mentor Kanye West began his June 2016 track “Saint Pablo”:

Yeah, 9:08 L.A. time
Back in the lab and shit

lyrics: (Another world premiere!)
annotation:
This ‘world premiere’ announcement was a recurring theme on Kendrick’s previous album, To Pimp A Butterfly. It appeared on several songs, including “Momma” and “i”:

This is a world premiere!

Just as Kid Capri introduces “YAH.,” “ELEMENT.” and “DUCKWORTH.,” here he announces that the listener is witnessing yet another lyrical masterpiece.

lyrics: Poppin' pills in the lobby and I pray they don't find her naked
annotation:
He’s popped pills with some girl in the lobby and now hopes they don’t find her dead and naked from overdosing because he would then be charged. This goes back to the “blue/red pills” allusion made on the matrix line.

This also references his previous line, as “Racing” can be used to describe someone high off ecstasy.

Kanye had a very similar set of bars a year later in his track “Blood On The Leaves” off of his album “Yeezus”:

Let’s take it back to the first party
When you tried your first molly
And came out of your body
And came out of your body
Running naked down the lobby
And you was screamin' that you love me

lyrics:
Tell the world I know it's too late
Boys and girls, I think I gone cray
Drown inside my vices all day
Won't you please believe when I say
annotation:
He understands that it’s too late to change his karma, and there’s nothing he can do to turn back time and live his life differently. He accepts the reality of his fate.

Some think that “cray” is a reference to Christian rapper and friend of Kendrick’s, Lecrae, who has a track called, “Tell the World," which is an anthemic song to proclaim the message of Jesus Christ, the figurehead of Christianity. Kendrick fears that, with his reputation, people won’t listen to him – he’s too late.

His flow changes to upbeat singing, indicating that he knows of the problems in his life but is choosing to ignore them.

lyrics:
Feel somethin' wrong
You actin' shifty, you don't ride
With me no more, I need
Loyalty, loyalty, loyalty
Loyalty, loyalty, loyalty
annotation:
Being “shifty” means to not have your heart all the way in doing something; being fake and disloyal. This could also be a play on words as “shifting gears” are done while driving a vehicle.

“Ride” used in this line means to be there for someone no matter the circumstances.

lyrics: That's what you're telling me, penitentiary would only hire me
annotation:
According to the New York Times, a young black man without a degree is more likely to end up in jail than get a job. Killer Mike considers the cheap labour thus obtained the “cornerstone of US economics” and Kanye also denounces it:

Meanwhile the DEA
Teamed up with the CCA
They tryna lock niggas up
They tryna make new slaves
See that’s that privately owned prison

lyrics:
I get those goosebumps every time, yeah, you come around, yeah
You ease my mind, you make everything feel fine
Worried 'bout those comments
I'm way too numb, yeah, it's way too dumb, yeah
annotation:
Goosebumps form on your skin whenever you are cold or experience strong emotions, such as fear or excitement—feelings that Travis could experience whenever he’s around someone he’s attracted to.

Alternatively, goosebumps are a symptom of opiate withdrawal. Travis may be alluding to the effects of Rx drugs or psychedelics which ease the mind and cause euphoria. Opiate painkillers and other prescription drugs are often used for escapism.

The drug theme further explains the numbness: he’s experiencing a side effect of the opiates. However, he could also be referring to “mouth numbing,” a side effect of many drugs, including cocaine.

lyrics:
Sippin' bubbly, feelin’ lovely, livin' lovely
Just love me
annotation:
I have no champagne of choice. That line came to me because my parents had visited the night before and we had went to my cousin’s play and we were sipping champagne.

As far as “Feelin' Lovely, Livin' Lovely” to me that means looking at things in life the best way you can. Life is beautiful. There’s things people can complain about, but there’s always something in life that you can look at and appreciate and love. It’s about loving yourself, being confident throughout the day and looking at life that way. There’s a lot out there to love and there’s a lot of love to give, and if you do, you’ll feel that way. You’ll feel the love.

lyrics: And I pray you niggas is hatin',
annotation: The pronunciation of “is hating” is a homophone to “is Satan”, which allows K.Dot to start a chain of biblical references by wishing that his enemies are all devils. If he can make the haters appear to be evil incarnate, killing them is no longer a sin.

lyrics:
Wouldn't you know
We been hurt, been down before
Nigga, when our pride was low
Lookin' at the world like, "Where do we go?"
annotation:
“Wouldn’t you know” is an English idiom used as a preface to express dismay at one’s situation. Lamar uses the idiom to introduce the material, emotional, and psychological consequences of being Black in America.

“Lookin' at the world like where do we go?” is an authentic question of action that is the primary referent underlying all studies of the African Diaspora.

Lamar suggests that identity conflicts and a lack of pride are often corresponding conditions. He draws a connection between the positive development of Black pride/power and the potential personal/social/political revolution that can arise from struggling.

This leads into the next lines about police hostility towards Black people and potential retributive violence (“my gun might blow.”)

lyrics: Is it unconditional when the 'Rari don't start?
annotation: “‘Rari” is slang for Ferrari. This is a metaphor for Kendrick’s success—when the Ferrari breaks down, will they (his family, friends, fans, and partner) still ride unconditionally and remain loyal?

lyrics:
Curse me till I'm dead
Church me with your fake prophesizing that I'ma be just another slave in my head
annotation:
K.Dot alludes to the Curse of Ham – a misunderstood explanation for black skin, slavery, and the alleged inferiority of black people.

When slavery existed slave owners would use Bible verses to keep the slaves in line such as Ephesians 6:5:

Slaves, obey your earthly masters with fear and trembling

lyrics: I get those goosebumps every time, I need the Heimlich
annotation:
Goosebumps can occur in a shocking or scary situation. In this circumstance, Travis' girl takes his breath away—giving him goosebumps.

The Heimlich maneuver is a first-aid procedure that is used to open up airways in order to recover breathing ability. This girl has Travis “all choked up,” hence needing the Heimlich.

This could also be interpreted as Travis needing the Heimlich maneuver performed due to nearly-overdosing on opiates—goosebumps are a symptom of opiate withdrawal.

lyrics:
I wanna be with you, ayy, I wanna be with
Just love me, just love me, just love
I wanna be with you, ayy, I wanna be with
Love me
I wanna be with you
Love me, just love me
annotation:
This is directed at Kendrick’s fiancé, Whitney Alford; the two have been dating since high school. During a 2015 Breakfast Club interview, Kendrick announced his engagement to her and said:

I’m loyal to the soil.

In a 2015 interview with Billboard, Kendrick expressed how deep their bond is:

She’s been here since day one. I wouldn’t even call her my girl. That’s my best friend. I don’t even like the term that society has put in the world as far as being a companion—she’s somebody I can tell my fears to.

lyrics:
shooters go after Judas
Jesus Christ, if I live life on my knees ain't no need to do this
annotation:
Judas refers to Judas Iscariot, one of the Twelve Apostles of Jesus Christ. He is infamously known for his kiss and betrayal of Jesus to the hands of the chief Sanhedrin priests, in exchange for a payment of 30 pieces of silver, after which he subsequently hanged himself out of remorse and guilt.

Therefore, in popular culture, a Judas is someone who sells out his friends or betrays them, also known as a rat or a snitch. Typically, these sort of people are looked down upon, and in this case, killed. Could then Kendrick be Jesus in this case?

Playing on the Judas/Jesus Christ reference, he uses Jesus' name as a statement of exclamation for the next line, also saying that if he had stuck to a religion and been a devout person at that young age (which he wasn’t), he would never have needed to use rap as an outlet to vent his emotions.

lyrics:
Nigga, and we hate po-po
Wanna kill us dead in the street fo sho'
annotation:
Po-po is a colloquial term for the police. This line is immensely important in modern day America due to police officers being guilty of killing many African-Americans. Hatred towards the police has been a long standing theme in hip-hop music, and it continues to be an issue.

This line was subject to criticism by Fox News following a performance at the 2015 BET Awards.

This line went on to be referenced in “BLOOD.”, the intro track to Kendrick’s follow up album, DAMN.

lyrics: That's what God for
annotation:
The fifth verse from Rihanna asks the listener who you’ll be loyal to. Family, a significant other, even yourself, God is the most important being to be loyal to.

Continuing with the overall theme of religion throughout DAMN., Kendrick retorts, saying you should be loyal to God, because he’s always there, as Exodus 19:5 states:

Now therefore, if ye will obey my voice indeed, and keep my covenant, then ye shall be a peculiar treasure unto me above all people: for all the earth is mine:

lyrics:
Institutionalized manipulation and lies
Reciprocation of freedom only live in your eyes
You hate me don't you?
annotation:
It’s no secret that African Americans are, proportionally, more likely to end up in prison. With legislation like the Three Strikes Law and past disparities in minimum sentencing for crack and cocaine possession, black citizens are imprisoned more than any other race, often even when they committed the same crime.

This is a shot to the white people who believe we live in a post-racial society, as well as those who believe that institutional racism does not exist and programs to combat it are unnecessary.

These lines build on a previous track on the album, “Insitutionalized”; they’re also similar to lines in the track “Poe Man’s Dreams”:

Since my uncles was institutionalized
My intuition has said I was suited for family ties

lyrics:
7-1-3
Through the 2-8-1, yeah, I'm ridin', why they on me?
annotation:
713 and 281 are both area codes for Houston. 713 covers central Houston, while 281 covers multiple Houston suburbs like Missouri City, where Travis grew up and seems to be headed.

713 and 281 are also imprinted numbers on common prescriptions. 713 is a common painkiller with codeine and 281 has hydrocodone.

lyrics:
If I didn't ride blade on curb, would you still love me?
If I minimized my net-worth, would you still love me?
annotation:
This is an homage to 50 Cent’s 2003 hit “21 Questions”:

If I fell off tomorrow, would you still love me?
If I didn’t smell so good, would you still hug me?

Kendrick wonders if this woman’s love is unconditional, or if she’s only with him for his wealth. “Ride blade on curve” refers to rims on expensive foreign cars. “Blades” is Houston slang that UGK and Jay Z popularized on their famous 1999 track “Big Pimpin'”:

Check ‘em out now, big pimping on B.L.A.D.’s

lyrics: Park it in front of Lueders, next to that Church's Chicken
annotation:
Lueders Park is a Park in Compton, across North Bullis Street from Church’s Chicken, both locations also bordering Rosecrans Ave. It is mentioned prominently in “Keisha’s Song (Her Pain).” .

Note that Kendrick says this in a ambiguous tone which makes it sound like looters, which would make sense since he is generally showing off. Also “church’s” ties in with previous bars reference to Jesus Christ.

lyrics:
Nigga, I'm at the preacher's door
My knees gettin' weak, and my gun might blow
But we gon' be alright
annotation:
Kendrick visits the preacher to ask for forgiveness for his sins. Kneeling is associated with obeisance​ and is therefore used as a position of prayer, as a way to submit to God.

He’s spent so long on his knees praying for patience that his willpower is weakening, forcing him to eventually take action.

lyrics:
It's so hard to be humble
It's so hard to be
Lord knows I'm tryin'
Lord knows I'm dyin', baby
annotation:
This outro leads into “PRIDE.,” where the intro states:

Love’s gonna get you killed
But pride’s gonna be the death of you and you and me

Rihanna and Kendrick have both reached high levels of fame, making it tough to be humble.

“HUMBLE.”, the first single from DAMN. and also found later in the album, details humbleness and the difficulties behind it.

lyrics:
I know you hate me just as much as you hate yourself
Jealous of my wisdom and cards I dealt
annotation:
Kendrick claims racism is based off personal insecurities.

Jay Z has expressed similar sentiments, particularly in “Justify My Thug”:

I just play the hand I’m dealt, I can’t say I’ve never knelt. Before God and asked for better cards, at times to no avail

Kendrick, on the other hand, claims to have dealt his own cards – he’s the master of his own fate.

lyrics: [Chorus]
annotation:
The minimal production contains two samples to let Kendrick flex his storytelling.

A sped-up and pitched-up section of “Maybe Tomorrow” by Grant Green is the focus of the instrumentals, most prominently the guitar.

He adds only a subdued hip-hop beat throughout – the drums, which are sampled from “Use Me” by Will Withers.

With strings swelling during the chorus, its stripped-down production gives out sentimental vibes while allowing focus on the story.

lyrics:
Why they on me? I'm flyin', sippin' low-key
I'm sippin' low-key in Onyx, rider, rider
annotation:
Onyx is a strip club chain that has a locations in Houston and Atlanta—a city that Travis goes to when he works on music.

In an interview with Billboard, Travis stated that he actually doesn’t drink or do drugs that often, which may be why he’s lowkey sipping on lean.

lyrics:
Ayy, I got somethin'
Hol' up, we gon' function, ayy, no assumptions, ayy
annotation:
Kendrick juxtaposes having somethin' with the previous line, where he says:

Keep it a whole one hund'
Don’t got you, I got nothin'…

The proverbial “you” here—that somethin' Kendrick seems to be expressing gratitude for—is actually Whitney Alford, his fiancée, seen here supporting Lamar at the 2018 Grammys:

He follows up on this wordplay with one of his many ad-libs. Kendrick has adopted the phrase “hol' up” and given it a personal touch on several songs throughout his catalog, including two others on this very album: “LUST.” and “HUMBLE.”

He also uses the slang term “function,” meaning to party or to dance—careful not to make any presuppositions about what kind of romantic activities might follow.

lyrics: All you pussies is losers, all my niggas is winners, screamin'—
annotation:
For more information, refer to one of the biggest winners, who unknowingly is explaining lyrics on winning.

“Losers” is pronounced like “loosers”, which is not a trait one wants in a pussy.

lyrics: [Verse 2: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation:
In this verse Kendrick is convincing himself that if God is in his corner, all will be well. Lucy, short for Lucifer, is introduced and entices Kendrick with worldly desires to try and pry him away from God, but Kendrick’s resolve is strong.

In the next song Lucy comes back full force, stating his capabilities and reaching influence, hoping to finally lure Kendrick. These persistent attempts to corrupt Kendrick prove how far Lucifer is willing to go for a soul

In observing vocal shifts, it seems the first 4 lines are delivered from Lucy’s perspective and the rest of the verse is coming from Kendrick. Very similar lines were used in the second verse of “Wesley’s Theory,” but from the point-of-view of Uncle Sam.

lyrics:
Watchin' me as I pull up, fill up my tank, then peel out
Muscle cars like pull ups, show you what these big wheels 'bout, ah
annotation:
Kendrick believes that those who hate him are also envious – jealous that he’s “black and successful.”

As examples of his success, Lamar mentions his “wisdom,” influence (“cards I dealt”), and uses wordplay on “pull-ups” to refer to “muscle cars.”

lyrics:
When the lights shut off and it's my turn
To settle down, my main concern
Promise that you will sing about me
Promise that you will sing about me
annotation:
Kendrick uses the metaphoric idea of death as sleep. Turning your lights off (your room’s/your eye’s lights) as you settle down and go to sleep.

John 11:13:

Howbeit Jesus spake of his death: but they thought that he had spoken of taking of rest in sleep.

When they die, they hope that they will be remembered in some way.

The use of sleep as a metaphor for death evokes Nas’s classic line from Illmatic’s “N.Y. State of Mind” that “sleep is the cousin of death”:

The Roots also utilized this poetic device on Undun’s “Sleep,” a song about the narrator dying.

The addition of “I’m dying of thirst” later in the song refers to the tradition of pouring out a little of one’s drink for the deceased. Both singing about a dead homie and pouring out liquor are rituals of eulogy and homage. Kendrick complicates the image with the Christian sacrament of holy water, which metaphorically mingles with liquor to produce a dense and paradoxical image of immortality, both intensely secular and religious.

Once Kendrick’s lime light has come and gone he’s not worried about how much money or fame he’ll have. His main concern is that his legacy will live on through his music, influencing new artist to the point that they sing of his traces. For an example, nowadays an artist may reference great past performers such as Elvis or James Brown in their music. This is the same degree of impact Kendrick wishes to have on future generations.

lyrics:
When I'm pullin' up right beside ya
Pop star, lil' Mariah
annotation: A reference to Mariah Carey, a huge popstar and a diva of the highest order. Travis allegedly dated Rihanna, so he’s well-versed in popstars.

lyrics:
Feelin' like Tyson with it
Knock it out twice, I’m with it
Only for the night, I’m kiddin'
Only for life, yeah, only for life, yeah
Only for life, let’s get it
annotation: Kendrick compares his sex game to Mike Tyson’s boxing game. By the numbers, Tyson was one of the greatest boxers of all time. A former heavyweight boxing champion, he was known for knocking out his rivals, most of the time within the first two rounds.

lyrics:
Goddamn I got bitches, damn I got bitches
Damn I got bitches: wifey, girlfriend and mistress
annotation:
A common theme in this song is overkill or over indulgence. He said “all my life I want money and power”, and he has now achieved that. So he can spaz with his newly attained influence, and have “bitches, wifey, girlfriend, and mistress”.

The allusion of “money, "power” and “women” being the be-all and end-all for all men stems from the movie Scarface and the infamous quote:

In this country, you gotta make the money first. Then when you get the money, you get the power. Then when you get the power, then you get the women.

Between the use of three and religious allusions in the previous verse – Wife, Girlfriend, and Mistress become Kendrick’s holy trinity (and since his dick has 72 hours, K.Dot has one girl for each day!)

The subtle use of K.Dot’s old adlib, eee, helps to place the story’s setting. This Kendrick is young, freestyling like he did in the past

lyrics:
What you want you, a house⁠? You, a car?
40 acres and a mule? A piano, a guitar?
annotation:
This is the third mention of 40 acres and a mule on the album. The same lyrics is repeated in “Wesley’s Theory,” To Pimp a Butterfly’s opening track.

After the Civil War and the dismantling of slavery, forty acres and a mule was the expectation of previously enslaved African American farmers. The farmers believed they had the right to this land, but not to our surprise, land was not redistributed in this way and most African Americans had to acquire land privately.

lyrics:
Black and successful, this black man meant to be special
Katzkins on my radar, bitch, how can I help you?
annotation:
Despite all the racism and oppression towards black people in our world today, Kendrick has still managed to become a successful black man – even winning two Grammy Awards a day before this song was released. In a world where black men can be judged and not given a full look, Kendrick proclaims that he is worthy of everything that has come his way.

Also note – K.Dot dedicated a whole song to the success of African-Americans in the good kid, m.A.A.d. City bonus track “Black Boy Fly”.

Katzkin is a brand of high end seat covers, that someone who is “black and successful” would be expected to drive.

A preemptive note to those that think Lamar’s primary reference is to “CAT scans”: If this was true then Lamar would literally be saying that radars are on his radar, which makes no sense. The context of the preceding lines reveals that Lamar is certainly referencing Katzkin, and that CAT scans is simply the secondary meaning evoked through his wordplay. Basically, Lamar is saying that he has exceptional things in his life (“on his radar”) because he is exceptional.

lyrics:
I said when the lights shut off and it's my turn
To settle down, my main concern
Promise that you will sing about me
Promise that you will sing about me
annotation:
When everything comes to an end and its Kendrick’s turn embrace eternal rest, his main concern is that he hopes the music he put out will be enough for him to be remembered and sung about for generations to come.

The meaning of this verse is amplified when we consider that Kendrick could actually be writing from the perspective of his friend who passed before the album came out. His friend had made the request that when he was killed, having been caught up in violence between the pirus and crips, that Kendrick would commemorate him on his album in a song.

lyrics:
When I text a cute game, wildness
Throw a stack on the Bible
annotation: “Text a cute game” means Travis is enticing this girl via direct message or DM, with cute or sensitive text messages. This induces her wild side, and he throws a stack of money on the bible, his version of placing a hand on the bible, to prove he’s being honest.

lyrics:
Hit that shoulder lean
I know what comin' over me
annotation: This is a reference to Young Dro’s 2006 debut hit single, “Shoulder Lean.” The track spawned a dance craze, which involves basically leaning from side to side—a move that Kendrick is performing in the bedroom:

lyrics: I've got 25 lighters on my dresser, yessir
annotation:
“Twenty-five lighters” refers to the practice of drug dealers hiding small baggies in the inside of lighters.

Kendrick, being familiar with classic hip hop, is probably referencing DJ DMD’s “25 Lighters,” which is also referenced in Big K.R.I.T.’s “Money On The Floor.” This line’s earliest use is in 8-Ball and MJG’s song “All in my Mind” from the album On Top of the World in 1995.

This is a very iconic line and has even made its way into the hook of the rock song by ZZ Top “I Gotsta Get Paid.”

lyrics: Anything, see my name is Lucy, I'm your dog
annotation:
Lucifer (Lucy for short) is a personification of the Devil who tries to capture Kendrick’s soul. Cerberus is the hellhound that guards the entrance of hell.

Additionally, in Goethe’s novel, Faust, the devil (Lucifer/Mephistopheles) takes on the form of a dog to deceive the protagonist to let him in. In the same way, Lucifer tries to befriend Kendrick in order to earn his trust.

This introduction mirrors the First Commandment (Exodus 20:2-3, Deuteronomy 5:6-7):

I am the Lord, your God
You shalt not have strange gods before me

The lyrics in “Alright” are almost identical to “Wesley’s Theory,” but the evil is switched from Uncle Sam to Lucy.

Anything, see my name is Uncle Sam, I’m your dog

lyrics:
How can I tell you I'm making a killin'?
You made me a killer, emancipation of a real nigga
annotation:
Kendrick references Abraham Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation – which freed enslaved blacks in Confederate states during the Civil War. Slavery was not constitutionally abolished until the ratification of the Thirteenth Amendment in 1865. However, even after the Thirteenth, Fourteenth (natural-born US citizenship), and Fifteenth (Voting Rights) Amendments were ratified, the white South still used fear to oppress the black population. Black Codes, Jim Crow laws, the Ku Klux Klan’s extralegal violence, poll taxes, Plessy v. Ferguson, sharecropping, and many other obstacles prevented the black population from exercising their constitutional rights.

He describes the cycle where white America sees his people as a violent uncontrollable “nigga” and thus condemns them, through laws and law enforcement, to being stuck in this self-perpetuating loop.

lyrics: [Verse 1]
annotation:
The first is a continuation of the skit at the end of “Swimming Pools (Drank)”. In the skit, Dave gets killed and his brother is looking for retaliation. This is Dave’s brother telling Kendrick that he appreciated the love that Kendrick had for Dave.

This verse could be tied to “His Pain II”.

Thereby, in a 2012 interview granted to Rob Markman from MTV, Lamar declared:

First verse is speaking from my partner talkin' to me, speakin' on a story of how I was there when his brother passed and I got to watch him take his last breath.

Much like the final scene in Boyz N the Hood after the violence was settled and the bodies fell, Dave’s brother is starting to realize that none of it was really worth and all that they are doing is perpetuating the violence further. He is starting to see the futility in his street life but feels like he is too far to come back. He is stuck. The dialogue is very similar to the final conversation between characters “Doughboy” and “Trey.” Doughboy being the gangster friend, while Trey is the good kid, much like Kendrick. In the movie, Trey is actually there to witness Doughboy’s brother get shot and killed and be there during his final moments.

lyrics: Never Snapchat or took molly
annotation:
Taking MDMA and taking selfies seem to have little in common, but they are two of the biggest downfalls for Travis' generation. Molly is causing real damage at music festivals (cf. “I Took A Pill In Ibiza”) and Snapchat both stunts social skills and leads to the occasional scandal—just ask Draymond Green. This girl Travis is talking about stays away from drugs and Snapchat, making her a rare find.

Snapchat is also the name for a specific production line of ecstasy that is made in Houston, Texas, Travis' hometown.

lyrics:
Backstroke oversea
I know what you need
Already on ten, all money come in
All feeling go out, this feeling don't drought
This party won't end
annotation:
“Backstroke oversea” is a metaphor for drinking alcohol. Kendrick used this metaphor before on his 2012 song, “Swimming Pools”:

Granddaddy had the golden flask, backstroke every day in Chicago

On his song “Sherane a.k.a Master Splinter’s Daughter” from that same year, he raps about performing better in bed when he’s drunk:

And I’m a professional porn star when off the Goose

This line is also figurative for the lengths Lamar will go to for Whitney Alford, his fiancée; he’d literally swim across the ocean for her. The two were high school sweethearts have been together for more than ten years. The “party” is their relationship, and there’s no “drought” because his feelings for her are as strong as ever.

lyrics: Put fire to that ass, body cast on a stretcher
annotation:
Kendrick’s lyrics will leave you paralyzed and burned, i.e. disrespected. This follows on from the 25 lighters mentioned in the previous bar.

Fire, alluding to both “lighters” and “heaters” are also also two of the many slang terms for a firearm, inferring that a 16 year old Kendrick would shoot you if needs be.

lyrics: Motherfucker, you can live at the mall
annotation:
Kendrick calls out consumer culture, similar to Kanye’s question:

How much time you spent at the mall?

Like in “Wesley’s Theory,” Kendrick attributes Uncle Sam-style consumerism to the devil’s influence. The devil tries to cut Kendrick a deal. Instead of usual materialism where a person enjoys a trip to the mall for a bit of retail therapy, Lucy ups the ante and offers Kendrick the mall itself.

lyrics:
This plot is bigger than me, it's generational hatred
It's genocism, it's grimy, little justification
annotation:
Kendrick alludes to the hatred of a rival gangs passed down from generation to generation. It’s common in Gangsta Rap to hear either parents, cousins, or aunties and uncles were “banging”, and subsequently influenced others to partake in their lifestyle.

Kendrick can use his platform (music) to embody his generation through his speech and provide a positive influence. However he needs more to join his cause – the attempt to “terminate his culture” is much bigger than him and he can’t take it on alone.

Furthermore, his use of the word “plot” may double as a term for ‘conspiracy’ as well as land used for a plantation.

lyrics:
I woke up this morning and figured I'd call you
In case I'm not here tomorrow
annotation:
Dave’s brother called Kendrick. He’s lost and looking for someone to talk to. The first thing he done in the morning was call Kendrick, just in case he dies tomorrow.

This foreshadows his death at the end of the verse, and builds up that atmosphere of ever-present, potential danger you can expect in Compton, that you could die at any moment.

A new morning, framing the song’s (and the album’s) 24h scaffold, uncovers new meanings on the past.

lyrics:
She fall through plenty, her and all her ginnies, yeah
We at the top floor, right there off Doheny, yeah
annotation:
Travis is painting the scene of a party. A ginny is slang for a beautiful exotic woman and
Doheny Road is a street in Beverly Hills, an affluent area of Los Angeles. Since the location is up in the hills, it also adds to the “at the top floor” reference.

May also refer to the Doheny Room, opened in 2016 in Los Angeles and already the venue for Nick Jonas and other A-List celebrities. Downstairs is for the regular people, the top floor is where the celebrities mingle.

lyrics: Pick up the phone for me, babe
annotation:
Travis Scott, one of the rappers behind the smash-hit “Pick Up The Phone” and performer on Kendrick’s “DAMN. Tour”, has a cameo in the “LOVE.” video. Minutes after the video was released, Travis shouted out Kendrick Lamar and potentially, his upcoming Nike’s, with the caption:

Kdot la flame
Nike boyz

Loading embed...

lyrics: And her body got that ass that a ruler couldn't measure
annotation: K Dot’s girl has a big ol' ass. More specifically, her curves are impossible to measure with a straight ruler.

lyrics: I can see the evil, I can tell it, I know it's illegal
annotation:
Under the devil’s influence, Kendrick sees an absolute right and wrong. There are actions that are moral and actions that are immoral, and this dichotomy exists even without the law. In this case, his awareness of good and evil literally comes before his cognizance of legal and illegal.

Coincidentally, a common phrase for viewing the two extremes of morality is “seeing the world in black and white.” The figurative contrast between those concepts reflects the racial themes of this song and the album as a whole.

Kendrick also refers to evil of the police department and their illegal targeting of the black population. According to some sources, police “killed at least 102 unarmed black people in 2015, more than any other race.”

lyrics:
I'm African-American, I'm African
I'm black as the heart of a fuckin' Aryan
annotation:
Kendrick juxtaposes the fair complexion of the Nordic people with the evil of the Nazis. Aryan is an archaic term for European and west Asian people. Today, it’s closely associated with the Aryan Brotherhood, a white supremacist prison gang that instills the values of Nazi teachings in their members. The Aryan Brotherhood frequently kills people from different races for no justification other than their race.

By repeating “I’m African-American, I’m African”, Kendrick might again be alluding to W.E.B. Du Bois' “double consciousness” of being a black man and an African-American.

Also note: this isn’t the first time he uses “white” imagery to define the term “black”.

lyrics:
I'm hopin' that I can borrow
A peace of mind, I'm behind on what's really important
My mind is really distorted
I find nothing but trouble in my life
annotation:
The homophones piece and peace make “borrow a peace of mind” a double entendre.

  • Peace of mind is an expression defined as “the absence of mental stress or anxiety.”
  • “A piece of mind” refers to Kendrick’s rational, smart decisions and evaluations.

Dave’s brother is looking for insight and a reminder of what his priorities should be, as he’s caught in the haze of Compton life. He asks to borrow it because he knows the troubling reality of his lifestyle: permanent relief is impossible and an early death is likely.

This is the only hope that Dave’s brother gets to verbalize, as he is cut short the next time he tries to hope for something.

Kendrick also makes use of the homophonic “borrow”/“burrow” – “To dig a hole or tunnel for habitation or refuge” – literally, this expresses Dave’s brother’s wish to dig an escape route from his situation, but figuratively, the idea of going underground has morbid connotations that poetically contribute to the hopelessness being alluded to & foreshadow his death at the verse’s end.

The phrase peace of mind could also be a reference to the word piece, which is a slang term for gun, to describe the type of lifestyle they had, full of gang wars and death.

lyrics:
Oh no, I can't fuck with y'all
Yeah, when I'm with my squad I cannot do no wrong
Yeah, saucin' in the city, don't get misinformed
annotation:
Saucin' is slang for swagging or styling on someone. The term originated in Atlanta but it has become popular in Houston thanks to the Sauce Twinz.

Despite the double negative, Travis implies that within his crew he’s untouchable, and even when drunk (another meaning of “saucing”) and sloppy he’s backed up by close associates.

lyrics:
Bad attitude from yo' nanny
Curves and your hips from yo' mammy
annotation:
“Nanny” is another name for “grandmother.”

The lyric forms a potential reference to Juvenile’s hit 2001 song, “Mamma Got Ass”:

Where she get them hips from? She get it from her mamma

It’s the second time on DAMN. that Kendrick pays homage to Juvenile, the first time being on the track “ELEMENT.”

lyrics: And it make me cum fast, but I never get embarrassed
annotation:
Quick on the trigger, but why would K.Dot care?

It’s totally understandable.

lyrics: I don't think about it, I deposit every other zero
annotation:
As Lucy continues to tempt Kendrick with worldly pleasures, he acknowledges his own greed.

In the previous line, Kendrick mentions how he can spot evil and illegal actions easily. The devil’s influence over him strengthens now, and he commits evil acts despite being cognizant of their immorality. Since he specifically refers to depositing money, the funds are likely tainted, perhaps involved illegal drug trade.

lyrics: I'm black as the name of Tyrone and Darius
annotation:
Although Tyrone in particular is sometimes looked at as a stereotypical black name, neither have black origins. Tyrone is an Irish name and Darius is Persian. This could be a commentary on the arbitrary nature of race. There is nothing in a name to permanently tie it to a race, and the small biological differences between races don’t explain the huge differences between races in American society.

Supposedly, this line stems from an actual feud between Tyrone Lamar and Dareious Hashaway, a.k.a Lil Flirty. He dissed Tyrone later, in a song posted to YouTube on June 12, 2016. Tyrone responded with a diss track of his own, posted to YouTube on July 6.

lyrics: I'm fortunate you believe in a dream
annotation:
The speaker is lucky Kendrick is following a dream, so that K.dot can tell his story when he pops off.

Could also be referencing Martin Luther King’s classic ‘I have a dream’ speech implying that Kendrick is very fortunate that you (society) believes in a dream like everyone believed in MLK’s dream.

Only so many things are as pure as a dream, thankfully KDot has one.

lyrics: Yeah, they gon' pull up on you (Brr, brr, brr)
annotation:
Pulling up on someone is approaching them with aggressive intent. If you get too close to Travis there might be trouble, and he uses onomatopoeia that mimics the sound of a gun to further prove his point.

Apparently he’s not afraid to fend for himself either. In 2015, Travis got involved in a brawl with fans at a tour stop in Tucson, AZ.

lyrics:
Remember Gardena, I took the studio camera
I know Top will be mad at me
I had to do it, I want your body, your music
annotation:
Gardena is a city just west of Compton. Up until 2012, the city’s demographics consisted mostly of young adults since apartments were cheap. Perhaps Kendrick’s fiancé, Whitney Alford, used to live there.

Kendrick was so enamored with Whitney that he was willing to take a camera from the TDE studio to film one of their sexual encounters. Although he knew that taking the label’s studio equipment would potentially ruffle some feathers with Anthony “Top Dawg” Tiffith, the CEO of Top Dawg Entertainment (TDE), he couldn’t resist the urge.

lyrics:
And I recognize you have what I've been wantin' since that record
That Adina Howard had pop it fast to impress her
annotation:
Kendrick references the singer Adina Howard, who found success in the mid-1990’s making pretty sexual songs. The song Kendrick is referencing is most likely “Don’t Come Too Fast”.

Sexy lady.

lyrics: Thinking of my partner, put the candy, paint it on the Regal
annotation: One of the urges brought on by our money-addicted society is to keep up with “the joneses.” In this case, Kendrick ties this line in with the lucifer/sin theme of coveting when he looks at his homie’s Buick Regal with the candy paint.

lyrics:
Excuse my French but fuck you — no, fuck y'all
That's as blunt as it gets, I know you hate me, don't you?
You hate my people, I can tell cause it's threats when I see you
annotation:
Kendrick uses the expression “Excuse my French” to mock the audacity of racists in America. The intention of the phrase is to tone down and pardon vulgarity – Kendrick’s usage in this context applies to how racists attempt to tone down and turn a blind eye to the prevalence of racism in current society.

Whilst Kendrick takes direct aim at racism in America throughout the track, he truly displays his rage and disgust at the treatment and perception of blacks in modern society. The switch from “fuck you” to “fuck y'all” shows that his anger isn’t towards just one person, rather racist white America as a whole.

lyrics: This orphanage we call a ghetto is quite a routine
annotation:
The ghetto is saturated with children whose parents are absent – thus Dave’s brother compares it to an orphanage

The speaker is metaphorically comparing the fact that they are in the hood living dangerous lifestyles with out any guidance, to being in a orphanage. Orphans have no parents, no guidance.

The hood is a vicious circle. When everyone’s parents getting blown up, everyone becomes an orphan. Almost everyone inevitably becomes an orphan, but in high crime areas, an orphanage manifests prematurely. This premature arrival of death lingers all over, tinting everything with despair, leading the orphans to see no end.

lyrics:
Yeah, we gon' do some things, some things you can't relate
Yeah, 'cause we from a place, a place you cannot stay
Oh, you can't go, oh, I don't know
annotation: This is a reference to gang related conduct. “A place you cannot stay or you can’t go” refers to the secret locations that are occupied by gang members. Most people don’t relate to this or participate in this.

lyrics: I bought the big one to prove it
annotation:
Back in 2015—almost exactly two years before the release of DAMN.—Kendrick revealed that he and his high school sweetheart, Whitney Alford, were engaged.

Kendrick took “Beyoncé’s advice” and put an engagement ring on his partner’s hand, giving her a “big one” to represent just how much she meant to him.

lyrics: She rollin',
annotation:
She’s wavy off the pills. Rollin' is the result of taking MDMA /Ecstasy/ Molly. Kendrick refers to these party drugs often in his songs.

In this case, it is also reference to the first verse:

Popping pills in the lobby I pray they don’t find her naked

lyrics: Digging in my pocket, ain't a profit big enough to feed you
annotation:
No amount of money is going to satisfy, or feed, his greed which is fueled by the devil. Materialism has him caught up.

If instead, Lucifer is speaking to Kendrick,“Ain’t a prophet big enough to feed you” could imply that there isn’t a savior to save him from his depression. This could be a reference to “Sing About Me, I’m Dying of Thirst.”

lyrics:
I can tell cause your ways deceitful
Know I can tell because you're in love with that Desert Eagle
Thinkin' maliciously, he get a chain then you gone bleed him
annotation:
Reminiscent of this line MF DOOM once used to decry intra-communal violence:

Jealousy the number one killer among black folk

A simple piece of jewelry may in fact be enough to kill his own kind over; whether it is to steal it or simply because it was symbolic of a rival gang.

lyrics:
And last night was just another distraction
Or a reaction of what we consider madness
annotation: In the narrator’s story, his brother had been shot the previous night, and Kendrick was outside helping him as he died. His brother’s death (a result of gang violence) is just another product of the corrupt nature of Compton and other ghettos; pure madness.

lyrics:
I want to press my like, yeah, I wanna press my
I want a green light, I wanna be like
I wanna press my line, yeah
I wanna take that ride, yeah
I'm gonna press my line
I want a green light, I wanna be like, I wanna press my—
Mama, dear, spare your feelings
annotation:
These lyrics are from the perspective of the girl Kendrick raps about throughout the rest of the verse. Notice the vocal change at “Mama, dear, spare your feelings"—that’s where Kendrick comes in.

This girl wants everything in life—social media attention (press my like), free reign to do whatever she wants (green light), a platform to push her agenda (press my line), and someone to take her to the top (take that ride).

lyrics: I'm holdin' my scrotum and posin'
annotation:
He is holding his nuts insinuating that he would like to fuck basically.

Note the homophone: ‘and posing’ and ‘imposing’, insinuating he’s taking a stance that would visually intimidate you.

Kendrick has previously posed while gripping his dick on “A1 Everything”, by Meek Mill.

I grab my dick in the picture; yo' ho be croppin' the image.

lyrics:
Every day my logic get another dollar just to keep you
In the presence of your chico... Ah!
annotation:
He wants to keep Lucy around and he figures that if he gets enough money it will make him stay.

Chico means boy in Spanish, as in “in the presence of your boy…” Alternatively, chico might be a reference to the dog in the movie Next Friday, as is “in the presence of your dog.” Lucifer’s dog , Cerberus, is the hellhound that guards the entrance of Hell.

Kendrick screams “ah!” because he is caught up by greed, wanting more and more money. He realizes it’s taking over his life. Materialism is a vice.

lyrics:
It's funny how Zulu and Xhosa might go to war
Two tribal armies that want to build and destroy
Remind me of these Compton Crip gangs that live next door
Beefin' with Pirus, only death settle the score
annotation:
The Zulu and Xhosa are the two biggest tribes of South Africa, and have had a long running rivalry. Even though they both live in harmony, anecdotal evidence shows some individual Zulu saying that they want to kill every Xhosa.

Gangs in America exist during periods of unemployment, poverty, and destabilization of the family unit. Likewise, tribes in Africa also turn to violence – after living in countries that have been robbed of natural resources and stability for well over a half a millennia.

20th century tensions between Zulus and Xhosas, especially between the majority-Zulu Inkatha Freedom Party and the majority-Xhosa ANC, were fuelled – and in some cases exaggerated – by the Apartheid Regime, largely incited and sustained by political and economic differences under white oppression, rather than tribal nationalism.

Black political philosopher Charles Mills writes, “White Supremacy has made the modern world what it is today” – black people in South Africa, and in the U.S., hate and kill each other while “the white man” prospers.

lyrics:
I know exactly what happened
You ran outside when you heard my brother cry for help
Held him like a newborn baby and made him feel
Like everything was alright in a fight he tried to put up
But the type of bullet that stuck
Had went against his will, that's blood spilled on your hands
annotation:
Dave’s brother is explaining the situation when Dave died and how Kendrick ran out of the car and held him until he died. Even though Kendrick could do nothing to save his life, he still made him feel like he was going to be okay and Dave’s brother is expressing how appreciative he was for that.

Even though he did what he could to help his brother, Kendrick still feels as though his blood is on his hands. Literally this is the case as his blood spilled on Kendrick’s hands as he died, but figuratively he might also feel this burden since it was because of him, that they were even out there. However Dave’s brother doesn’t blame Kendrick and is bent on revenge against the shooters.

Newborns have a blank slate; Dave was dying.It’s conflicting as Dave dies, but Kendrick offers him another glimmer of the life deprived. His new birth, into the next life, is all Kendrick could give. Maybe that’s enough, but nothing’s ever enough to fix these problems.

lyrics:
I'm relivin' moments, peeling more residual
(I can) buy the building, burn the building
Take your bitch, rebuild the building just to fuck some more
(I can) justify my love for you
And touch the sky for God to stop, debating war
annotation:
Residual income is the amount of income left after income taxes and debts have been paid. Think of it as your spending/saving money.

Kendrick’s residual income has been increasing so much so (he made $18.5 million in 2015 according to Forbes) that he could buy the building, afford to burn it, and rebuild just to fuck with you.

Kendrick pronounces “you” as “Yah” (or “Yahweh") here. It is common for Kendrick to reference God in this way (see “YAH.”). This latter section serves as contrast to the former declaration—Kendrick is caught between the ability to afford worldly acquisitions and his conviction to pray for its inhabitants who are at war.

lyrics: This voice here is golden,
annotation:
Kendrick puts on a number of voices for this song. A ‘golden voice’ generally refers to a radio voice or a deep, powerful voice.

His voice is also making him money, thus his voice is ‘golden’.

Also a possible reference to Goldenvoice, the LA-based concert promotions/planning company that has put on Kendrick Lamar’s shows.

As Kendrick often does, there’s also a homophone hidden under the surface of this line. “Golden,” as Kendrick says it, sounds just like “goading” (annoying someone to provoke a reaction). In the context of “Backseat Freestyle,” which represents a younger Kendrick’s goals and mindset, the multiple voices he employs throughout the song goad his older self on to write some of the more serious material in the latter part of the album. Good kid’s growing up.

lyrics: If I got it then you know you got it, Heaven, I can reach you
annotation:
If I got it then you got it – This suggests a certain connotation of charity, that Kendrick can help uplift his friends that need the money. But, coupled with the previous line, Kendrick might be also suggesting that the people around him imitate his attitude and reject being controlled by materialism.

Heaven, I can reach you – As if to say I can get through to you, but also suggesting that keeping one’s soul clean of material lusts will get one to paradise.

lyrics:
So don't matter how much I say I like to preach with the Panthers
Or tell Georgia State "Marcus Garvey got all the answers"
annotation:
The Black Panthers were a militant self-defense group for minority communities, and most notably recognized by prominent member Huey Newton. Kendrick’s aggression is similar to the Black Panthers.

On the other hand, Marcus Garvey was a black socio-economic and political leader that led a movement in the early 20th century. He preached about pan-Africanism and rebuilding infrastructure to overcome the social inequalities in the Americas and Caribbean. There is a dichotomy between what people are preaching and the way the black community actually acts – reference to the line below “hypocrite!”

Kendrick performed at Georgia State University, whose mascot is a panther in 2013 and one of their professors integrated good Kid, m.A.A.d city into his classroom curriculum; there is also a course on Kanye West at the school.

From left to right: W.E.B. Du Bois, Marcus Garvey, Martin Luther King Jr., Paul Robeson, Huey P. Newton, Malcolm X

lyrics:
My plan's rather vindictive
Everybody's a victim in my eyes
When I ride it's a murderous rhythm
And outside became pitch black
A demon glued to my back, whispering "Get 'em!"
annotation:
Like he said before, his “mind is really distorted”, and so now that Dave has been shot, his brother wants revenge.

He doesn’t care who it is, but somebody has to pay. There’s this demonic force possessing him to kill, and he is too fired up to scratch anyone’s name off the list of possible murderers, making everyone a suspect. The demon is only preoccupied with death and destruction.

“Everybody’s a victim” plays like a double entendre, since regardless of the demon controlling Dave’s brother, it’s a heavy truth in Compton: all of the lost friends and family, in Dave’s brother’s distorted view, were victims of senseless violence. The demon is prevalent, and anyone walking in their world at a given moment, could be a victim to someone from the other side.

It also sounds like “Everybody’s evictive in my eyes”, which means that he has written off everybody close to him and is now clouded by his newfound dark emotions.

lyrics:
Put the pussy on a pedestal (Ayy)
Put the pussy on a high horse
That pussy to die for
That pussy to die for
annotation:
“Put that pussy on a pedestal” is an allusion to 2005’s The 40 Year Old Virgin, where the phrase was used prominently. Generally, somebody who puts pussy on a pedestal treats women and sex as God’s greatest gifts.

Kendrick also used this phrase on “Bitch, Don’t Kill My Vibe”:

I’ll take your girlfriend and put that pussy on a pedestal

lyrics: so fuck y'all, I goes in, and—
annotation: Like he said in an earlier song, “motherfuck what a critic gotta say”. Young Kendrick takes the now cliche “fuck the world” stance in regards to haters.

lyrics:
Pat Dawg, Pat Dawg, Pat Dawg, my dog, that's all
Bick back and Chad, I trap the bag for y'all
annotation:
Pat Dawg is a cousin of Kendrick who passed away during the time of this recording. Kendrick mentions Pat Dawg in the official Alright music video.

Ay on my momma nigga (R.I.P. Pat Dawg)
I'mma be the greatest to ever do this shit
On my momma doe like
On the dead homies

Chad Keaton is another childhood friend that Kendrick has mourned for on YG’s Really Be Smokin

They killed Braze, they killed Chad, my big homie Pup
Puppy eyes on my face, bruh

Members & peers that are affiliated with the Bloods habitually replace letters with the ‘c’ sound with the letter ‘b’ to represent their affiliation. Kendrick is telling his dead homies to kick back in heaven while he brings in all the money as if he were in the trap.

lyrics: Or try to celebrate February like it's my B-Day
annotation:
In the United States, February is recognized as Black History Month. Instituted by President Gerald R. Ford in 1976, it’s used to recognize the achievements of Black Americans throughout history.

Kendrick’s encouraging the black community to not restrict themselves to uplifting their history and heritage for just one month. Kendrick has referenced Black History Month in a previous verses.

It’s also important to note this song was released on February 9, 2015 (the month of Black History Month).

Fun Fact: Kendrick’s birthday is actually June 17th.

lyrics:
I got 'em and I ain't give a fuck
That same mentality I told my brother not to duck
annotation:
Dave had to ride out and shoot-to-kill with an “I don’t give a fuck” mentality. Still, Dave’s brother has a realization that the same mentality (no ducking, only shooting) was the reason that Dave got killed. Carelessness is what allowed him to shoot the enemy, but at the same time, he stood in harm’s way and paid the price.

Dave realizes the irony of the whole system. He is now part of a cycle when he goes to shoot Dave’s killer, the family member of the first killer will be after Dave’s brother next. That “I don’t give a fuck” mentality creates a violent cycle in the hood.

lyrics:
Peter, piper, picked a pepper
So I could pick your brain and put your heart together
annotation:
Kendrick plays off of the famous nursery rhyme and tongue twister “Peter Piper,” conforming its first stanza to the faster flow he employs on the latter part of this verse.

He further segues this line into the popular idiom to “pick your brain,” saying that he’ll stimulate both the mind and the heart of girl he’s rapping about in this song.

lyrics: or, nigga, it's go time
annotation: The amount of typical immature rapper tropes (like starting a verse with some ridiculous phrase) Kendrick throws into this song is genius; while it’s mainly a window into Kendrick’s young self, it also serves as a great parody of undeveloped rappers.

lyrics:
I rap, I black on track so rest assured
My rights, my wrongs; I write 'til I'm right with God
annotation:
Kendrick writes songs/poems about both his good deeds and his sins in order to repent and be morally good with God. As he stated on “Poetic Justice”:

I could never right my wrongs ‘less I write it down for real

“Right with God” could also mean right next to God, or in other words, deceased.

This line can also be heard as “I black,” as in “I black out” on tracks (going into a trance and destroying any competition)

lyrics:
Or eat watermelon, chicken, and Kool-Aid on weekdays
Or jump high enough to get Michael Jordan endorsements
Or watch BET cause urban support is important
annotation: Kendrick continues to list stereotypes about black people, including playing basketball to attain Michael Jordan’s endorsement success, and being torn in supporting a station supposedly devoted to his people.

lyrics: In actuality it's a trip how we trip off of colors
annotation:
A native of Compton, California, Kendrick has surely seen the effects of gang violence. Bloods and Crips have long been an infamous gang rivalry, repping red and blue colors respectively. By simply wearing the wrong color in the wrong place, one is liable to face mortal consequences.

Dave’s brother is realizing how senseless that violence is. When a loved one is murdered, sometimes it results in disbelief at how something as futile as gang affiliation or race can spark such incivility.

lyrics:
We depart the shady parts and party hard
The diamonds yours, the coupe forever
annotation:
Since Kendrick has become a famous rapper, he is “departing" from his dangerous upbringing in the neighborhoods of Compton and is now able to party hard.

Kendrick also plays on the saying “diamonds are forever” (immortalized by Kanye’s “Diamonds from Sierra Leone”) but clarifies that while diamonds are forever for his lady friend, his soulmate is the coupe he drives.

Notice the wordplay on depart, parts and party, creating the stylistic scheme of polyptoton in which words derived from the same root are repeated.

It is also noteworthy to mention that Kendrick mentioned heart in the last line and then diamond in this one. The game of poker has 4 different suits, or patterns, 2 of them being diamond and heart.

lyrics: [Verse 3]
annotation: Kendrick channels his inner-Eminem in this verse with his aggressive flow and voice inflections. It would make sense, as Kendrick cited Eminem as an influence.

lyrics:
I keep my head up high
I cross my heart and hope to die
Lovin' me is complicated
Too afraid of a lot of changes
I'm alright, and you're a favorite
Dark nights in my prayers
annotation:
Continuing from where the hook of “u” left off, Kendrick admits it’s difficult to love someone as troubled as him. When experiencing sudden fame, his entire lifestyle and people’s perception of him changed, which was possibly frightening. The fear of not knowing how to handle the resulting stress lead him to depression.

Despite all the hardships, Kendrick promises that he’ll fight his depression and would rather die than to break his promise. He doesn’t think too highly of himself, but people he admires provides him the light to push forward. This helps him keep his head high through the struggles – it’s gonna be alright.

lyrics:
So why did I weep when Trayvon Martin was in the street
When gang banging make me kill a nigga blacker than me?
Hypocrite!
annotation: In this final couplet, Kendrick Lamar employs a rhetorical move akin to–and in its way even more devastating than–Common’s move in the last line of “I Used to Love H.E.R.”: snapping an entire lyric into place with a surprise revelation of something hitherto left unspoken. In “H.E.R.”, Common reveals the identity of the song’s “her”–hip hop itself–forcing the listener to re-evaluate the entire meaning and intent of the song. Here, Kendrick Lamar reveals the nature of the enigmatic hypocrisy that the speaker has previously confessed to three times in the song without elaborating: that he grieved over the murder of Trayvon Martin when he himself has been responsible for the death of a young black man. Common’s “her” is not a woman but hip hop itself; Lamar’s “I” is not (or not only) Kendrick Lamar but his community as a whole. This revelation forces the listener to a deeper and broader understanding of the song’s “you”, and to consider the possibility that “hypocrisy” is, in certain situations, a much more complicated moral position than is generally allowed, and perhaps an inevitable one.

lyrics: I wonder if I'll ever discover a passion like you and recover
annotation: Dave’s brother wants to find something that’ll help him get out of the hood and away from the madness going on in the hood. He wants something to be passionate about like Kendrick and his music.

lyrics: My best shots might shoot forever like (Brr)
annotation:
“Shoot your shot” is a common idiom that means to take the chance and talk to a girl. Kendrick is willing to take his “best shots” in a continuous attempt to woo his love interest. He compares shooting his shot to shooting bullets, using his version of the gunshot onomatopia Travis used in his verse.

Alternatively, Kendrick might mean that his best songs/hits (“shots”) will be heard forever. His music will be around long after he might be.

lyrics: I roll in dough with a good grind
annotation:
Kendrick is to money as a roll is to literal dough (i.e. he’s made of it!) To “grind” is to go to work. Kendrick is bragging about the money he’s making.

Also a play on “roll indo”, in keeping with all the weed K-Dot and his buddies claim to be smoking. And to roll your weed, you use a grinder, to put it into small pieces.

lyrics:
I remembered you was conflicted
Misusing your influence, sometimes I did the same
Abusing my power, full of resentment
Resentment that turned into a deep depression
Found myself screamin' in the hotel room
I didn't wanna self-destruct
The evils of Lucy was all around me
So I went runnin' for answers
annotation:
After ascending from a “peasant, to a prince, to a motherfucking king” in “King Kunta”, feeling lost & jaded in the four corners of the cocoon throughout “These Walls”, and contemplating suicide in a hotel room on ‘u’ – Kendrick continues to add to the poem he reads on the final track “Mortal Man.”

During his alcoholic binge in the hotel room, Kendrick “found” himself. Although he decided suicide wasn’t the way out, Kendrick still wasn’t straight – he had Lucy (Lucifer) hot on his heels.

Continue the poem on “For Sale?”

lyrics:
The life that I knew as a youngin
In pajamas and dun-ta-duns
annotation:
“Dun-ta-duns” are tighty-whities that have super heroes on ‘em. They’re called “dun-ta-duns” because that’s the sound that accompanies the entrance of a superhero.

Dave’s brother reminisces about his carefree days as a child—when he was more innocent and unexposed to the real Compton. Through success, he hopes to use his profit to ease his worries to the point where his lifestyle is as simple as it was as a child.

lyrics: And I run at ho with a baton
annotation:
In a relay race, runners hand off a baton to the next racer, who receives the baton and runs to the next, and so on and so forth. Likewise, Kendrick runs around with his ‘baton’ toward the next ‘recipient’, so they can ‘race’.

Also note that Kendrick pronounces “baton” as “boot-on”, a homophone for the Italian word for whore (“Butanna”, which is pronounced like “boot-on”).

lyrics: [Instrumental Outro]
annotation:
Terrace Martin spoke about his contributions to the song during his interview with Billboard:

Boi-1da was the one who made the beat, with the hard-hitting drums and shit; that comes from him. I came with the jazzy shit at the end with me, Lalah Hathaway and James Fauntleroy and that type of vibe. It’s a soulful record, it’s a record that needed to be done. It’s a record about being black and being proud at the end of the day. It inspired me to counteract what he was doing with something hella jazzy. He just got done talking about “hypocrites” and pro-black shit, and I’m like, “Let me calm that down because we [are about to] cause a riot out here!”

Jazz and hip-hop are both of supreme importance to African-American culture as they are African-American born musical genres. Settling down with this style of outro reaffirms Kendrick’s ties to his roots. Kendrick also used a jazz outro at the end of “Cartoon & Cereal”, released before good kid m.A.A.d city.

lyrics: When thunder comes it rains cats and dogs
annotation:
When gunshots are fired (or the metaphorical thunder), cats and dogs, or his friends, die. It’s a reference to the old saying “It’s raining cats and dogs”, and also demonstrates some wordplay as the TV series ‘ThunderCats’ aired during Kendrick’s youth.

It’s also a metaphor of the saying, “when it rains it pours” (meaning that trouble for Dave’s brother just seems to exponentially grow and never get better).

Notice how he distorts “When thunder comes” to sound like the previous “Dun-ta-duns”

lyrics: That's a relay race with a bouquet
annotation:
At the end of a running race, the winner is often presented with a bouquet of flowers. Kendrick is the uncontested champion.

This also references this practice of a bride throwing a bouquet to her unmarried friends at a wedding. The one who catches the bouquet will supposedly be the next to get married. All the girls want to catch the bouquet with Kendrick in mind as their future groom. He might also be suggesting that whenever he aims to pick up a “ho” he always scores, thus wins the metaphorical race with the bouquet (sex) as a final reward each time.

lyrics:
dumb
Niggas like me never prosper
annotation:
Often times, the hood creates an environment that perpetuates ignorance and a mentality of victimhood.

Dave’s brother is a prime example of this, he feels that just because he’s from Compton, he won’t accomplish anything of substance. He feels as though Kendrick is different because he’s talented and is truly a good person. However, he can’t see any good within himself and doesn’t feel as though he has any redeeming qualities.

The pause after dumb is because he’s saying when thunder comes it rains cats and dogs dumb, that all goes together, dumb as in a stupid amount, when it rains it pours. He means that its always raining trouble in Compton. One small thing (thunder) always leads to someone retaliating or worse (raining cats and dogs, series of events). In this case, stealing his mom’s van and going out to meet Sherane ended with him getting jumped and going with his friends to get revenge and Dave ending up dead.

Also, starting here, with the next few lines, Kendrick does a brilliant job of the literary device alliteration, or repetition of the same sound at the beginning of words.
“Dumb, niggas like me never prosper/prognosis, of a problem child, I’m proud and well devoted/This piru shit been near me forever. So forever, I'mma push it…"

lyrics:
They say, "K, you goin' marry mines."
