Beeotch! No way, beeotch! No way
Beeotch! No way, beeotch! Okay
annotation:
Kendrick runs into a problem that many talented rappers face: the women who want to marry him in the midst of his ascension to greatness (and probably profit from his success in a later divorce action). He knows better, though: just say no to gold diggers.

The bouquet in the previous line is thrown by the wife at weddings.

This line might also be an explanation as to why Sherane’s cousins/brothers jump Kendrick later on in the album. They see Kendrick as just another guy trying to get it in, then get out.

“Beeotch” is credited to Too $hort, who first pronounced the word “bitch” in that manner.

lyrics: Prognosis of a problem child,
annotation:
Dave’s brother feels as though he was one of the “dumb niggas”, those who don’t succeed. He sees it as the imminent path of a problem child in Compton, U.S.A.

Since this line and the previous line, and especially the words ‘prosper’ and ‘prognosis’, are practically hissed by Kendrick, this creates an air of contempt around the words.

The fact that Dave’s brother was born to be a ‘dumb nigga’ or a ‘problem child is accepted and recognized, however, this doesn’t mean Dave’s brother or Kendrick is happy with this fate.

lyrics:
I'm never livin' life confined
As I feel you even if I'm blind
annotation:
He’s enjoying all the pleasures of life, yet not restricting himself to a monotonous lifestyle of marriage, or anything else that holds him down, confines him.

To Kendrick, you’ve failed in life by limiting yourself, even if you didn’t see it happening. You have to live bigger.

lyrics: I'm proud and well-devoted
annotation: His pride and devotion are his prognosis. He is supposed to live his whole life loyal to his Piru gang, because he’s a typical ‘troubled child’, there’s irony that he can still be so devoted and loyal to his gang.

lyrics:
I can tell you who, what, when, where
How to sell your game right on time
Beeotch! Go play, beeotch! Go play
Beeotch! Go play, beeotch!
annotation:
Kendrick is familiar with the games women play. He could direct them to weaker men who could be taken advantage of, but they aren’t playing with him.

The way “go play” is pronounced is very similar to “Coldplay” and thus could reference a skit by Adam Devine (Workaholics) where he says “Beeeotch, Coldplay”.

lyrics:
This Piru shit been in me forever
So forever I'ma push it, wherever, whenever
annotation:
This is the only life he’s ever known.

The “speaker” in this verse is a piru (another name for the infamous Bloods) and he’s going to keep gang banging until he drops.

This admission from the speaker is puzzling as he has just previously recognized the futility of gang life and, more importantly, the futility of his brother’s murder. It illustrates how deeply ingrained the gang culture is in the young men of Compton, who aren’t able to change even if they want to.

lyrics:
I look like OJ
Killin' everything from pussy to a mothafuckin' Hit-Boy beat
annotation:
He’s talking about OJ Simpson, who people say infamously got away with the murder of his wife and a waiter who were supposedly having a love affair.

He’s a pussy slayer and he murders beats… and everything in between. And this just happens to be a beat produced by Hit-Boy.

There’s an amazing production trick here that I bet most of you didn’t notice on the first listen. Kendrick’s crazy-ass aggressive tone is faded out with the words ‘I look like OJ’, and a calm, smooth flow is faded in in order to better transition to the toned-down version of the hook that concludes the song. It also symbolizes he is coming out of his 16-year-old mindset and beginning to reflect on his past self from a point of hindsight.

lyrics:
And I love you 'cause you love my brother like you did
Just promise me you'll tell this story when you make it big
annotation: Verse one’s narrator loved K-Dot because Kendrick loved the storyteller’s brother. He wanted Kendrick to tell this story through his lyrics once he blew up in the music industry.

lyrics: She pussy poppin' and I got options like an audible, I be
annotation:
K-dot is using a simile. He is saying he has many different positions to fuck his girl. Just like how a quarterback in football, would call an audible to change a play if needed.

On the other hand, this may be Kendrick saying he has multiple different women to choose from as well as the different sex positions he can fuck them in.

lyrics: And if I die before your album drop, I hope—
annotation:
This sentence is interrupted by gun shots. The character died before the album dropped, but he wants Kendrick to sing about him. Kendricks’s fulfilling his last wish.

This line also speaks to the idea that if you continue down that path of violence like Dave’s brother, it’ll end up killing you, hence the gunshots interrupting mid sentence, showing us it could happen at any point, unexpectedly. This causes the listener to experience the sudden and jarring halt that is death in a smaller but still immediate sense.

The fact he’s murdered mid-sentence more broadly signifies he was killed before he was able to give all he had to give. It wasn’t enough his life was cut short, even his sentence is as well; death robs him of everything.

Also note that the shots come in right when Dave’s brother says “I hope”, signifying that there is no hope for kids like him in the ghetto and also, since he is cut off before he could express that hope, the line alludes to the ways violence destroys hopes and dreams, no matter how small before they can be realized.

NOTE: The same idea is used in M.A.A.D city when Kendrick says “If pirus and crips all got along, they’d probably gun me down by the end of this song”, saying that people like him live in such a dangerous place that they might get shot unexpectedly at any time, even when recording a song.

lyrics:
C-O-M-P-T-O-N, I win, then ball at your defeat
C-O-M-P-T-O-N, my city, mobbin' in the street, yellin'—
annotation:
Compton, Compton, ain’t no city quite like mine

Cali love, Kendrick’s home – originally given the spelling treatment by his mentor Dre back in 92:

But I’m never off, always on to the break of dawn / C-O-M-P-T-O-N and the city they call Long Beach

In addition, Kendrick’s ‘win/ball/defeat’ wording is a continuation of the football reference ‘audible’ from the previous line; moreover, the spelling with dashes between the letters of the word ‘Compton’ mimics the stacatto bark of a quarterback changing his play call.

lyrics: [Gunshots]
annotation:
Three gunshots end the verse, signifying the death of Dave’s brother before the album drop. The three sequential gunshots, which represent a sonic ellipsis, operate as a narrative gap—perhaps for listeners to interpret themselves.

Almost immediately after Dave’s brother went to get revenge for Dave’s death, he was gunned down. This demonstrates the “eye-for-an-eye” mentality in the hood.

The beat goes on, regardless of the gunshots. In other songs, like “m.A.A.d city,” with the YAWK YAWK YAWK) the track pauses for emphasis while the ad-lib/sample continues.

lyrics: Let it run, Ali
annotation: Kendrick shouts out his mixing and recording engineer, MixedbyAli. This line is interesting because it’s the only time Kendrick breaks character, and returns to the current moment.

lyrics:
[Chorus]
Promise that you will sing about me
Promise that you will sing about me
I said when the lights shut off and it's my turn
To settle down, my main concern
Promise that you will sing about me
Promise that you will sing about me
annotation: When everything comes to an end and it’s Kendrick’s turn to embrace eternal rest, his main concern is that he hopes the music he put out will be enough for him to be remembered and sung about for generations to come.

lyrics: [Verse 2]
annotation:
This verse comes from the perspective of Keisha’s sister.

She is mad at Kendrick for putting her sister on blast (on Section.80) without even knowing her properly.

She talks about how she is living the same life as her sister, as a prostitute, and is proud of her living and what she does. She claims not to be just another woman lost in the system. She says her sister died in vain. Unlike Dave’s brother she doesn’t want to be sung about on the album.

She feels great and says she’ll never fade away….but then she does, her vocals slowly fade out in to obscurity…perhaps she died or just became another nameless “hoodrat”.

Kendrick’s decision to rap this verse from the perspective of someone else rather than from his own is an iconic technique of Nas, of whom Kendrick is an admirer. Most notably, Nas raps from the perspective of a woman in “Sekou Story”.

lyrics:
You wrote a song about my sister on your tape
And called it Section.80
The message resembled "Brenda's Got a Baby"
annotation:
The female narrator is referring to “Keisha’s Song” from Kendrick Lamar’s 2011 mixtape Section. 80.

In that track Kendrick tells the tragic tale of a young prostitute who is raped and slain. The narrative is reminiscent of “Brenda’s Got a Baby”, from 2Pac’s debut album 2Pacalypse Now.

Kendrick also references “Brenda’s Got a Baby” within “Keisha’s Song”:

She play Mr. Shakur, that’s her favorite rapper
Bumpin' ‘Brenda’s Got a Baby’ while a pervert yelling at her

lyrics:
What's crazy was I was hearin' about it
But doubted your ignorance
How could you ever just put her on blast and shit?
Judgin' her past and shit?
Well, it's completely my future
Her nigga behind me right now askin' for ass and shit
And I'ma need that forty dollars
Even if I got to fuck, suck and swallow
annotation:
She’s upset that Kendrick released “Keisha’s Song” as she feels like Keisha was being unfairly judged. This is also due to the fact that being a prostitute will still be her job for the foreseeable future and she’s feeling judged just like her sister.

Especially in her job, the customer is always right even if he asks her to do nasty things; she has to earn that money one way or another. Her nigga refers to both Keisha’s pimp and a usual client, who are both looking for a girl to replace her with.

The preposition “behind” is also noteworthy, as it implies that she’s being “pushed” towards a dark future—this further reinforces Kendrick’s message about the hopelessness & inevitability of boys & girls getting sucked into gang life and prostitution, respectively. Just as we saw Dave’s brother follow Dave’s path, we’re seeing Keisha’s sister walking in Keisha’s footsteps—a comment on the cyclic nature of poverty and destruction.

lyrics:
In the parking lot, Gonzales Park, I'm followed
By a married man, and father of three
My titties bounce on the cadence of his tinklin' keys
annotation:
The woman Kendrick characterizes knows the rhythmic jingling sound of car keys is a signal. She knows her client has removed them from the ignition and stopped following her, an indicator for her to approach his car.

K-dot paints a picture of the harsh, unfortunate reality for many young girls who grew up where Kendrick came from and in tough cities across the country.

lyrics: Matter of fact, he my favorite 'cause he tip me with E's
annotation:
This married man is her favorite customer because he tips her with ecstasy instead of money. This is obviously a very flawed logic because it insures that she will never get out of her situation.

Kendrick creates a homophone “with ease” and E’s, indicating that she gets tipped easily because she’s good and ecstasy brings her ease.

lyrics: He got a cousin named David and I seen him last week
annotation: Keisha’s sister could be referring to Dave, Kendrick’s friend who was killed in front of his own eyes. This is possible due to the characters on the album are have a common interaction in some way, and is sung about in the first verse of the song. Dave, on the other hand, could have seen her when him and his homies pulled up on a bunch of working girls.

lyrics:
This is the life of another girl damaged by the system
These foster homes, I run away and never do miss 'em
annotation:
Lots of children from Compton grew up in foster homes with no guidance or support after their parents either were killed or OD’d. This mention of “foster home” parallels the metaphor of the ghetto as an “orphanage” mentioned in the opening verse.

While the boys end up hustling on the streets and join gang, the girls become prostitutes to earn some money and feel appreciated. As we can understand by the use of the present tense I run, Keisha’s sister is still in a foster house so she’s still a teen.

In the next verse, she’ll become tired of running.

lyrics:
See, my hormones just run away and if I can get 'em
Back to where they used to be, then I'll probably be in the denim
Of a family gene that show women how to be woman
Or better yet, a leader, you need her to learn somethin'
Then you probably need to beat her, that's how I was taught
annotation:
Kendrick plays on the word genes, pronouncing it like jeans to connect to a “denim” of a family gene.

If she would have been a girl cut from a cloth who had love and support for her instead of being a foster kid, she’d have learned how to respect her body and how to make others do the same, especially in the household.

She feels so far gone and so embroiled in a certain way of living that it’s easier to imagine how it’d have been to live a different life rather than fix the one she’s living.

lyrics:
Three niggas in one room, first time I was tossed
And I'm exhausted, but fuck that "Sorry for your loss" shit
My sister died in vain, but what point are you tryna gain
If you can't fit the pumps I walk in?
annotation:
She sardonically references the first time that she was used by three men at once (or “tossed”) as an example of how she was taught how to be a woman.

She doesn’t need Kendrick to apologize for the life she was forced into. She rejects criticism from people who can’t sympathize with her plight.

This line also marks a dramatic change in Keisha’s sister’s tone as she goes from sounding weak and vulnerable to sounding angry and forceful.

lyrics:
I'll wait… Your rebuttal a little too late
And if you have a album date, just make sure I'm not in the song
'Cause I don't need the attention, bring enough of that on my own
annotation:
His rebuttal (the 3rd verse) to this message literally comes too late as she has already faded away by the time he can explain himself.

When she says she gets enough attention on her own, she’s saying it to brag (not to plead with Kendrick to not mention her in his album) about how well she’s doing for herself as a hooker – which ties in with the defiant, “don’t feel sorry for me” tone of the previous lines.

lyrics:
And matter fact, did I mention that I physically feel great?
A doctor's approval is a waste of time, I know I'm straight
annotation:
Like many people with STIs, the woman in this verse doesn’t feel sick at all, but her claim that she “feel great” is a direct contradiction of her earlier claim about how tired she is.

The line dismissing the importance of a doc’s opinion suggests that Keisha’s sister is in denial and is lying to herself in an attempt to make herself feel better. This is shown in subsequent lines where she tries to convince herself that she’s in control of her life—which is just another contradiction, similar to the next few lines where she claims she’ll never fade away, while her verse begins to fade out.

lyrics:
I'll probably live longer than you and never fade away
I'll never fade away, I'll never fade away, I know my fate
And I'm on the grind for this cake, I'ma get it or die tryin'
I'm eyein' every male gender with intentions of buyin'
annotation:
She tries to prove her point to Kendrick once again, saying that she’s so good with her clients that there will be more people who’ll remember about her rather than remember him and GKMC.

The music itself directly contradicts her however. Her lyrics literally ‘fade away’ as she sings. Despite her insistence that she knows her fate, the fading volume highlights the bitter reality that death is universal and inescapable. No matter what she claims, the reality of death makes it all bluster.

She then motivates herself, thinking that the only important thing is making money right now, whether she dies in the process or not. Her profession has disallowed her from seeing men as human beings who have also been corrupted by the “m.A.A.d city” they live in. Rather, she sees them solely as potential sources of income.

On a broader note, it means that prostitution will go on and on; the current condition of these women will perpetuate for longer than this song will be played for. This reinforces the point that Kendrick should not talk about her on his album, there is no way that the song will make any difference and the paradigm will continue well after the song has lost in popularity.

lyrics:
[Chorus]
When the lights shut off and it's my turn
To settle down, my main concern
Promise that you will sing about me
Promise that you will sing about me
I said when the lights shut off and it's my turn
To settle down, my main concern
Promise that you will sing about me
Promise that you will sing about me
annotation: When everything comes to an end and it’s Kendrick’s turn to embrace eternal rest, his main concern is that he hopes the music he put out will be enough for him to be remembered and sung about for generations to come.

lyrics:
Sometimes I look in the mirror
And ask myself: Am I really scared of passin' away?
annotation: This line recalls 2pac’s sentiment from “Changes.” Kendrick is in deep thought about death because he’s sees it around him daily.

lyrics:
If it's today, I hope I hear a
Cry out from Heaven so loud it can water down a demon
With the Holy Ghost 'til it drown in the blood of Jesus
annotation:
Kendrick hopes that he ends up in heaven. He wonders if he has done enough to get there. This might be a reference to the 1941 film The Blood of Jesus which is heavily centered around African-American culture. One of the main characters is also introduced to alcohol by a demon.

According to certain Christian theology, the notion that communion wine is legitimately Christ’s blood (without changing the physical appearance of the liquid) is known as Transubstantiation. These lines demonstrate Kendrick’s willingness to acknowledge the reality of God, although the hyperbolic nature also suggests that his prayer is one of desperation.

lyrics:
I wrote some raps that made sure that my lifeline reekin'
The scent of a reaper, ensurin' that my allegiance
With the other side may come soon, and if I'm doomed
annotation: Reeking the scent – yeah, reeking the scent. Basically coming to grips with reality, saying I’m a teenager, I am out here, and there is possibly a chance that I won’t see tomorrow, so looking in the mirror and really understanding that was a tough point to deal with, a tough time to deal with. I could walk out there – there was one particular summer that was so hot you couldn’t even walk to the corner because the neighborhoods was feuding that crazy. If you walked to the corner for sure you were going to run into some action because somebody is on the other end of the corner, waiting for you to walk on that corner. That is how crazy Compton is, you know. You are waiting on that corner, you pull up, they hop out, shoot at you down the block so that you could run the opposite way, and have another car waiting on you as soon as you get to the corner, and that’s it for you. You ain’t got nowhere to go, you feel me? And you come to grips with that. You look in the mirror and say damn, this might be my last day walking out here as a teenager, you feel me? That is what that particular line, and that whole verse, is about really – grasping the idea of death, for a kid.

lyrics:
I suffer a lot
And every day that glass mirror get tougher to watch
I tie my stomach in knots
annotation:
As he states at the beginning of the verse:

“Sometimes I look in a mirror and ask myself
Am I really scared of passing away,”

It’s harder to look at himself everyday because he’s becoming a man he doesn’t like, thus making him sick to the stomach.

Also note the inference on glass and watch, the typical mirrors are made of glass, so why be so specific? The wordplay infers he’s watching a hour-glass, with time slowly slipping away from him. He talks about looking in the mirror every day. This line might imply that the sins he’s committed makes looking at himself in the mirror harder and harder.

Kendrick here makes watch sound like “wash”, to infer not only that its getting harder to “watch” the person he is slowly becoming, but also to say as this change is happening he is slowly not recognizing the person he sees in the mirror, like a mirror with a blurred reflection that he can’t “wash” and fix.

lyrics:
And I'm not sure why I'm infatuated with death
My imagination is surely an aggravation of threats
annotation: The curiosity is still there because, like I said, I am a dreamer. And one thing about a dreamer is it is not always a good thing, you feel what I’m saying? Your mind can take off and wander to negative things as well. It is not always, ‘I could be the greatest basketball player one day.’ It is the idea that I can actually walk outside and get hit by a train in the middle of the street, you know what I’m saying? So I know what it is but it is always going to be a constant thing playing in the back of my head.

lyrics: That can come about, ’cause the tongue is mighty powerful
annotation:
These threats can happen, because the tongue, or his voice, is powerful, and things you say can easily carry a lot of weight.

“Death and life are in the power of the tongue: and they that love it shall eat the fruit thereof.” – Proverbs 18:21

lyrics: And I can name a list of your favorites that probably vouch
annotation:
He can name some of your favorite rappers that can tell you they felt the same way about the feeling he described over the last few bars.

“Be careful what you wish for, you just might get it”.

Something like how Biggie Smalls put out Ready to Die and said and acted like he was really ready to go and sure enough his time came prematurely…same thing with Pac and many other rappers who spoke their fate into existence.

lyrics: Maybe 'cause I'm a dreamer and sleep is the cousin of death
annotation:
Kendrick wonders if his aspirations are the cause of his fixation with death. He also creates a metaphor playing off the connections that sleep, dreaming, and death have with one another.

Additionally, this may be a reference to the 1994 Nas track “NY State of Mind”:

It drops deep as it does in my breath
I never sleep ‘cause sleep is the cousin of death

The lines about Kendrick being a dreamer, halfway between life and death, reveal something interesting. There are five people being discussed on this track—two are dead before the song’s timeline (Dave’s brother and Keisha’s sister), two are alive (although Dave gets shot at the end) and the fifth, Kendrick, is halfway between life and death.

lyrics: Really stuck in the schema of wonderin' when I'ma rest
annotation: “Schema” is a psychological term for the category of thought we immediately put our experiences into. This happens automatically, and it’s a hard habit to shake—hence why Kendrick is “stuck” in it (he also explains earlier how this becomes routine). In his case, the schema is death: he’s been exposed to so much dying that he routinely interprets his experiences through the category of death. “Schema” also sounds like “scheme of.”

lyrics:
And you're right, your brother was a brother to me
And your sister's situation was the one that pulled me
In a direction to speak on somethin'
That's realer than the TV screen
annotation:
Kendrick takes the time to address the first two speakers in this song.

  • “Your brother was a brother to me”: Is aimed at Dave’s brother, Kendrick is validating the statement that Dave’s brother made in verse 1 and he’s making sure that Dave’s story is being told because it’s something that the world needs to hear.

  • “Your sister’s situation…”: Keisha’s sister had it wrong, she assumed that Kendrick was putting Keisha on blast and judging her for the choices that she was forced to make in her life. When in reality, none of what Kendrick was saying was coming from an evil place, Keisha’s situation has inspired him to do music he’s doing now. Real music that shines a light on the dark.

This shit he’s saying is realer than any of the tragic drama you watch on TV.

lyrics:
By any means, wasn't tryin' to offend or come between
Her personal life, I was like "It need to be told"
Cursin' the life of twenty generations after her soul
Exactly what'd happen if I ain't continue rappin'
annotation: Conversely, Kendrick implies her lifestyle and actions have consequences, not only for her, but for her descendants (cursed Madame Zeroni/Elya Yelnats style). Her lack of educational/occupational success and financial stability will directly affect her offspring, in every aspect, from where they grow up to the amount of guidance and emotional support they receive. This, in turn, will heavily influence who they become and, subsequently, how they raise their children, inevitably perpetuating the cycle of destitution. Being a surrogate role model, he has the opportunity and responsibility to break the cycle by any means necessary, even if that means uproarious anecdotes.

lyrics: Or steady bein' distracted by money, drugs and 4-5's
annotation:
If he had cared about money, drugs or gang violence, he wouldn’t have rapped.“four, Fives” is a reference to a .45 calibre handgun.

If you listen to the pronunciation of the word “four”, Kendrick pronounces it as “foe” (as in enemy). He adds double meaning to this word as he follows it by “fives” to give reference to 45 used in a particular gun.

Also could be another gang reference, 5 being another name for a Piru Blood as a reference to their symbol, a five-point star.

Connected to the next line: “Fives, I count lives all on these songs.” Dave, Dave’s brother, Keisha, Keisha’s sister, and himself = Five lives.

Since 4 x 5 = 20, the four fives could reference the 20 generations whose lives are being cursed in the line earlier in the verse.

lyrics:
I count lives, all on these songs
Look at the weak and cry, pray one day you'll be strong
Fightin' for your rights, even when you're wrong
And hope that at least one of you sing about me when I'm gone
annotation:
All of his songs are dedicated to people he knew who died or suffered. He recognizes their pain, prays for them, and fights for a different reality, even if they’ve been “wrong” (killed, prostituted, used drugs, etc.)

There’s also a Biblical allusion here:

2 Corinthians 12:10

Therefore I take pleasure in infirmities, in reproaches, in necessities, in persecutions, in distresses for Christ’s sake: for when I am weak, then am I strong.

He counts 5 lives on this song: Dave, Dave’s brother, Keisha, Keisha’s sister and himself.
The “count lives” is a play on to the two previous lines, “Four/ Fives” and “20 generations”.

And in doing this, he hopes in turn, someone will sing for him.

lyrics: Am I worth it? Did I put enough work in?
annotation:
Kendrick explains that this is the way he raps because of his experiences. He’s saying that those listening are the reason why he’s doing what he does. By the time he’s “gone” (be it death or retirement from the rap game), he wonders if everyone will be “singing” (talking about his significance in the rap game) by then? Was he worth it? Did he put enough work to be recognized?

Other methodologies for the explanation include:

  • Kendrick is asking someone, possibly God, if this song was enough to pay off the sins he’s committed that he talked about earlier in the verse.

  • He might be realizing that you cannot actually pay off debts (you can’t change the past), but you can change other people’s present moments (if they come to their own insightful revealations) which could, in effect, change their pasts when they get to the future.

In the first verse you have someone that wants their story to be told by Kendrick. In the second verse you have someone that’s upset with Kendrick for telling their sister’s story on Section.80 and doesn’t want him to talk about them anymore. So when he asks whether or not if he’s worth it, he’s asking if he’s worth being wrote about in a song as well. Which basically means that him rapping about them isn’t him trying to be disrespectful. In fact it’s the complete opposite because he’s questioning whether or not if he’s worthy of the same honor. Kendrick must hold writing a song about someone very high, because he hopes that one day someone will do the same to him and tell his story.

This is also a play on the gang life and the process of moving up in the ranks. When you put in enough work and show you’re worth being promoted, you are.

lyrics:
Promise that you will sing about me
Promise that you will sing about me
I said when the lights shut off and it's my turn
To settle down, my main concern
Promise that you will sing about me
Promise that you will sing about me
annotation: These are the voices Kendrick hears from all the people around him – poor people who aren’t represented by the media, who are politically and culturally voiceless – asking him to tell their stories, because they can’t

lyrics:
Promise that you'll sing about me forever
Promise that you'll sing about me for— ooooh
Promise that you'll sing about me forever
Promise that you'll sing about me for— ooooh
Promise that you'll sing about me forever
Promise that you'll sing about me for— ooooh
Promise that you'll sing about me forever
Promise that you'll sing about me for— ooooh
annotation:
In the song’s conclusion, the audio of the voice is panned back and forth, from the right stereo channel to the left. It symbolizes a right to left spectrum, where it characterizes the voice in such way that:

-It speaks on behalf of the people who are/were involved in the Crips-Bloods (right vs left) issue. The deaths of Dave and his brother were gang-related.

-It speaks on behalf of all the people around Kendrick whose stories have not been heard no matter where they stand socially/culturally/economically etc.

lyrics: [Part II: "I'm Dying of Thirst"]
annotation:
This is a deeper thirst of the soul that, ironically, “Swimming Pools” of alcohol will never quench. Rather, Kendrick needs the baptismal pool to cleanse his soul from sin.

As St. Paul details in verses 3-4 of Romans 6, the baptismal waters represent, when one is plunged beneath them, identification with Jesus in his crucifixion, death to sin, and a subsequent resurrection into life with Christ.

lyrics: [Produced by Skhye Hutch]
annotation:
Minimalistic beat featuring background vocals drums and the occasional bass chords. “I’m Dying of Thirst” opens after a skit with the drums kicking in and vocal effects to the ambient choirs. Conceptually, this song works with the beat, especially the way Kendrick speaks on a lot of church based themes over a choir-based track.

Almost every line is punctuated by this “uh” sound, like Kendrick is gasping, literally parched. It creates this restless, dry, heavy breathing effect throughout the whole thing that basically makes this track. It feels like he is dying and therefore can´t breathe. Another interpretation is that Kendrick is being suffocated by his environment with all the violence, the peer pressure and their inevitable death – no way out.

lyrics:
(On the phone)
"Ay, ay, ay, Where you 'bout to go?"
"Nigga, the homie's brother-- nigga, right here, he gone, my nigga, he gone!"
"Nigga-- they just killed the homie's brother, my nigga. We right here on the block, my nigga."
"Al- alright, nigga-- nigga just come-- alright, alright, just call me back, man, just call me back."
[Hangs up]
"Arghh... Fuck!
So what we gon' do, my niggas? What we gon' do?"
"Bro, we can go back right now, my nigga. Like... nigga, I don't give a fuck, my nigga. We can go back right now"
"Fuck! I'm tired of this shit! I'm tired of fuckin' runnin', I'm tired of this shit! My brother, homie!"
annotation:
K.Dot’s homies talking after Dave has been killed. Some of them want to go back and get revenge. Dave’s brother finally snaps and says he is tired of this shit

One can hear the desperation in K.Dot’s friend’s voice. They killed his brother; an unbearable loss.

Kendrick’s friends want revenge. Their desire for vengeance continues them down a path in which they will eventually die of “thirst.”

Dave’s brother and the “tired of this shit” phrase also resembles Tre crying to his girl in Boyz n the Hood:

lyrics:
Tired of runnin', tired of huntin'
My own kind, but retirin' nothin'
annotation:
Kendrick is tired of the never-ending cycle of violence that he’s forced to take part in. It’s either him chasing his “enemy” or him being chased by the other side, essentially a matter of life and death. The worst part is that he’s acknowledging that he’s chasing people just like him, an exemplification of the black-on-black violence plaguing many communities—particularly with the ongoing gang rivalry between Crips and Bloods.

The use of “retiring nothing” essentially means that nothing is gained from this gang violence but how those involved in this cycle may end up going to prison or getting killed based on the criminal activity they’ve committed.

lyrics:
Hands on the wheel, who said we wasn't
Dyin' of thirst, dyin' of thirst, dyin' of thirst?
annotation:
The tires are still screeching – i.e. the cars are still doing drive-bys as the drivers grip the wheels still. Nothing has been retired.

Kendrick and his friends are dying of thirst, meaning they are much in need of God in their lives. Thirst plays on their need for holy water, or their need to be baptized. There may also be a thirst for blood, as Dave was just killed. In “The Art Of Peer Pressure”, he mentions his hunger “for anything unhealthy”

The fact that they’re still running is why Kendrick questions whoever said something has changed.

This line could also be referring to label mate, and fellow Black Hippy member, ScHoolboy Q’s song “Hands on the Wheel” which was released in January 2012, the same year as this album.

lyrics: Stray bullets, AK bullets
annotation:
Shot, perhaps unintentionally, but with the same result.

The AK-47 is notorious for being the choice of weapon in drive by shootings, which have a strong association with California street gangs and the resulting warfare arising from conflicting issues and tension. Often with inexperienced and often trigger happy shooters, one of the devastating common occurrences is that of a stray bullet claiming the innocent lives of bystanders.Kendrick coming from Compton has probably witnessed this on numerous occasions.

lyrics:
cameras is lookin'
It's hard to channel your energy when you know he crooked
annotation:
When you’re poor, it’s hard to generate motivation to do anything.

Note the wordplay repetition of ‘channel’. Kendrick is emphasizing that you can’t channel the energy when you know you’re “crooked”. Being crooked isn’t about being poor — it’s about knowing you’re doing wrong. When you’re crooked, you find it hard to have the energy to care about what’s going on, such as feeling bad for the death of innocent bystanders. So you’re not showing up in front of cameras mourning, instead you’re just numb.

lyrics: Banana clip, split his banana pudding
annotation:
Banana clips are long clips that are curved like bananas. Some guy got his head split by bullets.

Kendrick reprises this term on “1 Train”

Also note the use of the word “split” (like a banana split)

This also juxtaposes some contrasting imagery, an instrument of killing and a dessert, the latter usually associated with relaxation, the last course of a proper meal. This highlights the brutality of the killings going on in the hoods he describes, at no point are you safe.

lyrics: I'm like Tre, that's Cuba Gooding
annotation:
An inspiration for good kid, m.A.A.d city. Cuba Gooding Jr.’s character, Tre, is very much like Kendrick: a smart, charismatic kid caught up in violent gang-ridden city.

Tre, like Kendrick, realizes that this gang life is not for him so looks from afar.

lyrics:
I know I'm good at
Dyin' of thirst, dyin' of thirst, dyin' of thirst
annotation:
Kendrick is aware of his sinful behavior that has come from the violent activities he has indulged in. His use of the phrase, ‘dying of thirst,’ is a metaphor for his neglect of God, whereas the ‘thirst’ he feels is a play on his need for holy water or to be baptized.

In the same way that Dave’s brother and friends convert to Christianity in the outro skit of “I’m Dying of Thirst,” Lamar actually converted to religion after the death of a close friend in real life. Kendrick told Complex that the stories on good kid, m.A.A.d city were reflective of his reality. Regarding this song, he expressed:

It represents being baptized, the actual water, getting dipped in holy water. It represents when my whole spirit changed, when my life starts—my life that you know right now, that’s when it starts.

lyrics:
How many sins? I'm runnin' out
How many sins? I lost count
annotation:
Kendrick feels as though he has committed a fair amount of sins in his life. Kendrick feels as though, even though he knows God to be forgiving, there’s only so much that CAN be forgiven.

Jesus was asked by the disciples how many times they needed to forgive someone. Jesus said, “I do not say to you, up to seven times, but up to seventy times seven” (Matthew 18:22).

That particular total is 490, however, the meaning behind it is that since you most likely won’t sit there and count each time you’ve forgiven an individual, the limit does not exist.

A reference to when he earlier said, “I am a sinner who’s probably gonna sin again/Lord forgive me, Lord forgive me/Things I don’t understand”. No matter how many sins he commits, he’ll always have faith in god, a major theme in his music.

lyrics: Dreams of ballin' like Spalding
annotation:
Spalding is a sports equipment company that manufactures basketballs.
This is a wordplay:

  • Balling means to have much money. He always dreamed about having money, because he grew up poor.

  • Balling is also another word for playing basketball. Spalding is, as mentioned in the annotation, a sports equipment company.

lyrics: But only shotty bounce
annotation:
Play on the previous basketball line, also pertaining to the fact while some crews are out balling and enjoying life, something Kendrick dreams of doing, he is stuck in a cycle of sin and mischief at this point in his life.

As well as this, while he aspires to be a baller, the only thing that’s “bouncing” is the shotgun, while rounds are being shot.

Could also be “shoddy bounce” as in he dreams of balling but he’s just not good enough to make it – think of Biggie’s line from “Things Done Changed‘:

And a third could be “shorty bounce” as in the girls a young man inevitably has when playing ball.

All three are dangers of a new future, temptation leading astray.

Either you’re slinging crack rock or you got a wicked jumpshot".

These are the two choices for many kids in the hood.

lyrics: The reaper callin', I'm cottonmouth
annotation:
This is a double entendre. A “Reaper” is a machine that gathers a crop, such as cotton. The grim reaper is the personification of death.

Based on the skit, Kendrick and his friends are seeking vengeance for the murder of their brother Dave. Kendrick realizes he too can be killed in this anger-driven vendetta he’s on. His mouth is dry because of the realization that death may be around the corner, or because of the weed he smoked.

lyrics: Money is power (Money is power)
annotation:
The theme of money relating to power and the dream of obtaining wealth is very relevant in cities like Compton, where Kendrick is from, and seems to be the goal of most black artists coming from poverty.

All my life I want money and power
- “Backseat Freestyle”

lyrics: Yours is ours (Yours is ours)
annotation:
Double Entendre:

  1. Typical hood mentality “If you make it, we all made it.” So your money (power) is also theirs.

  2. In reference to the mentality of Youths in Compton, who’ll rob someone simply because they have money. Your power is theirs because they took your money(Power).

lyrics: Lay with a snitch, die with a coward
annotation:
Good character is spoiled by bad company – so you may get killed along with the snitch (popularly seen as cowards).

Alludes to the Bible with the snake corrupting Adam making him sin, since Kendrick is around such bad influences constantly it could poison his strong character as well.

lyrics:
Hope we get rich, hope we can tower
Over the city with vanity with the music louder
annotation:
Kendrick always had dreams of being successful and hopes to stand tall with pride showing that he made it.

Most kids in the hood dream of becoming rich. The problem with money and power in the hood, is that it’s wasted on fly cars, jewelry and flashy stuff. Turn up the music in the car and blast your vanity over the city you’ve conquered with money and power. Perhaps he is suggesting that there is a more productive use of resources.

lyrics: The same song,
annotation: Once he makes it he hopes that his entire city can follow his message of change in the hood.

lyrics: a black flower
annotation:
The color black in reference to flora is symbolic of death, departure, and sadness in the European culture. However, in certain cultures (mostly Asian) black is symbolic of good luck, fortune and power.

Kendrick mentions a flower growing in a dark room in Poetic Justice which is symbolic to the rose growing out of concrete that Tupac spoke of. True black roses do not occur naturally (they are usually a dark purple or burgundy at the darkest). Black flowers are genetically engineered to be tinted to have an appearance of black. Just as “bad people” aren’t created naturally but are products of the environment they are brought up in.

In the lines below, Kendrick also says he will show you how to “dye your thirst”

lyrics: I'll show you how to
annotation: Kendrick has been through all troubles of living in Compton so hes saying he can show you how to be better

lyrics: Dye your thirst, dye your thirst, dye your thirst
annotation:
Kendrick suggest that you should turn your negatives into positives. A few bars earlier he says that he is dying of thirst (check the wordplay on dye and die).

However, when you dye something, you change it’s appearance. He’ll show you how to kill your thirst for sin.

And from the previous bar, flowers are never truly black, so the only way to have a black flower is to dye it.

lyrics: What are we doin'?
annotation:
He asking all these people in his m.A.A.d. city what are we really doing ? Why are we doing these ignorant and negative things in our community.
Pac would be proud

lyrics: Who are we foolin'?
annotation: By gang banging and being tough, we are only fooling ourselves because we can be doing way more positive things.

lyrics:
Hell is hot, fire is proven
To burn for eternity,
annotation:
It’s always hot in hell and those flames are definitely burning forever, unlike regular flames.

In addition to that DMX' first album “It’s dark and Hell is hot” inspired Kendrick to start writing rhymes.
It is also in his top 25 favorite albums.

lyrics:
return of the student
That never learned how to live righteous but how to shoot it
annotation: Kendrick is not really speaking of a student in the classical sense (in a classroom). He is referring to the typical “student” of the hood who is a product of his/her environment. The individual is driven by a mindset that states “he who holds the gun, holds the power”.

lyrics:
Tired of runnin', choirs is hummin'
Tell us to visit, we lie about comin'
annotation:
Kendrick is playing off the “choirs is humming” line.

“Choirs” (church people) are telling Kendrick to visit the church. Even the hardest of gangsters sometimes don’t want to be disrespectful to religious invites, so they’ll say they’ll come, knowingly patronizing the person.

lyrics: Now back to business, loadin' the guns in
annotation: They were polite to the religious people in the line before, but now they get back to the business of “loading the guns in”

lyrics: it's no discussion
annotation:
There is no other way to handle this situation, because the mentality of hate has been passed down from generation to generation. It’s hereditary, in his blood, so that there is no way you can convince him to do anything else.

Similar to the way Andre 3000 paints a picture of gangster life on Return of the “G”
With younger generations finding it impossible to get up out of the ghetto, as all they have is violence and negative influences around them.

Could also refer to the socialization (nearly the inculcation) of children growing up in such an environment: feuds, behaviour, and violence is inherited through how they are taught to live and survive in that which they grew up in.

lyrics:
Hereditary, all of my cousins
Dyin' of thirst, dyin' of thirst, dyin' of thirst
annotation:
Since people are often stuck in the ghetto from a lack of opportunity, it might as well be hereditary for them to suffer from the same thing. Generation after generation has to go through the same struggle of living in such a bad environment. Crips also usually refer to each other as “cuz,” who are a more full-fledged product of a violent setting.

The hereditary also refers to cycle of violence to avenge fallen family/homeboys:

You killed my cousin back in ‘94, fuck your truce

lyrics: Somebody send me a well for the drought
annotation:
A well has water in it, a drought is a lack of water

Also note that the thirst is growing. It’s gone from knowing he’s good at dying of thirst, to having a cottonmouth sensation from the thirst, and now he needs an entire WELL to get enough water for the drought because the thirst has grown so large.

In John chapter 4:11-15, Jesus talks with a Samaritan Woman:

11 “Sir,” the woman said, “you have nothing to draw with and the well is deep. Where can you get this living water?

12 Are you greater than our father Jacob, who gave us the well and drank from it himself, as did also his sons and his livestock?”

13 Jesus answered, “Everyone who drinks this water will be thirsty again,

14 but whoever drinks the water I give them will never thirst. Indeed, the water I give them will become in them a spring of water welling up to eternal life.”

15 The woman said to him, “Sir, give me this water so that I won’t get thirsty and have to keep coming here to draw water.”

lyrics:
See all I know is takin' notes
On takin' this life for granted, granted, if he provoke
annotation: Kendrick writes down what he has seen and experienced. He raps as a way to escape the conflict he faces in his home town, but it is still a part of him–so don’t fuck with him.

lyrics:
My best days, I stress days
(Lord, forgive me for all my sins, for I not know—)
My best days, I stress days
annotation:
Even during a beautiful day, many of the stresses from Compton due to gang violence are still on his conscience causing him to be stressed and pray for forgiveness for the mistakes he may have made unknowingly.

This line relates to one of Jesus' sayings on the cross:

Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do
-Luke 23:34

Kendrick stresses that he only has a “days” where he is at his best. This shows how the hood has affects even intelligent people like Kendrick and stops them living up to their potential.

lyrics: Say "fuck the world," my sex slave
annotation:
He uses the typical “Fuck the world” phrase, as in – who gives a fuck but then makes the line a double entendre by calling it his sex slave, which evokes the other meaning of “fuck” and has connotations of exploitation and disrespect.

Also referencing his song Backseat Freestyle, and acknowledging that his previous ideology was the wrong way to live.

lyrics: Money, pussy, and greed – what's my next crave?
annotation:
This is his personal wordplay on the common hip-hop phrase “Pussy, Money, Weed”.

It is widely known that Kendrick doesn’t smoke weed; in fact, he has mentioned it in several songs and explains why.

Instead, he replaces “weed” with “greed”; two common themes throughout this album were his desire for Sherane and his desire for money; hence, the addition of the word “greed”…

lyrics:
Whatever it is, know it's my next grave
Tired of runnin', tired of runnin', tired of tumblin'
Tired of runnin', tired of tumblin' – backwards
My momma say "See, a pastor give me a promise
annotation: Kendrick say that whatever his next craze is, it will be part of his grave that is slowing killing him. He’s tired of running from his evils and when he says he tired of tumbling he means falling deeper as a sinner. And his momma once told him to visit a pastor most likely to enlighten him and cleanse him of his sins.

lyrics:
What if today was the rapture and you completely tarnished?
The truth will set you free, so to me be completely honest
annotation:
IF the world ended today via the Rapture, only Christians would go to heaven. So he says live your life honest and free, so when God takes your life, you end up in Heaven.

“The truth will set you free” – (John 8:32)

lyrics: You dyin' of thirst, you dyin' of thirst
annotation:
Just after this line we’ll get to hear this woman explaining the meaning of ‘Dying of Thirst’.

“That means you need water, holy water. You need to be baptized with the spirit of the lord”

Baptizing is a Christian rite that initiates (admits, adopts) your soul into the Christian faith by baptism. You receive god as your savior.
When you baptize someone you cleanse the person from their sins.
baptein — to wash something
baptizein — to wash, often a person in a ritual context
baptismos — Jewish ritual washing
baptisma — the new Christian rite

lyrics: So hop in that water, and pray that it works."
annotation:
This line and the skit/outro is spoken by the now deceased Maya Angelou, the legendary American poet and author. The line itself refers to (hip) hop in the holy water and pray that God forgives Kendrick for the sins he’s committed.

The line has a tinge of cynicism, because Kendrick himself is not sure that it will work. He is doing it out of desperation, because his soul is dying.

lyrics:
[Skit/Outro]
Fuck! I’m tired of this shit!
I’m tired of fuckin' runnin', I’m tired of this shit!
That’s my brother, homie!
Young man, come talk to me! Is that what I think that is?
I know that's not what I think that is
Why are you so angry?
See, you young men are dying of thirst
Do you know what that means?
That means you need water, holy water
You need to be baptized, with the spirit of the Lord
Do you want to receive God as your personal savior?
Okay, repeat after me:
"Lord God, I come to You a sinner."
(Lord God, I come to You a sinner)
"And I humbly repent for my sins."
(And I humbly repent for my sins)
"I believe that Jesus is Lord."
(I believe that Jesus is Lord)
"I believe you raised Him from the dead."
(I believe you raised Him from the dead)
"I would ask that Jesus come into my life."
(I would ask that Jesus come in my life)
"And be my Lord and Savior."
(And be my Lord and Savior)
"I receive Jesus to take control of my life."
(I receive Jesus to take control of my life)
"And that I may live for Him from this day forward."
(And that I may live for Him from this day forward)
"Thank you, Lord Jesus
For saving me with Your precious blood."
(Thank you, Lord Jesus
For saving me with Your precious blood)
"In Jesus name, amen."
(In Jesus name, amen)
Alright now, remember this day
The start of a new life – your REAL life
annotation:
K.Dot and his friends, still angry and upset over Dave’s death, are met by an older woman, a neighbor of Kendrick’s (as revealed by Kendrick’s mother in the skit that appears at the end of “Real”) who approaches the boys. The woman sees that one of the boys has a gun:

Is that what I think that is?
I know that’s not what I think that is

She then begins to reveal to them that they are dying of thirst and that they need to take a new path and let Jesus into their lives. She then leads them in a prayer which is a rendition of the Sinner’s Prayer, which is heard in the beginning of the album.

At this moment, Kendrick sheds the hood mentality of K.Dot and begins to lead a new life as a newly enlightened Kendrick Lamar.

The woman is Maya Angelou. On the set of Poetic Justice, she met Tupac. He was about to get into a confrontation with another man, and she talked him out of it. Her being the voice of the wise woman is paramount because this conversation she has with the boys in the skit is eerily similar to the one she had with Tupac.

lyrics:
I got a story to tell, you know that I cherish thee
Hope it ain't too many feelings involved
annotation:
Kendrick Lamar begins with a common introductory line in hip-hop, which may find its roots in Beastie Boys' 1986 track, “Paul Revere”:

Now here’s a little story I’ve got to tell

E-40 went on to sample the Beastie Boys line on his 1996 track, “The Story.”

The exact phrase Kendrick uses was popularized by The Notorious B.I.G., on his March 1997 track, “I Got A Story To Tell.” In a 2014 Complex article, Kendrick called Biggie, “The King of New York.” In turn, Wyclef Jean started his June 1997 song, “Bubblegoose,” with:

Hey kids, gather around, it’s Wyclef and Melky Sedeck
I got a story to tell, here we go

lyrics:
I see niggas in this bitch
Stuntin', poppin' bottles
Gettin' drunk with these bitches
And when they leave they get followed
Fall asleep with that bitch
And really don't know much about her
Then she let us in, we take all of your shit
And when you wake up, she help you try to find it, I love it
annotation:
Wayne explored the theme of hiring women to seduce men in order to rob them, on his 2015 song, “Plastic Bag”:

Get a bitch with ass
Drop her off at the nigga pad
Now she goin' through the nigga’s stash
You slept all night nigga, you deserve it

lyrics: I say, "No, bitch, I said get him"
annotation: In this line it sounds as Wayne says kill him.

lyrics:
I smoke color purple, I'm up in here feelin' like Celie (Ooh)
Nappy-ass dreads, what's that you say?
annotation:
The Color Purple is also a 1982 novel written by Alice Walker. It chronicles the story of Celie Johnson, who wears her hair in dreadlocks. In 1985, a film adaptation of the book was released.

Purple Haze is a potent strain of marijuana. “Celie” also sounds like “feeling silly,” an effect of being high.

lyrics: All day, nigga
annotation:
Yeezy season approachin'
Fuck whatever y'all been hearin'

Ye runs everything all day, every day – can you name anyone else more influential or talked about? Coming up all the way from producing for Hova – he’s reached God Level.

lyrics: Watch your mouth, Milli Vanilli (Ooh)
annotation:
In November 1990, German R&B duo Milli Vanilli was stripped of their Grammy award for Best New Artist, after it was revealed that they hadn’t sung a single note on any of their songs.

Suspicion was first raised when the group took interviews but had trouble speaking English, and their lip-syncing was exposed in a July 1989 live performance, when the audio of their song started to skip, but the duo kept moving their mouths, proving they were not singing. They eventually ran off stage.

lyrics:
How long you niggas ball? All day, nigga
How much time you spent at the mall? All day, nigga
annotation:
Kanye’s come a long way since rapping about the “single black female addicted to retail” who literally spent all day at the mall.

Is he picking up girls? Is he holding a seance? Is he getting married? Nope – he’s probably buying everything to show off his wealth and success, just like Jay Z before him:

I’m so appalled, I might buy the mall
Just to show niggas how much more I have in store

The cycle is complete. Kanye’s gone from rapping about people who buy more than they can afford, to being able to afford more than he can possibly buy. In 2014, he earned an estimated $30m – about $100,000 a day!

lyrics:
You can get snaked, you can get faked
Out by the bitch that you feelin'
'Cause you thought that she was an angel
That bitch ain't no angel, I treat her halo like a frisbee
annotation:
To get “snaked” and “faked out” means to be deceived. The concept of a snake being deceptive derives from Genesis 3:13, where the serpent deceived Eve.

A “halo” is a circular crown made of light, that indicates a holy or sacred figure.

Wayne creates imagery of a female dog or “bitch” playing catch with a frisbee to show that this woman is the opposite of pure.

lyrics: How many runners do you got on call? All day, nigga
annotation:
Ye has goons on call all day, every day. Just ask Skepta:

This may be a reference to productions runners on tour. Productions runners help with everything, and generally speaking wait on executives or artists hand and foot. It would be a sign of power and wealth to have one runner, let alone multiple runners as Kanye implies, on call for you all day.

Another interpretation: “Runner” has the same meaning as “thot” (basically, “hoe”). Both words originated from Chicago. The slang term “runner” was created in the 90s.

lyrics:
And you tellin' your business, she tell me your business
You tell that bitch what you feelin'
All of the beans you be spillin'
To you, she lie through her teeth cavities, fillin's
annotation: To “spill the beans” means to reveal secret information unintentionally or indiscreetly and to “lie through one’s teeth” is to offer a blatant lie. “Fillings” are used to treat dental cavities, but this word also sounds like “feelings.”

lyrics: Swish, swish, how long they keep you in court? All day, nigga
annotation:
Kanye’s had multiple run-ins with the law and has subsequently spent some time in court. His line from “Mercy” – “you gon' see lawyers and niggas in Jordans” comes to mind.

Incidents include; Allegedly assaulting an 18 year old man in 2014 for attacking Kim and calling her a “n****r lover”, the case was later settled for more than $250,000. Fighting with a paparazzo in 2013, which resulted in him receiving 2 years probation, and 250 hours of community service and 30 days of anger management. Scuffling with a paparazzo at an airport in 2008 – Kanye received 50 hours of community service.

Apart from his troubles with the law, Kanye’s use of “swish, swish” doubles as a basketball and drug allusion. While a “swish” is when the ball lands clean through the hoop. For most inner city basketball games, the winner stays on the court, so if you are making swishes – you could be on the court all day.

  • “swishers” are used to roll blunts, something your P.O might get you in trouble for.

SWISH was also one of the earliest titles for Kanye’s 7th studio album, The Life of Pablo.

lyrics: Mona Lisa, long hair, don't care
annotation:
Wayne’s earliest use of the meme quote “Long hair, don’t care” can be traced back to Lloyd’s 2006 track, “You”:

Me and lil Lloyd baby, long hair don’t care

He has since compared his long hair to other people’s hair on multiple occasions. For instance, on 2011’s “Green and Yellow”:

Long hair, don’t care, Clay Matthews

And on 2013’s “Trigger Finger,” he said:

Long hair, don’t care, Hacksaw Jim Duggan

Here, he compares it to the portrait of Mona Lisa:

lyrics:
Don't tell a lie on me
I won’t tell the truth 'bout you
Don't tell a lie on me
I won’t tell the truth 'bout you
annotation:
This is an interpolation of James Brown’s 1974 song “Don’t Tell A Lie About Me and I Won’t Tell the Truth on You.”

Khalid, though uncredited, performs the background vocals. When the song dropped, he tweeted:

lyrics: Take you to get this fly? All day, nigga
annotation:
Come up in the spot lookin' extra fly

While most people have to grind all day just to be fly, it comes easily for Mr. West. He has plenty of money to blow on kicks and clothing, not to mention he’s been heavily involved in fashion design for the past few years.

lyrics:
I say, "Good girl, just remember what I told ya"
She gave me the salute, I say, "Girl, you're a soldier"
annotation:
The military salute is a formal gesture used to signify one’s obedience—typically as a display of respect toward a superior or an object.

Wayne portrays Liz, the protagonist of “Mona Lisa,” as a strong, ride-or-die girlfriend. This is reminiscent of themes presented in his featured verse on the Destiny’s Child 2004 hit single, “Soldier”:

If you don’t see me on the block I ain’t trying to hide
I blend in wit the hood, I’m camouflage
Bandanna tied, so mommy join my troop
Now every time she hear my name she salute

lyrics:
Thirty millions later, my future favors
The legendary status of a hip-hop rhyme savior
annotation:
In 2016, Forbes estimated Kendrick had made over $30 million in total career earnings. His future earning potential looks favorable with the release of his impending fourth studio album and festival headlining slots.

It seems Kendrick’s ultimate goal as an MC is to repopularize lyricism. With the ever-growing popularity of tracks with catchy hooks and simple flows, often referred to as “mumble rap,” many are beginning to wonder if lyricism is still a rapper’s most important talent.

This is likely a direct response to Big Sean’s “No More Interviews,” where he dissed Kendrick:

Who you put in your top five and claim they the savior of rap

Kendrick also mentions the 30 millions in “ELEMENT” from DAMN.:

Thirty millions later, know the feds watchin'
Auntie on my Telegram like, “Be cautious!”

lyrics: Tell your P.O. how-how long you been high? All day, nigga
annotation:
P.O. is short for parole officer (or probation officer) – someone who monitors an ex-convict once they are out of prison.

Explaining to your P.O. that you’ve been high all day means you’re breaking the law, and shows them you haven’t made any progress since you’ve been out of prison.

This lyric connects with the one above that alludes to “swishers” – “Swish, swish, how long they keep you in court? All day, nigga.”

lyrics: They started French kissin' so he didn't see moi
annotation:
A “French kiss” involves heavy usage of the tongue. Wayne makes a double entendre with ‘moi’—the French word for ‘me’—and ‘mwah,’ which is onomatopoeia for a kiss.

Wayne is hiding and the unsuspecting character in the song is too busy tongue-kissing his girl to notice.

lyrics:
Travel 'round the atlas in this spaceship
Candy-coated, my day shift's
annotation:
An atlas is a book of world maps. Kendrick’s success granted him the ability to travel the globe and perform. This provided him insight into the world outside of Compton. Kendrick’s first taste of it heavily shaped his 2012 album good kid, m.A.A.d. city, and his 2015 project To Pimp a Butterfly was largely inspired by his trip to Africa.

A “candy coat” is a high-gloss paint finish on a car, while a “spaceship” is a car equipped with high-tech tools like TVs or video game consoles. The image of a candy-coated spaceship evokes funk’s Afro-futuristic motifs, dating back to George Clinton & Parliament Funkadelic’s P-funk Mothership. Kendrick has worked with Clinton on multiple tracks, and in the video for the remix of “Ain’t That Funkin' Kinda Hard on You?,” Kendrick raps in a spaceship.

lyrics:
You already know I’m straight from the Chi, all day, nigga
South, south, south side! All day, nigga
annotation:
We comin' from the South (side), South (side)

Even though Kanye was born in Atlanta, he moved to Chicago when he was 3 years old (and what he loved most, she had so much soul…)

Since then, Ye has constantly praised and given back to Chicago — including but not limited to remixing Chief Keef’s “I Don’t Like”, featuring King Louie on “Send It Up” and Vic Mensa on “Wolves”, and co-founding Donda’s House — a program that is dedicated to providing art programs for Chicago’s youth.

If this song was any more Chi it’d need a DJ Pharris outro…

lyrics:
Nigga, turn around, I ain't here to fuck around
I ain't here to fuck around, caught you wit' your pants down
annotation: To “catch one with one’s pants down” is an idiomatic expression meaning to catch someone off-guard. Here, it’s both an expression and literal, since the man has his pants down to have sex with Liz.

lyrics:
Just penetratin' that throat, dawg
She choked on it like smoke, dawg
annotation:
Whether you’re smoking or giving head, you’re gonna have to contend with your gag reflex

“She choke on it like smoke, dawg” could also reference Chris Tucker’s character in the movie, Friday, where he calls himself “Smoke Dawg.”

May mean that he had her erform oral sex maybe.

lyrics: Been devoted to fuckin' up bundles of paper
annotation:
“Fuckin' up bundles of paper” is a metaphor for making money and it also means he’s writing lyrics or taking notes. There are sounds of him “fuckin' up paper” by balling it up at the end of the song.

In December 2015, Kendrick told the New York Times:

I’m just writing, writing, writing.

The ideas of making money, writing lyrics and taking notes are all intertwined since Kendrick’s notes are transferred to songs and his songs make him money.

lyrics:
This Ye, nigga
Shoppin' for the winter and it’s just May, nigga
annotation:
In fashion, Fall/Winter lines usually drop around the various fashion weeks in August/September. However, now that he is recognized in the industry, Kanye can cop his clothes straight from the designers in May, before they’re available to the public.

Ye has been setting trends for a minute, so you’d expect him to be a “season” ahead of the fashion game. He’s often seen in luxury aesthetics like leather, or fur during the winter months.

Kanye previously touched on this subject on “Illest Mother Fucker Alive”:

And I swear to God they so cold
Got a nigga in Miami wearing winter clothes

lyrics: If Liz call you daddy, she about to be a bastard, oh
annotation: The technical definition of a bastard is a child born out of wedlock or a vile person. However, a more informal definition is a child without a father. “Daddy” is also a sensual nickname that women sometimes call their boyfriends or husbands. Wayne plays on this idea by insinuating he’s about to murder her ‘daddy’ or boyfriend, thus making her a bastard.

lyrics: I won't say her name ‘cause she married now
annotation:
T.I probably doesn’t want to ruin the marriage and/or feels that if anyone should tell her husband about all the things she used to do back in the day it should be her.

Plus, she now has her husband’s surname, so the girl with the name he knew no longer exists; this change in name accompanies her change in lifestyle

lyrics:
Pi equals three-fourteen
The devil's pie is big enough to justify the whole thing
annotation:
Pi is the ratio between a circle’s diameter and circumference. It is an irrational number beginning with 3.14. Kendrick used the same pi/pie pun on his 2009 song “Is It Love”:

At 3:14, it’s time to give me a slice

The devil’s pie is a metaphor for vice. In D'Angelo’s song of the same name, he defines the ingredients of the dessert as:

Materialistic, greed and lust, jealousy, envious
Bread and dough, cheddar cheese, flash and stash cash and cream

This may also be a reference to the biblical verse Genesis 3:14:

And the Lord God said to the serpent, because you have done this, you are cursed above all cattle, and above every beast of the field; on your belly shall you go, and dust shall you eat all the days of your life.

lyrics: Ball so hard, man, this shit cray, nigga
annotation:
A reference to the iconic hook from “Niggas In Paris”:

Ball so hard mothafuckas want to fine me
(That shit cray, that shit cray, that shit cray)

lyrics: I hope you alone like bankruptcy, nigga
annotation:
Wayne plays on the homophones “alone” and “a loan,” as in a loan from the bank.

A “bankruptcy” is a court judgment granting people relief from debts like credit cards and loans they are unable to pay.

lyrics: [Hook: Kris Stephens]
annotation: Kris Stephens is a relatively new addition to the Grand Hustle roster, a grammy-nominated songwriter who TIP scooped up after hearing her voice and realizing her talent.

lyrics:
Wait up, lampin' in Jamaica
The clouds turnin', my thoughts turnin’
annotation:
In March 2016, Kendrick went on vacation to Jamaica. He paid homage to Bob Marley at the Bob Marley Museum, watched Usain Bolt train, and met up with dancehall artist Assassin for the first time. They previously collaborated on 2015’s “Blacker the Berry” but had never met face to face.

“Clouds turnin'” calls back to a lyric on his 2011 track “Kush and Corinthians”:

Make them clouds turn to speakers

lyrics: And you ain't gettin' money 'less you got eight figures
annotation:
Rich Boy claimed “you ain’t ballin' with a million.” The Social Network reminded us that a billion dollars is cool.

Kanye, then, provides us with a proper synthesis of the two.

lyrics:
Mona Lisa, I done painted the picture
Mo-Mona Lisa, out the frame on these niggas
annotation:
The Mona Lisa is a portrait painting by Leonardo da Vinci, widely considered to be the most famous work of art on Earth. The woman in the painting is noted for the ambiguity and irregularity of her smile, which can be interpreted as disingenuous. She comes “Out of the frame” in the form of Liz, who’s also disingenuous.

Wayne also uses the phrase “paint the picture” in a metaphorical sense, to describe how elaborately he has depicted the details of the scene.

lyrics:
When the lights go out
And I'm in my bed
I think of all the madness in my head
All of the things that I did back then
When I'm in my bed
I think of all the memories I've had
All of the things I did back then
annotation: This track is about reminiscing about a person from your past. The song was originally called “Somebody That I Used Know”, after the Gotye hit, which the beat was supposed to sample (possibly with a chipmunked version of the chorus from the original).

lyrics: Burnin’ castor oil, yo I been determined to make an earnin'
annotation:
Castor oil is a pale yellow, vegetable-based oil that Egyptians used for hygiene, and burned in lamps as early as 4000 BC.

Linking to the previous two lines about his time in Jamaica, we can deduce that Kendrick refers to Jamaican black castor oil, a type of castor oil often used in skin/natural hair products today and named “black” due to the roasted castor bean ash mixed in which gives it a darker colour.

“Burning the midnight oil” is an idiom that means “to work late into the night” Kendrick’s constantly working late (even on vacation) so he can elevate his career. In a 2015 Billboard cover story, he revealed he typically goes to the studio around 9 P.M. and often doesn’t leave until 5 A.M.

It’s hard to fall asleep. I pop right back up—my brain is still working.

lyrics: For that Jesus piece, man, I've been saved, nigga
annotation:
Kanye’s a devout Christian – Jesus & God play a huge role in his life.

Although it’s been 11 years, his début album The College Dropout was heavily influenced by soul and religion. He even made the song “Jesus Walks”, and may believe that song did indeed “save” him.

Note, also, the spend/save wordplay — he had to “save” up for his first Jesus piece (“I been saved” = “I’ve been saving up”), though today one assumes he can buy them on a whim.

lyrics:
Ah, every day she wake up with a different color makeup
And a promise he gone take her to the movie and the mall
Chillin' with the Laker, on the floor, fourth quarter
Four minute on the clock, Black Mamba with the ball
Paparazzi lookin' at 'em both poppin' up and take a picture, uh
Probably on a Internet blog
In a minute, he gon' be admittin' that he love her on his mother
Man, he want to meet her mother by tomorrow
annotation:
Kendrick details the cycles of courtship with a woman. He starts by mentioning the cosmetics his love interest is inclined to wear, a topic he explored on 2011’s “No Makeup (Her Vice).”

He then takes her to a basketball game, where they sit court-side, watching “The Black Mamba”—a nickname for Los Angeles Lakers legend, Kobe Bryant. Kobe retired in 2016, but was possibly still an active player when this song was recorded due to Tha Carter V’s delayed release.

The encounter concludes with paparazzi capturing an image of Kendrick and the woman, leading to internet rumors that the two are romantically involved. This process mirrors Kendrick’s 2013 collaboration on Eminem’s “Love Game”:

She doesn’t love me, no, she don’t love me no more
She hates my company, yeah, she don’t love me no more

The line “in a minute, he gon' be admittin' that he love her” is delivered at the 3:40 mark of the song. Interestingly, one minute later at 4:40 he raps:

Tell me who love you, I bet I love harder

lyrics:
The ghost of Mandela, hope my flows stay propellin'
Let these words be your Earth and moon, you consume every message
As I lead this army, make room for mistakes and depression
And with that being said, my nigga, let me ask this question:
annotation:
Nelson Mandela was the most prominent anti-racism activist of Apartheid South Africa. He died in 2013, aged 95, after spending his life campaigning for racial equality.

Kendrick hopes that he can continue Mandela’s legacy through his rapping. He has encouraged his fans to research Mandela’s life. They will become an army fighting for justice.

At the same time, Kendrick recognises that he isn’t perfect. His fans must accept that he’ll make mistakes, and he won’t always be able to do the best he can.

lyrics:
We got close over time, her and I
Right around the time that I first got signed
annotation: This maybe a reference to his video of “No Man’s Land” and the girl in the video.

lyrics:
This seed in this soil is classified
I’m satisfied when I strategize my kid's future
annotation:
Kendrick plans to have children with his longtime girlfriend and recent fiancée, Whitney Alford. After years of refusing to discuss his love life with the media, Kendrick announced their engagement in April 2015, telling The Breakfast Club “I’m loyal to the soil,” meaning he’s loyal until death.

In a March 1, 2017 New York Times feature, K-dot spoke about his parenting plans, especially if he has a daughter:

When I say ‘the little girl,’ it’s the analogy of accepting the moment when she grows up. We love women, we enjoy their company. At one point in time I may have a little girl who grows up and tells me about her engagements with a male figure—things that most men don’t want to hear. Learning to accept it, and not run away from it, that’s how I want this album to feel.

In contrast, Kendrick is less confident about his financial future on “FEAR.”:

All this money, is God playin' a joke on me?
Is it for the moment, and will he see me as Job?
Take it from me and leave me worse than I was before?

lyrics:
Just talked to Farrakhan, that's sensei, nigga
Told him I've been on ten since the 10th grade, nigga
annotation:
Louis Farrakhan is the current leader of the Nation of Islam, and is an American religious movement centering on a version of Islam particular to African-American communities.

While Kanye associates with Christianity, a deep sensibility for black culture is something himself and Farrakhan have in common. The pair are said to be working on a film project together – a documentary about Louis Farrakhan’s musical history.

lyrics:
Pussy good enough, it got him sinnin' in the walls
And he diggin' in it like he livin' in it
Make a new religion with it, man a nigga 'bout to go against God
annotation: “Diggin' in the walls” means to “have sex.” These lines are reminiscent of “These Walls” from Kendrick’s 2015 studio album, To Pimp a Butterfly. “Walls” is a slang term for “walls of the uterus,” and symbolizes being trapped, which Kendrick points out in his 2015 interview with The Breakfast Club.

lyrics:
When shit hit the fan, is you still a fan?
When shit hit the fan—
(one two, one two)
When shit hit the fan, is you still a fan?
When shit hit the fan, is you still a fan?
annotation:
Kendrick plays on two meanings of “fan” – an avid supporter, and the machine that blows air. Kendrick uses the latter definition in a familiar expression that indicates a situation going from bad to worse.

Loyalty is a running theme on To Pimp A Butterfly, and Kendrick is demanding it without reservation. Even if he’s framed for drug crime or child abuse, he wants to know that his fans will stick by him.

The “one two, one two” is a sample of The Gravediggaz' “Mommy, What’s a Gravedigga?”

lyrics:
But I guess one night I had a few
Huh, one night I had a few
Yeah, this little chick that caught my eye
I told her: "Hurry up, meet me at the room!"
And no, I didn't have a contraceptive
What my common sense neglected
annotation:
B.o.B was drunk one night, and, neglecting his common sense, slept with this girl (without any condom) who wasn’t the girl he was seeing.
Alcohol can have that effect.

The “without any contraceptive” points out why B.o.B. immediately thought the child was his, a few lines later. And immediately told his girlfriend that he cheated and made another girl pregnant by doing that.

(later seems that the kid wasn’t his though, but there was a big chance, since they did it without protection)

lyrics: I ain't sanctified enough to say that I won't shoot ya
annotation:
To be sanctified is to be free of sin. Though Kendrick tries to live a righteous life, he acknowledges that he’s not pious enough for pacifism.

This topic would be explored in greater detail on the song “XXX,” where Kendrick tells the story of a friend who’s son had just been killed. He asks Kendrick for spiritual advice, but all Kendrick can think of is the vengeance his flesh would desire if any one ever harmed his loved ones, saying:

I’ll wait in front a nigga’s spot
and watch him hit his block/ I’ll catch a nigga leavin' service if that’s all I got/ I’ll chip a nigga, then throw the blower in his lap/ Walk myself to the court like, “Bitch, I did that!”

Kendrick often draws on his rough upbringing to challenge complacency towards violence and express his frustration with gang culture. In a 2015 MTV interview with Rob Markman, he said:

I been through a lot. I seen a lot. Where I come from, I’ve done a lot to tear down my own community.

On “The Blacker the Berry,” he rapped:

So why did I weep when Trayvon Martin was in the street
When gang banging make me kill a nigga blacker than me?
Hypocrite!

And on “m.A.A.d city,” he wondered how his fans would react if they discovered he had murdered someone when he was 16 years old:

If I told you I killed a nigga at 16, would you believe me?
Or see me to be innocent Kendrick you seen in the street

lyrics: Got a middle finger longer than Dikembe, my nigga, uh
annotation:
Dikembe Mutombo was an NBA center who was famous for wagging his pointer finger after he blocked a shot.

Dikembe may be 7'2", but according to Ye, his fingers weren’t as long as the G.O.D’s.

lyrics: Poetry in a pear tree
annotation:
The character is making a new religion to worship this girl as she is poetry in motion, graceful and beautiful. The fruit tree in many religions and cultures is representative of fertility and physical nourishment, most famously used in the story of Adam and Eve and the tree of life (an apple tree). Instead of an apple, Kendrick uses the pear tree, perhaps alluding to the feminine form.

He is blindly obsessed with this deceitful woman (Mona Lisa). The musical arrangement in the background of this section portrays the feeling of euphoric love for this woman that the character has.

lyrics:
Do you believe in me? Are you deceiving me?
