Could I let you down easily, is your heart where it need to be?
Is your smile on permanent? Is your vow on lifetime?
Would you know where the sermon is if I died in this next line?
annotation:
The central theme of this song is directed at Kendrick’s fans—will you be there through thick and thin, trials and tribulations, achievements and mistakes?

‘Sermons’ are part of a typical church service. They are a platform for religious or moral subject matter. While Kendrick delivers his sermon in the present, he questions whether he can trust his fans to spread his legacy into the future after he’s gone.

This particular passage is reminiscent of one of the closing tracks from his 2012 debut good kid, m.A.A.d. city, entitled “Sing About Me, I’m Dying of Thirst.” In what essentially comprises the climax of the album—and another song with a lengthy 12-minute run time—Kendrick establishes themes that concern the fragility of life and loyalty:

I said when the lights shut off and it’s my turn
To settle down, my main concern
Promise that you will sing about me
Promise that you will sing about me

Just promise me you’ll tell this story when you make it big
And if I die before your album drop, I hope—[Gunshots]

lyrics:
On top of all that, it wasn't even mine
I went and got paternity tested—damn!
annotation:
B.o.B detailed similar imagery on his Cloud 9 track “My Story”:

But on top of that I thought I got a bitch pregnant
For seven damn months I thought she was expectin'
Then I found out it wasn’t mine, but that was only half the issues off my mind

lyrics: I done vandalized the industry full circuit
annotation:
Kendrick may be referring to his feature on Big Sean’s 2013 track “Control.” Kendrick declared himself rap’s “king” and put almost every relevant rapper in the game on notice.

Another way Kendrick challenged the music industry was his performance of the racially-charged track “The Blacker The Berry” at the 2016 Grammys. The performance included depictions of African tribal dances, mass incarceration, murder, and other political issues pertaining to African-Americans. It could be considered “vandalizing the industry” as such powerful topics and imagery involving the concerns of black Americans are rarely addressed at mainstream music awards shows like the Grammys.

lyrics:
I don't let 'em play with me
I don't let 'em talk to me no kind of way
Uh, they better watch what they say to me
Niggas still gettin' popped on the day to day
annotation:
In similar fashion to his line on “Cold”: “We in the building, we still keep it basement” – Kanye reminds everyone that even though he hasn’t lived in the streets recently, he still has the “street mentality”. He’s well aware that there were 509 murders in Chicago just a few years ago.

During his interview with Zane Lowe, Ye spoke on what it means to be “levelled” – just because he’s a black rapper trying to be a fashion designer, it doesn’t mean people should speak down to him.

lyrics:
Sweet tone like a hummingbird when she asked him
Did he want to make love in a yellow taxi
annotation:
Hummingbirds make short, soft calls. created by the rapid beating of their wings. This could be referencing how quickly they began their romance when she asked him to have sex on the ride home. Making love in a taxi, or on the ride home shows a rush into romance like the rapid humming of a hummingbird.

Specifically talking about a yellow taxi could be a reference to the Joni Mitchell classic, Big Yellow Taxi, in which a big yellow taxi takes the main character’s girl away. This links to the song as she falls quickly for someone bigger than him and is taken away.

lyrics:
If I’m tried in a court of law, if the industry cut me off
If the government want me dead, plant cocaine in my car
Would you judge me a drug-head or see me as K. Lamar?
Or question my character and degrade me on every blog?
annotation:
Since Lamar’s image is relatively clean – he doesn’t smoke or drink heavily and is engaged to his high school sweet-heart – finding cocaine in his car evokes conspiracy theory. While the “establishment” may be threatened by his controversial thinking, Kendrick asks his fans if they’ll stand behind him, or will they stereotype him as “just another gang banger”?

Conspiracy theory is something fellow TDE member Ab-Soul is very familiar with.

lyrics: [Verse 3: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation:
Kendrick Lamar’s verse were shots at a beautiful popular girl who he had a crush on in High school maybe. She didn’t show Kendrick any attention or give him the time of day because he didn’t have enough money or a car like other guys, she wouldn’t settle for someone who didn’t have money to please her. After a while Kendrick realized she was a gold digging ho. She was stuck living in the time and hadn’t planned for the future to find a man who had potential, like Kendrick.

In his last verse “Memories Back Then”, Kendrick says:

Fast forward, wait is that you?
With them big old thighs after school?
And your 3 kids and 3 baby daddies
And car note that’s overdue?
I know

A couple years later, he notices her after school (probably picking up one of her three kids), Kendrick used “big ole' thighs” as an insult in this verse because from having three kids she has gotten fat. She doesn’t have a man anymore so she has no time to work out. Her car note hasn’t been paid. She jumped from man to man, maybe because her previous men fell off and went broke, who would want a girl with three children, also which comes with three different fathers of those children. This girl is nothing but trouble. She’s going through hell. He adds the “I Know” only because he knew she’d end up that, he knows that she is upset and regrets it.

lyrics:
The earthiest slash thirstiest nigga you know versus this
Scum of a land that transcend two surfaces
annotation: Kendrick juxtaposes being down to earth with his “thirst” for fame and success—he still lives in Compton, but he’s one of the most successful artists of his generation.

lyrics:
Yeah, I still got the hundred with the small face, nigga
Might spend 50 racks on my off day, nigga
annotation:
Old money, Benjamin Button “What?” nothin'

While the new $100 note looks like this:

The old one looks like this (note the smaller face):

By referencing currency with an older design, Kanye slyly suggests that he’s been rich since before big-face hundreds debuted in 1996. His Throne partner Jay Z made a similar boast in ‘98 on “Money Ain’t A Thang”:

I been spending hundreds since they had small faces

lyrics: Woke up in the morning to The Great Gatsby
annotation:
The Great Gatsby is a famous novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald, published in 1925.

While both Kendrick and Kobe wake up every morning to an extravagant lifestyle, similar to main protagonist Jay Gatsby, here, the novel’s title is used as a metaphor for a car crash. A series of vehicle collisions comprise the story’s climax.

‘The Great Gatsby’ is also a story about adultery. In the novel, Daisy Buchannan cheats on her husband Thomas Buchannan with Jay Gatsby. The novel also has a tragic ending similar to the song.

Linking to the “yellow taxi” line above, Gatsby drove a Yellow 1928 Rolls Royce Phantom I Ascot dual-cowl phaeton.

lyrics:
Everybody, everybody, everybody
Everybody sit yo' bitch-ass down
And listen to this true mothafuckin' story
Told by Kendrick Lamar on Rosecrans, ya bitch
annotation:
Rosecrans Avenue, the location of the story, is a famous street that runs through Paramount & Compton, California, known for the large amount of violence on which it occurs.

Won’t you spend a weekend on Rosecrans, nigga
Khaki creasing, crime increasing on Rosecrans, nigga

lyrics:
Want you to love me like Nelson, want you to hug me like Nelson
I freed you from being a slave in your mind, you’re very welcome
You tell me my song is more than a song, it’s surely a blessing
But a prophet ain’t a prophet til they ask you this question:
annotation:
Kendrick wants to be revered like the iconic Nelson Mandela. He compares freeing the minds of Black America with songs like “i” to Mandela’s work against the apartheid regime in South Africa.

Kendrick’s consciousness dates as far back as 2011, with the closing song, “Hiiipower,” from his album, Section.80, where Kendrick helps the audience free their minds from being a slave. At the end of the first verse, along with the other verses in the song, he says:

While you mothafuckas waiting, I be off the slave ship
Building pyramids, writing my own hieroglyphs

As each verse progresses, he changes it from ‘my,’ ‘your,’ then ‘our.’

Kendrick commented on The Breakfast Club, saying a lot of his fans take his music very seriously.

lyrics: A new Monte Carlo that cruise
annotation:
Kendrick got a new Chevrolet Monte Carlo.
But he makes his girl feel so special like being on one of these luxurious cruises in Monaco, Monte Carlo, one of the most expensive casino cities in the south of France.

ACCEPTED COMMENT: He’s actually tying this line with the previous line. He is saying that the girl wouldn’t ride with him unless he was pushing a new Monte Carlo (Which he did not have) And that’s why it shot his pride in the next line

lyrics:
The richer the poorer, the bigger the picture
The more blood pours, but—
annotation:
Kendrick’s alluding to impending social upheaval caused by inequality.

“The richer the poorer” refers to the steady increase of the wealth gap and the diminishing middle class in the U.S. To Kendrick, “the bigger the picture” is that crime stems from inequality, so the people in power who manipulate the system are just as responsible as the people committing the act.

On “Mortal Man,” the last song on Kendrick’s 2015 album To Pimp a Butterfly, Kendrick sampled a previously unreleased 2Pac interview wherein the deceased rapper expressed the same idea:

The poor people is gonna open up this whole world and swallow up the rich people. ‘Cause the rich people gonna be so fat, they gonna be so appetizing, you know what I’m saying, wealthy, appetizing. The poor gonna be so poor and hungry, it’s gonna be like… there might be some cannibalism out this mutha, they might eat the rich. I think that niggas is tired of grabbin’ shit out the stores and next time it’s a riot there’s gonna be bloodshed for real.

“Picture” and “pitcher” are homophones when “picture” is pronounced like Kendrick pronounces it here—pitchers are used to pour liquids, and the bigger a pitcher is, the more liquid it can hold.

lyrics:
You a fake Denzel like the Allstate nigga
If you run into me, better have Allstate with yah
annotation:
The actor that appears in a majority of Allstate Insurance commercials, Dennis Haysbert, has a strong resemblance to Denzel Washington – but he’s no Coach Boone.

Playing off the Allstate remark, if you’re messing with Kanye you better be in good hands, ALL DAY.

“Better have allstate with ya” might also mean something along the lines of having backup (instead of having insurance). For example, “all-state” is a way to refer to a team, implying you should have a whole squad with you.

lyrics: Then he dogged it again like the bitch Lassie
annotation:
“Lassie Come-Home” is a novel written in 1940 by Eric Knight. It was adapted to film in 1943, which in turn was nominated for an Oscar. Following the film, a TV series was created, which ran from 1954 to 1974 and subsequently, another film adaptation in 1994. The story revolves around the eponymous female dog.

To “dog” is a figure of speech used by men to describe how well they performed during sex. “Dogged” is also synonymous with “disrespected.” It originates from the occurrence of male dogs that have intercourse with bitches or female dogs, and then immediately abandon them.

lyrics:
Smokin' on the finest dope, ay-ay-ay-ah
Drank until I can't no mo', ay-ay-ay-ah
Really I'm a sober soul
But I'm with the homies right now
And we ain't askin' for no favors
Rush a nigga quick, then laugh about it later, ay-ay-ay-ah
Really, I'm a peacemaker
But I'm with the homies right now
And Momma used to say (say, say, say, say)
One day it's gon' burn you out (woo)
One day it's gon' burn you out, out, out
One day it's gon' burn you out (you, you, you, you, you, you)
One day it's gon' burn you
But I'm with the homies right now
annotation:
Kendrick doesn’t smoke, drink, nor commit acts of violence, but he feels pressured when all his friends are doing so.

Now on the threshold of manhood, Kendrick’s mother can no longer make decisions for him, only give him advice. She warns him that this lifestyle of being in the streets will eventually tire him out or bring about more serious consequences. He pays no regard to her warnings because he’s still faded with the homies, not worrying about inevitable future events.

lyrics:
Do you believe in me? How much you believe in her?
You think she gon’ stick around if them 25 years occur?
annotation:
As he did in the first verse, K. Dot begins the second verse with a series of rhetorical questions for his fans.

Just as Nelson Mandela’s wife waited 27 years for him to be released from prison, Kendrick wonders if his fiancée will wait 25 years (the minimum sentence for murder) for him to return.

Kendrick has alluded to committing murder five times (including this line) in his lyrics. Twice in Section.80: “Hol' Up” & “Ab-Soul’s Outro”, as well as good kid, m.A.A.d city: “m.A.A.d city”, and To Pimp A Butterfly: “The Blacker The Berry”.

lyrics:
And that shot my pride, I tried to improv
But no freestyle I never do
annotation:
He tried to compensate for his lack of wheels, but he knew that no freestyle (the only gift he could then afford) could change her mind

This could also have a deeper meaning if you think about it. He said he tried to improv which is what a rapper would do in a freestyle, but Kendrick doesn’t freestyle metaphorically so he couldn’t improv on being what the girl wanted.

lyrics: [Verse 2]
annotation:
The song switches here to a familiar beat: the same one Kendrick uses on the DAMN. track “FEAR.,” which was released a few weeks after “The Heart Part 4.” Alchemist is the sole producer on both tracks. Kendrick uses this beat for the first eight bars of verse two, before switching to a different instrumental.

Interestingly, Kendrick discusses his own fears on the DAMN. track—e.g. his mother during his youth, his mortality during adolescence, losing the respect of his peers now that he’s older—but during this interpolation, he uses the beat to address all who fear him.

lyrics:
You a Rico Suave nigga
Ride 'round listen to Sade, nigga
If you ain't with us, you in our way, nigga
annotation:
Gerardo’s “Rico Suave” was a hit single in 1990; the song and video depicted a tan, oiled-up Latin playboy who specializes in small-time womanizing and corny dancing.

Sade is one of the great R&B artists of the last thirty years; she is known for her dark, soulful ballads of love and loss. Her biggest hit, 1984’s “Smooth Operator”, mocks men who think they are more or less Rico Suave types.

Why does Kanye think you’re a buster if you take after Gerardo and Sade? First, because it suggests that you’re trapped in the 1980s and 1990s, when these artists were in their heyday. And second, because it suggests that you’re “soft” (not to say feminized), like the tanned and shirtless “Rico Suave”, or like the proverbial guy who breaks down crying in the middle of a soulful Sade ballad. On a song so hardcore that the President from 24 gets called out, that isn’t going to cut it for Kanye.

lyrics:
Britney with the twin and the girl Ashley
Found out that I fucked, he was unhappy
annotation:
Ashley and Britney are two very common names for women.

The line is a homage to Weezy’s 2015 track “Alphabet Bitch” where he raps:

Well the A is for Ashley
She always ask for me to take it out her pussy […]
B is for Brittany she right in the class
She be hatin on Ashley cause she tight in the ass

The guy has sex with multiple women but when he finds out his girl had sex with Kendrick and Wayne, he gets angry.

lyrics: [Verse 1]
annotation: The bass that comes just before the first verse is a sample from the beginning riff of “The Arrival” by WZRD.

lyrics:
You think he can hold you down when you down behind bars, hurt?
You think y’all on common ground if you promise to be the first?
annotation:
After asking the male perspective, Kendrick asks the female audience if the man they think is “the one” would really be there for them through the thick and thin.

The question based style is reminiscent of 50 Cent’s “21 Questions”:

If I got locked up and sentenced to a quarter century / Could I count on you to be there to support me mentally?

lyrics: To make it rain on you like I'm about to break a levee
annotation:
Levees are raised ridges on the sides fo rivers, designed to prevent flooding

This girl is looking for a dude with LOTS of money

Famously, levees in New Orleans broke during Hurricane Katrina in ‘05

lyrics:
My fans can't wait for me to son ya punk-ass
And crush ya whole lil' shit
I'll Big Pun ya punk-ass, you a scared lil' bitch
annotation:
Kendrick pays homage to deceased lyricist Big Pun, while possibly taking shots at either Drake or maybe Big Sean.

Top Dawg told Rosenberg that Kendrick wrote this on March 21, 2017. This suggests that Kendrick decided to steal Drake’s thunder as he celebrated the release of More Life, which came out March 18, 2017.

On the other hand, Big Sean often uses the catchphrase, “lil bitch,” which Kendrick could be using here to mock him.

Kendrick has mentioned Pun before on The Heart Series. On 2010’s “The Heart Pt. 1,” he lists him amongst legendary deceased MCs. Surprisingly, after Pun died, a video appeared of him hitting his wife with a gun.

lyrics:
You an actor, you should be on Broadway, nigga
'Cause you do shit the broad way, nigga
annotation:
Broadway is a theatrical district in NYC that has been home to some of the most famous actors/actresses and performances. Ye plays off the Broadway reference by commenting that this person behaves like a woman (the broad way).

This line connects back to the previous mentioning of fake people – they act a certain way but truly have completely differing intentions.

lyrics:
Better yet, I wanna break up, don't you ask me
'Bout a motherfuckin' double standard, acting
Fucking on another nigga, that's a negative alone
But you sucked this dick, that's just nasty
Matter of fact, bitch, gimme your phone! (No!)
You fuckin' with Wayne's? (No!)
Bitch, gimme your phone! (No!)
annotation:
Kendrick has dipped into the perspective of the male in this relationship. He begins the verse as a narrator which creates a greater psychic distance as he is telling this story. With the shift into this perspective, Kendrick increases the psychic distance and changes his voice literally as he raps, as well as the voice of the character in the story he is telling. This signifies the perspective switch.

This technique is comparable to what Eminem does in the song “Stan.”

lyrics:
Me and my niggas four deep in a white Toyota
A quarter tank of gas, one pistol and orange soda
Janky stash box when the federales'll roll up
Basketball shorts with the Gonzales Park odor
We on the mission for bad bitches and trouble
annotation: After playing basketball in Gonzalez Park, Kendrick drove around all day with his homies, leaving only a quarter tank of gas left. With a pistol and a box to stash drugs in with them, Kendrick and his homies seem to be up to no good, looking to take part in dangerous activity and expel any bit of positivity in the air.

lyrics:
Can you be immortalized without your life being expired?
Even though you share the same blood, is it worth the time?
Like, who got your best interest?
Like ,how much are you dependent?
How clutch are the people that say they love you?
And who pretending?
annotation:
Kendrick questions if becoming a martyr for the people is worth the suffering of his family. Throughout the album, especially in “u”, Lamar feels guilty that he was chasing his legacy while his friends and family in Compton went through tough times. He further alludes to this in the third verse.

Kendrick poses a similar sentiment on 2012’s “Sing About Me, I’m Dying of Thirst”:

I said when the lights shut off
And it’s my turn to settle down
My main concern
Promise that you will sing about me
Promise that you will sing about me

lyrics: Hol' up, that pussy petty
annotation:
Her pussy/sex is worthless. Not even worth trying to get with her anymore.

Petty is also a homophone with “pedi” as in pedicure, which Kendrick describes with the next line, “Yeah, your nails did, your hair did”. Petty/Pedi could also just be linking an association with the type of woman absorbed in her appearance.

Kendrick also describes pussy as “pedicured” in the track Westside Right on Time feat. Jeezy.

Also this is a play on words. “Pussy” can be used to refer to a cat. Cats are generally kept as “pets”.

Also a reference to his track “Hol' Up” from album Section.80.

By calling her pussy petty, I believe that Kendrick is trying to say that the female is sexually spiteful/conceited/and small-minded, if you will, because she only wants to be with males who are superficially rich.

lyrics:
Tiptoein' around my name, nigga, you lame
And when I get at you, homie
Don't you just tell me you was just playin'
Oh, I was just playin', K-Dot
C'mon, you know a nigga rock with you, bro
annotation:
This could be a shot at Drake, who’s been involved in a subliminal war with Kendrick since 2013’s “Control.”

Kendrick mentioned Drake’s name on “Control,” but Drake has never put Kendrick’s name in a verse. However, he has subbed him on numerous occasions, including “The Language,” “Shit (Remix),” “6PM in New York,” “Used To,” “100,” and “Summer Sixteen.” The irony of these bars is the receiver is left unnamed, likely to leave the general public to decide.

In 2016, Drake tiptoed around Kendrick’s name again on “For Free:”

And like your boy from Compton said
You know this dick ain’t free!

Big Sean, another possible target of these lines who also has a history of possibly sending subliminal shots at Kendrick, might have tiptoed around Dot’s name in his 2016 song “No More Interviews.”

Sean mentioned “the savior of rap"—something Kendrick essentially refers to himself as on the same song.

These lines draw similarities to 21 Savage’s “No Heart.”

lyrics: Your bitch got a ass, but my broad way thicker
annotation:
I wanna dip that ass in gold, I wanna dip that ass in gold

Ye continues the “Broadway” rhyme scheme by using the homophone, broad way. Knowing that his wife is Kim Kardashian, it’s safe to say that his broad is way thicker. We know Kanye loves it.

lyrics:
Let me, let me take this call real quick
(… lick me like a lollipop) He on your fuckin' ringtone?
annotation:
During Wayne’s relationship with Karrine Steffans, Karrine claims that she “prioritized Wayne over her other partners” and even set Wayne’s 2011 hit “She Will” as a ringtone to his contact in her phone.

Kendrick parallels this with Lil Wayne’s popular 2008 track, “Lollipop,” featuring Static Major playing as the ringtone:

She, she, she lick me like a lollipop (I like that)
She, she lick me like a lollipop

This choice of ringtone is connected to Kendrick’s earlier line about his girlfriend providing oral sex to another man.

lyrics: [Produced by Flying Lotus & Ronald "Flippa" Colson]
annotation:
Additional production came from Sounwave and Stephen “Thundercat” Bruner. Horns and alto saxophone by Terrace Martin. Background vocals by Dr. Dre, Anna Wise, Ash Riser, Josef Leimberg and Whitney Alford (Kendrick’s fiancée).

Kendrick Lamar previously worked together with Flying Lotus on FlyLo’s hit single “Never Catch Me” which he actually wanted for this album.

Flippa says he co-produced his part with Pop Wansel.

lyrics:
I hope the universe love you today
'Cause the energy we bringin' sure to carry away
A flock of positive activists that fill they body with hate
If it’s necessary;
annotation:
Since Kendrick and his friends are riding around behaving recklessly, he hopes that luck is on the side of anyone that decides to test them, as they could body a whole group and fill their bodies with hate (bullets).

We see that this peer pressure extends to even people outside Kendrick’s group. Ff the friends or family of positive activists were shot, they’d likely abandon positivity and become filled with rage, motivating them commit revenge killings. Thus is the vicious cycle of a m.A.A.d city.

lyrics:
How tough is your skin when they turn you in?
Do you show forgiveness?
annotation: Kendrick continues to draw parallels with Mandela, who was incarcerated for almost three decades in South Africa during the Apartheid era. After becoming President, many people expected Mandela to seek vengeance and retribution against his oppressors. However, he enacted a policy of forgiveness – Kendrick is asking if the listener is magnanimous enough to do the same.

lyrics: Yeah, your nails did, your hair did
annotation:
He’s describing the woman that has manicured nails, nice hair and an expensive cell phone.

In addition to that, in the Drake’s T.I. featured track “Fancy”, Swizz Beatz raps repeatedly, “Nail done, hair done, everything did”, which this line here is a reference to.

lyrics:
Shut the fuck up, you sound like the last nigga I know
Might end up like the last nigga I know
Oh, you don't wanna clash? Nigga, I know
annotation:
“The last nigga I know,” may be a shot at Jay Electronica. Jay dissed Kendrick in a video, calling him lame and his son. He refused to play his music and said he didn’t like any of it except “Cartoons and Cereal.” After Ab-Soul dissed him, Jay backpedalled and posted a video saying he would collab with Kendrick, showing he didn’t want confrontation.

Kendrick may have dissed Jay before on “untitled 7:”

I can never end a career if it never start

Terrace Martin later denied that “untitled 7” was directed at Jay.

“You don’t wanna clash,” may also be a minor slight at Drake, who’s a big fan of the U.K. grime scene. Kendrick uses the word “clash” instead of “battle,” to highlight his awareness of Drake’s tendency to borrow U.K. slang.

lyrics:
Late for the class, in the hallway, nigga
Yeah, the dropout at it as always nigga, as always
annotation:
By now we should all know that the college dropout likes to do things at his own pace. Kanye’s been telling us about his tardy tendencies since at least 2005:

I know it’s late and I took all year but
You can stop complainin' cause I’m finally here

Even now, almost 10 years later, Yeezus premiered “All Day” almost 8 months after he told GQ magazine that this track was his “new single”. You know what they say though – better late than never. And fortunately Kanye always makes it worth the wait.

Notice how these lines also describe the cover art for his second studio album, Late Registration.

lyrics:
Is that the shit that you do? [sniffing]
Touchin' yourself, lookin' at Kendrick videos
annotation:
In these lines, Kendrick is rapping thru tears, from someone else’s perspective. His character has accepted this girl’s deception—that she is secretly attracted to a famous rapper—so he’s reprimanding her. This voice can be heard on other songs, such as his March 2015 track, “u.”

There was also an experimental music video released as a short film, titled “God is Gangsta”:

lyrics:
Every nigga is a star, ayy, every nigga is a star
Every nigga is a star, ayy, every nigga is a star
Every nigga is a star, ayy
Who will deny that you and I and every nigga is a star?
annotation:
The album opens with a sampled excerpt of Jamaican singer Boris Gardiner’s “Every Nigger is a Star,” the title track for the 1974 soundtrack of a film bearing the same name. Intended to change the perception of the word “nigger” in Jamaica and encourage black pride during the 1970s, its aim bears similarities to what Kendrick attempts to do for his listeners later on the record with “i.”

In an April 2015 interview with Mass Appeal magazine, Kendrick was asked why he chose to open with this interpolation:

It represents how I felt when I first got signed. That’s the first initial state—you get money, you feel like this. But overall, in general, it represents those without money of my color that’s rich in spirit. You don’t need dollars to feel like you have a place in the world.

This sample draws an immediate parallel to the caterpillar/butterfly metaphor throughout the album; how the lowliest caterpillar can become a beautiful butterfly. It is possible for a black person to succeed, despite all the institutionalized racism that works against them.

lyrics: What brush do you bend when dusting your shoulders from being offended?
annotation:
Kendrick explores the durability of one’s integrity – brush strokes represent coping mechanisms that barricade the negativity and prejudice someone may encounter.

This line also has a sense of empowerment. You possess the brush, allowing yourself to paint the world in whichever way you please; your ability to change your own perception of life grants you the power to change the perception of others.

Additionally, this line invokes Holy Grail’s “Dirt Off Your Shoulder” – Kendrick questions the audience as to what means they use to cleanse their shoulders.

lyrics: Her new prima donna I smelt it
annotation:
Kendrick can tell just by her smell, possibly overly gaudy perfume, that she is a prima donna, someone who is vain, arrogant, or generally obsessed with material things.

There is also the pun on prima donna and pre-Madonna by which Kendrick means he sees/smells, that this woman will become famous one day, like Madonna, hence the pun on pre-Madonna and prima donna. Since Kendrick is the new westcoast rap king, he even wants to be her new pre 2Pac, whom Madonna had an affair with.

lyrics:
I put my foot on the gas, head on the floor
Hoppin' out before the vehicle crash, I'm on a roll
annotation: “Foot on the gas,” is a metaphor for Kendrick’s upcoming album. After the album releases, the industry will be injured from the impact it makes. He uses the homonym “roll” to mean both rolling out of a car and his belief that his next album will be his third classic in a row.

lyrics:
I took a young sweet breath, and I reached into my Earth
Gave him what I had left
At that moment I dispersed
At that moment I dispersed
annotation:
Allan’s bridge describes Ye’s creative process and his “service to the people” mantra.

Kanye’s become one of the great curators of the modern era and has always been admired for his “open” creative process. Rather than doing it all himself, Ye likes to surround himself with the best individuals in each field before “dispersing” product into the world.

There may also be a connection between Allan Kingdom’s refrain and a passage of Genesis that describes God’s creation of man.

Genesis 2:7 says:

Then the Lord God formed a man from the dust of the ground
and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life,
and the man became a living being.

Kingdom discusses the song coming from a religious mind-state in his Complex interview, stating:

The chorus was just a piece of a larger story that I had written. It was like a prayer, a whole prayer-song thing that I wrote, and he liked that one piece for that song.

lyrics:
Forgot all the shit that I did for your daughter?
The Pampers, the Pedialyte and my momma
annotation: Pampers are a brand of diapers and Pedialyte is a drink, fueled with electrolytes, used to treat dehydration and vomiting in small children.

lyrics: [Intro: Josef Leimberg]
annotation:
Josef Leimberg is a producer, trumpeter, and former member of 90’s hip hop group MadKap. Though Leimberg was largely unknown before To Pimp A Butterfly, he has an extensive discography, including a horn credit on Big KRIT’s “Angels”.

On his turn behind the mic for this intro to “Wesley’s Theory,” Leimberg claimed that it was almost by accident; a friend of bandleader Terrace Martin’s, Leimberg was laying down some horns for To Pimp a Butterfly when Kendrick overheard Leimberg speaking. In an interview with DJBooth, Leimberg said:

“When [Kendrick] heard my voice, he turned around and said ‘I need that on my album.’ I thought he was bullshitting until the homie Terrace called me and said, ‘Kendrick said have your horn guy come back.’ He didn’t even know my name. So when Dre came up to do a vocal piece on the song he asked Kendrick who that was on the intro, he said, ‘That’s LA Joe.’ He didn’t know my name was Josef Leimberg or the history of what I’ve done in the early ‘90s. He just heard my voice and he wanted that on his album.

Leimberg appears on trumpet throughout the album, and also received writing credits on “How Much a Dollar Cost” and “You Ain’t Gotta Lie (Momma Said)”, the same two tracks produced by unknown producer LoveDragon, whose identity is widely believed to be either Leimberg or both Leimberg and Terrace Martin.

Through all the smoke in the car, Kendrick can only see a hand pass a blunt, which we later find out to be laced with cocaine. He mentions George Foreman, a former boxer and inventor of the George Foreman Grill, which heat up very quickly, hence hotboxing, a term that also refers to smoking weed in a closed environment. Kanye West originally used this pun in “Family Business.”

“Grilling the masses” refers to how Kendrick and his crew have hardened faces toward the outside world, especially those who don’t understand them (i.e. corporate America).

lyrics: What kind of den did they put you in when the lions start hissing?
annotation:
Kendrick alludes to the parable of Daniel, whose belief is tested when he’s thrown into a lions den after his friends betray him.

Daniel’s true enemies are not the lions, or the King who placed him in the dungeon, but rather his peers who betrayed him. This is stressed by the unnatural hissing of the lions, as if they were not lions but snakes in disguise. Lamar toys with the concept of loyalty being tested: his den is fame and the lions he’s trapped with are the music industry – false friends who will try to take advantage of his power.

lyrics: Only deal with rich niggas—fuck you and Mick Romney!
annotation:
Kendrick’s annoyed at her. She’s only going for rich people. This line is a shot at her for going for the rich people and at the rich people themselves (Mitt Romney). Why should they get girls simply because of their money?

Mitt Romney’s policies favor and support the rich. So they both have in common their love for the rich while neglecting those of lower socioeconomic status

He in fact says: “Fuck you and MICK Romney.” He did this on purpose to emphasise his hate and lack of respect for Romney, the fact that he doesn’t give people like him attention for anything they have (Including the pronunciation of their name), which I think adds that much to the flavour of that line.

lyrics:
Yellin', "One, two, three, four, five
I am the greatest rapper alive"
So damn great, motherfucker, I've died
What you hearin' now is a paranormal vibe
annotation:
Since To Pimp A Butterfly, Kendrick has bragged about being “the greatest,” and for good reason. The seven-time Grammy Award winner (he took home five in 2016 alone) can boast that both of his major label albums are considered classics, and he placed at #9 on Billboard’s “Top 10 Rappers of All Time” list.

He plays on the idea that once you die you live in infamy forever. Rappers such as Tupac and The Notorious B.I.G. soon became legends after their untimely deaths, with their rap legacies left untarnished. Kendrick has become one of the greatest without having to die but jokes that this verse is from beyond the grave.

Interestingly, Kendrick admitted to dying on “Buried Alive Interlude:”

So dig a shovel full of money, full of power, full of pussy
Full of fame and bury yourself alive, then I died

These lines reference KRS-One’s 1997 song “Step Into a World (Rapture’s Delight),” and have been thought to be directed at either Big Sean or Drake, both of whom have claimed they’re top 5 on numerous occasions. The line draws similarities to Drake’s claim on “Gyalchester,” which was released only six days before “The Heart Part 4.”

lyrics:
Pour some Hen out for my niggas that died, all day, nigga
And I keep a bad bitch on the passenger side, all day, nigga
annotation:
In a tradition as old as time, Yeezy pours out some Hennessy for his lost brethren.

Additionally, he brought along a little something for himself.

lyrics:
Bitch I'm emotional 'cause I'm in stress
I'm not supposed to go through this, I guess
So in conclusion, since you like rappers that's killin' that pussy
I'm killin' myself
annotation: Kendrick plays on the word “pussy” as it is a common term for the female’s genitalia and is also a term for a person that’s not manly or in this case, “emotional.” Kendrick is “emotional” after finding out that his girl has been sleeping with different rappers like Weezy, therefore he calls himself a “pussy”—tying into the “I’m killin' myself” line.

lyrics:
Hit me!
When the four corners of this cocoon collide
You’ll slip through the cracks hopin' that you’ll survive
Gather your weight, take a deep look inside
Are you really who they idolize?
To pimp a butterfly
annotation:
“Hit me” was a common catchphrase employed by funk legend James Brown, and later repurposed as a hip-hop intro by Public Enemy on “911 Is a Joke.” The introductory sample of “Every Nigger is a Star” paints a picture of the larger metaphor of “Wesley’s Theory.” The term “four corners” may refer to street corners, but it usually speaks in regard to the globe, as discussed in such biblical verses as Revelation 7:1:

And after these things I saw four angels standing on the four corners of the earth…

This apocalyptic imagery also recalls the numerous earthquakes that are predicted to take place during the eschatological Tribulation Period, or the Second Coming of Jesus Christ. This is further established in the last song on the tracklist, “Mortal Man,” when 2Pac says:

The ground is gonna open up and swallow the evil, right
That’s how I see it, my word is bond

When the artist “breaks out” of the proverbial cocoon, or ghetto, their journey begins as the butterfly. Described as “the talent, the thoughtfulness, and the beauty within the caterpillar” in the album’s outro, the artist must continue to stay true to themselves. If they’re successfully pimped, perhaps they are no better than those who are idolized in the hood, such as sex traffickers, drug dealers, or murderers.

lyrics:
we pulled up on a bunch of workin' girls
And asked them what they workin' with
Look at me, I got the blunt in my mouth
Usually I’m drug-free, but, shit, I’m with the homies
annotation: This verse ends with an interesting spin on the hook’s idea of being “with the homies”. In addition to friendship, hanging with them can also pressure you into behavior you wouldn’t otherwise engage in such as smoking weed and hanging with prostitutes. He’s said in several interviews that he doesn’t smoke anymore, so he overlooks his personal choice to vibe out with the homies.

lyrics:
What kind of bridge did they burn?
Revenge or your mind when it’s mentioned
You wanna love like Nelson, you wanna be like Nelson
annotation: Once freed from prison and elected as the first democratic president of South Africa, Nelson Mandela was in the position to punish/ seek retribution. Instead of starting another civil war, Mandela taught both white & black communities to love and respect one another – to love like Nelson, is to love unconditionally.

lyrics:
I’m po-o-o-oppin'
Change my phone now when I get home now
I got o-o-o-options
annotation:
Shows where Kendrick is now. he has options, he doesn’t need her anymore.

Sounds mighty similar to a line in Backseat Freestyle

She pussy popping and I got options like an audible

lyrics:
House on the hill, house on the beach, nigga (facts)
A condo in Compton, I'm still in reach, nigga (facts)
annotation:
On Kendrick’s last project, To Pimp a Butterfly, he criticized himself for abandoning his hometown for fame. On “u,” he rapped:

You ain’t no brother, you ain’t no disciple, you ain’t no friend
A friend never leave Compton for profit or leave his best friend

Kendrick’s wealth has allowed him to buy homes in expensive, “upper-class” areas, but he still has a condo in his hometown of Compton. Despite his success, he’s still connected to his roots and understands the issues of the socioeconomically disadvantaged.

This could also be a subliminal shot at Drake, who owns a home in Hidden Hills. Kendrick is likely responding to Drake thinking he outgrew condos on “Gyalchester:”

I gotta do mansion, ‘cause I outgrew condo

lyrics:
I could do this all day, boy, I'm finna turn this bitch out
They need that Ye in the streets, boy, there's been a mothafuckin' drought
annotation:
Yeezy has dropped an album almost every year since his debut in 2004, so he uses the metaphor of a drought because there’s been a 2-year wait for this album.

Alternatively, the drought could refer to a period of time without much good music released – Kanye’s back to fill that vacancy.

Note – “Ye” is also short for yayo. These lyrics equally serve as a reference to the American crack epidemic. As he raps on “Crack Music”:

Sometimes I feel the music is the only medicine
So we, cook it, cut it, measure it, bag it
Sell it, the fiends cop it, nowadays they can’t tell if. That’s that good shit, we ain’t sure man
Put the CD on your tongue, yeah that’s pure man

lyrics:
At first, I did love you
But now I just wanna fuck
Late nights thinkin' of you
Until I get my nut
Tossed and turned, lesson learned
You was my first girlfriend
Bridges burned, all across the board
Destroyed, but what for?
annotation:
Kendrick metaphorically refers to the rap game as his “first girlfriend,” acknowledging how the relationship quickly transformed from love to lust. This coincides with the album’s overall theme of artists being used or enticed by the industry.

Kendrick would revisit a similar phrase later, on his March 2017 single “The Heart Part 4”:

Tables turned, lesson learned, my best look
You jumped sides on me, now you ‘bout to meet Westbrook

lyrics: [Hook 1]
annotation: Kendrick impersonates his younger self’s enthusiastic and stereotypical attitude towards gang activities. The tone and pitch of his voice in this interlude clearly mocks the empty threats that young K.Dot is making and reinforces the songs main theme of peer pressure.

lyrics:
You wanna walk in his shoes, but your peacemaking seldom
You wanna be remembered that delivered the message
That considered the blessing of everyone
This your lesson for everyone, say;
annotation:
Many voice their opinion on the wrongs in the world but do nothing themselves to correct it. Nelson Mandela gave 27 years of freedom for his beliefs. Can you do the same?

Kendrick has dedicated an entire album to lead by example. The message Kendrick delivers throughout To Pimp a Butterfly attempts to inspire others to not only learn about the plight of Black America, but to do something about it.

lyrics:
Fast forward, wait, is that you?
With them big ol' thighs after school?
And your three kids and three baby daddies
Same car note that’s overdue?
annotation:
The girl he once pursued is now a mother of three, all of whom have different fathers. This, as well as the overdue car notes that infer she’s financially not well off, give the impression her life didn’t play out how she would’ve envisioned it as a youth.

Additionally, in the verse’s beginning her “big ol' thighs” were a desirable quality, however now in this context it’s implied she’s no longer curvaceous but out of shape, sporting old and out of shape thighs likely due to carrying her three children and minimal care she allocates to her health/appearance.

lyrics: I'm fresh out the water, I'm 'bout to breach, nigga
annotation:
Large sea animals often “breach” the ocean’s surface by lifting most of their body out of the water and then crashing back down, making an enormous splash.

Much like those animals, Kendrick has emerged from the two year hiatus he’s been on since he released To Pimp a Butterfly. He plans on making a big splash with his new album.

Kendrick uses similar aquatic imagery in “Deep Water” from Dr. Dre’s 2015 album Compton. He describes Compton as an environment full of dangerous predators. His return to this theme emphasizes his continuing ties to Compton, and warns other rappers that while their lives may be endangered here, this is Kendrick’s natural habitat.

lyrics:
Don't really matter what I make, boy, you know I still go wild
Like a light-skinned slave, boy, we in the mothafuckin' house!
annotation:
Kanye draws parallels between slaves and his own experience in the fashion world. Privilege was often given to slaves of lighter skin tone during the 18th and 19th centuries, such that they were allowed indoors (e.g. tending to the master’s children, cooking or cleaning). On the other hand, darker skinned slaves were forced to work in the fields. Malcolm X elaborated on this topic in his famous “The House Negro and the Field Negro” speech.

Kanye’s foray into fashion has taken him from picking the cotton himself, to being let into the house. It’s no coincidence fashion companies are referred to as “houses”.

lyrics: [Verse 1: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation:
Kendrick starts off the story emulating a young version of himself. In this verse he alters his voice as he did in “m.A.A.d city”. He discusses his early dream of cashing out while still an ignorant artist without true understanding of the world.

Young Kendrick, focused on escaping his home of Compton, has yet to realize the dangers that come with money. He plans to throw money around with all of his friends but doesn’t realize the danger that lurks around success.

This braggadocious verse is reminiscent of Kendrick in his “Backseat Freestyle,” adding to the setting of this verse.

lyrics:
Yeah, nigga, we off a pill and Remy Red
Come through and bust ya head, nigga!
annotation:
A young Kendrick and his homies took some drugs and alcohol so they’re ready to fight.

The combo of pills and Remy Red has been mentioned in a Kendrick song before

lyrics: I been wrote off before, I got abandonment issues
annotation:
His abandonment issues come from the departure of friends in his life and the fact that he was not given a full chance but still made it against the odds.

Like labels have dismissed Kendrick’s work in the past. He has previously mentioned his animosity toward the labels who wrote him off in Overly Dedicated’s “Ignorance is Bliss”:

Now the only way these labels get me back is when they rewind me

lyrics: I know
annotation:
He knows that it’s sad she ended up that way and the irony’s Kendrick the broke nigga is now rich & famous, but he doesn’t want her anymore. On top of that Girls love Kendrick so he got o-o-o-options

The “I know” is a very all-encompassing statement. It’s used as a tool, almost answering to a statement that wasn’t even made. The previous 4 lines are almost asked directly to the girl in question, and the “I know” is tacked on to show that she doesn’t even need to attempt to explain herself. Just a statement to show that whatever she’s been through and whatever she says her story is, he knows without even having to have the entire convo with her.

lyrics: The five-foot giant woke up out of his sleep, nigga
annotation:
The phrase “awaken a sleeping giant” is thought to have orginated from Japanese admiral Isoroku Yamamoto after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941 which brought USA into World War 2.

I fear all we have done is to awaken a sleeping giant and fill him with a terrible resolve.

This comparison suggests that attacks by other rappers on Kendrick have forced him to attack back.

Kendrick stands below average height at only 5'5", but his position in the rap game makes him a giant. He creates an oxymoron to emphasize his mental capabilities—despite his physical stature, his words make him powerful. His “sleep” represents his two-year hiatus; he hasn’t released a full-length album since 2015’s To Pimp A Butterfly.

lyrics: Right now, you lookin' real sus right now
annotation: Kanye might also be mocking the perception of African-American men as looking “suspicious” when they are merely going about their business. This misconception is one that leads to misjudgment of young black males, a theme West explores in great depths on his June 2013 album, Yeezus, and in particular on “New Slaves.” “Sus” is not only a prefix for “suspicious” and “suspect,” it is also slang for lame.

lyrics:
When I get signed, homie, I'ma act a fool
Hit the dance floor, strobe lights in the room
Snatch your little secretary bitch for the homies
Blue-eyed devil with a fat-ass monkey
I'ma buy a brand new Caddy on vogues
Trunk the hood up, two times, deuce-four
annotation:
In these lines, Kendrick seems to have given up on being a voice for the voiceless in the ghetto, as he had first planned. Instead of fighting for the people who are still poor, he is being selfish and enjoying the fact that he isn’t poor anymore, rather than using his success as a way to help others. He broke down this part of the verse in a March 2015 MTV interview with Rob Markman:

The lines portray a speaker falling into the same trap that many black artists fell into before him. Once these artists are signed, they lose touch with their former goals and aspirations; exchanging them for wealth and fame. They’re being “pimped” by label owners and submerged in carnal delights.

For example, Kendrick uses the term “monkey” as slang for a vagina, while “blue-eyed devil” is a racial epithet which, in this case, is directed toward a white woman. This foreshadows the personification of “Lucy,” or Lucifer, as a promiscuous woman. The phrase “blue-eyed devil” has historical use among the Nation of Islam—including Malcolm X before his pilgrimage to Mecca.

lyrics: Me and the homies
annotation:
Kendrick employs more simplistic lines to complement the more important section of this hook/interlude which happens to be the teen yelling about getting fucked up, sagging his pants, and just being all-around ignorant. This shows how peer pressure and bad influences can really misguide someone’s mentality.

He is known to use this technique, like in his song “Swimming Pools,” where he portrays someone trying to get the party drunk. In reality, Kendrick is really trying to warn people about the effects of alcoholism.

lyrics: I hold grudges like bad judges, don’t let me resent you
annotation:
Bad Judges and magistrates are notorious for holding one view of the law – being either harsh on a certain type of criminal for a certain type of offense (or being too easy on certain types of criminals), or, even worse, holding an actual grudge against a particular individual, and sentencing him/her more harshly when that individual is brought before the judge.

Kendrick has also documented this side of his life before in the Song ​m.A.A.d city where he sings:

Aw man, goddamn, all hell broke loose
You killed my cousin back in ‘94, fuck your truce

He also told us his feelings about the judge in King Kunta, early in this album:

Ah yeah, fuck the judge
I made it past 25 and there I was
A little nappy-headed nigga with the world behind him

Now you see why you shouldnt hold a grudge with this kid?

lyrics:
Oh yeah, oh yeah, mo' cars, mo' lears
Mo' bars, no peers, no scars, no fear—fuck y'all, sincere
I heard the whispers, I curved the whispers
annotation:
“Lear” is an abbreviation of Learjet, a line of business class jets. Kendrick’s flaunting his wealth and success, which may make people “leer,” or look unpleasantly, at him. “Leer” could also be short for “lyrics,” tying into “mo' bars.”

Kendrick may also be poking fun at Drake. On “Do Not Disturb,” Drake rapped:

More blessings because I’m generous
Thirty-seater plane for like ten of us

Dissing Drake would be eliminating peers. He’s gone toe-to-toe with Drake before; he has no scars from their battles and no fear of going at it again. “The whispers” are likely Drake’s numerous subliminal Kendrick mentions, like those on “The Language,” “Shit (Remix),” “6PM in New York,” “Used To,” “100,” and “Summer Sixteen.”

lyrics: I swear I've been on this flight like a month right now
annotation: This song was likely recorded sometime around the Yeezus Tour, so it’s likely Kanye was writing between shows. He also flew to Germany and China for his Adidas line – both long-haul flights. This was when the Yeezy Boost 750 was first spotted.

lyrics:
When I get signed, homie, I'ma buy a strap
Straight from the CIA, set it on my lap
Take a few M-16s to the hood
Pass 'em all out on the block, what's good?
annotation:
Kendrick continues to indulge the stereotype of a newly wealthy rapper on the come up. But he complicates that with the mention of weapons from the CIA—politics are never far from Kendrick’s mind. He reminds us of the CIA’s contribution to a crack epidemic in the 1970’s and their role in the influx of guns in urban areas, particularly Los Angeles. The CIA, whether directly or indirectly, has contributed to the influx of drugs and guns in urban communities.

This also refers to the way a lot of rappers glorify the lifestyle of crime Kendrick described in GKMC. While they don’t directly give kids guns, the way they brag about them may prompt kids in similar situations to turn to that lifestyle.

lyrics:
Sag all the way to the liquor store
Where my niggas pour up 4 and get twisted some more
annotation:
They all sag their pants and walk to the liquor store so they can get even more fucked up.

Alternatively, in LA, the term “sag” is referred to driving, usually driving recklessly. So in previously lines he mentions how they are already off a pill and Remy Red, so they are about to “sag” (drive) to the liquor store and “get twisted some more.” .

lyrics:
That’s not Nelson-like—want you to love me like Nelson
I went to Robben’s Island analysing; that’s where his cell is
annotation:
Kendrick’s anger toward those who mistreated him is contrary to the more peaceful philosophies of Nelson Mandela.

Mandela was held in a cell on Robben Island for 18 of his 27 years spent in prison. Kendrick describes visiting Mandela’s cell to try and find clarity.

Nelson spoke on love many times throughout his life. He was an advocate for embracing all of humanity.

lyrics:
You know what the risk is
Earthed in ditches, your body revertin' to stiffness
annotation:
Rigor mortis is the stiffening of the body after death; the consequence for talking shit about Kendrick is lyrical murder.

This may also be an allusion to his song “Rigamortis” from 2011’s Section.80.

Also note that the statement “Earthed in ditches” can also be heard as “Earth indigenous”. Genesis 2:7 says this:

Then the Lord God formed a man from the dust of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and the man became a living being.

For something to be “indigenous” means that it originates from a certain place. Kendrick is saying that rappers were made out of the dust of then Earth and after death their bodies will return to their origin; the dust of Earth, thus making the “Earth indigenous” for them.

lyrics: Stupid niggas gettin' money, Forrest Gump right now
annotation:
As he did on The Breakfast Club in 2015, Kanye refers to the classic Tom Hanks film Forrest Gump.

Ironically, Forrest got rich from investing in Apple – the company Kanye talks about whenever he gets a chance:

Lieutenant Dan got me invested in some kind of fruit company. So then I got a call from him, saying we don’t have to worry about money no more. And I said, that’s good! One less thing.

Ye feels most businessmen aren’t on his taste level and he should be earning more dollars.

Using “stupid” in this context also brings to mind one of Forrest’s favorite sayings:

Stupid is as stupid does!

lyrics:
I'ma put the Compton swap meet by the White House
Republican run up, get socked out
annotation:
Compton’s swap meet (flea market) is known as the “Rodium” – it’s also a place Kendrick’s known his whole life.

Even though Kendrick graduated high school, his actions in this verse play with the stereotype of the “rapper” persona. He wants the new car, but he also wants to take over the White House. This is a similar to a notion label-mate Ab-Soul repeats throughout his songs.

It should be noted that these lines describe the scene of the album cover: An unconscious, possibly Republican, gavel-holding judge socked out at the Compton swap meet in front of the White House.

Kendrick (in the center holding a baby) and 20 homies are popping bottles, throwing up signs, and flashing a bunch of cash.

lyrics: I ride for my mothafuckin’ niggas
annotation:
Kendrick expresses undying loyalty to his crew, which is a common rap trope. The question here is if that’s the smart thing to do.

Also a reference to the famous “Fuck them other niggas, cause I ride for my niggas" hook in “Down 4 My Niggas” by C-Murder, featuring Magic and Snoop Dogg. This fits in pretty well since they’re listening to exactly that kind of music through the album ("Jeezy’s still playing and our attitude is still ‘nigga, what is you sayin’”)

lyrics:
See I got to question it all; family, friends, fans, cats, dogs
Trees, plants, grass, how the wind blow, Murphy’s Law
Generation X—will I ever be your ex?
annotation:
Kendrick is questioning his audience about their loyalty to him if something were to ever happen, presumably the change in the type of music he’s making now. Murphy’s Law states that “anything that can go wrong will go wrong,” so Kendrick uses that to ask if everyone of his generation is just going to stop being a Kendrick fan after some sort of change or wrongdoing. Also, Kendrick uses juxtaposition of dynamic things that may change and can be reasonably questioned, such as family, fans, and pets, to static things that will never change and wouldn’t really be reasonably questioned, such as nature. Kendrick possibly tries to say that while nature follows specific laws, interpersonal relationships aren’t defined.

“Will I ever be your X” could also be in reference to Malcolm X who is mentioned a few lines later. Malcolm X’s name comes from the custom of Black Panthers rejecting the surnames they were born with, on the grounds of their originating from slave owners, and instead using X as a stand in for their original ‘true’ African names – perhaps “generation X” (usually referring to grungy insolent white boys) is being turned on its head to refer to a new generation of black activists spearheaded by Kendrick

lyrics:
The whole world gone mad
Bodies is addin' up, market's about to crash
Niggas is fake rich, bitches is fake bad
Blacks that act white, whites that do the dab
annotation:
The world has become an increasingly dangerous and unstable place. Terrorist attacks, police violence, and military conflicts like Syria plague the world with violence and bloodshed. Kendrick also cites disingenuous people and cultural appropriators as causes for decline.

His prediction that the world’s unstable social climate will lead to a stock market crash isn’t unfounded—outlets like Forbes and Express have also theorized that the market is headed for a crash.

lyrics: Shout-out to Jackie Chan, I need to stunt right now
annotation:
While Jackie Chan is an actor known for doing his own stunts, despite all the dangers involved, Kanye’s version of “stunt” is street slang for showing off, or being flashy.

Like he rapped on “Devil In A New Dress”:

Hard to be humble when you stunting on a jumbotron.

lyrics:
Hit the prez with a Cuban link on my neck
Uneducated, but I got a million-dollar check like that
annotation:
Less than a year after making this boast, Kendrick would find himself invited for a one-on-one with Obama in the Oval Office, in which they spoke about Kendrick’s work with children, racial issues, and—just maybe— the president’s favorite song of the year.

Kendrick is definitely wearing a chain in their meeting, but it appears to be a bit more modest than the broader style of the classic Cuban link.

The second line, as referenced in the Genius interview with Kendrick about this album, shows how Kendrick is deeply troubled by the fact that in today’s school system, kids are taught about many things which they will never need in life but not about important, practical life lessons such as handling money and paying taxes. This plays into the song and the album as a whole, as Wesley Snipes is the example given in this song of someone who wasn’t educated on what they could and could not do with taxes and suffered the consequences.

lyrics: Me and the homies
annotation: The repetition of this simple line throughout the song is done to emphasize the change of Kendrick’s character from the “Good Kid” he normally is, to the crime committing Compton Kid he becomes when he is peer pressured by his homies. In addition, from a grammatically correct point of view, this line would be written as “The homies and I”; however, due to the “Compton/ghetto” mood he is creating, he uses informal slang throughout the song.

lyrics:
Put me under stress, crawled under rocks, duckin' y’all
It’s respect—but then tomorrow, put my back against the wall
annotation: The theme of the song (“When shit hit the fan, is you still a fan?”) is seen here: while Kendrick may have respect now, fickle fans are quick to “put [his] back against the wall” at a moment’s notice, over sometimes very little. Kendrick feels that pressure to do well and please everyone.

lyrics:
Donald Trump is a chump
Know how we feel, punk—tell him that God comin'
annotation:
Kendrick is among the many critics of U.S. president Donald Trump, who was inaugurated in January 2017. Many hip-hop artists share a mutual disdain for Trump—Kendrick’s fellow Compton rapper YG released a song titled “FDT (Fuck Donald Trump)” in March 2016.

This also isn’t the first time K-Dot has referenced Donald Trump on a track; he mentioned Trump on 2015’s “Black Friday” and rapped about vandalizing and smoking weed in the Trump Tower on label-mate Isaiah Rashad’s 2016 track “Wat’s Wrong.”

lyrics:
They've been lookin' at the Gram, I've been lookin' at the Grammys
Like, huh, that's us right now
annotation:
While you’re admiring Kanye on Instagram wishing you were there, he’s killing it on stage with Sir Paul McCartney & Rihanna at the Grammys.

Note – gram is another allusion to drugs, something Kanye did in earlier in this verse.

lyrics:
We should never gave
We should never gave niggas money
Go back home, money, go back home
We should never gave
We should never gave niggas money
Go back home, money, go back home
(Everybody get out)
annotation:
“We should have never gave you niggas money” was a phrase from the extremely influential Rick James sketch originally seen on a 2004 episode of Chappelle’s Show.

This may also be a reference to the Back to Africa Movement started by Marcus Garvey, as well as a nod to a previous Ab-Soul line from 2014’s “Tree of Life”:

You shoulda never gave us niggas money
We comin' for everything, you nah mean?

lyrics:
Matter of fact, I hop out that mothafucka
And be like "doo-doo-doo-doot, doo-doo-doo-doo-doot!”
annotation:
The group of homies talk a lot of shit about how they aren’t scared to shoot or kill someone. The “doo doo” sounds are imitating gun shots. Kendrick obviously knows this is ignorant, but doesn’t want to be the buzz killer of the group.

While this whole interlude is intended to be somewhat comical, there is also an element of foreshadowing to it. Kendrick’s homies dream about getting twisted and then doing a drive-by, which is exactly what happens during “Swimming Pools (Drank)” and the outro to that song.

lyrics:
How many leaders you said you needed then left ‘em for dead?
Is it Moses? Is it Huey Newton or Detroit Red?
Is it Martin Luther? JFK? Shooter—you assassin
Is it Jackie? Is it Jesse? Oh, I know it’s Michael Jackson—oh
annotation:
Kendrick is showing everyone how some of the most influential people throughout history have been betrayed:

  • Moses lead the Jews out of the oppressive rulers of Egypt to freedom but, while getting the ten commandments from God, the people he had just helped started to worship false Gods.

  • Huey Newton was an African-American political and urban activist who co-founded the Black Panther Party. He was assassinated by a member of the Black Guerrilla Family, which had former Black Panthers among its members.

  • Detroit Red, or Malcolm X, was one of the most influential leaders during the civil rights movement in the US. He was assassinated by members of the Nation of Islam, the group he once led.

  • Martin Luther King Jr. was a civil rights activist. He was assassinated by a white supremacist.

  • JFK, or John F. Kennedy was the President of the United States. He was assassinated—Kendrick calls the listener (metaphorically) a “shooter” and “assassin,” accusingly.

  • Jackie Robinson was the first black man to ever play in the Major Leagues for the then-Brooklyn Dodgers.

  • Jesse Jackson is an American civil rights activist.

  • Last but not least is the King of Pop himself, Michael Jackson. Although he was one of the greatest musicians to ever live, he faced scrutiny after accusations of child molestation and on his bizarre appearance and behavior.

lyrics: And Russia need a replay button, y'all up to somethin'
annotation:
President Trump is under heavy scrutiny—from both Democrats and Republicans—for his alleged interactions with the Russian government officials during the 2016 election. Kendrick claims that whatever may or may not have occurred between Russia and President Trump, and therefore the election outcome itself, needs to be examined with a “replay button,” like those used to allow sports officials to review a controversial call.

This is also a possible allusion to the 2009 “reset button” given by then Secretary of State Hillary Clinton to Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov in an attempt to symbolize a spirit of renewed good faith between the countries. Due to a comic translation error, the inscription on the gift read “overcharged button” rather than “reset button.”

lyrics: 24/7, 365 days, everybody gettin' paid
annotation: Echoing the words of Pusha T, Kanye reminds everyone it’s not just him who’s eating, it’s his entire team. The likes of Don C, Ibn Jasper, Virgil Abloh & Jerry Lorenzo all began working for Kanye before branching out and doing their own thing.

lyrics: [Break: Dr. Dre]
annotation: Aside from executive producing the album with Anthony “Top Dawg” Tiffith, this break is Dr. Dre’s only contribution to the album (aside from a rumor that he is LoveDragon). On Kendrick’s previous album good kid, m.A.A.d city, Dre mixed many of the tracks alongside Derek “MixedByAli” Ali and was featured on two tracks (“Compton” and “The Recipe”). He recognized that Kendrick didn’t need him as a prominent creative force for the project, assisting almost solely in polishing the album in the mixing process. For To Pimp A Butterfly, Dre has shown even more creative trust in Kendrick by almost completely stepping out of the process and letting Kendrick do his own thing.

lyrics:
It’s 2:30 and the sun is beamin'
Air conditioner broke and I hear my stomach screamin'
annotation:
Hot afternoon without a working air condition, and he’s hungry. Once again just setting the scene for the rest of the verse.

Possibly on purpose, or just by coincidence, Dot says it’s 2:30 at the moment where the song is 2 minutes and 30 seconds in.

lyrics:
When shit hit the fan, is you still a fan?
When shit hit the fan, is you still a fan?
That nigga gave us "Billie Jean," you say he touched those kids?
When shit hit the fan, is you still a fan?
annotation:
Controversy from a A-list celebrity leads to a heavy panning to said celebrity. Most notably, the “King of Pop” Michael Jackson faced numerous accusations of child sex abuse. This permanently tarred his reputation, even though he was later acquitted.

Kendrick is criticizing moral absolutism — the belief that people are wholly virtuous or wholly wicked based on a certain deed or group of deeds. For example, some point out that MLK was unfaithful to his wife and therefore should not be praised as the morally correct leader that many believe him to be.

Similarly, Kendrick does not want people to write off Michael Jackson as a mere child molester, even if he in fact was one. Because if the allegations that “he touched those kids” are true, they still don’t take away from the fact that Jackson was a revolutionary artist who touched the lives of millions and influenced a generation of musicians.

This line reflects a broader theme pervading the track and indeed the album as a whole: the need for forgiveness. As “Mortal Men”, all of us are in need of forgiveness; all of us are all sinners, from Kendrick to Michael Jackson to the pope himself. Yet in a world full of sinners, we must find the ability to empathize, identify, and share our common flaws if we are to find peace. And as Kendrick goes on to explain in the outro, all of this begins with forgiveness. We must forget “all the pain and the hurt we caused each other” and embrace love over hate, love over pride, love over everything. Only then can we find it possible to forgive ourselves and others.

lyrics:
Electorial votes look like memorial votes
But America's truth ain't ignorin' the votes
annotation:
Kendrick decries the electoral process of the United States of America. The President is elected not via “direct democracy” but by Electoral College delegates or “electors”. In November 2016, Donald Trump won the Presidential election by winning more states as opposed to winning the popular vote, which he lost to Democratic Party nominee Hillary Clinton by over 2.9 million votes.

Kendrick thinks America should fight for a more democratic process. From his perspective, the electoral vote system issued a “death sentence” for America because it resulted in Donald Trump’s win; a “memorial” service is a ceremony honoring the dead.

lyrics:
Niggas lookin' at me like I'm worth both MJs
People saying, "Ye, Ye, take it easy"
annotation: Kanye refers to Michael Jackson, the king of pop, and Michael Jordan – the greatest basketball player of all time. Both MJs are worth a lot of money, and had significant impacts in their professions – as has Kanye. Ye’s had huge impacts in both music and footwear.

lyrics:
Yo, what's up? It's Dre
Remember the first time you came out to the house?
You said you wanted a spot like mine
But remember, anybody can get it
The hard part is keepin' it, motherfucker
annotation:
This interjection from Dr. Dre introduces the next key part of the narrative—the temptation that comes with fame and success. You can have all the good intentions in the world but if you lose sight of yourself, it can quickly fall apart. Lamar’s mind and talent are a threat to the fearful “Uncle Sam,” who lures Lamar away from his beliefs and good intentions with materialism.

Dr. Dre reminds Kendrick that artists can blow up just as quickly as they can become irrelevant. Fame and fortune may seem easy enough to attain, but not becoming a “pimped” butterfly, like so many others, is harder than making it in the first place.

Kendrick spoke about this conversation with Dre as early as 2013. In an interview with XXL, Kendrick says:

I think my second studio session with Dre, we were at the house recording—this is one of his places—and I said, ‘Man, this shit is crazy here. I can’t wait to get one of these.’ He said ‘Oh, that’s the easy part. You could get it. Matter of fact, you probably can get it within the next year. The hardest thing is keeping it.’

lyrics:
Hungry for anything unhealthy
And if nutrition can help me
I’ll tell you to suck my dick, then I'll continue eatin'
annotation:
Kendrick has the munchies from the blunt he just smoked, and wants some snack foods. If someone tells him that he should eat something healthier he will tell them to fuck off. He may also be speaking metaphorically as well. “Hungry for anything unhealthy,” meaning he’s looking for trouble, and if doing the right thing (nutrition) is better, he still doesn’t care… because he’s with the homies.

Kendrick seems to touch lightly on some of America’s eating habits too. In cities/neighborhoods with working class people living near the poverty line, parents are sometimes so busy working to pay bills and put clothes on their kids backs that they don’t have time to cook a wholesome meal at home. The kids choose to go out and eat unhealthy because there’s nothing at the house to eat.

The second line could also be symbolic of abusing someone who’s just trying to help him. At this stage of the album Kendrick is still a rebellious youth, and it isn’t until later on in the album that he’s willing to listen to someone trying to put him on the right track.

lyrics: Spoken Outro:
annotation:
The album culminates with an outro comprising a fictional discussion between Kendrick and the late Tupac Shakur in the and may be broken into 3 parts:

  1. Kendrick reciting a poem to 2Pac, segments of which were scattered throughout the album
  2. Kendrick conversing with Pac about his experiences and views on the current state of America (check 2Pac’s original interview here)
  3. Kendrick reciting a second story to Pac and revealing the significance of the album’s title To Pimp A Butterfly.

Kendrick previously spoke about an experience he had when he was 21, where 2Pac came to him in a vision:

I was coming from a late studio session, sleeping on Mom’s couch. I’m 26 now – it wasn’t that long ago. I remember being tired, tripping from the studio, lying down, and falling into a deep sleep and seeing a vision of Pac talking to me. Weirdest shit ever. I’m not huge on superstition and all that shit. That’s what made it so crazy. It can make you go nuts. Hearing somebody that you looked up to for years saying, ‘Don’t let the music die.’ Hearing it clear as day. Clear as day. Like he’s right there. Just a silhouette.

Kendrick clearly draws a lot of his inspiration from 2Pac, even choosing to release this album 1 week early to coincide with the 20th anniversary of Me Against The World.

Pac famously stated:

I’m not saying I’m gonna change the world, but I guarantee that I will spark the brain that will change the world

Kendrick’s brain has certainly been sparked and now it’s his turn to spark the youth for long-term change.

lyrics:
It's blasphemy, how many gon' blast for me?
I prophesized on my last song, you laughed at me
annotation:
Here Kendrick references his West Coast idol Tupac and the East Coast great Jay Z—whose legacy he defends later in the verse.

In the first line, Kendrick highlights the oft-used “blasphemy/blast for me” homophone Tupac delved into in 1996, and Hov employed in his triple entendre line on 2006’s “Dear Summer.”

Kendrick, who sees himself as one of the GOATs like Jayhovah and Pac, feels it is blasphemous that rappers don’t send enough reverence his way, or “blast at [him]"—subliminally or explicitly. Kendrick is also rhetorically asking his dedicated fanbase how many of them are [literally or figuratively] willing to shoot at these detractors.

Continuing the religious theme, the second line interpolates Prophet Hov’s “Hard Knock Life” (Ghetto Anthem):"

I gave you prophecy on my first joint, and y'all lamed out
Didn’t really appreciate it ‘til the second one came out

Much has been written on Kendrick being a prophet for this generation of rap. In March 2015, Kendrick prophesied on “Mortal Man,” where he pondered a similar question:

When shit hit the fan, is you still a fan?

lyrics: 20 Gs for the Yeezys off of eBay
annotation:
Kanye’s shoes are an item in very high demand. One go-getter once tried to sell their Red Octobers on eBay for $16.3 million after they sold out in 11 minutes at the regular price of $245.

The Red Octobers actually ended up selling for around $7,500 on eBay.

lyrics: [Verse 2: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation:
Contrasting the first verse of exuberance and excitement, this verse is from the perspective of Uncle Sam – who represents the government and it’s view of African-Americans who come into money.

Uncle Sam encourages outrageous spending, because he gets money from the taxes paid and the economy improves due to the spending multiplier. He suggests that you spend even more than you have and borrow money because it seems like you are invincible and rich, until you slip up and get Wesley Sniped.

lyrics:
We speedin' on the 405, passin' Westchester
You know, the light-skinned girls in all the little dresses
annotation:
The 405 Is an Interstate Freeway in California, and they are passing Westchester, a middle class area in LA. .

Kendrick may also be referencing the popular high school called Westchester, which is known for pretty light skinned women.

lyrics: Kendrick Lamar & 2Pac
annotation:
In this simulated interview, Kendrick and 2Pac discuss the situation of the society. The gradual, ethereal piano swelling in the background and the title of the song suggest they are in some kind of heaven or afterlife.

The audio of 2Pac’s voice is taken from an actual interview with Sveriges Radio Station (P3). The interviewer met Tupac in New York City back in November 1994, only two weeks before the 1994 shooting in Quad Recording Studios.

lyrics:
But when the shit get brackin', don't you ask for me
How many leaders gon' tell you the truth after me?
annotation:
“Brackin'” is slang for “crackin” and denotes when a situation becomes heated. Blood gang members replace “Cs” with “Bs” as a mark of disrespect to the opposing Crip gang. In keeping with his Gemini duality dichotomy, Kendrick calls back to his gang affiliation but also distances himself from gang-related activity.

Kendrick explored the countless occasions where leaders have been abandoned or ignored on “Mortal Man,” questioning whether his support network would come to his aid if he were ostracized for the stance he takes. He points to the rarity of leaders with integrity to get the audience to think carefully about the messages in his lyrics.

lyrics:
Niggas do the most and they ain't done shit
Only way I can sum it up, sumbitch
annotation:
Yeezy believes all the people who are talking bad about him haven’t reached the level of success that he has.

This is similar to Drake’s line in “Blessings”:

For niggas that don’t really do shit, I swear, y'all be doing the most

Kanye also takes great pride in his work in the fashion industry, so he may be making fun of other celebrities who try to sell their merchandise or clothing lines for similar prices, even though “they ain’t done shit” when it comes to designing the product lines.

lyrics:
What you want you? A house or a car?
Forty acres and a mule, a piano, a guitar?
annotation:
Uncle Sam is seducing Kendrick, offering him multiple choices that all symbolize something. “House and a car” stand for material things, forty acres and a mule illustrate staying close to the black roots and “piano and a guitar” represent artistry.

Forty acres and a mule was a proposal for reparations to former slaves in the aftermath of the Civil War as a way to get a new life started which was almost realized in Sherman’s Special Field Order #15. However, the order merely created a false expectation that only served to worsen the blow of the poverty that immediately followed emancipation.
