Kendrick is drawing a comparison between the false promises made to freed slaves during reconstruction and the similarly tantalizing riches available to the few African-Americans chosen for the pedestal of celebrity culture.

These lines are repeated on “Alright,” suggesting Uncle Sam and Lucy are very similar.

lyrics:
Good Lord, they knew we weren’t from ‘round there
‘Cause every time we down there
We pullin' out the Boost Mobile SIM cards
annotation:
Westchester is a nice, suburban area.

However those considering the idea of how far back this story takes place, pre-paid phones were looked down on as far as popularity goes. So when they ride through Westchester and they pull out their “Boost Mobile sim cards” he really means their pre-paid phones. Boost Mobile used to be known for having notoriously shitty phones that were watered-down versions of their counterparts on on Verizon, AT&T, etc.

Also, drug dealers use multiple SIM cards or phones. If they’re in a nice area – picking up girls with different phones – it’s likely that they’re selling drugs.

lyrics:
"I remember you was conflicted
Misusing your influence
Sometimes I did the same
Abusing my power, full of resentment
Resentment that turned into a deep depression
Found myself screaming in the hotel room
I didn’t wanna self destruct
The evils of Lucy was all around me
So I went running for answers
Until I came home
But that didn’t stop survivor’s guilt
Going back and forth trying to convince myself the stripes I earned
Or maybe how A-1 my foundation was
But while my loved ones was fighting the continuous war back in the city
I was entering a new one
A war that was based on apartheid and discrimination
Made me wanna go back to the city and tell the homies what I learned
The word was respect
Just because you wore a different gang color than mine's
Doesn’t mean I can’t respect you as a black man
Forgetting all the pain and hurt we caused each other in these streets
If I respect you, we unify and stop the enemy from killing us
But I don’t know, I’m no mortal man
Maybe I’m just another nigga”
annotation:
Kendrick recited parts of this poem throughout the album. Each part is specific to a song, fitting into the overall concept of the LP.

Kendrick rose to power and influence on “King Kunta,” ascending from a “peasant, to a prince, to a motherfucking king,” and felt lost and jaded in the four corners of fame (the cocoon) during “These Walls.” The turning point came as he contemplated suicide in a hotel room on “u,” wrestled with Lucy (Lucifer) during “For Sale?” and struggled with “survivor’s guilt” during an internal war with himself on “Hood Politics.”

He alludes to “Complexion (A Zulu Love),” “The Blacker The Berry,” “You Ain’t Gotta Lie” (Momma Said), and “i”—songs inspired by a trip to South Africa in 2014.

Towards the end of the poem, Kendrick details his determination to educate his community. This is something he’s touched on during the outro of “Real” from 2012’s good kid, m.A.A.d city, where K.Dot’s mother tells him to come back to his hometown and preach what he’s learned.

lyrics: G Malone, big bro, kudos to him
annotation: Glasses Malone is a rapper from Watts, California. Malone featured Kendrick on his 2015 song “Thuggin'.”

lyrics: (Hands up, hands up, hands up)
annotation:
Ye yells at you to put your hands up and get low.

Similar to putting many luxurious and great things next to the word “nigga” in the first verse, this is a role reversal on the dichotomy between stereotypical black and white roles in America. But these phrases can also easily be interpreted as something said to drum up hype at a concert. They are likely both.

lyrics:
Anythin', see, my name is Uncle Sam, I'm your dog
Motherfucker, you can live at the mall
I know your kind (That's why I'm kind)
Don't have receipts (Oh, man, that's fine)
Pay me later, wear those gators
annotation:
“Uncle Sam” or the American government is deceiving Kendrick and the black community to frivolously spend their money on expensive brands and products without carefully considering costs and taxes. For many years, the black community, as a whole, has been known for it’s high buying power. Although the black population in America is low at 14%, their annual purchase rate is at $1.2 trillion.

Shoes made of alligator skin are an example of expensive products that many dream to purchase. The buyer doesn’t have the money now, but Uncle Sam encourages him to buy on credit. Kendrick is dramatizing the cycle of consumerism and debt that plagues so many American citizens.

Also, take notice to the wordplay on the homophone “kind”—Uncle Sam is cunningly portraying himself as nice and “kind” while also speaking to the stereotype of black people being the “kind” of group to spend money at high rates.

The song’s main theme of paying taxes are connected to these lines as well. Receipts are vital to keep in order to organize one’s annual spending when it’s time to file taxes, but instead of warning Kendrick to how taxes will increase the more he purchases, Uncle Sam tells him to keep buying.

lyrics:
Bougie bitches with no extensions
Hood niggas with bad intentions, the perfect combination
annotation: The homies think that ghetto niggas and higher class women are a match made in heaven (bougie comes from the French word “bourgeoisie”, which refers to the upper class). This supports the cliche that opposites attract. Bougie women are normally well off and stuck up. Often females go after the bad boy, in this context the hood niggas caters to the bad boy image.

lyrics:
Shit and that’s all I wrote
I was gonna call it "Another Nigga" but, it ain’t really a poem
I just felt like it’s something you probably could relate to
Other than that, now that I finally got a chance to holla at you
I always wanted to ask you about a certain situa-
About a metaphor actually, uh, you spoke on the ground
What you mean by that, what the ground represent?
annotation: Kendrick’s main influence throughout his life and career, stated multiple times by himself, has been Tupac Shakur. He illustrates a fictional conversation that he would have had with 2Pac if he was still amongst the living.

lyrics: I was two O's from a M, tryna be big as Em
annotation:
An “M” is $1 million, so if Kendrick’s net worth was “two 0’s from an M,” he’d have $10,000, as that’s the resulting number after you remove two zeros.

Kendrick could also be referencing the age-old prophesy that states you need 10,000 hours to perfect a skill, which he mentioned on “Black Friday”:

And I won’t mention
My ten thousand hours in trainin'
While jugglin' gang-bangin'
My balancin' was tremendous

Eminem is the highest-selling rapper of all time. Two of his albums, The Marshall Mathers LP and The Eminem Show, sold more than a million copies in the first week. Em’s net worth is over $100 million, whilst Kendrick sits at approximately $18 million dollars.

This line is also reminiscent of Kendrick’s verse on Eminem’s “Love Game”:

That ain’t what you like, ain’t it?
What about if I was as famous as Marshall?
Would you give fellatio in the carpool?

lyrics: [Break: Kanye West]
annotation:
In the BRIT Awards performance, Yeezy says “yo Skepta, thank you!”

Kanye once again proves his ear is to the ground by bringing out UK Grime Artist Skepta and most of the grime scene on stage with him at the Brit Awards 2015 to premiere the song.


“Kanye’s in the studio working with everybody! You’ve always got the new guys, who may not even be next in the studio, so you keep your ear to the street” – The Breakfast Club.

This comes days after Drake praised Skepta and Wiley on Instagram.

lyrics:
I can see the baller in you, I can see the dollar in you
Little white lies, but it's no white-collar in you
But it's whatever though because I'm still followin' you
annotation:
White-collar jobs are those that take place in an administrative setting. An office or cubicle worker has no problem following the typical rules and format of American capitalism; however Kendrick has never been in this situation, so it is more difficult to urge him into a contract to ‘white-collar’ him.

For some, a person’s worth is measured in dollars or potential profit; a person’s wealth could be an indicator of their success. Uncle Sam would like to convince Kendrick to spend his money to show off his wealth rather than remaining humble, as consumption contributes to tax revenue.

Also worthy of note is the foreshadowing of white-collar crime. The U.S Government, personified by Uncle Sam, is implied in this case to believe that by getting him to spend more than he owns they will catch him in a tax-fraud scandal like the did Wesley Snipes.

lyrics:
Before we sparked a conversation
We seen three niggas in colors we didn’t like
Then started interrogatin'
annotation: Kendrick is associated with the Piru set (Bloods) through his father. They see some guys wearing blue (signifying the rival Crips) and roll up on them.

lyrics:
The ground is gonna open up and swallow the evil
Right
That’s how I see it, my word is bond
I see—and the ground is the symbol for the poor people
Right
The poor people is gonna open up this whole world
And swallow up the rich people
annotation:
As he says in his own words, “The Ground” is the symbol for the poor people.

Basically, poor people are the foundation, the root, the impetus of society. The poor harvest the food, the poor build everything, the taxpayers pay for everything. The working class, the bottom of the pyramid.

Although these people may have less money, these people make up 95-98% of the population, or simply put an overwhelmingly large majority. Now once the foundation ceases to support, what happens to the top of the building? It collapses and it gets swallowed into “The Ground”.

This may be a reference to Numbers 16:1-32

lyrics: Salmon and capers, fame and lawsuits
annotation:
In April 2016, soul and R&B singer Bill Withers sued Kendrick over a sample of his 1975 song “Don’t You Want To Stay?” that Kendrick used on “I Do This” from his 2009 Kendrick Lamar EP. Kendrick was also sued in 2014 for the horns on “Rigamortis.” He suggests that lawsuits are just another part of a successful career in hip-hop—fame and lawsuits are a natural pairing, like salmon and capers.

Salmon and capers are stereotypically “haute cuisine,” expensive food from expensive restaurants. D.R.A.M. described his taste for salmon and capers as a result of his newfound wealth on his 2016 hit “Broccoli.”

lyrics:
[Guitar Interlude: Paul McCartney]
Whistling
annotation:
The guitar strum and whistling both come from Paul McCartney’s “Two-Finger Chord & Whistle”. Paul wrote this song after viewing a print of Pablo Picasso’s The Old Guitarist while in the hospital for the birth of his second child, Mary.

After questioning why the guitarist only used two fingers, Paul became inspired to create the song that would eventually be sampled in and interpolated throughout “All Day”.

lyrics:
Because you make me live forever, baby
Count it all together, baby
Then hit the register and make me feel better, baby
Your horoscope is a gemini, two sides
So you better cop everything two times
Two coupes, two chains, two C-notes
Too much ain't enough, both we know
Christmas, tell 'em what's on your wish list
Get it all, you deserve it, Kendrick
annotation:
Born on June 17, 1987, Kendrick’s zodiac sign is Gemini—the twins. Gemini links into the “duality” theme that runs throughout the album. Examples include the extended caterpillar/butterfly metaphor and the reference to schizophrenia in “Blacker the Berry.”

The real beneficiaries of Kendrick’s success will then be the producers of the goods he buys—the businessmen who already run America. Rampant consumerism thus ensures the societal hierarchy will never be overthrown.

Despite his success, Kendrick remains a man of modest means—the first big purchase Kendrick made after finding success was a modest $500,000 home for his parents.

C-notes refer to $100 bills.

lyrics:
I never was a gangbanger, I mean
I never was stranger to the fonk neither, I really doubt it
Rush a nigga quick and then we laugh about it
That’s ironic, 'cause I’ve never been violent
Until I’m with the homies
annotation:
“Fonk” or “phonk” are terms used by Piru Bloods. “P-funk” is another title they use. Kendrick grew up in Westside Piru territory.

He could also be conflating “fonk” with “folk.” In Chicago, gangs are mostly Folk Nation and People Nation. Kendrick’s father was with the Gangster Disciples while in Chicago, who represent the Folk Nation.

“Rushing” someone means they jumped him and beat him up. Kendrick has a mob mentality, but questions his actions in a moment of introspection.

Kendrick has touched on the irony of where he’s from before.

lyrics:
Right
You know what I’m saying, it’s gonna be like
You know what I'm saying, it's gonna be...
There might, there might be some cannibalism out this muh-fu-
They might eat the rich, you know what I'm saying?
annotation:
This segment comes from a 1994 P3 Soul interview with Swedish radio show host Mats Nileskär. In a different 1994 interview, Tupac Shakur posed a similar scenario about poverty and hunger in the ghetto-stricken cities of America.

If I know that in this hotel room they have food every day, and I’m knocking on the door every day to eat and they open the door, let me see the party; I mean, just throwing food around [and] they’re telling me there’s no food. Every day, I’m standing outside trying to sing my way in: ‘We are hungry, please let us in. We are hungry, please let us in.’ After about a week that song is gonna change to, ‘We hungry, we need some food.’ After two, three weeks, it’s like, ‘Give me the food or I’m breaking down the door.’ After a year you’re just like, ‘I’m picking the lock, coming through the door blasting!’ It’s like, you hungry, you reached your level. We asked ten years ago. We was asking with the Panthers. We was asking with the Civil Rights Movement. We was asking. Those people that asked are dead and in jail. So now what do you think we’re gonna do? Ask?

Interestingly, the slogan “Eat the rich” is attributed to Swiss-born French philosopher Jean-Jacques Rousseau:

When the people shall have nothing more to eat, they will eat the rich.

lyrics:
You lookin' at me in Chucks, I'm lookin' at y'all suits
Me and Top Dawg playin' rock-paper-scissors in court
A real hustler lose money just to go get some more
annotation:
Chuck Taylor tennis shoes are a Los Angeles staple. Kendrick is pointing out that “suits” or corporate business types look at him strange for wearing urban clothing even though he has so much money. The feeling is mutual, since Kendrick doesn’t understand their air of superiority.

On March 24th, the day after this song dropped, Top Dawg posted a picture of himself and Kendrick playing rock-paper-scissors in court:

Instead of taking lawsuits seriously, they’re keeping themselves entertained by betting. Kendrick doesn’t think lawsuits are a problem for him because he’s so determined to keep making music that he’ll easily get the money back.

lyrics:
Well, well, well, let me run (let me run)
Let me run to see who came undone
You've been right in my face
Let me run 'til you're off my case
Whooooa, whooooa
Whooooa, whooooa
Whooooa, whooooa
Whooooa, whooooa
annotation:
This whole song can be viewed as a satire against mainstream media. It could be argued that mainstream media’s biggest objection to Kanye West was the lack of radio friendly singles.

The blatant overuse of the word “Nigga” in this song is ironic because even the clean version plays dirty due to the suggestive context of the muted gaps.

Paul McCartney sums this thesis up by asking let’s all see who this fxcks up. They’ve (the media) been in Ye’s face. “Running” with this song allows him some space.

Now see if I care if this verse get aired
Even if you mute it, the curse is there

lyrics:
And when you hit the White House, do you
But remember, you ain't pass economics in school
And everything you buy, taxes will deny
I'll Wesley Snipe your ass before thirty-five
annotation:
Wesley Snipes is well known for tax evasion. Kendrick plays on Snipe’s name—Uncle Sam will “snipe” or target you if you slip up financially, which countless entertainers have fallen victim to, including: Snipes, Lauryn Hill, and Michael Jackson.

On the album’s closing track, “Mortal Man,” Tupac says:

‘Cause once you turn 30 it’s like
They take the heart and soul out of a man

lyrics:
(Just ridin’, just ridin’)
Me and the homies
(Bullshittin’, actin’ a fool)
Me and the homies
(Trippin’, really trippin’)
Me and the homies
(Just ridin’, just ridin’, just ridin’)
annotation:
This isn’t the type of hook you would expect from the kid who has gotten the reputation as one of the realest up-and-comers. But the hooks in this song shows the homie mentality, and are deliberately made to be ignorant. It’s the verses where Kendrick shows what he really thinks about them.

The slow speed of this interlude and the “trippin', really trippin'” could be indicators of the effects of the blunt that he’s been smoking or, the effects of “lean” (mentioned in the previous interlude).

When he says “Just ridin'” the third time, it sounds less like him and his homies having fun and more like him trying to assure himself everything’s cool when it really isn’t.

lyrics:
Aight so let me ask you this then
Do you see yourself as somebody that’s rich
Or somebody that made the best of they own opportunities?
annotation: Kendrick is asking one of his biggest role models whether he thinks he corrupted himself and became rich, or if he just made the right choices in life and was highly rewarded for his work.

lyrics:
I said it's like that, dropped one classic, came right back
'Nother classic, right back
My next album, the whole industry on a ice pack
With TOC, you see the flames
In my E-Y-E's—it's not a game
annotation:
In 2012, Kendrick Lamar dropped his major label debut good kid, m.A.A.d. city. The critical response to the album was universal praise; it received a score of 91 on Metacritic.

Three years later, Kendrick dropped To Pimp A Butterfly, which received even higher praise for its experimental sound and political topics. It’s also Metacritic’s highest rated album of all time.

His third album will be so hard-hitting that you’ll need an ice pack to recover; ice relaxes the muscles and is often used in sports as a recovery technique after an injury. The “flames” in Kendrick’s eyes symbolize his courage and determination.

lyrics: [Produced by Velous, Kanye West, Diddy and Charlie Heat; Co-produced by Mike Dean, French Montana and Noah Goldstein; Additional production by Plain Pat, Travi$ Scott, Allen Ritter & Mario Winans]
annotation: Velous made the skeleton of the beat on a friend’s couch while watching Saturday Night Live. During an interview with MTV, he also commented on French Montana’s involvement, stating that, although French isn’t your typical “producer”, the ideas he brought to Kanye for the beat were worthy of co-production.

lyrics: [Bridge: George Clinton & Kendrick Lamar]
annotation:
North Carolina native George Clinton is an American singer, songwriter, bandleader, and music producer. He was the mastermind of the bands Parliament and Funkadelic, in addition to his own successful solo career, and has been cited as one of the foremost innovators of funk music. Although suggested by FlyLo to appear on the album, George’s music (or at least style of music) was a very heavy influence on this album.

George speaks on the place Kendrick is at with his fame. Despite being elevated to amazing heights through the success of his music, he can still see that at any moment he could fall back to where he once was. He is applauded for getting out, but is still troubled despite seemingly getting through the worst of it.

lyrics: Braggin' 'bout the episode we just had
annotation:
Bragging cheerfully about the crimes they had just committed, instead of guilt or remorse for their actions: Kendrick and his friends are feeling rambunctious and braggadocious.

The underlying message conveyed here is that when influenced with peer pressure, the perception of the implications subside temporarily.

lyrics:
I see myself as a natural born hustler
A true hustler in every sense of the word
I took nothin’, I took the opportunities
I worked at the most menial and degrading job
And built myself up so I could get it to where I owned it
I went from having somebody managing me
To me hiring the person that works my management company
I changed everything, I realized my destiny
In a matter of five years, you know what I’m saying?
I made myself a millionaire, I made millions for a lot of people
Now it’s time to make millions for myself, you know what I’m saying?
I made millions for the record companies
I made millions for these movie companies
Now I make millions for, for us
annotation:
Tupac never had anything handed to him. He worked for everything he acquired during his lifetime, and the reverence that has been given towards him even until this day. A true “rags to riches” story, starting from the “bottom” and climbing up to the “top” of the societal ladder.

(Source)

lyrics:
And the whole world is goin' mad, daddy, it's sad, daddy
My only advice? Go and get you a bag, daddy
annotation:
This may be yet another shot at Champagne Papi (spanish for ‘daddy’), who featured British artists on More Life and is fond of British vernacular.

In a Vine video Drake once said, “Truss mi daddi,” a slang phrase used by people in the U.K. when trying to convince someone of something. Skepta sampled it at the beginning of his song, “Shut Down.” Kendrick seems to be mocking Drake by repeatedly saying “daddy.”

“Bag” is slang for money. K. Dot plays on the word “Baghdadi” as an example of the world going mad. Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi is the leader of ISIS, and Baghdad is listed as one of the least hospitable places.

lyrics:
Yeah, lookin' down, it's quite a drop (It's quite a drop, drop, drop)
Lookin' good when you're on top (When you're on top, you got it)
annotation:
From growing up in the ghettos of Compton, Kendrick understands how far he has come and that he has much to lose if he is not cautious.

George Clinton quotes Sly & The Family Stone’s June 1973 track, “Let Me Have it All”:

Close, closer to the top
Looking down is quite a drop
Let me have it all

lyrics: A shot of Hennessy didn't make me feel that bad
annotation: People usually think one shot of liquor or a hit from the blunt does no harm. This is the process of peer pressure. You do it once, you become more used to it until it’s completely natural. The art of peer pressuring sometimes leads to the path of addiction. The shot of Henn helps him feel better about what him and his homies just did, getting violent towards someone who wasn’t even bothering them. .

lyrics:
And through your different avenues of success
How would you say you managed to keep a level of sanity?
annotation:
Kendrick wants to know how to keep sane in this industry that can easily get the best of you and make you crazy. 2Pac remained strong and didn’t go mad over the fame.

The question in the original interview was worded as follows:

Tupac, how have you on a personal level survived all the arrests, all the controversial things, all the headlines saying, “Is this man crazy or not?”

In a 2017 interview with Rolling Stone, Kendrick provided his own answer to this question:

Things could be worse. That’s how I look at it. I always go back to that – food stamps and welfare and being evicted out of house rentals. I still got family that go through hard times, and I have to look out for them. Think of it like this: This lifestyle I live now has only been, what, five years. Since 2012. Before that, it was a whole two decades of not knowing what’s next to come. I still have that embedded in me. So I can’t let my career get the best of me.

lyrics:
Lee Baca on trial tryna portray a boxer
Beatin' up on my niggas while the CO's watch him
annotation:
Lee Baca is a former Los Angeles County Sheriff who was convicted of beating inmate Tyler Willis while he was housed in Men’s Central Jail in 2009. Kendrick explains that, while Baca committed the crime, the correctional officers (CO’s) working at the prison were equally responsible because they did nothing but look on as Willis was brutally beaten.

Baca was given the option to either pay $100,000 in punitive damages or face liens on his assets. On March 15th, 2017, Baca was also found guilty of obstruction of justice as well as lying to federal investigators in relation to his attempts at covering up beatings in multiple L.A. County jails.

lyrics: Look both ways before you cross my mind
annotation:
This is a play on the phrase “look both ways before you cross the street.” This adage is often imparted to children, to ensure their safety when crossing a road.

The “mind” imagery is possibly used to foreshadow the wild, angry, and aggressive thoughts whizzing through Kendrick’s mind throughout To Pimp a Butterfly’s narrative. Interestingly, George Clinton’s voice pans from left-to-right as he says “cross my mind.“ The sound of his voice literally crosses the listener’s mind.

lyrics:
I'm usually a true firm believer of bad karma
Consequences from evil will make your past haunt ya
annotation:
“Do good and let good things happen. Do bad and prepare for the worst.” Normally this type of quote would be on Kendrick’s mind when he was making a decision, but when he’s with his boys he doesn’t think for himself.
This philosophy ends up having a bigger effect than young Kendrick could predict. Throughout the album bad karma works it’s magic with Kendrick until he decides to change his life and do good, thus giving him good karma at the end.

Like Pac said:

I believe that everything that you do bad comes back to you. So everything that I do that’s bad, I’m going to suffer from it. But in my mind, I believe what I’m doing is right. So I feel like I’m going to heaven.

lyrics: By my faith in God,
annotation: Tupac was not religious but was a theist, meaning he had faith in one God and was, in his words “the realest religion there is”.

lyrics:
Tables turned, lesson learned, my best look
You jumped sides on me, now you 'bout to meet Westbrook
Go celebrate with your team and let victory vouch you
Just know, the next game played I might slap the shit out you
Technical foul, I'm flagrant, I'm foul
They throwin' me out, you throw in the towel
annotation:
This is likely aimed at Drake, who’s a fan and friend of NBA star Kevin Durant. Drake rapped a similar line on 2013’s “Pound Cake”:

Tables turn, bridges burn, you live and learn

Kendrick also used a similar phrase on 2015’s “Wesley’s Theory”:

Tossed and turned, lesson learned
You was my first girlfriend
Bridges burned, all across the board
Destroyed, but what for?

These lines reference pro basketball player Kevin Durant’s decision to leave Oklahoma City Thunder and sign with the Golden State Warriors. Durant and Russell Westbrook had played together for eight years for Oklahoma. Westbrook appreciated Kendrick’s shoutout and had this to say:

I was surprised. I’m happy. You know, whenever you hear your name in a song you feel like [you] made it. I feel like I’ve made it. Especially from my man.

Kendrick views Durant’s decision as an act of betrayal akin to Drake’s flaky behavior, and threatens to seek vengeance against Drake. Westbrook also sought revenge against Durant, nearly scoring a triple-double during their first match against each other, but the Thunder still lost.

Kendrick and Drake collaborated on tracks like “Poetic Justice” and “Buried Alive,” and were friends before Kendrick’s “Control” verse. After that, Drake decided not to work with Kendrick again.

Additionally, “throw in the towel” is boxing terminology meaning to quit or surrender. Kendrick juxtaposes this notion with being thrown out of a basketball game for a technical foul.

lyrics:
Tax man comin', tax man comin'
Tax man comin', tax man comin'
Tax man comin', tax man comin'
Tax man comin', tax man comin'
annotation:
Kendrick criticizes taxation, just as George Harrison of The Beatles did on the 1966 song “Taxman,” which denounced the British Government for enforcing high progressive levels of income tax.

The saxophone in the outro leads into the next song, “For Free?,” the theme of which revolves around being pimped and used by the record industry. The proverbial “tax man” is the record industry sapping Kendrick of his money and artistry.

lyrics: We tryna conquer the city with disobedience
annotation:
This is a reflection of the mental state of the friendship group he is a part of.
‘Rebels without a cause’ would be a fitting definition but given the next line, it could be argued that they are simply misguided and looking for fun.

lyrics:
Right
You know what I’m saying?
And it was happening to me for a reason
You know what I’m saying, I was noticing, shit
I was punching the right buttons and it was happening
So it’s no problem, you know
annotation:
If you believe then you can achieve, just look at me

Tupac also is aware of Karma and has talked about it before so Tupac knows everything, good and bad is for a reason. He and Kendrick are both gemini’s and know there’s two side of the coin.

You reading this, you can do it too if you believe in the law of attraction and focus on your purpose, you’ll see things will “magically” start to fall into place and you’ll get the magic touch like Pac had when he was “punching the right buttons”.

lyrics:
Look at the crowd, they— (Naw, I don't like that)
Look at my smile, I'm smirkin'
Calm but urgent (That ain't the style, fuck!)
So many verses, you live in denial (Fuck!)
So many verses, I never run out (What?)
annotation:
The stylization of crumpling paper strongly suggests that Kendrick is contrasting his writing style with Drake’s. Kendrick makes audible that he constantly reviews and revises each of his lines and lyrics, rather than letting someone ghostwrite for him.

It’s likely no coincidence that this set of bars is similar to Big Sean’s on “Voices In My Head / Stick To The Plan,” where he shows signs of doubt:

Voices in my head sayin' I could do better, damn
Voices in my head sayin' that I knew better

The song can be seen as a diss towards both Sean and Drake.

The stylization of this passage is definitely reminiscent of Nas’s paper-crumpling in 2002’s “Book of Rhymes.” This continues Kendrick’s theme of comparing himself to the greats.

lyrics: Quick to turn it up, even if we ain't got the CD in
annotation: “Turn it up” is used as a double entendre here. It generally refers to adjusting the volume of a song but here he makes reference to how he and his homies will cause a ruckus (“turnt up”), definitely what some weed and Henn can do to you…

lyrics:
Would you consider yourself a fighter at heart or somebody that
Somebody that only reacts when they back is against the wall?
annotation:
Kendrick asks Pac if he sees himself as some one who gone fight when he gets threatened (A fighter at heart)
Or does he see himself as some one who gone fight when it’s the only option left for him (When they back is against the wall?)
Since both of them come from a rough area where gang violence and shootings are a common thing, Kendrick wants to see how that affected pac and his fighting mentality.

lyrics: You makin' him nervous, the music is loud
annotation:
Kayla Duckworth, Kendrick’s sister, voices this line. She also appeared at the end of 2015’s “Black Friday.”

Kendrick uses this line to give his dad a shoutout. When he was a newborn baby on his way home from the hospital, his dad was blasting Big Daddy Kane in the car, and his mother asked him to turn it down. His dad refused and said the loud music is good for him. Kendrick is attributing his skills and success in the music industry to his early exposure.

lyrics:
But Jeezy still playin'
And our attitude is still "nigga, what is you sayin'?"
annotation:
The CD is on repeat; it was 2:30 in the second verse, and in this one “the sun is going down,” so that just means they played the CD again.

Their attitude is exemplified with the phrase “nigga, what is you saying?”, because you “can’t tell them nothing,” as the saying goes. They’re still in gangbanger mode.

lyrics: Shit, I like to think that at every opportunity I’ve ever been, uh Threatened with resistance, it’s been met with resistance
annotation:
2pac avoids answering A or B and simply states he reciprocates what is dealt to him, he affirms it’s in his nature to fight and that he reacts but makes his answer ambiguously transcend the limits of the question.

In other words,
He ain’t a killa but don’t push him

2pac once shot two off-duty cops, not because he wants to just shoot cops but because they were drunk, being unlawful and harassing an innocent man and 2pac felt the need to stand up for someone who couldn’t stand up for themselves.

2pac is not a menace and doesn’t bully people, he usually attacks those that attack him first but he’s not the hero either, he’s simply a human and a product of his environment.

lyrics:
Ho, JAY-Z Hall of Fame, sit yo punk-ass down!
(Sit yo punk-ass down)
annotation:
In February 2017, JAY-Z became the first rapper ever inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame.

This is likely a shot at Drake. Drake and Jay have thrown a number of subliminal shots at each other over the past few years. On “Summer Sixteen,” Drake said:

I used to wanna be on Roc-A-Fella
Then I turned into Jay

And on “Grammys” from his 2016 album Views, he rapped:

Doing plat, plat only, boys better back off me
Hall of fame, hall of fame
Like I’m shirt off, like I’m shirt off
Like I’m shirt off shorty, whole city goin' crazy
Whole city goin' crazy, top 5 no debating
Top 5, top 5, top 5 and the whole city rate me

Kendrick seems to have taken offense at these grandiose declarations and checks Drake’s ego, reminding him he has not reached a level—musically or financially—where Hov comparisons are valid.

lyrics:
Pull in front of the house
That we been campin' out for like two months
The sun is goin' down as we take whatever we want

[Break]
Aye, aye, nigga, jackpot, nigga, pop the safe!
Aye, nigga, I think there's somebody in this room!
Wait, what?!
Nigga, there's somebody in this room!
annotation:
They’ve been scouting a house with value stuff in it for 2 months, figuring out when the owner’s go away, go to sleep, and other details that would help them rob it when they get the chance. They decided tonight was the night to go.

The break in the song for conversation has someone surprised by the presence of someone in a room of the house they are robbing. Despite their two months of preparation, someone was in the house when they were robbing it, and although this person couldn’t stop them, they most certainly were the ones to call the cops showing up in a couple lines.

lyrics:
Aight well, how long will you think it take before niggas be like
"We fighting a war, I’m fighting a war I can’t win
And I wanna lay it all down"
annotation:
Black Americans have been fighting the freedom war that was a literal Civil War in the 19th century. Then in the 20th century with Jim Crow laws, it became freedom fighting in the context of prejudice and racism.

Now, in the 21st century, racism often takes a more covert form where outward inflammatory remarks are less common – but still present. Incidents that come to mind are the Ferguson shooting and the killing of Trayvon Martin. Black Americans – often more specifically young, black men (as 2pac discusses in his answer to this question that Kendrick poses) – are still waging a war for their freedom that they have been fighting for centuries.

Kendrick wonders: will Black America quit fighting at some point?

lyrics:
So that means you ain't bigger than rapping (What else?)
So that means no more playin' the back scenes (What else?)
annotation:
Kendrick repeats “What else?” in the same way Jay Z did on DJ Khaled’s 2016 song “I Got The Keys”:

My baby Blue (What else?)
I dream in color (What else?)
That’s too much flavor (What else?)

Kendrick employs this technique to continue his “sonning” of Drake, who recently boasted he has ways to make more money than he currently does through rapping. In addition, when he was dodging ghostwriting allegations in 2015, the Canadian rapper’s producer and friend Noah “40” Shebib responded by saying they make music in a genre beyond rap, where co-writing techniques are normalized. Kendrick chastises Drake for using ghostwriters during the time he was claiming to be the greatest rapper alive, and dropping subliminal diss lines directed at the self-penning Lamar.

lyrics:
I hit the back window in search of any Nintendo
DVD's, plasma-screen TV's in the trunk
annotation:
Kendrick is just searching around for the most valuable items. Most of his work is pretty personal, but a lot of the time he is portraying young teens who have been raised in rough cities with bad influences (most likely this case). And the fact that Kendrick continues to steal after they realize someone is in one of the rooms shows his reckless behavior.

On an early song, “Is this love?” Kendrick says he “he sold sega games”, so whatever he got from this house, he likely sold to make money.

Notice how in these lines he drops grammar and goes quickly from stealing valuable items to having them in the trunk of his crew’s vehicle. This is to add to the mood/sense of panic while he jacks as much shit as fast as he can.

Also, right when Kendrick starts rapping again, the beat is more heavy and makes you want to know what’s going to happen – he becomes way more serious.

Also a reference to classic Ice Cube lines from the song ‘Friday’, featured on the soundtrack to the iconic movie of the same name.
“Smokin indo
Playin dat Super Nintendo
Hear a rat tat tat on my window”.

lyrics:
In this country, a black man only have like
5 years we can exhibit maximum strength
annotation:
Hold up, did Pac know he would die in 96?

Tupac got famous in 92… 93, 94, 95 and died in 96. Which means he lasted 5 years in limelight. This interview was conducted in 94, while he was three years strong from Juice but still two years before Tupac passed.

#Eerie

Tupac may have actually meant he was just entering his prime in 96 and that he would’ve had maximum strength and hunger until 2000.

It seemed like 2Pac would’ve never ran out of energy the way he was cranking out music and movies, but it happens to the best of them, people get famous, get successful, then after a while they stop trying as hard as when they wanted to make it, they’re not as hungry.

50 Cent got rich and stopped trying.
JAY-Z proved to himself he was the best, then retired for a short period of time in 2003.
Mike Tyson eventually got knocked out.
Michael Jordan proved to himself he was the best, then retired unexpectedly (at least the first time).

When you reach the top, the only way to go is down. Kendrick is about to reach the top, and this part of Pac’s interview is expressing how Kendrick needs to stay in his prime for as long as he can.

(Source)

lyrics:
My spot is solidified if you ask me (What else?)
My name is identified as "That King"
I'll let y'all worry about a list, I'm on some other shit
A difference between accomplishments and astonishments
annotation:
“King Kendrick”’s spot among the best in the industry has been set in stone, thanks to two classic albums (good kid, m.A.A.d. city and To Pimp A Butterfly), as well as two well received projects (untitled unmastered. and Section.80). Kendrick has also received cosigns from GOAT’s Eminem and Jay Z (among others), and seen his name appear on Billboard’s Top 10 Rappers of All Time.

It’s likely Kendrick is referring to the Billboard list when he mentions people worrying about a top rapper list. The community’s response to the list was rough, and while Kendrick did speak on the topic, he’s moved on and isn’t focused on his spot.

“Astonishment” is defined as a surprise, while “accomplishments” are what you’ve earned. Kendrick’s success and ranking among the great’s shouldn’t be a surprise to anyone.

It’s likely this is a continued shot at Drake, who’s recently rapped about his spot in the rap game. On “Grammys:”

Whole city goin' crazy, top 5 no debating
Top 5, top 5, top 5

And more recently, “Gyalchester:”

I know I said top five, but I’m top two
And I’m not two and I got one
Thought you had one, but it’s not one, nigga, nah

lyrics:
We made a right, then made a left, then made a right
Then made a left, we was just circlin' life
annotation:
They got into the car after robbing the house, and see that they are getting chased by a cop car. They keep turning corners to make an escape.

But the endless turning is also a metaphor depicting the lack of direction Kendrick and his friends have: they’re making thoughtless decisions and not making any real progress in life.

lyrics:
That’s crazy, because me being one of your offsprings
Of the legacy you left behind,
annotation:
Kendrick sees himself as a “disciple” of 2Pac, which he also referred to in his verse on Big Sean’s “Control”:

I’m Makaveli’s offspring, I’m the King of New York
King of the Coast; one hand, I juggle ‘em both

2Pac referred to himself as “Makaveli” after the political philosopher Niccolo Machiavelli, who famously discussed faking his own death in his book The Prince.

lyrics:
You know what time it is, ante up, this is in forever
Y'all got 'til April the 7th to get y'all shit together
annotation:
On April 7, 2017, Kendrick released the iTunes pre-order for his new album and revealed the full list of composer credits. Fans assumed that mention of this juncture implied an album release date, however, Anthony “Top Dawg” Tiffith confirmed via Twitter that this was false—implying that the day originally coincided with a possible drop date for the album’s lead single, “HUMBLE.”:

Meanwhile, in poker and card-game terminology, an “ante” is a stake put up by each player as a required contribution to the group pot that becomes the winner’s prize. Kendrick is challenging other rappers to play the rap game at his level.

This ending is similar to the end of “The Heart Part 3”:

Will you let hip-hop die on October 22nd?

Kendrick’s critically acclaimed debut album good kid, m.A.A.d city was released on October 22, 2012. He anticipates this new album will raise the bar and warns the competition that they best be up to par if they want to compete.

He also mirrors Jay Z’s closing lines from his 2006 post-retirement single “Show Me What You Got”:

Get the fuck out the throne, you clone, the King’s back!
Y'all got less than two months to get y'all thing together
Good luck

This and the previous line also bear resemblance to Kendrick’s bars from the second part of ​"untitled 07 | 2014-2016":

What an accomplishment, broken promises
Kept my focus anonymous ‘till I dealt with the consequence
The greatest, the latest mogul, you know what time it is

lyrics:
My mama called: "Hello? What you doin'?" — "Kickin' it."
I shoulda told her I’m probably ‘bout to catch my first offense
With the homies
annotation:
Kendrick’s mother calls him up during the chase. Then there’s a pause, indicating that Kendrick has to think about how to respond. But then he quickly says, “just kicking it”.

A more accurate response to what they’re doing is getting chased by the cops and on the verge of being arrested. This is what Kendrick wanted to say at first, but then realized that his homies were in the car and he couldn’t tell on them like that. The peer pressure around him even makes Kendrick lie to his own mom.

There’s also another obvious reason he doesn’t tell his mother what he’s doing – Kendrick doesn’t want his mother to get worried about him. She simply doesn’t need to know about his dirty work.

He ends this line using the same ending as the other verses, “with the homies.” This pattern creates suspense, making it seem like Kendrick would be getting arrested.

lyrics:
I can truly tell you that
There’s nothing but turmoil goin’ on so, I wanted to ask you
What you think is the future for me and my generation today?
annotation:
20+ years ago, In Tupac’s time, there was Latasha, Rodney King, Yummy, Kato…

Today, In Kendrick’s time, there’s Trayvon Martin, Eric Gardner and Mike Brown, among many others…

Even though Pac left behind a legacy and a message, shit hasn’t changed. People are still dying, people are still rioting and looting – shit is still in chaos.

Kendrick is asking for some answers from someone who’s been through it before.

Unfortunately, Kendrick isn’t going to get any good news, nothing but the real, harsh reality from Pac.

lyrics:
Let's get it!
Look, look!
On foenem
annotation:
“On foenem” is Chicago slang. It’s closely associated with Four Corner Hustlers (Foes), a Chicago street gang, but it can be used by anyone. The phrase is the shortened version of “On folks and them,” and refers to friends or random people. It’s similar to the phrases “On my Mama” and “on the dead homies.” In an interview on VladTV, rapper Rico Recklezz broke down its meaning:

Kendrick’s parents are from Chicago, which explains his use of Chiraq slang. Ironically, his parents moved from Chicago to Compton to avoid gang violence.

lyrics:
But – they made a right, then made a left
Then made a right, then another right
One lucky night with the homies
annotation:
You hear police sirens before this part insinuating that the police are close and about to catch them. However, they made some clutch turns and got away.

It could also refer to the proverb that two wrongs (robbery and assault) don’t make a right, because he talks about the idea of karma and how things come back to haunt you throughout the song…

(Notice Kendrick and his homeboys' last turn was a left in the “circling life” part. The police’s last turn was a right.)

lyrics:
I think that niggas is tired of grabbin' shit out the stores
And next time it's a riot it's gonna be like, uh, bloodshed
For real, I don’t think America know that
I think America think we was just playing
And it’s gonna be some more playing but
It ain’t gonna be no playing
It’s gonna be murder, you know what I’m saying?
It’s gonna be like Nat Turner, 1831, up in this motherfucker
You know what I’m saying, it’s gonna happen
annotation:
A major reoccurring theme in Tupacian lyricism, Shakur advocates retributive / revolutionary violence against the state, while predicting that criminal inclinations (looting and rioting) will unexpectedly turn revolutionary (to “bloodshed”) – that “The ground is gonna open up and swallow the evil.”

The price of freedom is death—Nat Turner was a slave who lead a rebellion in Virginia in 1831 killing fifty White people, decades before the start of the Civil War. Turner was captured on November 5 and executed on November 11. He was beheaded, skinned and quartered.

Shakur had a large tattoo on his back of a cross bearing the number 1831 .

That's why we burn shit and wreck / Cause the punk police ain't learned shit yet / You mutha-fuckas gonna pay the price / Can't make a Black life, don't take a Black life / It's on, the next real nigga fall dead / Dread, jheri curl, process, or bald head / Be prepared for the smoke to bust / What niggas need to do is start loc'in up

–Tupac Shakur, Last Wordz

They finally pulled me over and I laughed / Remember Rodney King and I blast on his punk ass

–Tupac Shakur, Souljah’s Revenge

lyrics:
K. Dot, you faded, hood?
Yeah, we finally got that nigga faded
I think he hit the wrong blunt though
Ooh, which one?
Well, which one he talkin' about?
I was finna hit the one with the shenanigans in it
I pray he ain't hit that
Nah, that nigga straight, he ain't hit that one
Got the shenanigans? Give that nigga the shenanigans!
annotation: I try not to explain this story so much, just because – for future references that might happen within my creative process. But I was in the wrong place at the wrong time.

lyrics:
That’s crazy man, in my opinion
Only hope that we kinda have left is music and vibrations
Lot a people don’t understand how important it is, you know
Sometimes I can like, get behind a mic
And I don’t know what type of energy I’ma push out
Or where it comes from, trip me out sometimes
annotation:
Kendrick’s view is that music is the only manner through entertainment to get a message across to the populace. It’s the best platform for him and other artists to express themselves and have an effect on society.

Kendrick is talking about sonic vibrations and the physics of sound, and how most people take the science behind these wavelengths for granted. He’s saying that what he’s making is more than music, and that his vibrations are meant to bring about a better society—that his lyrics have worth and come from a higher place.

lyrics:
Because it's spirits, we ain’t even really rappin’
We just letting our dead homies tell stories for us
Damn
annotation:
Credit given to “spirits” or “ghosts” of dead predecessors is common in the lyricism of Lamar and Shakur.

In this imagined conversation with the ghost of 2Pac, he concludes by repeating prior assertions that his “murderous lyrics [are] equipped with spirits of the thugs” who came before him, as detailed on February 1996’s “Ambitianz Az a Ridah.”

Lamar’s response, “Damn,” represents not only his agreement, but is also coincidentally the name of his 2017 follow-up album.

lyrics:
What that nigga— what's that Jeezy song say, nigga?
"Last time I checked I was the man on these streets!"
Yeah, yeah, that shit right there
I'm tryna be the nigga in the street
annotation:
The line being referred to here is from Young Jeezy’s song “Trap or Die” on the aforementioned album Let’s Get It: Thug Motivation 101.

These lines lead directly into the theme of the following song, Money Trees

lyrics:
I wanted to read one last thing to you
It’s actually something a good friend had wrote
Describing my world, it says:
annotation:
After Kendrick asks Shakur for his thoughts Shakur concludes his presence in the record by crediting the spirits, to which Lamar responds “Damn.”

Lamar then proceeds to read a poem describing his world (written by a friend) to Shakur who never responds.

lyrics:
There he go. Man, you don't even know how the shit go
Look, here's the plan, luv
We gon' use the kickback as a alibi, wait 'til the sun go down, roll out,
annotation: Kendrick’s homies are trying to figure out what to do. They decide to use the story of them chilling as an alibi in case anyone asks, and push back to the city after the sun goes down.

lyrics:
What’s your perspective on that?
Pac? Pac? Pac?!
annotation:
After explaining the album title, concepts and interconnecting layers, Kendrick asks Pac for his thoughts.

Because the spirits, we ain’t even really rappin’, we just letting our dead homies tell stories for us

Were the last words Pac spoke to Kendrick. This explains why we don’t hear Pac’s perspective, because it is Pac, living through Kendrick’s music. Lamar has previously mentioned dreaming of Pac, and recalling his words: “Keep doing what you doing, don’t let my music die.”

While the interpretation is open, Kendrick’s sudden stop requires the listener to think about what their perspective is – are we the butterfly, or are we the caterpillar destroying our surroundings?

Similarly, Kendrick paid homage to Makaveli on “HiiiPower,” from his debut album Section.80.

Also, Pac has left us hanging because he literally did. He died too early, too young. He didn’t fully grow as a person, he didn’t finish his work. This final line of the outro also represent the young male growing up in ghettos, that have a predicted life expectancy of 25 years, which includes Kendrick’s street brothers Dave, Braze, Chad and Pup, who all died before 25. Pac also died at 25.

lyrics: 'Cause I know he tryna fuck on Sherane tonight
annotation: Sherane is Kendrick’s girlfriend whom he mentioned earlier.

lyrics: [Produced by Sounwave]
annotation:
The track was produced by Sounwave. Instrumentalist and vocalists are listed below.

Bass: Thundercat.
Keyboards: Robert Glasper & Junius Bervine.
Guitar: Marlon Williams.
Alto Saxophone: Terrace Martin.
Trumpet: Josef Leimberg & Ambrose Akinmusire.
Background Vocals: James Fauntleroy & Javonte.

The beat samples the drums from Houston Person’s cover of “I No Get Eye for Back,” originally by Fela Kuti.

lyrics:
That's what he’s not gon' do
Then we all gon' meet back at the block at about 10:30
That's straight, but we should meet up around 12
I'm tryna fuck on somethin' too
Nigga, sit yo' dumb-ass back down!
Nigga, you ain't doin' shit tonight!
Matter of fact, nigga, get in the mothafuckin' car!
We finna get active!
annotation:
“That’s what he’s not gon' do.” is referring to the fact that Kendrick is tripping as in the dialogue shown above, and is probably too doped up to have sex with Sherane.

One of Kendrick’s homies suggests that they meet back up at 12 (midnight), because he wants to fuck someone too and wants more time. “Nigga you ain’t doing shit tonight” is an attack on homie’s pimp status. It’s a waste of time to delay until 12 because this he’s not gonna laid for sure no matter how much time he has.

They killed the homie’s suggestion to meet up around 12 while still sticking with the original plan of dropping Dot off at his mother’s van. In the meantime, they’re going to get in some trouble.

lyrics: [Produced by Tabu]
annotation:
“The Art of Peer Pressure” was one of the first tracks recorded for good kid, m.A.A.d city. In an interview with Complex, Kendrick stated:

Immediately when I heard the beat, I just want to take people on that ride, on that journey. It’s about being a teenager from L.A. and being influenced by your peers and who you’re hanging out with.

When Kendrick first heard the beat, it’s likely that it already had vocals on it – it was previously released as the backdrop to Suspekt’s “Helt Alene.” Once the beat was purchased, a separate intro was added.

lyrics:
It was always me vs the world
Until I found it's me vs me
Why, why, why, why?
Why, why, why, why?
annotation:
Even though Bēkon performs the intro, Kendrick is still the protagonist. These lines represent Kendrick’s inner thoughts as he experiences an epiphany: realizing that, rather than overcoming the obstacles of the world, he has to overcome his own. It’s about self awareness; accepting that the world isn’t against you and that you control your own destiny through your actions. This is a running theme throughout DAMN.

This can also be seen as a reference to 2Pac’s 1995 hit album, Me Against the World, and its title track. Kendrick name-dropped this influential project before, on his 2010 single, “Michael Jordan”:

Bumpin' ‘Me Against the World,’ hello, world, Kendrick here

As we learned on his previous album, 2015’s To Pimp a Butterfly, Kendrick considers himself to be the offspring of Tupac’s legacy. Here, at the end of his third LP, he is no longer just a young rapper that idolizes Pac and his rebellious attitude; he has advanced, embracing the role that he plays in his own predicaments and trying to take responsibility for his shortcomings.

lyrics: Just remember, what happens on Earth stays on Earth!
annotation:
Kid Capri also dropped this line on “ELEMENT.” It’s an adaption of the phrase “what happens in Vegas, stays in Vegas,” but also alludes to the Bible verse 1 Timothy 6:7:

For we brought nothing into this world, and it is certain we can carry nothing out.

Kid Capri also annotated this line on “ELEMENT.,” saying:

To tell the truth, I never asked Kendrick the meaning of it. I said what I said and I never asked him the meaning. He told me to say that part.

The most interesting detail about this line is that Kendrick considered titling the album “What Happens on Earth Stays on Earth,” as stated in an interview with Big Boy.

lyrics: We gon' put it in reverse
annotation:
Capri is telling listeners to play the album in reverse order, which eventually happened with the DAMN. COLLECTOR’S EDITION. It’s also a reference to the track-reversal producing technique employed by 9th Wonder at the end of the DAMN. project.

At the end of this, the album’s final track, there is a reversed audio clip, and the anecdote from “BLOOD.,” the album’s opening track, is replayed.

Throughout DAMN., Kendrick briefly touched on multiple major events in his life. This reverse to the intro brings the story full circle, wrapping up his narrative.

lyrics:
Darling, I told you many times
And I am telling you once again
Just to remind you, sweetheart
That my—
annotation:
This excerpt is sampled from Ted Taylor’s song, “Be Ever Wonderful,” which featured on his 1978 album, Keepin' My Head Above Water.

Also note the end of the line that gets cut off is “love for you has never changed.”

lyrics: [Produced By Vinylz]
annotation:
This track is a freestyle over J. Cole’s song “A Tale of 2 Citiez.”

As stated in the FHD credits, no samples were used. The beat was produced in its entirety by Vinylz.

Vinylz spoke with HotNewHipHop on how he ended up working with Cole.

The Jeremih “Planes” record originally featured Chance The Rapper. [I’m] not sure what happened, but Jeremih ended up having to replace him with Cole. So one day while driving I got a call from a weird number and it was Cole saying “Man I love that ‘Planes’ beat! It would be an honor to have you work on my album and build.” We met up a week later in L.A. and created “Fire Squad”, then two weeks after that I sent him the “A Tale From 2 Citiez” beat and he bodied it.

For those who are curious, these are its notes:

lyrics:
Oh, Lamar
Hail Mary and marijuana, times is hard
Pray with the hooligans, shadows all in the dark
Fellowship with demons and relatives, I'm a star
annotation:
Kendrick is speaking to himself as he reflects on his troubled beginnings. He remembers smoking weed, praying, and dealing with dangerous people before he rose to fame due to the twist of fate he chronicles on this verse.

Relatives is a term used to describe members of the bloods; a notorious street gang originating from California. Kendrick references dealing with relatives in “Average Joe”.

Growing up, K.Dot had family members and friends with gang affiliations, and at times got involved with the criminal activity himself, which he talked about on “The Art of Peer Pressure.” His life could have turned out much differently than it is today.

Also a reference to his reverence for 2Pac whilst growing up; “Hail Mary” was released in 1996, when Kendrick was 9. He’s spoken on seeing 2Pac filming in Compton during his childhood.

This echoes the opening bars of another verse from DAMN., on the track “XXX.”:

Hail Mary, Jesus and Joseph
The great American flag is wrapped in drag with explosives
Compulsive disorder, sons and daughters
Barricaded blocks and borders

lyrics:
[Intro]
Dick hard like rottweiler
Can you handle it? Can you handle it? Woo woo, woo woo
annotation: In the intro of the song, Kendrick recites Ox from the Hype Williams movie Belly, starring DMX & Nas.

lyrics:
Life is one funny mothafucka
A true comedian, you gotta love him, you gotta trust him
annotation:
Both in the physical copy and the leaked version of DAMN., Kendrick says “God”; whereas in the digital and vinyl release, he says “Life.” However, even though the digital/vinyl release switches “God” with “Life,” the catch is that both terms are interchangeable. For example, Numbers 27: 16-18 calls the Lord God “the source of all life.” This might explain why Kendrick personifies the concept of life here, referring to it as “him”; in either version of the song, Kendrick is still talking about God.

Kendrick finds irony in the plans of God that connect everything in his life. This may also be a reference to Dante’s 14th century poem, The Divine Comedy. Kendrick believes that everything happens for a reason, and yet the conditions he grew up in were dire: e.g. surrounded by sex, money, and murder.

This line also foreshadows what this song is about and the major event that took place in Kendrick’s childhood.

lyrics:
The whole industry been in shambles
Everybody fugazi, I’m just changing the channel
annotation:
The term “fugazi” means fake or false. Kendrick feels like the music industry is disingenuous and focuses more on business rather than the music itself. Kendrick refuses to conform to this mentality and wants to be independent; dominating his own way.

Bill Fugazy led protests against the HBO hit TV show The Sopranos. Fugazy believed the The Sopranos were giving Italian-Americans bad names. This could explain why Kendrick’s “changing the channel.”

lyrics:
I might be buggin', infomercials and no sleep
Introverted by my thoughts; children, listen, it gets deep
annotation:
An infomercial is a long-form advertisement that’s typically played on late night TV.

“Introverted” means K. Dot prefers to be alone. Interestingly, Kendrick calls himself an extrovert and antisocial on his track, “DNA.”:

And I’m gon' shine like I’m supposed to
Antisocial, extrovert

While Kendrick’s deep thoughts cause introversion, his actions as a performer are inherently extroverted—a theme throughout the album is Kendrick’s confliction with this dichotomy.

lyrics: Kendrick Lamar, the people’s champion, I'm animal for analysts
annotation:
Kendrick Lamar won Best Male Hip-Hop Artist at the BET Awards. That award is chosen by listeners' vote, making Kendrick “The People’s Champ.”

However Kendrick could be referring 2005 album by Paul Wall; “The People’s Champ”.

The line’s contradictory self-descriptions — “champion” vs “animal” — continue Kendrick’s proclamation as popular sovereign, in spite of how so-called critics would label him: though some (e.g. Geraldo Rivera) jump to denigrate his music, he knows his words resonate with the masses.

“Animal for analysts” could also be a boast referring to the depth of Kendrick’s lyrics, relative to the rest of the industry’s. His lines, fuller than most, are an analytical smorgasbord, like a sumptuous roast beast.

lyrics:
See, once upon a time inside the Nickerson Garden projects
The object was to process and digest poverty's dialect
Adaptation inevitable: gun violence, crack spot
Federal policies raid buildings and drug professionals
annotation:
The Nickerson Gardens Projects is a public housing unit in Watts, California. The Bounty Hunter Bloods were formed there, and fellow Top Dawg Entertainment member Jay Rock, as well as Top Dawg himself, grew up in the area. Jay Rock even referenced the projects on his “Money Trees” verse:

From the gardens where the grass ain’t cut
Them serpents lurkin', Blood
Bitches sellin' pussy, niggas sellin' drugs

“Adaptation inevitable” refers to being a product of your environment. You either adapt and take part in the crime (gun violence, drugs, etc.), or suffer the consequences of inaction.

Starting in 2014, around Christmas-time, TDE has held an annual free concert and toy giveaway at Nickerson Gardens.

lyrics:
Uh-oh, runnin' out of breath, but I
Oh, I, I got stamina
Uh-oh, running now, I close my eyes
Well, oh, I got stamina
And uh-oh, I see another mountain to climb
But I, I, I got stamina
Uh-oh, I need another lover, be mine
Cause I, I, I got stamina
annotation: Sia compares achieving greatness with the journey the LGBT community are on. The finish line is acceptance, understanding, and equality—mountains or obstacles must be faced down with stamina and strength.

lyrics: Career damaging verses, meditating with candles lit
annotation:
Kendrick’s most famous verse came on Big Sean’s “Control.” Many claimed (including Rolling Stone) Lamar “changed the game” by name dropping 11 of his peers in 3 bars. Reactions were abundant and ranged from quips on Twitter to response tracks. Many of these responses were logged and included in a timeline by XXL.

Kendrick was featured in an article “Hip Hop and Meditation,” where it was alleged he “meditates in his own way by starting each day staring at himself in the mirror for ten minutes.” Kendrick speaking on meditation:

It started when I was nine years old. Talking to myself in the mirror I saw something a little different than just what the eye can see in the physical form. I saw my soul in the mirror. It’s scary to realize you can take your mind somewhere totally different…what it does for me is lets me know who I am and who I always will be and where I came from and what I’m trying to do with myself and the people around me as far inspiring others and continuing to be positive…it’s a tricky thing but it works. It lets you know who you are for real.

Note that he also touched on this on his eponymous EP’s “Let Me Be Me”, stating:

Oh, I stare at the mirror then realize, that real lies within me

lyrics:
Anthony was the oldest of seven
Well-respected, calm and collected
Laughin' and jokin' made life easier; hard times, mama on crack
annotation: Anthony “Top Dawg” Tiffith is the founder of Top Dawg Entertainment, the label Kendrick signed to as a 16-year-old that he’s stuck with since.

lyrics:
Don't give up, I won't give up
Don't give up, no no no
Don't give up, I won't give up
Don't give up, no no no
annotation:
This lyric addresses the need for perseverance in the difficult battle for LGBT equality (a community Sia is part of—she’s bisexual) and also applies to Sia’s personal struggles with depression.

Sia herself has talked about depression and wanting to give up. Her earlier album Healing is Difficult deals with the death of her friend in 2001. In a 2001 interview with the Sunday Times, Sia opened up:

I was pretty fucked up after Dan died. I couldn’t really feel anything. I could intellectualise a lot of stuff; that I had a purpose, that I was loved, but I couldn’t actually feel anything.

Her perseverance through these hard times has paid off, being that she is now a very successful artist, winning 20 major music awards.

lyrics:
I like my raps extra prolific
Since freestyling on lunch tables and park benches
annotation:
Since his early days rhyming under the K.Dot moniker in Compton, Kendrick’s raps have been jam-packed full of hot bars that use heavy amounts of inner rhyme schemes and wordplay to articulate his ideas. See “Vanity Slaves Part 1” from the Kendrick Lamar EP released in 2009.

May also be a nod to Nas’s song “Memory Lane (Sittin' in Da Park)” from his classic debut, Illmatic.

lyrics:
A four-year-old tellin' his nanny he needed her
His family history: pimpin' and bangin'
He was meant to be dangerous
annotation:
The interaction between a child and grandmother embodies innocence, but the same grandmother in this story represents the legacy of the family—including gang affiliation and crime. The circumstances surrounding the child makes the path he chose predictable.

This cycle of criminal influence within a family is something Kendrick has acknowledged previously—highlighting innocence overshadowed by a reckless environment—as demonstrated on “Cartoons & Cereal”:

Now I was raised in a sandbox, next to you and her
You was holding the handgun, she was giving birth
To a baby boy to be just like you, I wonder what’s that worth
I-I wonder if you ever knew that you was a role model to me first

lyrics:
I'm free to be the greatest, I'm alive
I'm free to be the greatest here tonight, the greatest
The greatest, the greatest alive
The greatest, the greatest alive
annotation:
Sia reminds everyone that regardless of your gender, sex, religion, or sexual identity, you’re free to be the greatest you can be.

The LGBTQ+ community has the highest suicide rates of any social group. The Suicide Prevention Resource Center estimates 30% to 40% of LGBT youths have attempted suicide. Sia is telling everyone to keep on going, not give up, and stay alive.

Redemption, self-preservation, perseverance, and finding inner-strength are all common themes in Sia’s music.

lyrics:
And I won’t mention my 10,000 hours in training
While juggling, gang-banging, my balancing was tremendous
annotation:
The “10,000-hour rule” was popularized by Malcolm Gladwell’s book Outliers. He explored the habits of some of the most successful people across myriad careers and found a common thread of at least 10,000 hours spent at their task before they evolved into the masters the world knows them as.

With natural skill one of hip-hop’s most sought-after attributes, admitting his hard work would take away from the awe-inspiring view of Kendrick as an effortless talent, even whilst he was gang-banging:

I hit the back window in search of any Nintendo
DVDs, plasma screen TVs in the trunk

This may also be a reference to his 2007 mixtape, Training Day.

lyrics:
Clocked him a grip and start slangin'
Fifteen, scrapin' up his jeans with quarter pieces
Even got some head from a smoker last weekend
annotation:
“Clocking grips” usually means to make money, but Kendrick may be using “grip” to mean gun.

Anthony had a gun and was slangin'/drug dealing at the age of 15. A “quarter piece” is a synonymous term for seven grams of cocaine, a quarter ounce.

Anthony’s initiation into gang life is the culmination of family influences described in lines just before.

It is a very common practice for drug dealers to give drugs in exchange for sexual favors. Anthony was receiving oral sex from a crack addict.

lyrics:
Ayy, I am the truth
Ayy, I am the wisdom of the fallen; I'm the youth
annotation:
Kendrick covers a plethora of real, visceral topics and social issues.

He also really is the word of the fallen. On To Pimp A Butterfly, he included a previously unreleased interview with 2Pac that he repurposed for the song. Pac said:

Because the spirits, we ain’t even really rappin’, we just letting our dead homies tell stories for us

lyrics:
And now we look at the competition as quick submission
They tappin’ out before we even get a chance to miss ‘em
annotation:
In many combat sports, an opponent who knows they’ve lost will bang on the ground, or “tap out”, to show that they’ve submitted to their opponent and conceded the fight.

Kendrick feels as if upcoming rappers aren’t even letting him hold them on the ground – they’re giving up competing with him before they can make an impact.

lyrics:
Dodged a policeman, workin' for his big homie
Small-time hustler, graduated to a brick on him
annotation:
It’s customary for drug dealers to start off selling small amounts of product at the street level before dealing with larger amounts. “Brick” and "bird” are slang terms for a kilogram of cocaine and they go for $16,000 — $24,000.

The phrase “graduated to a brick” was originally used by Jay Z in “My 1st Song.”

lyrics:
I ran out of tears when I was 18
So nobody made me but the main streets
'Cause too many people think they made me
Well, if they really made me then replace me
annotation:
In 2007, at age 17, The Weeknd dropped out of high school to pursue music.

Abel’s animosity in these lines seem to be directed at Jeremy “Zodiac” Rose, who was originally credited for producing the three songs “What You Need,” “Loft Music” and “The Morning” on The Weeknd’s first mixtape House of Balloons. Those songs initially got The Weeknd recognized by outlets like The New York Times and Pitchfork and essentially boosted him into stardom.

The Weeknd and Jeremy parted ways because of what was initially said to be “creative differences.” But in an interview with VICE Jeremy said it was because The Weeknd would not pay him for his production.

In the same interview, Jeremy claimed that since he was the one who produced those three songs, he was the one who had conceptualized The Weeknd’s sound—basically making The Weeknd.

The Weeknd challenges Jeremy Rose, or anyone else who claims they “made” him, by saying he’s irreplaceable—a claim that’s supported by his massive album sales and chart performance. Borrowing JAY-Z’s logic, if people made the Weeknd who he is, why can’t they just make another star of his stature?

lyrics:
Ayy, I am the greatest
Ayy, this is the proof
annotation: Kendrick crowned himself the king of hip-hop on Big Sean’s 2013 song “Control” and continues to shine bright with the likes of 11 Grammy nominations in 2015.

lyrics:
What this about, is it money or skill?
Maybe it’s both and I got large amounts of it, it’s real
annotation:
An age-old debate within hip-hop circles (and the world in general) is whether an artist should create music to make money or to make amazing art. Kendrick claims he can do both – and he’s not wrong. His career average Metacritic score of 89 validates his skill, and the $12 million he made this year is nothing to laugh at.

While he may not earn as much as his peers like Drake or Nicki Minaj, as Kendrick said, “all money ain’t good money”. His refusal to endorse a liquor company hurts his wallet but spares his younger listeners from seeing their favorite rapper promoting drinking.

J. Cole made a similar statement on “Jodeci Freestyle”, saying:

But is this ‘bout skills or is this 'bout sales?
Cause either fuckin' way, man all them niggas is less to me

lyrics:
10,000 dollars out of a project housing, that's on the daily
Seen his first mil twenty years old, had a couple of babies
annotation: Anthony would make 10k daily, while still living in the Projects. By the age of 20, he already made a million dollars hustling. His status got him lots of girls, who ended up impregnating.

lyrics:
Homeless to Forbes List, these niggas bring no stress
I feel like Moses, I feel like I'm chosen
annotation:
Abel placed first on the Forbes 100 Richest Celebrity Newcomers of 2016 list, with a net worth estimated at $55 million. He went from being unknown before releasing 2011’s House of Balloons to selling out an arena tour in 2015.

In the Bible, Moses was chosen by God to lead the Israelites out of Egypt—Abel believes his rise to fame is similarly miraculous.

lyrics: Ayy, I work hard, pray hard, pay dues, ayy
annotation:
Kendrick flips the popular idiom “work hard, play hard.” A man of faith, Kendrick often references religion in his music. When asked about his spiritual lyrics, Kendrick had this to say:

Truthfully, it comes from me as a person, someone who is always inquisitive on life, inquisitive on God and Jesus himself. Always trying to figure out and just become a better person — not saying I’m an actual saint — but this is me, this is who I am… I couldn’t stray away from that, this is how I think on a daily basis, and my music reflects my actual life so I will always continue to put that type of message and them type of stories in my music no matter what I’m doing because this is me as a person.

Kendrick has emphasized the importance of hard work before, and has shown us time and time again, how dedicated he is towards his craft.

lyrics:
You see my oath is very unbreakable, my style is never mistakable
I can see y’all incapable
To be the God emcees,
annotation:
While the original God MC was Rakim, Kendrick feels like staying true to his craft and possessing a unique style puts him above other rappers.

Charlamagne tha God seemed to agree.

lyrics:
The first in the projects with the two-tone Mustang
That 5.0 thing, they say 5-0 came
annotation:
Kendrick juxtaposes this with the term “5-0” which refers to the police. Anthony’s big loud car, a Ford Mustang 5.0, draws attention to him from the police.

Ford introduced two-tone factory paint when they updated the Mustang body style in the 1987 model year, which was released to the market in 1986. Based on the timeline given, it sounds like Anthony bought a 5.0 as soon as they hit the street.

Loading embed...

lyrics:
And if you ain't my nigga then your girl single to me
I don't give a damn if a nigga said he knew me
annotation:
Abel has a closed circle of friends, and if you’re not with him, you’re against him. Outside of that circle, he has no respect for the sanctity of relationships—invading them to get with a girl he likes has been a recurring element in his lyrics, like in “King of the Fall”:

Man, your girl so bad, let me get her
Your girl so bad, let me get her

Sometimes the tight bond Abel has with his crew has no bearing on his adulterous ways, though. They are so close that they often share girls with each other:

You lookin' at my nigga, you can have him too
‘Cause baby, I ain’t cuffing girl, I hope you knew

lyrics:
I transform with pressure, I'm hands-on with effort
I fell twice before, my bounce back was special
annotation:
Kendrick transforms with pressure like a rough diamond, polishing himself around the edges before being ready (bouncing back) to hit the spotlight.

K.Dot struggled with depression and suicidal thoughts throughout the recording process of his 2015 album To Pimp A Butterfly and prior to that, the pressure he felt around the time of his debut studio album, good kid, m.A.A.d city.

lyrics:
you know me well
Ridiculous, venomous, hate in my heart, the sinister
Run for cover, my lineage prove itself
annotation:
Juxtaposing off the previous line where Kendrick calls himself the “God” emcee, Kendrick then goes on to self-proclaim himself a list of traits that contradict God’s attitude. Kendrick’s verses aren’t always forgiving, with some of his raps resulting in straight up savagery:

And tucked a sensitive rapper back in his pajama clothes

Kendrick’s father was part of Chicago’s infamous Gangster Disciples gang during the 1970’s.

“Run For Cover” could also be a nod to Rakim, the god MC, who had a song with Eric B. called “Run for Cover”; hence the mention of ‘god emcee’ in one of the previous lines.

lyrics:
Circlin' parking lots and parking spots
And hoppin' out while harrassin' the corner blocks
Crooked cops told Anthony he should kick it
annotation:
There’s a constant police presence in the area, and local drug dealers are always being harassed.

Crooked police officers have attempted to recruit Anthony, either as a confidential informant, as a partner in selling dope, or both à la “Deep Cover.”

Anthony declined their offer despite the fact that without the protection of the crooked officers as either a snitch or a source of income, he’d eventually end up in prison.

lyrics: Grew up with no father so nobody ever "son" me
annotation:
To “son” someone is to make them seem inferior to you—Abel’s lack of a father figure ensures no one has ever had superiority over him.

Abel was raised by his mother and grandmother in Scarborough, Ontario, and has little recollection of his father, who abandoned the family when Abel was young.

Though Abel has only briefly mentioned his father in his music, he spoke about him in a 2015 Rolling Stone interview following the release of Beauty Behind the Madness:

I saw him vaguely when I was six, and then again when I was 11 or 12, and he had a new family and kids. I don’t even know where he lived—I’d see him for, like, a night. I’m sure he’s a great guy. I never judged him. He wasn’t abusive, he wasn’t an alcoholic, he wasn’t an asshole. He just wasn’t there.

lyrics:
Letdowns'll get you, and the critics'll test you
But the strong'll survive, another scar may bless you, ah
annotation:
Kendrick weaves some of his own experience into the wider message he’s preaching: strength and solidarity in oppressed communities. His own “letdowns” came in the form of a music industry he felt disconnected from, with its preoccupation with material goods at odds with his own motivations for creating.

Critics have rushed to heap praise on his musical output, but he’s faced opposition from conservatives over tracks like “The Blacker The Berry,” and his video for “Alright.” His strength has shone through, and these attacks are merely “scars” he can proudly display. Kendrick reminds us all that struggle produces beauty.
