lyrics: I’m rollin’ deep in that paper like two Adeles
annotation:
One of Adele’s best-known songs is “Rolling in the Deep”.

With three best-selling albums to her name, it’s safe to say Adele is rolling in money – her wealth has been estimated at about £100m ($150m). Kendrick’s claiming to have twice as much cash – that would make him worth around $300m!

Despite what he boasts, Kendrick’s net-worth doesn’t amount to a quarter of this total.

lyrics:
He brushed 'em off and walked back to the Kentucky Fried Chicken
See, at this chicken spot
There was a light-skinned nigga that talked a lot
With a curly top and a gap in his teeth
He worked the window, his name was Ducky
annotation:
This is the introduction to the second character in this story, Kendrick’s father, Kenny Duckworth—otherwise known as Ducky.

Kenny was prominently featured on skits throughout Kendrick’s major label debut, good kid, m.A.A.d city, and even appeared on Kendrick’s “Backseat Freestyle” music video.

lyrics: [Produced by Scoop DeVille]
annotation:
A laid back beat that has some banging drums. The chorus on this record is catchy and it has vocals sampled in the background. Instrument change ups throughout this track, features a wide range of instruments from the pizzicato strings to the sample hits on the chorus as well as extra string melodies on the third verse. The last part of the song the beat just plays solo until it fades out.

Although Dr. Dre assisted “The Recipe” serves as a single from Kendrick Lamar’s good kid, m.A.A.d city album, according to producer Scoop DeVille in an interview with HipHopDX, the record was initially intended for placement on Dre’s long delayed album, Detox.

It contains a sample of “Meet the Frownies,” as performed by Twin Sister. These background vocals play throughout the record.

lyrics: My flow too sick, Kevin Costner couldn't touch me
annotation:
In the 1987 drama The Untouchables, American actor Kevin Costner plays a federal agent in pursuit of the infamous gangster Al Capone (played by Robert De Niro).

Kevin Costner’s team gets dubbed “The Untouchables” as they’re the only cops that can’t be bribed and/or intimidated by the mob. Just like no one can touch The Untouchables antagonist, Abel claims no one can touch his flow.

lyrics: Before scholars, I flowed tighter than virgin lips
annotation:
Kendrick describes the longevity of his raps, claiming he was a dope lyricist before being documented by hip-hop journalists and Genius contributors alike.

“Virgins lips” refers to a woman’s vagina. It’s thought that a virgin’s vagina is “tighter” than that of a woman who’s more sexually experienced. This has actually been proven to be more myth than truth.

lyrics:
He came from the streets, the Robert Taylor Homes
Southside Projects, Chiraq, the Terror Dome
Drove to California with a woman on him and 500 dollars
annotation:
Robert Taylor Homes was an 11,000-inhabitant housing project in Chicago that aimed to offer low-priced rents.

Terror Dome is a gang faction native to Chicago.

In a 2015 Rolling Stone interview, Kendrick explained how his parents made the move from Chicago to Compton in 1984, three years before his birth. His mother issued an ultimatum to Ducky, who was part of a South Side Chicago gang named the Gangster Disciples, saying that she couldn’t stay with him if he kept his gang ties:

They were going to go to San Bernardino. But my Auntie Tina was in Compton. She got ‘em a hotel until they got on their feet, and my mom got a job at McDonald’s. Eventually, they saved enough money to get their first apartment, and that’s when they had me.

lyrics:
Smokin' weed with you
'Cause you taught me to
Smokin' weed with you
'Cause you taught me to
annotation:
The woman’s voice is sampled from the song “Meet the Frownies” by Mr Twin Sister. It is repeated throughout.

The use of dream-pop samples, with their sexy, vintage sounds and heavy use of reverb, helped shape the smooth, California sound that made GKMC so popular (see also: Beach House vis–à–vis “Money Trees” or the Danish artists Quadron, whose side project Boom Clap Bachelors found their way into another Kendrick song).

This sample could be referencing a line from “Forgot About Dre” when Dre says:

Who you think taught you to smoke trees?

“In the leaves, in the fall” is also heard faintly in the back of the hook.

Similarly, Dr. Dre and Kendrick both have publicly announced many times they do rarely smoke marijuana, with Kendrick only trying it once ever as mentioned in this album. For both man’s instances, the street, gangster, and hip-hop life introduced them to this weed. Both have tried it because, well, hip-hop taught them to. Being two big names in hip-hop, many are appalled at the fact they do not smoke.. given they live in California, rap with many smokers, and are two pioneers in West Coast rap and a California Los Angeles style – often about relaxing, smoking weed, and politicking. They get together to announce their love for L.A. and the recipe of women, weed, and weather, and although they do not both smoke, they know this weed is definitely part of the lifestyle they live.

lyrics:
Well, this the life we always fantasized
Rich folk problem through a Queen Street nigga's eyes
annotation:
Queen Street in Toronto is where Abel rose to fame, performing at a bar called Social. Despite his wealth and success, Abel remembers his humble beginnings.

Abel also repped Queen Street on “King of the Fall” and “Tell Your Friends”:

Used to roam on Queen, now I sing Queen Street anthems

lyrics: We here to shake the game up and you're flying through turbulence
annotation:
Turbulence on a plane is caused when the flight path cuts through a jet stream and mixes faster and slower moving air.

Just as planes tend to “shake” while going through turbulence, Kendrick & Cole have shaken the game up and other rappers are nervous.

lyrics:
They had a son, hopin' that he'd see college
Hustlin' on the side with a nine-to-five to freak it
annotation:
The move to California was a new start for Kendrick’s parents and their soon-to-be-born son. The allure of Compton was talked about in the intro to Dr Dre’s Compton:

Compton was the American dream. Sunny California with a palm tree in the front yard, the camper, the boat. Temptingly close to the Los Angeles ghetto in the 50’s and 60’s, it became “The Black American Dream.” Open housing paved the way as middle-class blacks flooded into the city… But the dream that many blacks thought they were buying has turned sour… The problems of crime and growing welfare is slowing turning suburban Compton into an extension of the black inner city. Crime is now as high as the ghetto. Juvenile gang activity, muggings, small robberies make some blacks want to leave

This downfall is reflected in Ducky’s story. He departed Chicago to leave criminal gangs behind and to help his future son get to college but soon he was hustling as well as his normal nine to five at KFC. In a culture where everyone is part of a gang, it is easy to get sucked in, as Kendrick himself learned.

lyrics: [Verse 1: Dr. Dre & Kendrick Lamar]
annotation: Kendrick actually wrote Dre’s verses on this track.

lyrics:
Every time you see me pulling up in Aventadors
Just know we been grinding on them sidewalks
annotation:
The Lamborghini Aventador is worth around $440,000. Abel rose from his humble beginnings (“grinding on them sidewalks”) to an estimated net worth of $55 million—he’s got more than enough to buy expensive cars.

Abel owns a red Aventador SV Roadster, which made a brief cameo in the video for “Starboy.”

lyrics:
Everything is high stakes nowadays, that’s how it played nowadays
It’s like an 8-ball to the face nowadays
annotation: “8-ball” is slang for 1/8 ounce of cocaine. Kendrick likens competing in the Rap industry to ingesting an entire 8-ball. Snorting the 8-ball would soon lead to overdose and likely death, and your career can die just as quick in the competitive genre of hip-hop. “High” stakes indeed.

lyrics:
Cadillac Seville, he'd ride his son around on weekends
Three-piece special with his name on the shirt pocket
annotation:
Kendrick previously mentioned riding shotgun and eating chicken with his father on Isaiah Rashad’s “Wat’s Wrong”:

My daddy said a Mercedes had haunted him
But now he got one, I’m ridin' shotgun
With a three-piece chicken dinner and shot gun

“The name on the shirt pocket” also suggests that his father just got out of work at KFC.

Kendrick mentions riding around with his father during the peak of the Rodney King Riots. on Good Kid MaaD City.

“Papa, you really telling me we can just get some more of it
If we run out?” He said, “Lil' nigga, today the poor is rich
Don’t tell your mom that you seen a Molotov bomb
If she ask just know you have to lie and son don’t forget
Bitches ain’t shit, hoes ain’t neither
Niggas gon' snitch, watch the company you keeping
And one day you’ll put money in the ghetto when you got it
Rather than having to hustle off these Rodney King riots”
That’s right the mothafuckin’ Rodney King…
You was with your daddy on Bullis Road

lyrics:
good time to get caked up, uh
Sunshine coming through my blinds,
annotation:
“Caked” up means to get a lot of money or to be wrapped up in a relationship.

‘Sunshine through my blinds’ is a metaphor for happiness coming to a dark place.

Gettin caked up is also a slang term for getting high

lyrics: Say, say, say
annotation: The video for Paul McCartney and Michael Jackson’s “Say Say Say” depicts the lives of common con-men traveling from street corner to street corner, hustling to stay alive. This ties into the “grinding for success” theme of “Sidewalks.”

lyrics: I'm laced nowadays, my gun is off the waist nowadays
annotation:
At this point in Kendrick’s career, it was common for him to fire shots at other rappers—for instance, he had a well-documented beef with Drake. An example of this can be found on Dr. Dre’s 2015 cut “Darkside/Gone”:

But still I got enemies giving me energy
I don’t wanna fight now
Subliminally sent to me all of this hate
I thought I was holding the mic down

The “8-ball to the face” from the previous line is likely an 8mm bullet. “Laced” also refers to marijuana infused with cocaine, another reference to the 8-ball mentioned before.

lyrics:
'Cross the street from the projects, Anthony planned to rob it
Stuck up the place before, back in '84
annotation:
Anthony “Top Dawg” had planned on robbing the Kentucky Fried Chicken that Kendrick’s father Ducky worked at in the ‘80s; a restaurant he had robbed before in '84.

This moment is important in Kendrick’s life, as it introduced Top Dawg and Ducky. Together they would indirectly change the rap game forever through their signee and son Kendrick Lamar.

lyrics:
Everybody wanna visit for women, weed and weather
They come for women, weed and weather
For the women, weed and weather
From all around the world for the women, weed and weather
annotation:
“Women, Weed & Weather” was the original title of this song before it was renamed “The Recipe”.

The Notorious B.I.G. concurs:

Going back to Cali, strictly for the weather
Women and the weed – sticky green

“Come for” also sounds like “comfort”, so he finds peace in these three things.

lyrics: I come from murder one, brung late night melee
annotation:
Everyone knows Kendrick was born and raised in Compton, California.

Compton has one of the highest murder rates in the world which is why Kendrick refers to his hometown as “murder one”. The frequency of violence in Compton serves as inspiration for Kendrick’s earlier work as well as his more recent work.

In keeping with the theme of “Sidewalks,” Kendrick reminds the audience of his humble beginnings and how they’ve shaped him.

lyrics: It’s seven figures and retainer for the case nowadays,
annotation: Kendrick “got a million-dollar check like that” and he’s gonna have to use it to settle court cases. Most recently photographer Giordano Cipriani sued Kendrick for the use of the image used for “The Blacker The Berry” artwork off of his album To Pimp a Butterfly.

lyrics:
That's when affiliation was really eight gears of war
So many relatives tellin' us, sellin' us devilish works
Killin' us, crime, intelligent, felonious
Prevalent proposition with 9's
annotation:
The mid-80s had some of the highest violent crime rates Compton has ever experienced.

The term ‘gears of war’ refers to people being used as part of one big machine of war. At that time gang crime was so prevalent that simply being affiliated with a gang member made you part of the fight.

Not only this, but it was impossible to avoid gang members as they were in every family. Members of your family that were smart, those which had been to prison, all of them trying to get you to join them in criminal activity. A nine refers to a 9mm pistol.

In “Poe Man’s Dreams,” Kendrick talks about his family being tied to criminal activity:

Since my uncles was institutionalized My intuition had said I was suited for family ties

lyrics: Still everybody gotta build for that, me? I make mills off that
annotation:
Whereas others have to work and slowly build to attain the three W’s, Dre capitalizes on them and makes millions.

Dr. Dre came up as an artist talking about weed and women, evident with his debut album The Chronic which is a type of weed.

lyrics: We hung all summer, sprung mattress with bae bae
annotation:
Kendrick is likely referencing Sherane, his teenage crush who he rapped about on 2012’s good kid, m.A.A.d. city. A “sprung mattress” is one with broken springs from too much sex. “sprung” is also slang for in love.

“Dyke” is lesser-known slang for Dihydrocodeine—semi-synthetic painkiller. “Trippin'” is slang for getting high.

Kendrick alludes to worker strikes, which are typically over wage amounts. Workers go on strike and don’t work in hopes of the company seeing how valuable they are.

lyrics:
I'm talking
Higher power, every other hour since Eddie Bauer
Since stash boxes and lead showers, breaking the padlock
annotation:
This is a reference to Kendrick’s ideology of HiiiPoWer and the title of a song from Section.80, produced by J. Cole. Kendrick has been conscious of the world around him since childhood, when he wore Eddie Bauer, a popular American clothing company.

“Stash boxes, lead showers, and breaking the padlock” are ideas that describe his young adulthood. It may also be a reference to “Backseat Freestyle” from good kid, m.A.A.d city:

All my life I want money and power
Respect my mind or die from lead shower…

This is also a reference to a bar in “Michael Jordan,” a song from his EP Overly Dedicated:

This is Hiii-power since the Eddie Bauer, I’ve been popular
I’m popping now, every other hour…

lyrics:
Ducky was well-aware
They robbed the manager and shot a customer last year
He figured he'd get on these niggas' good sides
Free chicken every time Anthony posted in line
Two extra biscuits, Anthony liked him and then let him slide
They didn't kill him; in fact, it look like they're the last to survive
annotation:
Kendrick recounts his fathers interaction with Top Dawg at KFC. Had Ducky not “processed and digested poverty’s dialect” to find a way to navigate the situation without conflict, he could have been another statistic along with Anthony. Instead, the two men are apparently the only ones of their generation left alive by the seemingly inevitable violence that plagued their area.

This ties back into the main “wickedness” or “weakness” theme of the album—Top Dawg and Ducky both broke the curse of Deuteronomy that Kendrick mentions throughout the album by not engaging in acts of wickedness.

lyrics: Roll it up, baby, come and lift that dress then roll it up for me when I'm stressed
annotation:
In these two lines, Dre employs 3 different meanings of the word “roll” —one for each of the three W’s of life. The Woman can roll up her skirt, roll up the Weed, and rolling thru the CPT enjoying the beautiful Weather.

Stress will be relieved…

lyrics: Flippin' blue lightning, tightening, strapped with AK
annotation:
Blue Lightning Bolt is a pill containing MDMA. “Flipping” means “selling"—Kendrick is moving drugs while armed with an AK-47.

In real life, Kendrick has escaped such a fate, but he often talks about the gang life in Compton in other songs and interviews.

lyrics:
And the dead coward dying a thousand deaths, entire lion
Surround itself with bears, watch it nigga, you share a profit, ah!
annotation:
“A coward dies a thousand times before his death, but the valiant taste of death but once,” says William Shakespeare in Julius Caesar. This is also the intro on 2Pac’s “If I Die 2Nite.”

It should be noted these terms are eerily similar to the book of Revelations. The Antichrist and False Prophet bring the world to it’s knees. The Antichrist (beast from the sea) is described as: “like a leopard, with feet like the feet of a bear, and had a mouth like a lion.”

Note the wordplay on “profit/prophet” and the “d” alliteration here. (“And the dead coward dying a thousand deaths”)

lyrics:
Pay attention, that one decision changed both of they lives
One curse at a time
Reverse the manifest and good karma, and I'll tell you why
You take two strangers and put 'em in random predicaments
Give 'em a soul so they can make their own choices and live with it
Twenty years later, them same strangers, you make 'em meet again
Inside recording studios where they reapin' their benefits
Then you start remindin' them about that chicken incident
Whoever thought the greatest rapper would be from coincidence?
Because if Anthony killed Ducky, Top Dawg could be servin' life
While I grew up without a father and die in a gunfight
annotation:
The characters of the story are revealed to be Kendrick’s father, and Anthony “Top Dawg” Tiffith, the founder of TDE, Kendrick’s label. When Anthony spared Ducky’s life they could never have realised what would become of it.

The “curse” Kendrick refers to is the curse of Damnation from the book of Deuteronomy. It’s a major theme throughout the album and is mentioned on songs like “YAH.” and “FEAR.” By breaking the cycle of “wickedness” and submitting to the ways of God, Ducky and Top Dawg’s good karma created Kendrick.

If Kendrick’s father had died he wouldn’t have had a male role model and would have gone further into the cycle of gang crime and death that he barely avoided. Meanwhile, Anthony may have been arrested for murder and never could have started his label. He began by building a studio next to his house, before signing 15-year-old Kendrick Lamar. Top described TDE’s inception for a 2014 Record Label Headquarters feature:

I said, shit, everybody doing music—let me build a studio. I was beating the streets up for a while, and shit got kinda hot and crazy out there. I know I’ll probably never work a 9-to-5. After the streets got kinda hot, I needed something to fall back on.

lyrics:
You might catch me in Atlanta looking like a boss
New Orleans and then Miami, party in New York
Texas I be screwed up, Chi Town I be really pimpin'
annotation:
Kendrick chooses his geography carefully here – all of the places he mentions have deep hip-hop histories.

Atlanta’s rap scene goes back to the 1980’s, when it was home to Atlanta bass music. Atlanta bass was itself an outgrowth of Miami bass. New Orleans is the home of bounce. New York, of course, is where hip-hop began. Texas – Houston in particular – is the home of screw music. And Chicago, while not having an area-specific genre, has quite an extensive rap history.

lyrics:
OG one, told me one, show me one, eight ways
How to segue
annotation:
Section.80, good kid, m.A.A.d. city, and To Pimp A Butterfly all feature tracks that “segue” into one another, or blend cohesively.

It’s likely the “OG” Kendrick mentions is his mentor Dr. Dre, who signed Kendrick to Aftermath Entertainment in 2011. After meeting Dre, his next two albums—good kid, m.A.A.d. city and To Pimp A Butterfly—featured increased thematic cohesion compared to Section.80.

lyrics:
This is what they want, I’m the one
This is vintage from 1980 somethin'
I’m the son of the pioneer that got you near the sun
annotation:
This was brought to you by Dre
Now every motherfucker in here say:
“Look who’s responsible for taking Compton international
I make ‘em holla”

Kendrick was discovered and mentored by Dr. Dre, who changed the game when he dropped Straight Outta Compton with N.W.A. during the 1980s.

Kendrick was born in 1987.

And Kendrick gets you “near the sun”, because he’s hot and he spits fire.

lyrics: [Gunshot]
annotation:
Kendrick seems to have developed a pattern of connecting songs together to convey the overall message in his records. At the end of “Real,” Kendrick wraps up his good kid, m.A.A.d city tale with the recorded cassette tape being fast forwarded, signaling his rise to stardom and his maturity as a man. On To Pimp A Butterfly, he ends “Mortal Man” with a poem containing lines and excerpts that are scattered throughout the album which refer to each track building into the encouraging message of unity in the black community.

Now, on DAMN., the reversed audio symbolizes a flashback or a wormhole representing Kendrick’s life—both past and present, flashing by him as he dies. It’s also a clue to listen to the album in reverse order for an alternate storyline. The first line of the album is then repeated, which connects the last track and the first track, showing the cyclical nature of this record. This plot device was foreshadowed in the outro to “untitled 07 | 2014-2016”:

Forecastin' my future, this is the future
The mastermind, until my next album, more power to you… [gunshot]

Sounwave—one of Kendrick’s closest collaborators, and co-producer of 8 of this album’s 14 tracks—detailed what cohesion meant to them:

The album is half the battle. The real battle is making everything cohesive. That is the most challenging part, but the funnest part for me and Kendrick. We’ll sit there for hours eliminating songs—that are so amazing—because [they] don’t fit. It has to make sense. [It has to be] a perfect circle. It has to connect.

lyrics: But nothing like my hometown I'm forever livin'
annotation: No matter where Kendrick is, his hometown, Compton, will always have his heart. Compton was also the base for legendary rap group, N.W.A, which Kendrick’s mentor & collaborator on this song, Dr. Dre, was a part of.

lyrics: Pussy, power, profit and headache
annotation:
Kendrick references gold diggers, who use sex to manipulate and get rich.

The Weeknd tackles the problems of achieving great wealth on Starboy, noting the disturbing elements of his newfound fame. In a Beats 1 interview, he mentioned how “Starboy” had an influence on Kendrick’s verse:

I played him songs, the “Starboy” theme, of course, which he incorporated in his verse.

The alliteration here is reminiscent of a line that 2Pac used on Me Against the World, an album which Kendrick has cited as one his 25 favorite albums of all time.

Furthermore, the run of plosive P’s recalls lines from Kendrick’s prior songs “Bitch, Don’t Kill my Vibe” and “The Jig Is Up (Dump'n)”.

lyrics:
Play with him, bitch you better off voting for Donald Trump
I’m yelling Mr. Kanye West for president
He probably let me get some head inside the residence
I’m in the White House going all out
Bumping College Dropout, God bless Americans
annotation:
In 2015, Donald Trump’s presidential candidacy wasn’t taken seriously by many. Trump was a walking controversy, from his comments on immigrants and Mexicans, to wanting to register Muslims to making fun of a disabled reporter. His eventual 2016 campaign success shocked many.

During his speech at the 2015 VMAs, Kanye West announced that he wanted to run for president in 2020. Kendrick joined the Yeezus tour and later collaborated with Yeezy on “No More Parties In LA,” so it makes sense that he would support him.

While Bill Clinton attempted to hide his 1998 sex scandal, Kenny makes light of the notion of fellatio in the oval office. This isn’t the first time Kendrick referred to Clinton’s promiscuity in the White House. In his 2015 single “King Kunta,” he says:

The yam brought it out of Richard Pryor
Manipulated Bill Clinton with desires

Not only does The College Dropout mark the start of Kanye’s prolific career, but Kendrick plays on the album title to make a larger point—even as a college dropout, Kanye could reasonably formulate a campaign for president.

Kendrick also plays on the phrase “God Bless America,” instead, asking for the people of America to be blessed, belying an underlying disillusionment with the federal government and political corruption.

lyrics:
Women, weed and weather
They come for women, weed and weather
For the women, weed and weather
From all around the world for the women, weed and weather
Got that women, weed and weather
Don't it sound clever, come and play
Wh-What more can I say? W-Welcome to LA
annotation:
California, land of the beautiful women, good weed, and sunny weather. Best said by Biggie:

“Going back to Cali, strictly for the weather
Women, and the weed – sticky green”

Note the alliteration: When he says “what more can I say, and welcome to LA,” he also repeats the “W” sound before the word for the 3 W’S, Women Weed And Weather.

lyrics:
I reminisce my life innocence or life innocent
Or life intimate, with fame
annotation:
Kendrick has evolved from being a troubled youth on the streets of Compton to an international superstar.

On Kendrick’s second studio album, good kid, m.A.A.d city, he discussed his loss of innocence:

Every time you clock in the morning, I feel you just want to kill
All my innocence while ignoring my purpose to persevere as a better person

On his third album To Pimp A Butterfly, he rapped about how fame caused him to lose touch with his roots:

But if you pick destiny over rest in peace then be an advocate
Tell your homies especially to come back home

lyrics:
Nothing more influential than rap music
I merge jazz fusion with the trap music
I mix black soul with some rock and roll
They never box me in, I’m David Blaine-ing all you hoes
annotation:
Kendrick and many other rappers know that hip-hop can be bigger than just music. His song “Alright” became a protest anthem in the summer of 2015 and it’s even considered to be the new Black National Anthem. Kendrick’s eclectic style on To Pimp A Butterfly also broke down musical barriers and influenced rock legend David Bowie during the recording of his album ★ Blackstar. Bowie told Rolling Stone he loved how Kendrick “didn’t do a straight-up hip-hop record” and how it inspired him to take a similar approach with his new album stating that “the goal, in many, many ways, was to avoid rock & roll.”

David Blaine is a famous magician who is known for one of his stunts called Above The Below in which he was put inside a suspended glass box while fasting in it for 44 days straight. Kendrick compares his competition to Blaine, accusing them of not experimenting with their music or thinking outside the box like Kendrick did when he blended jazz stylings and trap drums on TPAB to break that box.

J Cole also mentions David Blaine on a similar line from “Sideline Story”:

I’m David Blaine, I’m breakin' out of my own box, you stay the same

lyrics: Ribbon in the sky on the radio 'cause Stevie know I control
annotation:
Kendrick shouts out the Stevie Wonder tune “Ribbon in the Sky”. As it turns out, the pop legend actually owns a Cali radio station. Also, the blind Stevie Wonder clearly has “no eye control”. Stevie doesn’t “wonder” that Kendrick controls radio, he knows it.

Kendrick has once before rapped “Ribbon in the sky”, on Blow My High.

It could also be a reference to Steve Jobs, also known for his i Products (iPhone, iPad, etc.) Kendrick has iControl.

lyrics:
Light limo tint with light women, dark women in it
Awe Kenny, good game
She wanna hang with a Starboy
The sun and the moon and star, boy
Astronomer, anonymous
I line 'em up, we grind 'em up, there's nine of us
And five of us have probably fucked
She mollied up, I tallied up all the parts, boy
Twenty legs, arms, head (Head)
Head, head, and more head (Head)
annotation:
“Starboy” is Jamaican slang for a promiscuous man. Stars are also astronomical objects, just like the sun and moon. There’s also nine planets in the Solar System—likely why Kendrick chose the number nine. Finally, “Starboy” is the title of the album this song appears on.

Kendrick depicts the crazy lifestyle a Starboy of Kendrick’s stature lives. Molly mixed with a handful of people makes for a crazy night.

These lines borrow the lyrics from “I Wanna Rock (Doo Doo Brown)”:

Let me hear you say, “Head, head and more head”
(Head, head and more head)

lyrics: Oh yea, let’s go there, my DNA is DMT, I’m so rare
annotation:
Kendrick compares his DNA to DMT, a psychedelic compound that can produce psychedelic experiences including intense visuals, euphoria and hallucinations. Kendrick’s raps are euphoric in nature.

The compound is said to be released in the brain shortly before death via the pineal gland. However, this is has never been scientifically verified.

lyrics: So the peons can be gone and pee on their hearts
annotation:
He will still be around living the good Cali life when the other lame rappers (peons) are gone.

“Pee on their hearts” is just saying basically kicking them while they are down.

Inspired by a Wayne line?

I’m beyond, I pee on you peons for eon’s

And/ or inspired by one of his own lines?

And the rest of y'all is peons / I pee on the best

lyrics:
Oh God, bless the dead (Yah)
I'm livin' life, high off life
I wear my chokes off to bed
annotation:
Perhaps referencing 2Pac’s “God Bless the Dead,” Kendrick pays respect to the friends he has lost, possibly to gang violence in Compton. He plans to honor their memory by living life to the fullest.

“Chokes” is slang for necklaces. By wearing his gold chains to bed, Kendrick will be constantly reminded of his successes.

Unlike Abel, whose affinity for drugs is well-documented, Kendrick only gets high “off life"—he’s rapped about abstaining from marijuana and subsequently said in interviews that he only occasionally smokes weed:

You know the thing when I said I didn’t smoke, it was a trendy thing going around saying, you know, everybody’s like ‘the weed heads’. I just said I wasn’t a weed head… I feel good time to time.

lyrics: My Juvenile was wilder than the Nolia
annotation:
Juvenile hails from New Orleans. Magnolia Projects is a housing district where Juvenile grew up in New Orleans. Juvenile has a song called the “‘Nolia Clap.”

Kendrick’s childhood in Compton was crazier than New Orleans, the party capitol of the world.

lyrics: Fuck with a nigga, ride with a nigga
annotation: This line is a quote from Schoolboy Q’s verse in “Hell Yeah.” Lamar and Q are both members of the Black Hippy collective

lyrics: I'm the greatest nigga, why you scared to say it?
annotation:
Kendrick was ranked by Billboard in the top 10 rappers of all time. With critically acclaimed albums like good kid, m.A.A.d. city and To Pimp A Butterfly, it’s easy to see where his accolades come from.

However, Kendrick has yet to convince his doubters that he deserves a spot at the top. Some claim he isn’t the “dopest lyricist,” or debate whether or not he’s been in the game long enough to be the greatest.

Kendrick Lamar affirms his greatness in his guest verse on Sia’s “The Greatest.”

Ayy, I am the greatest
Ayy, this is the proof

lyrics:
Runnin’ this shit with four pair, son of my bitch, I might demolish
A bitch right in front ya, chico, what have you done here?
annotation:
Kendrick’s metaphorically running with 4 pairs, as in 4 pairs of shoes/feet. This means he can run faster than anyone else. Kendrick released a shoe through Reebok earlier in 2015.

Kendrick often drops Spanish lines in his verses. The most notable instance of this was on “Collard Greens” with fellow TDE member Schoolboy Q. “Chico” is Spanish for “buddy.”

lyrics:
Hennessy and, for my niggas, OG Killa
Call it Jason Voorhees, boy, he's on his job
annotation:
Jason Voorhees is one of the original horror movie killers. He slays his fair share of people throughout the Friday the 13th film series—though he is famously not the killer in the first movie, released in May 1980.

Meanwhile, Hennessy is an extremely popular Cognac among rappers and “OG Killa” is a potent version of the OG Kush cannabis indica strain.

lyrics:
I wanna rock, I wanna rock
I wanna cop more land, I never stop
I wanna quick advance on a bill if it ain't one
Break everything, I'm a hustler, came from
annotation:
Kendrick borrows lyrics from Luke’s “I Wanna Rock (Doo Do Brown)”:

I wanna rock, I wanna rock, I wanna rock

Kendrick comments on the destructive nature of hustling and gang activity. He previously compared gang life to the era of land ownership and slavery by citing the “40 acres and a mule” proposal for reparations to former slaves on “For Free (Interlude)” and “Wesley’s Theory.”

lyrics: D-Bo, all of it one year, Mississippi to California
annotation:
Debo is a character from the movie Friday. He’s known for being menacing and snatching people’s chains. Similarly, Kendrick is taking that rap money from everyone else from Mississippi to California. Like he rapped on “Control”:

James Bonding with none of you niggas, climbing 100 mil in front of me
And I’m gonna get it even if you’re in the way
And if you’re in it, better run for Pete’s sake

lyrics:
Boy, he sure be having the marks on they mark
Pretty bitches and tire marks, let 'em inhale them pipe exhausts
annotation:
These lines play on multiple meanings of the word “mark.” The most prominent is its meaning in a confidence trick or “con,” where a “mark” is the intended victim. In addition, there is the “on your mark” phrase, often used to start road races, as well as skid marks or “tire marks.”

It’s also worth mentioning that on November 2010’s “Look out for Detox” he opens the track with:

Tire marks, tire marks, finish line with them tire marks

Based on the OG Killa/Jason Voorhees line, Kendrick could also be playing on the pronunciation of “morgues”—meaning the line could actually be “boy he sure be having the morgues, on they mark.”

lyrics:
It gets annoying, niggas wanna deplore him
And bitches wanna adore him, but industry shit ain’t for him
Probably thinking it’s for him, only one me
annotation:
Kendrick’s previous album, 2015’s To Pimp a Butterfly, touched on themes of industry corruption and manipulation. Whether it’s women who want him for his money, or executives that want him for his talent, Kendrick is too focused to fall victim to their advances. He’s creating music on his own terms.

In a March 2015 interview with Hot 97’s Ebro in the Morning, shortly after the release of TPAB, Kendrick discussed forgiving his haters:

lyrics:
Women, weed, weather, it's not my fault
That it's 82 degrees and my top peeled off
annotation:
California is known for it’s warm weather during the summer, so since it’s warm, Kendrick is riding with his convertible’s top down.

Further, this could mean that Kendrick is going shirtless because of the weather.

lyrics: Swallowed the key and kicking the door in, never leasing my foreign
annotation:
Reference to Biggie’s “Kick in the Door” on his 1997 sophomore, Life After Death.

Kendrick took the rap game by storm and figuratively “kicked in the door.” This aggressive approach paid off. Unlike some rappers who lease cars, Kendrick buys them outright.

The music industry is often divided by those who buy versus those who lease or rent. Kendrick, whilst not an overtly materialistic person, suggests that his levels of success means that he buys his foreign cars outright as opposed to leasing them. Foreign cars can refer to the German manufactured saloons such as BMW and Mercedes, all the way to Italian manufactured sports cars like Ferrari and Lamborghini. To which he’s referring to, no one knows.

lyrics: Known for that homegrown where I come from
annotation:
Dre is, of course, a California native. He got his introduction to the music world through the Los Angeles electro hop scene of the mid-1980’s. His first hit, 1984’s, “Surgery,” with his then-group the World Class Wreckin' Cru, below

However, he’s specifically talking about homegrown marijuana, which is notorious in California.

lyrics:
Mr. Valevictorian studied the game before them
Listen to you with boredom, baby rappers, abort them
To the grave I deport them, corporations extort them
annotation:
A valedictorian is the student with the highest grades in a graduating class. Kanye West used the term on his song “Good Morning.” Here, Kendrick makes a play on words with “valedictorian” and “victor,” elevating the braggadocio.

Kendrick has claimed to be the leader of the new school on numerous occasions, including his “Bitch Don’t Kill My Vibe (Remix)” featuring Jay Z:

I ministered this generation by far
Leader of the new school, on my toes like a ballerina

“Baby rappers” operates as a diss in contrast to Kendrick’s status as highly educated and successful “valevictorian.” While he’s pulling down straight A’s, most rappers haven’t even started school. Kendrick can’t suffer these fools gladly.

“To the grave I deport them…”

Kendrick is saying that he is killing their careers. This also fits in nicely with the ‘baby rappers’ theme as it suggests Kendrick is doing the same to rappers before they have even started their lives.

lyrics: Smoke one, palm trees,
annotation: Referring to palm trees as weed. This is a reference to both the “Weed,” and “Weather” sections of the recipe. “Women” follows in the next line.

lyrics: I’m snapping off my endorphins, I alien mighty morphin’
annotation:
Endorphins are the neurotransmitters responsible for our feelings of excitement and satisfaction.

“Mighty morphin'” is reference to the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. A group of teens were chosen to defend the world from alien invaders. They have the ability to “morph” into super-powered warriors and control robots called “Zords.”

lyrics: I shall proceed, that's me, mothafuck your opinion
annotation: “I shall proceed” is a rap phrase with a long history. Diddy has long used those words or a variation as a catchphrase, and The Roots' “Proceed” used them as well

lyrics:
My radiance rather gorgeous, hundred bill to the doorman
Hundred mil' in my fortune, they call me back in the morning
annotation:
Kendrick’s soul radiates love and positivity. He pays the doorman to protect his soul from evil vices like “money, pussy and weed.”

As he rapped on “Bitch Don’t Kill My Vibe”:

Look inside of my soul and you can find gold and maybe get rich

lyrics: Huh, how many ways am I killing 'em? Shit, right around a billion
annotation: While Dre “only” had a net worth of about $300 million when this song was recorded, since Beats By Dre was sold to Apple for a cool $3 billion it’s probable that Dre is now indeed a billionaire.

lyrics: You're racing against the tortoise, pace myself it’s important
annotation:
In one of Aesop’s most famous fables, “The Tortoise and the Hare”, a hare challenges a tortoise to a race, sure he will win because he is much faster. He’s so sure, in fact, that he takes a nap during the race, and the tortoise plods to victory whilst his opponent snoozes.

Kendrick is just as determined as the tortoise. He’s not going to burn himself out by releasing loads of music in a short space of time, like Future or Drake – he’s going to make sure everything he releases is perfect, until he’s the undisputed champion.

lyrics:
And I know that I'm in a position of controlling, anything out by that ocean
I'm a boss, I'll buy that ocean, ain't nobody fucking with this
annotation: Dre has quite an affinity for the ocean, even appearing on his protege The Game’s January 2011 song of the same name. California is right next to the Pacific Ocean and Dre is so rich he could probably purchase it.

lyrics:
Lace myself with the wisdom my playerism enormous
So pay the man for performance, saucy all of my garments
annotation:
Coming in hot from his widely acclaimed Kunta’s Groove Sessions nationwide tour, Kendrick has every right to demand payment for his shows.

Of course, Kendrick’s saucy style is well known.

lyrics: Jimi Kendrix performing, this fucking studio haunted (Ah!)
annotation:
Kendrick flips legendary guitarist Jimi Hendrix’s name, implying he channels the spirit of the legend in the studio.

Electric Lady Studios in New York was created by Hendrix, but he only spent four weeks recording there before his death. The studio is said to be haunted by Hendrix’s ghost as that was the last studio he recorded in.

lyrics:
I tell a bitch don’t sweat me (Don't sweat me)
I kill this whole fuckin’ beat if Cole let me (Please Cole)
Ib should’ve never sent the instrumental
annotation:
Ibrahim Hamad is J. Cole’s right-hand man and President of Dreamville Records – he came up with Kendrick and Cole’s “Black Friday” concept.

Kendrick is a close friend and collaborator with J. Cole so he’ll certainly do the “A Tale of 2 Citiez” beat justice.

lyrics:
Every time I start writing I get sentimental
This shit is just not fair
But why the fuck should I care?
annotation: Kendrick lived a rough life in Compton and raps about his following depression in “u.” Coincidentally, he emulates his drunken sobbing voice from “u” when he raps “This shit is just not fair, but why the fuck should I care?”

lyrics:
The story of your life here
Two young stars was born and y’all gon’ die here
annotation:
Cole was featured on “A Star Is Born” by Jay-Z. Kendrick incorporates himself in the idea as well, becoming the second young star. Kendrick also mimics whiny deliveries by emulating J. Cole’s style on his verse on the “TKO Remix”, which was a response to Kendrick’s “Control” verse.

Kendrick’s flow in the 3 lines starting with “story of your life..” is reminiscent of Drake’s on “Back to Back”. “Y'all gon die here” may or may not be a reference to Drake, but Kendrick has been known to throw subliminal jabs at Drake in the past.

lyrics: Oh Lord, gotta be the yams
annotation:
In Kendrick’s “King Kunta,” the yams represent power.

In many areas of East Africa the yam was historically considered to be the lifeblood, the cornerstone of communal life and ‘the king of crops’ due to their dependence on it—as detailed in the award-winning novel, Things Fall Apart by Chinua Achebe.

Incidentally ‘King Kunta’ is itself likely a partial reference to the Kunta Tribe of East Africa.

lyrics:
Billboard list need 2Pac, damn
But number 9 makes sure he lives on, yeah
annotation:
Billboard’s 10 Greatest Rappers of All Time list received a lot of hate and anger because of the exclusion of 2Pac, who is considered one of the greatest emcees of all time.

Kendrick was placed at number 9, and he wants to make sure Tupac’s legacy lives on through him.

lyrics: Hoochie, coochie, pussies in a trance
annotation:
“Hoochie coochie” is a dance performed by women of, or presented as having, an Eastern European gypsy heritage. Gooch, goochie or gootchie are terms for a woman’s vagina. “Hoochie coochie” has been suggested as referring directly to sex.

This might also be a reference to the movie Juice that 2Pac starred in. The character Steel is heard saying: “I was doing the hoochie coochie, my friend.”

lyrics:
Every day a celebration, but even the valley peaking me
Is not validation, nigga this TDE
And my doggies be salivating, salaries, better ratings
annotation:
San Fernando Valley, home to Hollywood, is a big contrast compared to Kendrick’s stomping grounds in Compton. The Valley is an area considered to be on of the most affluent in southern California.

Kendrick doesn’t need the approval of celebrities. His label, Top Dawg Entertainment are the only people he needs. Note the play on “doggies” – Kendrick’s label mates ScHoolboy Q, Ab-Soul, Jay Rock, Isaiah Rashad & SZA are all doing bigger and better things too.

It’s also worth noting valleys have “peaks.”

This may also contain a reference to Pavlov’s dog experiment concerning “conditional reflex”—where every time the subjects were fed, a bell would be rung. Eventually, upon hearing the bell, the dogs would begin producing saliva in anticipation of their food. Kendrick’s music is the “bell,” and his “doggies” (his labelmates) are ready to eat.

lyrics:
And casualties all around me, don’t make me do demonstrations
Whoa
Murder my allegations and burning my finger traces
Adjourning my power patience and earning royalty payments
annotation:
Kendrick has given demonstrations of his prowess in the past with things like his “Control” verse and his BET Cypher.

“Murdering my allegations” is wordplay, in that he is literally murdering the allegations of murder themselves while removing any evidence when he murders other rappers.

lyrics: I’m sorry y’all not relating, this party is reservated
annotation: In November 2015, Kendrick and friends crashed a wedding at a hotel he was staying at but was seen being asked to leave by one of the attendees.

lyrics:
I gotta lay it, gotta show you fuckers I’m not to play with
The ruckus had been my favorite, King Kunta the fuckin’ greatest
Whoa
annotation:
Kendrick admits to his guilty pleasure of stirring up the rap game – he loves to cause a ruckus and has steadily been stirring the pot since his infamous “Control” verse in 2013.

“King Kunta” is a song from his third album, To Pimp a Butterfly.

lyrics: Burnin’ my leather-
annotation:
Cole’s “Black Friday” song ends with:

Bitch never, they can’t handle two Black niggas this clever / But this Feburary, bet shit get scary when I fuck around and drop…

Based on his rhyme scheme, one would assume the album title (either the joint-album or Cole’s solo) rhymes with “never” and “clever.” Interestingly enough, Kendrick ends his verse with “Burnin' my leather.” Reconstructed:

Bitch never, they can’t handle two Black niggas this clever / But this Feburary, bet shit get scary when I fuck around and drop Burnin' My Leather

A saying that was highly popular in the early 2000’s hip hop/rap scene was, “Burn your leather.” If someone saw you with a nice leather jacket, wallet, boots, or whatever; they’d ask to burn your leather, and you would take a lighter and do so to show if it was real or not based upon the scent it gave off. This is possibly the name of the next tape they are working on or just a testament to the industry that he’s out here proving his legitimacy.

lyrics: (Nah I’m just fuckin’ wit cha)
annotation: Kendrick could have kept murdering the beat but he decided enough is enough. He also wants you to be kept on the edge of your seat for the potential future collabs with Cole. It closes out with Jay Rock saying “blood brazy” – Blood slang for “crazy.”

lyrics: [Kayla Duckworth: Laugh]
annotation:
Kayla Duckworth, Kendrick Lamar’s sister, stated she was on the track with a Facebook post. She also initially leaked the date of Kendrick and Cole’s collaborative project. The post was edited shortly after it was posted.

Here is the original post that was deleted:

lyrics: [Produced by Tha Bizness]
annotation:
Kendrick’s album opens up with a very dark, eerie and ambient sounding track full of synths and effects that sound fit for a movie score. The sounds on the production are original with a concept that starts Kendrick’s short film.

Tha Bizness on the making of the beat:

lyrics:
[Intro]
Lord God, I come to you a sinner
And I humbly repent for my sins
I believe that Jesus is Lord
I believe that you raised him from the dead
I will ask that Jesus will come to my life
And be my Lord and Savior
I receive Jesus to take control of my life
And that I may live for him from this day forth
Thank you, Lord Jesus, for saving me with your precious blood
In Jesus' name, Amen
annotation:
The sinner’s prayer is a verbal petition unto God that people use to repent of one’s sins and receive Jesus Christ as their personal Lord and Savior.

This same prayer is repeated by Maya Angelou and, presumably, two gang members at the end of the album on his track “Sing About Me, I’m Dying of Thirst”. It also dictates the tone of the album. It shows the upbringing of the character that we see facing the aspects of this life.

lyrics: [Verse 1]
annotation:
These songs, they come naturally for me to write off the experiences I grew up with and the things I been around. It was just what we were going through. It’s easy for me to write [real] stories rather than making up a crazy story

Via Complex

lyrics:
I met her at this house party on El Segundo and Central
She had the credentials of strippers in Atlanta
annotation:
El Segundo Blvd and Central Ave is a major intersection in Compton. This intersection is also very close to Centennial High School, where Kendrick went to high school.

Sherane reminds Kendrick of voluptous strippers from Atlanta, Georgia. Strip clubs such as Onyx and Magic City are some of the most popular in the country.

Could also be a reference to the 1990 movie, House Party starring hip-hop duo Kid ‘n Play that featured a love interest named Sharane that both of the main characters were interested in. Kendrick acknowledges he was a fan of the movie.

lyrics: [Produced by Tae Beast, Sounwave & Thundercat]
annotation:
Producers: Tae Beast, Sounwave & Thundercat
Keyboards: Terrace Martin & Robert Sput Searight
Background Vocals: Bilal, Anna Wise, Preston Harris & Dion Friley

This beat samples “All for Myself” by Sufjan Stevens.

lyrics:
Ass came with a hump, from the jump she was a camel
I want to ride like Arabians,
annotation:
Kendrick compares Sherane’s backside to the hump on a camel’s back, and he wants to ride it the same way a person would ride a camel.

Arabian (Dromedary) camels have only one hump and are used in the desert to go long distances for long periods of time. This desert imagery ties in well with the end of the second verse.

Representation of Sherane in “Backseat Freestyle”’s video:

lyrics:
K-Dot, pick up the phone, nigga
Every time I call, it's going to voicemail
Don't tell me they got you on some weirdo rap shit, nigga?
No socks and skinny jeans and shit, ha
Ha-ha-ha-ha-ha-ha-ha-ha-ha-ha-haha
Call me on Shaniqua's phone!
annotation:
A voicemail from one of Kendrick’s “friends”. He fears that K-Dot deviated from his Compton roots during his rise from the streets.

A mark of his deviation can be seen in his song “Kendrick Lamar”:

No more K. Dot, my mother had named me Kendrick
Fuck a stage name, that’s the name that I was given
The only thing that I can identify within this bidness

One of Kendrick’s issues with his old friends is that they aren’t accustomed with his new lifestyle; he can’t always be on his phone because he’s usually busy with work, whether it’s an interview or a studio session. Some of his old “friends” will take this personally, and think that he changed when he got money.

This could also be an Outkast reference. After their first album (André 3000, especially) they were criticized for acting soft and dropping their gangsta personas, as is evident in André’s reply on “Return of the ‘G’”

Return of the gangsta, thanks ta'
Them niggas that think you soft
And say y'all be gospel rappin'
But they be steady clappin' when you talk about
Bitches, and switches, and hoes, and clothes, and weed
Let’s talk about time travelin', rhyme javelin
Somethin' mind unravelin', get down

Kendrick, after this album, is predicting that he might be criticized for dropping some knowledge, and some people will mistake this as “gospel rappin'” or “weirdo rap shit”.

lyrics: push an '04 Mercedes-Benz
annotation:
This could tie into the prior line about riding like Arabians, who, at least in oil-rich Saudia Arabia, are usually seen in luxury sedans.

Take also note that the use of the ‘04 Benz relates to the year this story takes place in, to when the car would have been brand new.

lyrics:
I been A-1 since day one, you niggas boo boo
Your home boy, your block that you're from, boo boo
Lil hoes you went to school with, boo boo
Baby mama and your new bitch, boo boo
annotation:
A1 is a reference to something that is top notch (it’s also steak sauce), while “boo boo” is hood slang for shit. In this case, the other niggaz (and everything about them) are the polar opposite of him.

The hook displays politics in the hood, like beef between neighborhoods, and who’s boo boo and who’s not.

Kendrick used “boo boo” in a song with a very similar concept, “Cut You Off (To Grow Closer)”.

You boo-boo, you T’d, you turned down, you thirsty, you boo-boo!

It should also be noted that Kendrick was featured on a song titled “A1 Everything”.

lyrics: "Hello, my name is Kendrick,"
annotation:
He introduces himself to Sherane and he also introduces himself to the listeners.

This type of a heavily conversational verse is present in some of Kendrick’s other work.

lyrics: We was in the hood, 14 with the deuce-deuce
annotation: Deuce-deuce quite literally refers to a .22 caliber gun. Kendrick is pointing out how, in the hood, shit gets real fast. The trials and tribulations [of hood politics] reach far and wide – across generations and through all different age groups. He is saying that he, and others like him, get caught up in gang life from a early age, “14,” as in he was 14 years old when he started with the .22 caliber gun.

lyrics:
she said "No, you're handsome."
Whispered in my ear, disappeared, then found her dancin'
annotation:
Sherane responds to Kendrick’s introduction by flirting with him and then walking away – playing “hard to get”. Sherane also seems rather aloof, as are other females in Kendrick’s stories.

This line relates back to the stripper reference earlier in the verse, since strippers typically flirt with men, flatter them, and then walk away to dance on stage.

lyrics: I need some water,
annotation:
Kendrick indirectly references the idea of being “thirsty"—a slang term for being desperate. To quench his thirst, Kendrick states that he should have some "water” for his lustful desires, as the title of the song suggests.

In addition to Kendrick’s sexual thirst, this is also a reference to the crucifixion of Jesus. While on the cross, Jesus says “I am thirsty” (John 19:28), but the soldiers feed him nothing but sour wine, hence the “I need some water.” This would also tie into the Good Friday release date that Kendrick chose, which may have been symbolic.

One of the defining moments on good kid, m.A.A.d city was the interlude on “Sing About Me, I’m Dying of Thirst.”, where the concept of thirst for water is used to represent man’s need for God. In that case, it was the need is for holy water—spiritual cleansing.

lyrics:
14 years later going hard, like we used to on the dead homies
On the dead homies
annotation:
As mentioned by 2Pac in “Mortal Man”, rappers channel their dead homies' ghosts/spirits when they get behind the microphone.

14 years later, they are still going strong, or ‘going hard’, idiom on which K dot plays with the following statement—"Like we used to on the dead homies".

Kendrick isn’t talking big either. Saying on the dead homies means that he swears on their souls that he isn’t lying or faking his story.

lyrics: Ciara had played in the background
annotation: If I’m not mistaken it would be 1, 2 Step. Everybody one, two step – yup, definitely.

lyrics:
somethin' came over me
Way too hot to simmer down might as well overheat
annotation:
Kendrick uses good vs. evil paradigms often. When people say “somethin' came over me,” it’s usually synonymous with “the devil made me do it.” It’s usually because the devil says “you’ve already” done something sinful, so you “you might as well” sin some more.

In this case, Kendrick’s lust for sex is what’s already “way too hot to simmer down,” so he might as well “overheat. ”

Complimenting the “I need some water” line, Kendrick implies that he’s “thirsty” (overly eager) by saying “I’m way too hot to simmer down.”

lyrics: [Verse 1: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation: Another of the voices in Kendrick’s head gets some air time on this verse. Rebelling against the political narrative that Kendrick has been pursuing elsewhere on the record, this voice implores Kendrick to just spit bars, to not worry about what he is saying, to just spit lyrics for his homeboys to ride to and to bump.

lyrics:
as blood rush my favorite vein
Heartbeat racin' like a junkie's,
annotation:
Kendrick likens a rush of blood to the head of the penis during an erection to the euphoric sensation of shooting heroin with a needle. While this is normally known to cause such heart problems as ‘bradycardia’—or a slowed heart rate—the CDC also reports instances of heart rate elevation.

Kendrick has professed to living a sober lifestyle as a result of being surrounded by drugs and alcohol while growing up in Compton. Here, he opens up about an entirely different, perhaps more socially-acceptable addiction: sexual promiscuity.

lyrics:
I don't give a fuck about no politics in rap, my nigga
My lil' homie Stunna Deuce ain't never comin' back, my nigga
annotation:
Kendrick doesn’t care about petty rap beef when there are bigger things to worry about, like his good friend, Stunna Duece aka Chad Albert Lee Keaton who was killed in Compton in August 2013.

He expresses a similar sentiment on “The Heart Pt. 2”:

My uncle doing life, inside prison he wasn’t wrapped too tight / He told me to rap about life, not rap niggas

lyrics: The parade music we made had us all wearin' shades now
annotation: It is just basically talking about just the vibe and the atmosphere, more the party vibe. When I say ‘parade’ I am talking about the actual party and everybody having a good time, and making this feel like we have grown. We are feeling like we are adults, but really we don’t know shit. We are just faking it and living carefree.

lyrics:
I just need you to want me
Am I askin' too much?
annotation:
Lust, unlike love, is centered on using the other person to fulfill one’s selfish desires, rather than bringing the best out in the other person and, thus, yourself.

Ironically, this makes Kendrick a slave to the girl he is trying to seduce; if she says no, then he will find himself worthless. This is why Kendrick wants to ask her if he wants too much from her. He knows it is too much, but wants to make sure she doesn’t know that he is simply using her. He wants her to think he is generous; that he is doing something out of love, when he is really doing something to make himself feel good. This way, Kendrick can feel comfortable with going through with something he knows is wrong.

The self-destructive cycle this mindset perpetuates is characteristic of lust, and is the same mindset which fuels the later description of Kendrick being afraid to put the tip in.

lyrics:
So you better go hard every time you jump on wax, my nigga
Fuck what they talkin' 'bout, your shit is where it's at, my nigga
annotation: Jumping on wax is when one is on a track (vinyl wax). Kendrick’s warning himself that he better go hard and keep true to himself and his ways – then quite abruptly realizing / proclaiming that he has and always will go hard and keep it real.

lyrics: [Intro: Kendrick Lamar & Chelsea Blythe]
annotation:
Chelsea Blythe works A & R for Columbia Records per her Instagram Page. A & R’s are responsible for connecting producers and artists, scouting talent, and overseeing the process of developing artists. She started at Interscope, where she met Kendrick Lamar, ScHoolboy Q, and many others.

This goes to highlight the dichotomy of no one “praying” for Kendrick’s personal well-being despite him having a team of individuals behind him to ensure his career success.

lyrics:
Let me put the head in
Ooh, I don't want more than that, girl, I respect the cat
I promise just a touch, let me put the head in
If it's okay, she said, "It's okay"
annotation:
Referring to the common phrase “just the tip”—a tactic implemented by young men to persuade women into sex—Kendrick uses the term “head” to refer to the tip of the penis. Despite his lustful desires, he attempts to convey prudence or respect for women; but the underlying connotation suggests otherwise.

This implication caters to the theme of lust, showing the extreme desires that people possess, ultimately compelling them to put forth maximum output for minimal gain.

Kendrick may also be using “head” to represent knowledge, as he did on “untitled 04 | 08.14.2014.” and “untitled 07 | 2014-2016”:

Head is the answer
Head is the future

lyrics:
Came in this game, you stuck your fangs in this game
You wore no chain in this game, your hood, your name in this game
annotation:
These lines are allusions to a bar from section.80’s Ronald Reagan Era, where Lamar likens himself to Dracula:

are you trained? To go against Dracula draggin' the record industry by my fangs

Fangs (or canines) are teeth meant for tearing flesh. In these lines Lamar addresses himself as “you” and uses a double-entendre (“stuck your fangs in this game”) in order to introduce two assertions:

  1. He personally rejects the aesthetic and symbolic value of jewelry in rap music (“wore no chain in this game”)
  2. In the rap game he is the personification of Compton (“your hood your name in this game”).

Double-entendre = “Stuck your fangs in this game”

  1. You (Lamar) entered the rap game in order to survive and dominate
  2. You (Lamar) put your canines into an animal hunted for sport or for food (game)

lyrics:
"Cool, where you stay?"
She said: "Down the street from Dominguez High"
annotation:
Compton is home to a school zone known as the Compton Unified School District, it serves 3 high schools, 8 middle schools and 21 elementary schools.

Dominguez High is one of these high schools. It has produced 3 current NBA players including Tyson Chandler, an NFL player in Seahawks cornerback Richard Sherman, as well as MC Ren (of N.W.A fame).

lyrics:
Ain't nobody prayin' for me
(Ain't nobody prayin' for me)
(Ain't nobody prayin' for me)
Ain't nobody prayin' for me
(Nobody prayin' for me)
Ain't nobody prayin' for me
(Ain't nobody prayin' for me)
(Nobody prayin' for me)
annotation:
Praying is the medium through which man and God communicate. Praying for a loved one is a typical way of pleading with God for blessings, and finding hope in God.

This line is a direct link to previous track “ELEMENT” where Kendrick laments:

Bitch, all my grandmas dead
So ain’t nobody prayin' for me, I’m on your head, ayy

The image of prayer appears throughout DAMN. For example, Kendrick spits a similar line in the beginning of the streaming version of “HUMBLE.”:

Nobody pray for me
It’s been that day for me

lyrics:
Door and his Nike Air Rattles
Rush the fire exit, no time for battles
Well I, I never expected
annotation:
This is a pitched-up sample from “Knock Knock Knock,” a then-unreleased 2015 song by British indie rock artist RAT BOY, taken from his Neighbourhood Watch mixtape and later appearing on his debut album, SCUM. The 21-year-old singer had not heard “LUST.” prior to its release, only learning of his involvement via Twitter.

As RAT BOY explained to Clash Magazine in August 2017, the song is based on the true story of him being kept inside a recording studio against his will, while loan sharks stole the equipment:

Some guy burst in and held me and two other guys hostage for two hours because they owed him money… then he was calling up his mates so they could take all the stuff out of the studio. One of the other hostages went to the toilet and did that silent call thing to the police. The police came, and I had to go to court and I was really stressed out. It was pretty insane. I was sixteen or seventeen and I met these people on the internet and they asked me to make some music with them.

lyrics: Now you double up, time to bubble up the bread and huddle up
annotation:
Kendrick’s call to “Double Up” is reminiscent of Mase’s famous line in “Mo' Money Mo Problems,”

“You don’t believe in Harlem World, nigga, double up.”

But while Mase was finishing a couplet, Kendrick builds in a single line. Sure, double up, then keep working!

The expression “bubble up” implies a growth in popularity and fame, but also general growth or rising up – like the bubbles in champagne, soda, or rising bread. When bread’s baked the yeast creates a bunch of air pockets, or ‘bubbles,’ in the bread. Bread also means money.

There is also a strain of cannabis nicknamed “Bubba Kush”. So “bubble up”, in certain instances, can also mean you’re about to flame up some Bubble Kush.

lyrics:
Okay, I know that's borderline Compton or Paramount
"Well, is it Compton?" –
annotation: Dominiguez High is indeed located in Compton, CA. Paramount borders east of Compton.

lyrics: I feel like a chip on my shoulders
annotation:
To have a “chip on your shoulder” means to be indignant and combative.

Looking at the history of slavery, racism, inattention from the federal government and misguided policies like the War on Drugs, it’s no surprise Kendrick, and likely many other African Americans, are angry and irritable. Combined with an inability to climb the socioeconomic ladder, and you’ve got deep dissatisfaction that pervades all aspects of one’s life. This whole song describes various degrees of dissatisfaction with various aspects of Kendrick’s life.

This line connects directly with Kendrick’s phone conversation with his cousin Carl on “FEAR.,” where Carl challenges his negative attitude:

See family that’s why you feel like you feel like you got a chip on your shoulder. Until you finally get the memo, you will always feel that way.

Kendrick continues the idea of him having a chip on his shoulders. The words of Carl have manifested themselves in Kendrick’s mind at this point in the album, which results in Kendrick feeling jaded. He uses this idea to describe how disconnected he feels from life. He continues this thought with the realisation that although he values God so highly in life, nobody else around him does as well, which is why “aint nobody praying for [Kendrick]”.

lyrics:
This that new shit
This that new, new shit
annotation:
Kendrick parodies some of the biggest rappers today, whose songs claim they make “that new shit,” while regurgitating the same themes (lust and sex) again and again.

The detached and distant vocals add to the effect, giving us the feeling that the artists couldn’t care less about actually making “new shit” and are too lost in the lifestyles Kendrick goes on to describe.

lyrics: Stickin' to the scripts, now here if them Benjamins go cuddle up
annotation:
Kendrick is pointing in the past few lines he stayed true to himself and he’s become successful because of it.

These other rappers are “sticking to the script” or are embodying a stereotypical rapper image. Because of this, they aren’t the ones getting money.

“Benjamins go cuddle up” means making money. It refers to multiple bills (hundred dollar bills) all next to each other cuddling. Meaning a fat stack.

lyrics:
"No," she replied
And quickly start battin' her eyes
annotation: Kendrick’s interest in whether her home falls within Compton boundaries has significance later on the album when gang and region affiliation come into play. But, for now, he’s caught up in her…

lyrics:
I feel like I'm losin' my focus
I feel like I'm losin' my patience
I feel like my thoughts in the basement
Feel like, I feel like you're miseducated
Feel like I don't wanna be bothered
I feel like you may be the problem
I feel like it ain't no tomorrow, fuck the world
annotation:
Here, Kendrick touches on the pitfalls of fame and success as well as his own inner demons.

Kendrick has rapped about his suicidal thoughts before on “u” from To Pimp a Butterfly, rapping:

Shoulda killed yo ass a long time ago
You shoulda feeled that black revolver blast a long time ago
And if those mirrors could talk it would say “you gotta go”

K.Dot also spoke to MTV in MTV about his suicidal thoughts and depression:

The lyric “I feel like it ain’t no tomorrow, fuck the world” could be a nod to 2Pac’s song “Fuck The World.”

lyrics:
Wake up in the mornin', thinkin' 'bout money, kick your feet up
Watch you a comedy, take a shit, then roll some weed up
Go hit you a lick, go fuck on a bitch
Don't go to work today, cop you a fit
Or maybe some kicks and make you—
annotation:
Kendrick raps from the perspective of a conceited, lustful man. This perspective is reminiscent of the message conveyed in Kendrick’s “Poe Man’s Dreams (His Vice)” off of Section.80.

At first glance, it seems Kendrick is portraying an ideal day for a man. However, he ends the anecdote with “whatever you doin', just make it count,” which serves as a satirical jab at a lifestyle where little of value is accomplished and the day is wasted on weed, sex, lean, guns, partying. Ultimately, the man is giving into his lustful desires and has become an unproductive member of society.

lyrics: Skip, hop, drip, drop, flip, flop with the white tube sock
annotation:
A pretty onomatopoeic description of what a dude might do into a tube sock… further alluding to what others do. As he said previously… they “came in this game.”

The rhyme scheme is strongly reminiscent of the opening to ur-hip hop song “Rapper’s Delight.”

lyrics: And strictly had wanted her thighs around me
annotation:
Kendrick’s mind is focused completely on sex with Sherane. This part of the song acts as foreshadowing for later events.

He might have “read between the lines,” as he has done with female characters in his other songs.

lyrics: [Produced by Sounwave]
annotation:
The producer for the track, Sounwave, speaks on how the record as well as the beat came to be:

Me and Kendrick found this crazy record from this foreign group and we didn’t know where to go with it. So we looped that, I took it to my spot, and did the drums. I added everything I needed, the extra guitars, strings, all that. That inspired Kendrick to bring it to another level. Kendrick is hands-on with [beats]. He will find something he likes and call me right up: ‘Yo let’s go check this out!’ Like that’s how ‘Spiteful Chant’ came about. That’s how we much work all the time, we just sit, vibe, and listen to [beats] over and over.

The only sample used in the song is from the Boom Clap Bachelors “Tiden Flyver”. It sets the base for the whole beat, and Sounwave worked the rest of the magic on the track. The sample is at the beginning of the track in the sample and in Kendrick song:

lyrics:
The world is endin', I'm done pretendin'
And fuck you if you get offended
annotation:
This is the turning point of the verse. Before this line, Kendrick is apprehensive to explain what his real issue is.

This line, “And fuck you if you get offended” punctuates Kendrick’s building frustration with what is going on in the world and the fact that some people get offended by the way he expresses his views. An example of this is the misinterpretation of his BET Awards performance of the song “Alright” by FOX News reporters, which can be heard sampled earlier in the opening track “BLOOD..”

In his eyes, those who take offense are trying to avoid the real issues:

The problem isn’t me standing on the cop car. I think his intent is diluting the real problem, is the senseless acts, the killings of these young boys out here. And I think for the most part, it’s avoiding the truth. This is reality. This is my world.

lyrics:
Wake up in the mornin', thinkin' 'bout money, kick your feet up
Hop in the shower, put on your makeup, lace your weave up
Touch on yourself, call up your nigga, tell him he ain't shit
annotation:
Kendrick uses the refrain from before to recreate a female version of the same ideas presented in the first verse: the lifestyle of lust-driven and selfish individuals.

Kendrick is sarcastically encouraging women to live the lifestyle glorified by worldly individuals and many rappers, endeavors which accomplish nothing of worth.

In this case, it includes vain pursuits, masturbation, and calling up her boyfriend to say something similar to the intro from “For Free (Interlude)”. It includes seeking social validation on Instagram and reinforcing arrogant tendencies, taking drugs and showing off in the club.

These themes of seeking validation from your peers and being concerned with how they judge you is a major theme in DAMN.—particularly in the third verse of “FEAR.”.

lyrics:
It goes "Sherm Sticks, burn this"
That's what the product smell like when the chemicals mix
annotation:
A Sherm Stick is a joint or cigarette that has been dipped in liquid PCP which causes extreme hallucinogenic effects.

When you are smoking the sherm stick, you can smell all the chemicals from the PCP burning. This is because there are many different chemicals that are mixed together to create liquid PCP.

Also, notice how a voice is dubbed in that sounds “trippy” and “spacy”. He could be trying to show the listener what it feels like after smoking a sherm stick.

This refers to when Kendrick accidentally smoked a sherm stick – chronicled throughout good kid m.a.a.d city.

Fellow TDE member ScHoolboy Q used that exact phrasing on his song “The Purge”

lyrics:
Seventeen, with nothin' but pussy stuck on my mental
My motive was rather sinful
annotation: Like most young men, Kendrick found himself completely consumed by the lust for sexual interaction. He clearly had his fair share of some fucking problems. Citing religious influence, Kendrick acknowledges that raw lust to have been sinful.

lyrics:
I am a sinner who's probably gonna sin again
Lord forgive me, Lord forgive me
Things I don't understand
Sometimes I need to be alone
Bitch don't kill my vibe, bitch don't kill my vibe
annotation:
A major theme in Kendrick’s music is his faith, and how he reconciles it with the sinful activities that he has indulged in.

Kendrick humbly acknowledges that he is a human who makes mistakes. Saying “sometimes I need to be alone” is his need to avoid peer pressure and gather his thoughts to find himself. His resentment of peer pressure was further shown in “Swimming Pools (Drank).”

If the target of this song is the industry and/or his competition, he may be accusing those elements of holding him back. He wants to be in a category by himself – and the pressures around him are not helping.

lyrics:
I feel like friends been overrated
I feel like the family been fakin'
I feel like the feelings are changin'
Feel like my thought of compromise is jaded
Feel like you wanna scrutinize how I made it
Feel like I ain't feelin' you all
Feel like removin' myself, no feelings involved
I feel for you, I've been in the field for you
It's real for you, right? Shit, I feel like—
annotation:
Ending the first verse, Lamar gives a bold, straightforward and conflicted post-fame condemnation of his friends, family, industry and fans.

Concerned about the way his music may be perceived and exploited, Lamar addresses the people he works for, saying he’s tired of compromise and scrutiny—that he both “feel[s] for you” and wants to abandon you without feeling.

The lyrics mirror and foreshadow lyrics at the end of the second verse.

And I’m gon' shine like I’m supposed to
Antisocial, extrovert
And excellent mean the extra work
And absentness what the fuck you heard

–Kendrick Lamar, D.N.A.

So I could find clarity, like how much you cherish me
Is this relationship a fake or real as the heavens be?
See I got to question it all, family, friends, fans, cats, dogs
Trees, plants, grass, how the wind blow
Murphy’s Law, generation X, will I ever be your X?
Floss off a baby step, mauled by the mouth of pitbulls

– Kendrick Lamar, Mortal Man (2015)

lyrics: Credit card scam, get you a Visa, make it pay your rent
annotation:
A credit card scam usually involves obtaining someone’s bank information, using it to deposit fake checks, and withdrawing cash before the bank notices. From there a scammer can load the cash on Visa Giftcards and spend the money without tracing back to them.

This line draws parallels to the woman on “untitled 08 | 09.06.2014,” where Kendrick raps:

My home girl got a credit card scam
She got a scholarship to college but she don’t give a damn
Intuition she got a broke bitch wishin'
She tell me this on the phone with the noodles in the pan

Here, K-Dot is referencing a similar woman who’s using the scamming hustle to pay her bills.

lyrics: 50 nigga salute, out the Compton zoo, with the extras
annotation:
“50 Niggaz” was tatted on 2Pac’s chest with an AK-47. If Blacks from every US state were united, they’d be stronger than any weapon.

“Compton Zoo” is probably a reference to Ol' Dirty dubbing Brooklyn “Brooklyn Zoo,” and recording a song with the name. In both cases, the name is meant to represent the danger of the neighbourhood – Brooklyn/Compton being a metaphorical cage where the animals (gangsters, drug dealers, junkies, etc.) are caged.

lyrics: "What you tryin' to get into?"
annotation:
This is Kendrick’s roundabout way of asking Sherane:

Can I hit it?

lyrics: I can feel your energy from two planets away
annotation:
From the “bitch” angle these lines may mean it is involving a romantic relationship with a woman who won’t give Kendrick his space. Kendrick can feel negative energy whether it be two people away, or in this case two planets away. A possible reference to Men are from Mars, Women are from Venus? Mars is two planets away from Venus:

This analogy may also make reference to the Sun. The Earth is the third planet from the sun, making it two planets away. If you watch the video, the sun is very prevalent for much of his outdoor footage. Kendrick even looks into the sky on occasion.

lyrics:
I feel niggas been out of pocket
I feel niggas tappin' they pockets
I feel like debatin' on who the greatest can stop it
annotation:
Acting “out of pocket” is a figure of speech meaning to act wild or out of control. It is analogous to the expression “out of line.” Lamar couples the figurative “pocket” with the literal “pocket,” suggesting that people are overly concerned with money.

In a 2017 interview with Zane Lowe following the release of DAMN., Kendrick continued to assert his position as the greatest rapper alive, saying:

You have to challenge yourself and […] confirm to yourself that you’re the best, period. No one can take that away from me, period.

He also expressed concerns about money and his own post-celebrity behavior on his previous album, 2015’s To Pimp A Butterfly. In that sense, these lines may be directed both externally, toward others, and internally, toward himself.

lyrics: [Verse 2: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation:
The first verse describes the life of a male and female who are in a repetitive cycle—they wake up, take life for what it is, go to sleep, and do it all over. They live for short term pleasures rather than long term goals. The second verse focuses on the life of a rapper who is stuck in his ways, despite telling himself that he would change. It’s another example of giving up.

Kendrick closes the verse addressing the election of President Donald Trump. The majority of Americans voted against him, but he won the Electoral College, and millions have protested against him since. America had a “woke” moment as a nation but seems to be reverting to the old ways; eventually, America will just “take life for what it is” and conform.

lyrics:
El Cos, Monte Carlos, Road Kings, and dressers
Rip Ridaz, P-Funkers, Mexicans, they fuck with you
Asians, they fuck with you, nobody can fuck with you
annotation:
Kendrick is playing with the two meanings of “to fuck with somebody”:

  • To mess with somebody
  • To get along with somebody, in this context also to listen to his music
