He is referencing all the Southern California, Inland Empire-L.A. gangs. California has the biggest Sociopolitical influence AND Gangsta Rap populace out of all the states. The intimation is nobody can fuck with Southern California’s level of criminality and violence. The “zoo” in the previous line is a reference to the mix of races and ethnicities represented by the various gangs, and it’s also a clever slight at the racist statement that “Black people are animals,” as alluded to on “The Blacker The Berry.”

Nas used this 15 years previously:

Think about how us real niggas would be
If we united, a nation of thugs, who could fight it?

lyrics:
She didn't tell, just gave me her Nextel
Dropped the number, we chirped the whole summer, and well
annotation:
Nextel’s were popular in 2004 (the time this song presumably takes place in – Kendrick is 25 in 2012 and says that he’s 17 in the song)

Nextel phones were known for “push-to-talk”, a feature that turned the cell phone into a kind of walkie-talkie. Their distinctive ringtone was often called a “chirp”

This is the same idea that Kendrick alludes to in “The Art of Peer Pressure” when they talk about pulling out their “Boost Mobile Sim Cards”

lyrics:
I got my drink, I got my music
I would share it but today I'm yelling
annotation:
Sometimes Kendrick just needs to be left alone. At present, he doesn’t feel the need to share, because he is happy with his drink and his music.

His drink (alcohol), and some forms of music that could contribute to “sin,” or could be a sin in itself. Kendrick may or may not understand this, but in any event, he doesn’t want anyone to ruin his good mood.

lyrics:
I am legend, I feel like all of y'all is peasants
I feel like all of y'all is desperate
I feel like all it take is a second to feel like
Mike Jordan whenever holdin' a real mic
I ain't feelin' your presence
annotation:
Kendrick labels himself as the greatest rapper of all time and compares himself to Michael Jordan, who is widely considered to be the greatest player in NBA history. Lamar also declared himself to be the greatest on the previous song, “ELEMENT.” Additionally, he made similar claims in the lead-up to DAMN.’s release. On his March 2017 single, “The Heart Part 4,” he said:

Yelling, ‘One, two, three, four, five
I am the greatest rapper alive’

On the album’s lead single, “HUMBLE.,” he says:

If I quit this season, I still be the greatest

The wordplay between “Mike” and “mic” is also worth noting; as well as a possible reference to Francis Lawrence’s 2007 film, I am Legend. Furthermore, Kendrick has a song titled “Michael Jordan,” which was one of his first singles released in 2010, along with an official music video.

lyrics:
I wake in the mornin', my head spinnin' from the last night
Both in a trance, feelings are dead—what a fast life!
Manager called, the lobby call is 11:30
annotation:
After looking at the actions of others, Kendrick explores his own lustful actions in the second verse. His wording suggests he spent the previous night indulging in sex and substance abuse, and he wakes up regretting his behavior. His trance is likely due to a combination of disorientation upon waking, traveling from city to city, and hangovers from drinking the night before.

He is emotionally vulnerable as he questions what decisions he may not fully recall making. He also realizes he has broken the promises he made to those around him, to be more responsible about his commitments.

As one of the highest paid hip-hop acts of 2016, leading up to the release of DAMN., Kendrick’s music and tour schedule were responsible for employing friends and family at his home record label Top Dawg Entertainment. Despite being at the top of his game—both critically and financially—Kendrick is still capable of acknowledging the hypocrisy of expecting punctuality from others while he himself sleeps in past the hotel check-out time.

lyrics: [Verse 2: Kendrick Lamar]
annotation: Interestingly, the first, second and the beginning quarter of the third verse (as well as some of “Momma”), appear in a freestyle video captured when K-Dot was on Big Boy’s radio show promoting the album.

lyrics: The summer had passed, and now I'm likin' her
annotation: The summer is over, and Kendrick’s feelings for Sherane have maintained – this wasn’t just an average summer fling. He is beginning to actually like her beyond the lust he felt when he was in that young summer daze and wants to form a real relationship.

lyrics: [Produced by J. Cole]
annotation:
For this beat, Cole used a sample from the beginning of Ronnie Foster’s “Mystic Brew.” He didn’t really do much to the sample, except from adding drums.

This sample has been used MANY times before – most notably in A Tribe Called Quest’s “Electric Relaxation.”

Cole also later revealed the song “Neighbors” on his 4 Your Eyez Only album was this beat in reverse.

lyrics:
Bitch, don't kill my vibe; bitch, don't kill my vibe
Bitch, don't kill my vibe; bitch, don't kill my vibe
annotation:
Kendrick is trying to chill – he doesn’t mind if you are around, just don’t fuck up his mood.

But to further this conjecture, this song hook is a complex revelation of Kendrick’s true psychology and the chorus is actually a declaration of his attitude towards the world.

Kendrick is a diverse person, and there are many layers to his personality. He is spiritual, accepting and thoughtful, but he also comes from a city of violence, drugs, crime, etc. Kendrick is an incredibly empathic person; he sees things from all points of view and thus does not fall into any specific classification but rather covers the entire spectrum of humanity. Because of his debilitating empathy, there is a slight distance between himself and his peers. He lives in his own kind of world, observing the behavior and the nature of everything and everyone around him and contemplating it to himself. He is sincere and stable and his ultimate quest is to spread peace.

However, a common tendency for people of this personality-type is to shy away from complex, inexplicable situations where no fair and amicable solution is apparent. When such scenarios occur they may try to retreat into their metaphysical bubble and escape the paradoxical anxieties of life. This is exactly what Kendrick demonstrates in this song (either consciously or subconsciously), and the phrase “Bitch Don’t Kill My Vibe” is a solemn declaration of his desire to attain peace when things cannot be resolved easily.

lyrics:
Feel like I'ma learn you a lesson
Feel like only me and the music though
I feel like your feelin' ain't mutual
annotation:
Kendrick continues to boast about how dominant he is in the rap game—he’s not “feeling” their music and he “feels” (physically) that he’s competing against himself.

The line “Feel like I'ma learn you a lesson” is a continuation of his reference to Michael Jordan in the previous line and alludes to legendary NBA coach Phil Jackson. Kendrick feels like he’s that much better than every other rapper that he could be their coach.

lyrics: Did this before, promised myself I'd be a hour early
annotation:
This line symbolizes the way Kendrick is still trapped in the cyclical nature of life that he described for the male and female figures in the first verse.

Although he has been in this situation before—and promised himself this time would be different—he still can’t help but fall in the same routine, just like everybody else.

lyrics:
Hopped out the Caddy, just got my dick sucked
The little homies called and said, "the enemies done cliqued up"
annotation:
These two lines are the epitome of politics in the hood. Kendrick just got his dick sucked, and his rivals from another block are banding up to go to war against him and his homies.

Rivalries between neighborhoods are common occurrences in places like Compton, and they almost always end in the loss of a friend. Beef, violence, and sex are all a part of Compton.

Additionally, “The Little Homies” is a directing duo of Kendrick Lamar and Dave Free. They work together to direct many of Kendrick’s music videos.

lyrics:
Conversation we havin' probably enticin' her
Who could imagine? Maybe my actions will end up wifin' her
annotation:
Kendrick isn’t just getting physically close to Sherane, but they’re talking a lot and it has him contemplating their future together.

Kendrick has a penchant for including his conversations with females in his verses.

lyrics:
Me and my bitch, took a little trip
Down to the garden, took a little dip (Oh no)
Apple juice falling from her lips took a little sip, lil' sip
Took a lil' sip, took a lil' sip
T-T-Took a lil', took a lil', took a lil' sip
annotation:
J. Cole is speaking on Adam and Eve going to the Forbidden Garden and Eve took a bite of the Forbidden Fruit, the apple. J. Cole sees a woman’s lips and is being provoked into something sinful, just like Eve provoked Adam and created sin by eating and sharing the apple. Through this, he sees the truth.

A possible double entendre: Cole and his chick are having intercourse and he’s tasting her “apple juice” from her lips.

Following the chronological order of the album, as the hook plays right after the ‘Where’s Jermaine Skit’, it also furthers the plot of Born Sinner by showing him skipping church to go hang with his girl.

lyrics:
Look inside of my soul
And you can find gold and maybe get rich
Hol' up
annotation: The same beginning line as the original version, which the exception of the “hol' up,” which signifies the beginning of the actual remix.

lyrics: I feel like the enemy you should know
annotation:
Kendrick continues to addresses his compeition in the rap game, this time taking a leaf out of Sun Tsu’s “The Art of War.” In Chapter three of his aforementioned book, the great Chinese military strategist wrote:

It is said that if you know your enemies and know yourself, you will not be imperiled in a hundred battles; if you do not know your enemies but do know yourself, you will win one and lose one; if you do not know your enemies nor yourself, you will be imperiled in every single battle.

lyrics:
Room full of clothes, bag full of money: call it loose change
Fumbled my jewelry, 100k, I lost a new chain
Hop on the bird, hit the next city for another M
Take me a nap and do it again
annotation:
Just like the people described on the first verse, Kendrick’s life on tour is a cycle of meaningless routine.

Although the lifestyle he describes here may be another person’s dream, lines like “call it loose change,” “I lost a new chain,” and the final “Take me a nap and do it again” reveal that he sees little to no value in these objects and aspects of his life.

Like many other moments on DAMN., this shows that although Kendrick has success and celebrity, his human nature doesn’t operate very differently than that of any other “everyday” person in the working class.

lyrics: Oh, yeah? Puto want to squabble with mi barrio?
annotation: Puto is spanish slang for a bitch and mi barrio just means my neighborhood. Basically Kendrick is calling this guy out for thinking his weak stuff could squabble with Kendrick’s hood.

lyrics:
Love or lust, regardless we'll fuck, 'cause the trife in us
It's deep-rooted, the music of bein' young and dumb
Is never muted; in fact, it's much louder where I'm from
annotation:
Whether or not he actually loves Sherane, won’t change the fact that he’ll hit it. It’s a reality of their lives and conditions:

Gangsta Rap has long been associated with black youth in America (specifically Compton, Kendrick’s city) as it pertains to crime and violence. Such behavior is commonly coined as being ‘young and dumb’.

“Music” here also refers to the general feeling of being young and frivolous. While teenagers all over the world make immature decisions, Kendrick thinks that it’s even more pronounced in his area (like the music is louder and more aggressive)

lyrics: Ayo, I walk through the valley of the shadow of death
annotation:
This is a reference to Psalm 23:4

Even though I walk through the darkest valley I will fear no evil, for you are with me; your rod and your staff, the comfort me.

The actual meaning of this passage is to praise God even in your darkest moments. In Cole’s version of the verse he portrays his hood as a “shadow of death” where it may be difficult for him to retain his faith. As hard as it may be the theme of this song and the reference to “keeping a cross on my chest” a few lines down implies that Cole does still have faith in a higher power.

While Kanye – release date mate of Cole’s – played on this in his breakout “Jesus Walks,” this is more likely a reference to Coolio’s “Gangsta’s Paradise.”

As I walk through the valley of the shadow of death

As Cole mentioned before that he studied Makaveli, this could be a reference from 2Pac’s song “So Many Tears” where he starts song with lyrics:

I shall not fear no man but God
Though I walk through the valley of death

lyrics: Trinidad Jame$ in four weeks
annotation:
This is a reference to Trinidad James‘ hit song “All Gold Everything.” The metaphor implies that Kendrick’s album, good kid, m.A.A.d city, hit gold on the charts quickly.

­
Although, the album technically took seven weeks to hit gold—not four.

lyrics:
Feel like the feelin' of no hope
The feelin' of bad dope
A quarter ounce manipulated from soap
annotation:
Dope, or cocaine, can sometimes share similarities with soap in texture and color. These “dummy rocks”, or shavings of soap, are often created to appear as crack.

Whatever Kenny is going through, it feels fake and unsatisfactory.

This may also refer to Kendrick’s first experience with PCP-laced marijuana, which he mentioned on the song “m.A.A.d city”:

Imagine if your first blunt had you foaming at the mouth

lyrics:
We all woke up, tryna tune to the daily news
Lookin' for confirmation, hopin' election wasn't true
All of us worried, all of us buried, and our feelings deep
None of us married to his proposal, make us feel cheap
Still and sad, distraught and mad, tell the neighbor 'bout it
annotation:
During the 2016 United States Election campaign, Donald Trump was criticized for his racism, sexism, and his overall offensive nature. African Americans, in particular, disliked Trump—at one point they held a 94% unfavorable rating of Trump.

To the dismay of Kendrick, Trump did win the presidential election despite failing to win the popular vote.

This isn’t the first time Kendrick has shown distaste for Donald Trump. On “Wat’s Wrong”: and more recently, on “The Heart Part 4” he dissed Trump.

In his interview with Zane Lowe, Kendrick claimed meeting with President Obama convinced him not to make the entire album about Trump:

So me having a conversation with [Obama] and him sitting me down, he says ‘Change doesn’t start while I’m here, it starts once we leave the space that we’re in.’ That was the idea. Subconsciously that goes to that idea of me self-evaluating my own personal thoughts, the way I think, and what I would take from this meeting when I go outside the building. That’s something I will always hold dear, just the idea of knowing that in the moment of time I have to think further then this year or last year. Got to prep yourself for the next decade of what you want to do that’s going to result to change an idea or thoughts that we have consumed for so many years.

lyrics: Oh, yeah? Tell 'em they can run it for the cardio
annotation:
Kendrick’s telling the enemies to run for their lives if they’re gonna fuck with his hood. They’re gonna run hard because Kendrick is going to go at them hard.
In terms of wordplay, run exists in the sense of giving something to someone but can also be used in its primary meaning of running which is a cardio exercise.

lyrics:
We know a lot 'bout each other, her mother was a crack addict
She live with her granny and her younger two brothers
annotation:
Sherane doesn’t have the greatest home life. Kendrick has learned this presumably over many Nextel conversations, which he has endured in the pursuit of sex.

The fact that Sherane’s mother is referred to in past tense likely means she succumbed to the habit. This is another instance of Kendrick conversing with a female crack baby, possibly of the #Section.80 generation, which Kendrick has termed to describe the youth produced in the late 1980s.

Now that Sherane’s mother is dead (as if she ‘was’ a crack addict, this suggest she no longer is one; this could mean she got help but if that was the case Sherane would be living with her), she lives with her grandmother and two younger brothers.
It’s very likely this is one of the many instances of foreshadowing, and that her two brothers are “the two niggas [in] two black hoodies” that Kendrick finds waiting for him at her house, as they presumably live there.

This is interesting as subtly tells us a side story of Sherane’s family; their mother and father are out of the picture and they have a prominent family history of gang-banging. These influences lead Sherane’s two younger brothers to join the gang life with their cousin, and this realization makes Kendrick freeze at the final line.

lyrics:
Pimp-pimp! (Hooray!)
Pimp-pimp! (Hooray!)
(Hooray!)
Pimp-pimp! (Hooray!)
Pimp-pimp!
annotation:
Although “pimp-pimp hooray” comes off as celebratory, it’s delivered in an unsettling tone; “hooray” is sarcastic. This may be a nod to the music industry celebrating “pimping” artists to flip a profit. Even after the cathartic display on To Pimp a Butterfly, Kendrick acknowledges that the problems facing Black people in modern society have not yet been resolved.

The phrase itself is a play on “hip-hip hooray,” a common cheer originating in the early 19th century.

“Pimp pimp hooray” was also used in 2003 by The Bishop Don “Magic” Juan on 50 Cent’s “P.I.M.P. (Snoop Dogg Remix).”

This lyric is also included on the intro of “untitled 07 | 2014-2016.”

lyrics: Where niggas hold tech's like they mad at the ref
annotation:
A technical foul in basketball can be assessed in many different situations, one being when a player shows excessive disapproval to a referee’s call.

In this case Cole plays with the word technical and shortens it to tec. A tec obviously referring to a TEC-9 semi-automatic handgun.

lyrics:
But now my album platinum and shit, so what?
Y'all keep the numbers
annotation:
As of August 21, 2013, good kid, m.A.A.d city was certified platinum. Additionally, two of the album’s five singles were gold-certified, these being “Swimming Pools (Drank)” and “Poetic Justice.”

Regardless of going gold or platinum, Kendrick doesn’t care about sales figures. He raps for the love of it.

lyrics:
The feelin', the feelin' of false freedom
I'll force-feed 'em the poison that fill 'em up in the prison
annotation:
Kendrick presents the image of “America the free” as false, something especially evident in the Trump administration. This decrease in real freedom (while restrictions on our freedom increase), along with an institutional racism that prevents minorities from advancing promotes a sense of freedom that truly is false.

“Force-feed ‘em the poison that fill 'em up in the prison” refers to the destruction The War on Drugs brought upon his community. He was born in 1987—the tail end of the era (Reagan’s 2nd term expired in 1989). While President, Reagan passed aggressive legislation that saw the number of people behind bars for nonviolent drug law violations increase from 50,000 in 1980 to more than 400,000 by 1997.

“False freedom” and “force-feed ‘em” is also a multi-syllabic rhyme and alliteration.

lyrics:
Bet they agree, parade the streets with your voice proudly
Time passin', things change
Revertin' back to our daily programs, stuck in our ways
Lust
annotation:
On January 21, 2017, after Trump’s inauguration, protesters staged marches all over the world.

The demonstration was called the “Women’s March,” and it was the largest single-day protest in the history of the United States with at least 3.2 million attendees.

But Kendrick predicts that as time passes, the fervency of protesters will diminish as people slowly go back to their schedules and silently accepted America’s political situation.

lyrics:
Oh, yeah? Everythin' is everythin', it's scandalous
Slow motion for the ambulance, the project filled with cameras
annotation:
Kendrick describes the environment and ‘politics’ of the hood. The ambulance takes forever to arrive after a shooting, the projects have cameras everywhere waiting to capture a crime on film. Everyone looks at the people in the ghetto as thugs and criminals.

“Everything is Everything” is also one of Lauryn Hill’s most popular songs, and is about the struggle of inner city black youths and the injustices they face.

Kendrick has name dropped the legendary Ms. Hill in the past, and in his 2015 XXL essay, he wrote about some of the wisdom she shared with him as an artist.

lyrics:
Her favorite cousin Demetrius's irrepetible
Family history of gang bangin' did make me skeptical
annotation:
Sherane has a cousin that’s a known gang banger, but he is so focused on sex that he ignores it. Irrepetible (mispronounced) is Spanish for unrepeatable. Meaning Demetrius’s history of gang banging is so infamous it’s not spoken of. It takes a bilingual listener to hear “ear-reh-peh-tee-blay” in “ear-rept-able.”

It also sounds as if Kendrick calls Sherane’s cousin Demetrius ‘a reputable’. This means that Demetrius is a well-known gangbanger/ member who has gained respect in the streets by putting in work. All of these factors did make him skeptical, and messing with Sherane can get him stomped out, beaten up or even killed.

This line is another example of the heavy foreshadowing going on in this song – Sherane’s gang ties come into play at the end of the track. Kendrick often manipulates his words sonically

lyrics: I'm sick and tired of being tired
annotation:
Kendrick paraphrases civil rights activist Mrs. Fannie Lou Hamer’s speech “I’m sick and tired of being sick and tired,” which she delivered at a Harlem church in 1964. In it, she expresses her exhaustion for not having the same rights as a white person:

And you can always hear this long sob story: “You know it takes time.” For three hundred years, we’ve given them time. And I’ve been tired so long, now I am sick and tired of being sick and tired, and we want a change. We want a change in this society in America because, you see, we can no longer ignore the facts and getting our children to sing, “Oh say can you see, by the dawn’s early light, what so proudly we hailed.” What do we have to hail here? The truth is the only thing going to free us.

lyrics: That's why I keep a cross on my chest, either that or a vest
annotation: Cole gets protection from both the spiritual and physical worlds. Referring back to the previous lines, god and his bulletproof vest are the only things protecting him from the dangers of his own mortal existence.

lyrics: I'm more than another statistic, my nigga
annotation:
Throughout the good kid, m.A.A.d city album, Kendrick talks about how he was part of the “m.A.A.d City” and how he overcame being a part of it. He wasn’t just another statistic who got hooked on drugs or went to prison.

The same can be said for the album, in that he doesn’t care about it going platinum or the numbers associated with it.

lyrics:
I feel like it's just me
Look, I feel like I can't breathe
Look, I feel like I can't sleep
annotation:
Although the first line could be interpreted as Kendrick speaking on the loneliness that has accompanied his success, the lines that follow reveal that he is actually speaking on his depression, a topic he spoke on prominently in “u”, in which he criticizes himself for turning his back on those closest to him, instead choosing to focus, “on the road, bottles and bitches”.

Here, he returns to those same feelings, lamenting about the emptiness he feels from being unable to change the way things are in the neighborhood in which he was raised.

In an MTV interview published after the release of To Pimp A Butterfly, Lamar spoke at length struggling with feelings of survivors guilt, commenting:

That can draw a thin line between you having your sanity and you losing it…psychologically, it messes your brain up… I gotta get back off that tour bus and go to these funerals…

The phrase “I can’t breathe” was also repeated 11 times by Eric Garner before his death at the hands of police. This later became a power phrase, which was used by the Black Lives Matter movement countless times.

lyrics:
Lately, I feel like I been lustin' over the fame
Lately, we lust on the same routine of shame
Lately, lately, lately, my lust been heightened (Lately)
annotation:
This lyrical passage is missing from physical CD copies of the album purchased in-store. The vocoder/guitar solo remains, however.

Kendrick expresses his humility throughout the album, but he still struggles with feelings of lust—and not just sexual lust, but lust for fame, money, stimulants, etc. This sentiment directly contradicts lyrics from other songs on the tracklist, such as “LOVE.” and “FEAR.”:

Thirty shows a month and I still won’t buy me no Lexus…

lyrics: The LAPD gamblin', scramblin', football numbers slanderin'
annotation:
The Los Angeles Police Dept. (LAPD) sometimes makes risky moves by shooting people for unnecessary reasons or gamble due to all the scandals they constantly have, and then they have to scramble to cover it up or scramble to fix it.

Doing “Football Numbers” is a term for serving time in prison (3 years, 7 years, 10 years, 14 years, etc.) Quarterbacks also “scramble” in football.

Masta Ace mentions this in the intro to his song “Unfriendly Game.”

lyrics:
But not enough to stop me from gettin' a nut
"I wanna come over, what's up?"
That's what I told her soon as this episode
Of Martin go off, I'm tryin' to get off
annotation:
There is almost nothing a teenage boy won’t do for sex. Despite her gang affiliations, Kendrick asks Sherane if he can come over after he finishes watching Martin—his favorite 90’s TV series, starring Martin Lawrence:

Kendrick weaves wordplay to describe how he’ll get to Sherane: nut, come/cum and get off. Note Kendrick’s classic teenage game in this song—not exactly a smooth operator. This adds to prevalent themes throughout the song, such as the awkwardness of sex between young people.

This is also not the first time Kendrick has referenced Martin.

lyrics:
Can't pick a side, the Gemini
Prophesize if we live or not
annotation:
Gemini is a zodiac star-sign, originating from the constellation of the same name that looks like a pair of twins. Born on June 17th, Kendrick belongs to this astrological sign that represents duality. He’s in good company.

He’s split between his successful career and his life back home in Compton. While becoming famous has separated him from his family, his wealth and his status is what allows him to help those in need and give voice to his people.

On “Wesley’s Theory,” Kendrick rapped:

Your horoscope is a gemini, two sides

lyrics: Do you believe that Eve had Adam in check
annotation: Cole is cleverly using Adam and Eve in modern terms, having somebody in check means, you do whatever they ask, whatever they want you to do. Was Adam whipped? Would he do anything Eve asked?

lyrics:
This courtesy of Compton (Courtesy of Compton)
Brooklyn go hard, motherfucker
annotation: Thanks to Kendrick, who comes from Compton, this remix was able to happen. Also a nod to a Jay-Z’s song – “Brooklyn (Go Hard)”

lyrics:
Look, I feel heartless, often off this
Feelin' of fallin', of fallin' apart with
Darkest hours, lost it
Fillin' the void of bein' employed with ballin'
annotation:
Preceded by expressions of sadness and vulnerability, the lyric about “the void” marks the only point in “FEEL.” where Lamar temporarily transitions to using the homophone “fill.”

As an intentional transitive homophone, the lyric forms a double-entendre that expresses a conflict about being wealthy and ostentatious(“ballin'”).

The lyric can be heard to mean that:
1. Lamar feels the void of being employed as a baller (negative)
2. Lamar fills the void of employment with ballin' (positive)

"I remember you was conflicted / Misusing your influence / Sometimes I did the same / Abusing my power, full of resentment / Resentment that turned into a deep depression / Found myself screaming in the hotel room / I didn’t wanna self destruct / The evils of Lucy was all around me

– Kendrick Lamar, Mortal Man

Something's in the water / And if I gotta brown-nose for some gold / Then I'd rather be a bum than a motherfuckin' baller

– Kendrick Lamar, King Kunta

Also notice that “Feelin' of fallin, of fallin apart with'” and “Feelin' of falling off, falling apart with” are also interchangeable and form a sort of psuedo–double entendre. Lamar went more in depth into the concept of “falling off” and losing it all in the third verse of the song FEAR., the 12th track off the album:

At 27, my biggest fear was losin' it all
Scared to spend money, had me sleepin' from hall to hall
Scared to go back to Section 8 with my mama stressin'
30 shows a month and I still won’t buy me no Lexus

lyrics: Lately, it's all contradiction
annotation:
The contradiction Kendrick is referring to is shown throughout the album. It’s even apparent in the tracklisting of DAMN. as he juxtaposes a song like “PRIDE.” to precede “HUMBLE.”, or having a song called “LUST.” lead into “LOVE.”

Kendrick is conflicted and torn between his different sides: the sinful and foolish side, versus the righteous and good-willed.

lyrics: Niggas names on paper, you snitched all summer
annotation: The person Kendrick is talking about ratted out some people for a crime and got their names on a criminal record/put their “names on paper”. This is the ultimate act of disloyalty and can get you into a lot of trouble in the hood.

lyrics:
I was in heat like a cactus, my tactics of bein' thirsty
Probably could hurt me, but fuck it, I got some heart
Grab my momma's keys, hopped in the car, then, oh boy
annotation:
A cactus is a plant commonly found in hot, dry, climates. Cactus survive by extracting as much water as they can from any source they can find. You could say they are extremely “thirsty”, as most things are in the desert.

Kendrick’s “thirst” is for sex; he’s trying to get as much as he can, from any source, like a cactus in a desert.

The line also shares desert imagery with lines in the first verse. The desert imagery may mirror the lack of love, security, and/or self-worth felt by young Kendrick. Being thirsty he seeks it in sin, and it isn’t until toward the end of the album that he finds a true source of water.

lyrics:
Promise momma not to fear nobody
Seen black turn 'em Burgundy
Hundred of them, I know I'm greedy
annotation:
“Seen black turn ‘em burgundy” represents black people dying. Burgundy is a shade of dark red.

Burgundy is the secondary color that “old blood” Piru gang members don to signify their allegiance with the original Blood vision.

lyrics:
And if so, you gotta expect
To sip juice from the forbidden fruit and get loose
annotation: He is continuing his wordplay in the previous line. If Eve had Adam in check, then she could make him sip from the forbidden fruit, therefore he has tension lifted off of him and he can get loose, knowing that the action is already done.

lyrics:
Love me on the East like I'm Chuck D
Dominicans wish that I was born there
annotation:
Chuck D is a rapper/producer and leader of the group Public Enemy. He was born in Queens NY, thus having fans on the East Coast. Kendrick whose native to Compton CA, claims to having fans on the East as well as the West.

New York (Washington Heights in particular) has a pretty large Dominican population, and the fans in that area love Kendrick so much they wish he grew up where they live.

lyrics:
Streets is talkin', fill in the blanks with coffins
Fill up the banks with dollars
Fill up the graves with fathers
Fill up the babies with bullshit
Internet blogs and pulpit, fill 'em with gossip
annotation:
Lamar temporarily transitions verbs from “feel” to the homophone “fill.“

He says that the people are expressing themselves (Streets is talkin'“) then lists several things to be filled, including empty spaces with coffins and babies filled with "bullshit” from the internet and the stage (“pulpit”).

lyrics: Lately, I'm not here
annotation:
When Kendrick says lately he’s ‘not here’, he’s continuing with the song concept of him constantly surrounding himself with literal ‘lust’ (sexual activity), as well as buying himself worthless items and jewelry and going over the same monotonous daily routines throughout life.

He’s so built into this lifestyle he’s ‘no longer here’ and doesn’t even sense his own presence.

lyrics: Streets don’t fail me now, they tell me it's a new gang in town
annotation:
“Streets don’t fail me now” harkens the phrase “Feets don’t fail me now,” spoken by blacks in early movies when spooked, also an interpolation of the lyrics “feet don’t fail me now” from the Funkadelic song “One Nation Under a Groove”. Kendrick isn’t spooked by ghosts or anything comical, instead, it’s the institution. Instead of say wealthier people who the government protect, Kendrick only has the streets where he grew up. Ironically, all throughout To Pimp A Butterfly, Kendrick speaks of the streets, which in GKMC corrodes his life, as a savior from the poverous new life with fame.

Thinking in the street stream, Kendrick realizes the Crips and Bloods don’t stack up to the government’s indentured mishandling of poor areas. This relates back to Ronald Reagan essentially dumping cocaine on South Central LA, thus enabling the drug war to empower the Bloods, Crips, Eses, etc. The gang warfare in Compton may trace back to the government’s abuse of power and misjudgment.

“Streets don’t fail me now” is an interpolation of the lyrics “feet don’t fail me now” from the Funkadelic song “One Nation Under a Groove”.

lyrics: So now I'm down Rosecrans in a Caravan
annotation:
He’s driving in his mom’s Caravan down Rosecrans (a street in Paramount; the city east of Compton). The car on the cover of the deluxe edition is a Dodge “Caravan”.

Caravans were also groups of travelers commonly found in the desert, which once again ties into the desert imagery in the first two verses.

Was Kendrick, at this point, still “trying to duck the central bookings” while out on Rosecrans and Central avenues?

lyrics:
Stuck inside the belly of the beast
Can you please pray for me?
annotation:
Kendrick has used the ‘'belly of the beast’' analogy numerous times in his work. In this instance, the beast could refer to the music industry, racism, capitalism, and Compton as individual components or a combination of these within a broken system.

“Belly of the beast” also refers to the tale of Jonah. Matthew 12:40 reads:

For as Jonas was three days and three nights in the whale’s belly; so shall the Son of man be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth.

lyrics:
Cole is the king, most definite
My little black book thicker than the Old Testament
annotation:
J. Cole is acknowledging himself as the new new king in the rap game. He’s so popular with girls that his little black book – book used to keep numbers of girls he’s had sex with – is too big, bigger and longer than the Old Testament, a very long piece of writing.

He could also be referring to a little black book where he writes all his bars. The book is bigger than the the Old Testament thus he’s always writing to improve his craft which makes him King Cole!

lyrics:
I'm lookin' to be the god MC
You look at my hat and see thorns there
annotation:
This is a reference to the original “God MC”: Rakim. During his come-up, Kendrick’s fans perceived him to be a hip-hop savior of sorts, as God is a popular topic in many of his songs. For instance, on the 2009 track “Faith,” he says:

But what I do know, is that He’s real and He lives forever
So the next time you feel like your world’s about to end
I hope you studied because He’s testing your faith again

Kendrick’s “hat” covered in thorns is a reference to the Crown of Thorns that Roman soldiers forced Jesus to wear during his crucifixion in John 19:2. The soldiers mocked Jesus, calling him the “King of the Jews”—Kendrick may be comparing this to the mockery he receives for his own musical sensibilities.

lyrics:
I feel like this gotta be the feelin' where 'Pac was
The feelin' of an apocalypse happenin'
But nothin' is awkward, the feelin' won't prosper
annotation:
Kendrick is saying he relates to the late Tupac Shakur when it comes to stardom; Tupac did show similar thoughts to those shared by Kendrick in this song later in his career.

Kendrick may also be alluding to the interview with Tupac that was sampled on Kendrick’s closing track of To Pimp a Butterfly, “Mortal Man”:

Next time it’s a riot there’s gonna be, like, uh, bloodshed for real. I don’t think America know that. I think American think we was just playing and it’s gonna be some more playing but it ain’t gonna be no playing. It’s gonna be murder, you know what I’m saying, it’s gonna be like Nat Turner, 1831

Similar to Tupac, Kendrick feels pessimistic about the present times and feels that he is living through an apocalypse—which is an allusion to Pac’s 1991 debut album, 2Pacalypse Now.

lyrics: Lately, I lust over self
annotation:
Kendrick may be showing that he has a lust for his ego and his own image that he portrays. Showing the self-confidence and egotistical nature one can have when lusting over their self.

However, this could also mean he is indulging into his deepest desires, therefore, lusting over his self internally. Which follows onto himself fearing this type of lust as it dangerous and may be a problem.

lyrics:
From Compton to Congress, set trippin’ all around
Ain't nothin' new, but a flu of new Demo-Crips and Re-Blood-licans
Red state versus a blue state, which one you governin'?
annotation:
Think ‘red states’ and ‘blue states.’ Aren’t the Republicans considered the ‘red state party’, and the Democrats ‘blue’ like the Crips?

Who knew Kendrick read Jesse Ventura? In his 2012 book, DemoCRIPS and ReBLOODlicans: No More Gangs in Government, former Minnesota governor Jesse Ventura discusses how politicians are bought by corporate lobbyists. As a result, certain territories are now marked a certain color, making the American electoral and legislative process an unfair dual monarchy, and as divided as gang territory.

In fact, the term may have originated even earlier, with rapper Rusty California claiming he came up with it in 2007.

Kendrick uses that similarity to attack the hypocrisy of some government officials: they put a negative spin on street gangs when they do the same thing on a mass level — not only dividing people, but even distributing guns and drugs. Political gangs do the same thing street gangs do, only they affect each and every American.

Tupac, whose influence pervades this album, had similar thoughts on the gangs of the G-men from this interview from jail.

lyrics: Passin' Alameda,
annotation:
Alameda is a street connecting to California State Route 47 that runs through Compton. He’s using this route to get to Sherane’s crib.

Don’t get Alameda street confused with the city of Alameda, which is located a LONG way from L.A., near San Francisco.

lyrics:
Get God on the phone
Said it won't be long
annotation:
Kendrick calls God for his own future and the future of the Black race. God replies that “it won’t be long”, a reference to the apocalypse and “untitled 1.”

The main themes of the song are materialism, self-destruction, and hopelessness. Kendrick feels surrounded by talented, intelligent black artists who are succumbing to the temptations of wealth and the self-destructive elements of rapper culture (I see jiggaboos, I see styrofoams). He feels the same thing happening to himself, and this song expresses Kendrick’s feelings during a moment despair.

lyrics:
Niggas pay for head but the pussy sold separate
Same bitch giving brains to the minister
annotation:
Cole is saying that society is so corrupted & money driven now that girls will make people pay for head but to get the pussy you gotta pay AGAIN & probably more. After all that they go to give a minister head which he probably understands what she does for money & is paying for it as well. This also shows the concept of sinning as she is giving her body away to a minister, showing that she doesn’t care who she gives it to, as long as she makes money.

The minister, as a representative of religion, is implicated as a sinner of an equal, if not higher, degree.

lyrics:
I look at the game and see porn there
I'm fuckin' this industry hard
annotation:
Play on words with porn and fucking. He’s comparing the artists of today in hip hop, with artists from the porn industry. Porn is essentially fake sex – just like the fake music industry.

Note how he creates a contrast from the bar before. Talking about God in one line and then porn in the next, something he spoke about in “Ab Soul’s Outro” from Section.80.

lyrics:
The feelin' is toxic, I feel like I'm boxin' demons
Monsters, false prophets schemin'
Sponsors, industry promises
annotation:
Kendrick is at a point in his life where he is facing various enemies.

Spiritually, he has been battling with demons or inner issues such as his ongoing war with depression. He is also noticing masquerading religious people telling lies in order to gain riches which was foretold in 2 Peter 2:1:

But false prophets also arose among the people, just as there will be false teachers among you…

Kendrick has built a major platform for himself as a mainstream rapper. With the attention that he continues to gain, he will definitely attract more snakes from the music industry.

There also seems to be more Americans freely expressing views filled with prejudice and racism. With the election of President Donald Trump, there has been an influx of racist propaganda and threats.

lyrics: Lust turn into fear
annotation:
Lust is a desire that can become an action if obeyed. That action can soon be adapted to a person’s lifestyle. When secret lustful desires become apart of someone’s daily living, it turns into shame and fear of people noticing their contradiction or hypocrisy.

This line also conceptionally links “LUST.” to the song “FEAR.” that appears later in the DAMN. tracklisting.

Although a subtle reference, it helps establish the connective tissue between the lyrical content of songs that might be seen as otherwise unrelated. These connections are further explained in “FEAR.”

lyrics: They give us guns and drugs, call us thugs
annotation:
People who sell guns and drugs (and it seems Kendrick is hinting at the government, gun store owners, and drug dealers), make it sound like it’s all their fault they are in the streets thugging, even though they are the ones who sold them the guns and drugs. So really who’s fault is it?
